HEADLINE: 3 Hospitals Talk About Forming an Affiliation

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
THREE Westchester community hospitals have begun affiliation talks to meet what their directors describe as the demands of a quickly changing health-care environment.
The changing marketplace is "unlike anything we've ever seen,"said Roger Dvorak, president of Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, which is holding the talks with the White Plains Hospital Center and the Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco. All hospitals are facing cutbacks in Medicaid and Medicare reimbursements and stricter control of expenses and procedures from managed-care groups. In particular, health-maintenance groups and other managed-care organizations are limiting admissions, hospital procedures and length of stay. They are also paying less to hospitals for their services. 
 As an example of the pressures hospitals are facing, Jon B. Schandler, president and chief executive officer at White Plains Hospital Center, said that even though admissions had increased there, the number of patient days had dropped because of managed-care requirements.
Given those kinds of economic indicators for the future, Mr. Schandler said, the three hospitals had decided "to figure it out now rather than later."
"We can see the long-term economic projections," he said.
Even though all three hospitals have a tradition of operating independently, the administrators said an alliance was needed. What form this will take has not yet been worked out, they said, but they are discussing a range of possibilities from sharing purchasing power to merging assets and integrating delivery systems. They said a full merger was unlikely.
Hospitals throughout the country are facing similar difficulties, said Arthur E. Weintraub, president of the Northern Metropolitan Hospital Association, which represents 40 hospitals from New York City to Albany.
"Hospitals of today need to reinvent themselves," he said. "In particular, the stand-alone hospital will be very rare in the health-care picture of tomorrow."
Many Westchester hospitals are facing losses, Mr. Weintraub said, and some -- like Mount Vernon Hospital and Yonkers General Hospital -- have had to lay off workers.
There have been no layoffs at White Plains Hospital Center, Lawrence Hospital and Northern Westchester Hospital Center. But Lawrence Hospital, which showed a $1.4 million profit in 1994, is projecting a "small to moderate" operating loss this year -- about $250,000 to $500,000 -- said Harriet Rosenberg, a spokeswoman. The annual operating budget at the 85-year-old hospital, which has 259 beds, is $72 million.
Half of the 14 acute-care hospitals in Westchester reported losses in 1993, the most recent year for which audited figures are available, Mr. Weintraub said.
"And no hospital," he added, "showed very significant surpluses. Where they did show a gain, it was quite modest."
The 102-year-old White Plains Hospital, which had a $94.7 million budget last year, had an operating loss of $274,000. It is projecting a $350,000 surplus for the current year.
The Northern Westchester Hospital Center, which had a $75.7 million budget last year, had a $288,283 profit. That hospital, which was founded 79 years ago, is projecting a $500,000 surplus for this year.
The idea for a partnership among the three hospitals was raised close to a year ago. Two trustees from each hospital, along with two doctors and the president and medical director from each, are meeting regularly to complete the details, they said. A target date for a formal agreement has not been set.
Lawrence Hospital already has an affiliation agreement with a group of six Westchester hospitals and another in Connecticut -- called ExcelCare System Inc. -- to negotiate managed-care agreements.
The two others are in a group with St. John's Riverside Hospital in Yonkers, New Rochelle Hospital and Putnam Hospital -- called the Westchester Health Services Network -- to negotiate managed-care contracts.
The administrators said they did not know if they would continue those alliances once the other partnership is completed.
"All that we know for sure," said Donald W. Davis, president and chief executive officer of the Northern Westchester Hospital Center, "is that the world out there is changing and hospitals have to change with it."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BEDFORD - STUYVESANT;
400 Jobless as Bakery Closes

BYLINE: By DAVIDSON GOLDIN 

 BODY:
The Pechter family entered the business in 1888. The Field family did the same in 1928. Their companies merged in 1973, becoming Pechter Field's Bakery -- the largest independent bakery in the metropolitan area.
But diminishing prices for baked goods, high labor costs and greater competition took their toll over the last few years. In January, Pechter Field's filed for bankruptcy. Still, the bakery's 400 workers reported to work each day, hoping that a competitor would buy the bakery, or at least salvage some jobs by purchasing profitable delivery routes. 
 On Thursday, their hope turned to despair when a bankruptcy judge ordered Pechter Field's permanently closed and its assets sold to pay off $20 million in debt. Two competitors had considered -- and rejected -- buying part of the bakery.
As the 400 newly unemployed workers began worrying over their future, the management blamed several factors for the company's demise, chiefly the cost of maintaining an antiquated five-story factory at 800 Pacific Street and growing competition from out-of-state bakeries with lower production costs.
A few decades ago, there were a dozen independent bakeries like Pechter Field's in the city. They catered to restaurants, prisons, schools, hospitals and hotels. Now, the only one remaining is Fink Baking in Long Island City, Queens.
"After being in the business for 50 years, it's hard to believe we used to be the largest independent baker in the New York area and now this is happening," said Harold Field, 66, Pechter Field's former president. "We were the only full-line baker in the area, making everything -- breads, rolls, pies, cakes, danishes and muffins."
Mr. Field said that as recently as 1989, business was good, with $51 million in gross annual revenue. Last year, that figure was $41 million. This summer, he said, Pechter Field's lost a $12 million contract with the city's Board of Education.
On Thursday, as security guards sealed off the white and green factory on the edge of the Long Island Rail Road yard, workers wondered what they would do next.
"It's like a lost feeling -- you don't know where your next paycheck's coming from," said Nick Jones, 57, a production manager for the last two years.
Theodore Young, 58, who has spent 14 of his 32 years in the baking business at Pechter Field's, said, "I have to make a living someplace, but I guess in another line of work since bakeries are dying out."
Jimmie Jeffries, 62, said his biggest concern was for the younger workers. "They have families, they have mortgages -- not me," he said. "My babies are 34 years of age and have their own houses."
Pechter Field's former customers, who said they could always rely on prompt and courteous service, wondered how they would replace their supplier. "They're always there for us," said Hasting Stainord, a manager at Junior's Restaurant on Flatbush Avenue. "I don't know how we're going to find someone else who could do the same."
 DAVIDSON GOLDIN

GRAPHIC: Photo: Harold Field (right) is among 400 losing jobs at Pechter Field's bakery. (Thomas Dallal for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Where Did She Go Wrong?

BYLINE: By Alan Ryan; Alan Ryan, who has been a professor of politics at Princeton University since 1978, will be returning to Oxford next year. His latest book is "John Dewey: And the High Tide of American Liberalism."

 BODY:

THE DISENCHANTED ISLE
Mrs. Thatcher's Capitalist Revolution.
By Charles Dellheim.
416 pp. New York:
W.W. Norton & Company.
$25. 
IN "The Disenchanted Isle," Charles Dellheim provides a brisk and brightly written account of the rise and fall of Margaret Thatcher, and paints a plausible picture of her subjects' reactions to her reign. By way of background, he presents a clear and sensible account of the years of failing industrial performance and labor unrest that led up to Mrs. Thatcher's triumph in 1979. He then retells the tale of Margaret Hilda Roberts's ascent from her father's grocery shop in Grantham to the Prime Minister's residence at No. 10 Downing Street, gives us a string of vignettes of her impact on politics, industry, academia and the social climate generally, and ends with a rousing account of her downfall. Mr. Dellheim breaks no new ground, but he comes at a good moment to provoke fresh thoughts.
The rise and fall of Mrs. Thatcher perhaps has a moral for us all. Here in the United States the Gingrich revolution is in full flood: public hostility to government spending on welfare and services for the poor is unabated, and a get-tough approach to crime has lost none of its appeal; privatization is all the rage among economists; a return to Victorian values is widely advocated by conservative intellectuals. These were just the attitudes and ideas that fueled Mrs. Thatcher's revolution, but today her Conservative Party trails the Labor opposition, led by Tony Blair, by close to 30 points in every opinion poll. So desperate is the Conservative plight that Mr. Blair's well-wishers are giving him advice on how to hold onto power in the next millennium rather than on how to win the general election that must be held sometime within the next two years.
"The Disenchanted Isle" doesn't invoke comparisons between Margaret Thatcher and Newt Gingrich, but Mr. Dellheim's portrait of his flawed heroine irresistibly suggests them. Mr. Gingrich and Mrs. Thatcher conquered their respective parties in similar ways. He fought a war to the death against the Democratic leadership in Congress, while she seized the leadership of the Tory party in 1975 because she was prepared to stand against Edward Heath when senior (male) figures would not. Both went on to overawe their critics by winning electoral majorities for policies their conservative predecessors had thought were too extreme and divisive to present to the voters.
But Mr. Gingrich might find Mrs. Thatcher's example depressing. We now know that her 11 1/2 years as Prime Minister did not permanently alter British political culture, did not produce a once-and-for-all leap forward in industrial productivity and did not destroy the Labor Party, even though, as Mr. Dellheim says, she surely put paid to the far left. Those years did, on the other hand, see a considerable increase in inequality: the poorest tenth of the population lost ground in the 1980's and the richest tenth saw their incomes rise by 65 percent; trade union membership was halved, and new industrial-relations legislation removed much of the power that remained to the shrunken unions.
Britain also had her own version of the culture wars of the American 80's. They were fought not between the defenders and opponents of gay rights or abortion, however, but between the admirers of Mrs. Thatcher's creed of laissez-faire at home and nationalism abroad on the one side and the beleaguered defenders of the postwar British welfare state on the other. Mr. Gingrich might reasonably be depressed at the inconclusiveness of the struggle in this arena, too.
Mr. Dellheim teaches history at Arizona State University, but he has devoted much of the past 20 years to studying British social and economic history, and his long list of those who have helped him suggests that he must have spent a lot of those 20 years in the drawing rooms of people close to, if not always in tune with, the Thatcher upheaval. They range from Conservative cabinet members like Sir Geoffrey Howe and Nigel Lawson to captains of industry like Sir John Harvey-Jones of Imperial Chemical Industries (I.C.I.), religious leaders like Rabbi Julia Neuberger, and on to the leader of the Labor Party, John Smith, who died last year.
One engaging result is that whatever Mr. Dellheim's account of the British industrial revolution of the 80's may lack in depth, it more than makes up for in liveliness. His account of Sir John Harvey-Jones's renovation of I.C.I. is couched in the authentic naval idiom of this former submarine commander, while the none-too-dulcet tones of Sir John Egan, who masterminded Jaguar Cars' ascent from nationalized near-bankruptcy to privatized profitability (and eventual sale to the Ford Motor Company), ring out loud and clear.
Nor is Mr. Dellheim without a sense of the ironies of the scene he describes. John Harvey-Jones was a supporter of the Social Democratic Party, and rescued I.C.I. by sharing power rather than hogging it. "Great believer in personal enterprise that he was, he was not a market mystic who believed that those who fell on the wayside should simply be left there to read Milton Friedman." John Egan was a fierce Thatcherite who loathed trade unions and thought the Labor Party's industrial policies were pure poison, but he still "dispatched a team of Jaguar observers to Japan to see what Coventry could learn from Kyoto," and he instituted Family Nights, when management served dinner to shop floor workers and their wives. Not exactly Iron Lady tactics.
INDEED, the moral of the entire book might well be that Mrs. Thatcher was her revolution's worst enemy. By 1979, the British were persuaded that much of what she stood for was right -- overmanning had to go, higher education had to think about its graduates' entrepreneurial and business skills, trade unions had to be stopped from damaging their members as well as everyone else by endless obstructiveness. But her headlong assaults on people who might have been wooed into cooperation and her relentless betrayal of all her political allies meant that she accomplished less than she might have, and that what she did accomplish was bought at too high a price.
Perhaps more than anything else, she persuaded people that she was simply callous. Socialism had been inefficient but inspiring, yet Mrs. Thatcher failed to make efficiency attractive. "Not only did she weaken the moral foundation of the capitalist revolution by favoring the rich over the poor," Mr. Dellheim concludes, but she "undermined its legitimacy and appeal by an indifferent or meanspirited attitude to those who could not help themselves." Revolutionaries take note.

HEADLINE: CHOICE TABLES;
Where Provincetown Fare Takes a Lively Turn

BYLINE: BY MOLLY O'NEILL; MOLLY O'NEILL is a reporter in the style department of The Times and the author of "A Well Seasoned Appetite" (Viking).

 BODY:
PROVINCETOWN, the gangly spit of sand that sweeps away from Cape Cod Bay to form a spine of dunes that flank the Atlantic on the town's back side, is a fragile land. It is vulnerable to and constantly reshaped by tide and wind. Were it not for the rocky, man-built breakwaters, waves would regularly gobble whole neighborhoods. And if the dunes were not planted with beach grass, the dunes themselves would slide back and forth, from ocean to bay, burying both the hurly-burly and the echo of a fishing industry that are Provincetown.
It's always been this way. Historians, poets and writers have long speculated that the hazards of the landscape forced people to live by their wits, to be aware of danger, appreciative of pleasure -- particularly the pleasure of a good meal. 
 Home diaries and shopping lists I've seen from the 18th and 19th centuries show that the buttoned-down bland style of cooking of the rest of New England never took in Provincetown. Instead, the town developed a lusty fare whose inspiration was the Latin flavors of the French and Portuguese fishermen who settled there. The climate called for hearty meals. The waters were rich. The only thing standing between a cook and a fine meal was ingenuity. And the sort of people who are passionate about Provincetown tend to be ingenious.
Today, of course, truck drivers unloading cases of institutional food supplies ceaselessly stop traffic along Commercial Street. Fast-food joints are the constant that artists' easels once were. This is not to say that you can't eat well in Provincetown. You can eat very, very well. If you try.
Until recently, a good meal was a given. But in the past decade, as the crowds of day trippers who arrive daily has increased by about 20 percent, the median quality of the cooking has declined from universally excellent to a hit-and-miss affair in which some meals are surprisingly superb.
As the T-shirt by a local artist, Susan Baker, says, the tip of Cape Cod still considers itself "The Town Too Good For Burger King." But while there are no national food franchises, the smell of fryolators and greasy grills hangs over the place as certainly as the smell of beach roses and brine.
Two of the new fast-food places, as a matter of fact, are excellent. Silva's Seafood Connection, situated in a former Dairy Queen (and still called Dairy Land by the locals who pack the place at lunch), serves the best fried scallops, clams and squid in town, each barely floured and exquisitely fresh. Its lobster roll is a thing of sweet, sumptuous beauty.
Clem and Joe's Rotisserie Chicken and Ribs, about 100 paces from the bay beach in the center of town, serves not a shred of seafood, nor any food faintly Yankee. Instead, there is a fine grilled chicken and smoky ribs, as well as spicy pulled chicken and shredded pork, Southern-style stewed vegetables, slaw, cornbread and mashed potatoes -- all cooked well enough to make a Southern Grandma cry. A meal that bends a sturdy paper plate costs $4.95 and curiously hits the spot in the cool evening, with its frequent fog. There are a five tables on the porch outside the storefront, but most people order food to go, or have it delivered.
For nearly 25 years, the co-owner, Clem Silva, was a chef in some of Provincetown's fine restaurants. Cash and carry is a departure. "That's what's happening here, that's what people want," he says and his menu, he thinks, isn't so far removed from the Sunday-style dinners that were served in the boarding houses that crowded the town when he was a boy.
Whatever the genesis of his Southern-style food, it is the rare local person who does not stop by to pick up dinner once a week. And following local people is not a bad practice.
The residents, as distinct from a summer colony that, according to the Provincetown Chamber of Commerce, bloats the full-time population from 3,500 to more than 17,000, tend to live by daring, luck and chance. Just as the land itself constantly shifts, the veneer of the prototypical Provincetowner changes.
But no matter how drastically the landscape is altered, the town is more like itself than it is like any place else in the world, and the people -- summer and permanent -- who are passionate about the place today are more like the people who loved it 50 years ago than those who find it a crowded and insufferable honky-tonk.
Those lured by Provincetown are intrigued by the new, often artistic, always eager. Their eagerness for well-prepared, innovative meals has been frustrated in the past five years. A shaky local economy curtailed creativity and bred a sort of culinary conservatism. But three restaurants, two new, one of long standing with a new chef, seem to have shrugged off these shackles and kicked up their heels.
The Cafe Edwige, upstairs and across from the Public Library, has meant breakfast in Provincetown for more than 20 years. The loft-style dining room, with hand-hewn wooden booths and tables, elevated the hippy esthetic, with its look, its morning fare -- fresh orange juice, croissants, mile-high omelets and whole-wheat pancakes dense with fresh fruit -- and its waitresses, who regularly stopped taking orders to line dance to "Stand by Your Man."
Dinner, on the other hand, was a dreary, stir-fry-and-tofu affair until last year when Steven J. Frappolli, who formerly cooked at An American Place in Manhattan, began turning out stylish New American cooking. The gestalt of the place is still casual, but the food is quite good.
Of the appetizers sampled, a dish of clams, mussels, lobster and shrimp in a bouillabaisse-like broth was delicious, as were the skewers of grilled chicken and pork that were served over cellophane noodles with a minced peanut and fresh cilantro relish. However, peppered, sliced tuna over a Caesar salad with crisped noodles and roasted tomatoes was a muddle of flavors. And using local, shredded crabmeat, rather than the lump crabmeat taken most often from Pacific waters, makes for a mushy hash of a crabcake.
Planked codfish drizzled with a ginger-scented carrot broth and served with roasted corn and shiitake mushrooms was a delicious main course, and so was the ragout of lobster and scallops that came over ragsheet pasta with wild mushrooms and a tomato-lobster broth. A roasted pepper juice didn't stand up to the strong herbs in which the chicken was marinated, but the chicken, served with mushroomed-mashed potatoes, was good. So was the grilled swordfish with oven-dried tomato relish accompanied by a salad of peppery local greens and grilled vegetables.
The breakfast camp -- and the throng it beckons -- gives way to Pachelbel and a mellow crowd most nights.
The thought behind the fare at the Martin House on the Atlantic Street landing -- local ingredients prepared with international seasoning -- is similar to that of the Cafe Edwige. But its execution is more elaborate. Alex Mazzocca, the chef, appears to be the first in town to have figured out that Japanese wasabi and pickled ginger make an addictive foil for Wellfleet oysters and that the local squid is toothsome when grilled and served over cellophane noodles with a spicy relish of minced cucumbers and carrots. Mussels and littleneck clams were slightly bitter from the preserved lemon and garlic they were steamed in, but the steamed Chinese buns -- dough stuffed with black beans and watercress -- were fabulous.
The main courses read like a travel guide to the Middle and Far East and sounded ominously complex. But the spinach, feta and grilled eggplant tart wrapped in a flaky walnut envelope was tasty and a simple lobster and sugar snap pea saute was a delicious foil for gingered buckwheat noodles. While it was too sweet for my taste, the rack of lamb with spicy sausage drizzled with garlicky meat juice and served with dried apricot relish was good. Only the halibut, served under a crust of roasted plantains with a passion-fruit vinaigrette and a salad of undercooked black-eyed peas, was over-wrought and under-flavored.
The restaurant is situated in three snug rooms of a house dating to 1740 that has been restored in a Yankee arts and craft style; there is also a garden where you can dine. The wait between courses was interminable, but Martin House is one of the few restaurants in Provincetown today with a service staff that appears to care.
According to local restaurateurs, the skyrocketing price of real estate has made it difficult to find well-seasoned waiters and waitresses.
"One of the reasons I chose the to-go model," said Mr. Silva of Clem and Joe's, "is because you can only get local high school kids to wait tables. People who pay their own rent can't afford to."
The Dancing Lobster, a coral-pink shack on Fisherman's Wharf, is, to my taste, the best new restaurant in Provincetown. Even so, the cadre of experienced waiters can't quite keep up with the crowds who wait for up to 90 minutes for one of the 20 tables. Reservations are not accepted.
The owner, Nils Berg, called Pepe locally, honed his craft at his family's restaurant in town, Pepe's Wharf, as well as at Harry Cipriani in Manhattan and Harry's Bar in Venice. He is a superb cook, and his simple, direct Italian cooking brings out the best in local ingredients.
A light, lemon vinaigrette, for instance, transforms shrimp, squid and lobster into a delectably clean-tasting starter. Local mussels remain sweet and plump steamed in a spicy sauce of red and black pepper. The saffron-based fish soup, prepared from a Venetian recipe, is a dream. Salads, ranging from a mound of mescal tossed with feta cheese, cucumbers and tomatoes, a decent Caesar salad and a tumble of radicchio, arugula and fennel with goat cheese, could make a sprightly meal.
But then you would miss the crab ravioli or the linguini with squid and spicy tomato sauce, or the penne with shrimp, squid, mussels and clams in a tomato broth that, like the eight other pasta dishes offered, are flavorful and perfectly prepared. Fish is also a strong suit. Mussels steamed in garlic with a garlic and basil aioli, a shellfish melange steamed with white beans and wine sauce, and salmon grilled with artichoke hearts lead the pack.
The Dancing Lobster celebrates local ingredients, pays homage to the Latin flavors that have always permeated Provincetown cooking, and has a simple, contagious joy about it. The windows offer a panorama of the curving natural harbor and they were front-row seats last month for the re-enactment in a copy of the Mayflower of the Pilgrims' first landing in Provincetown in 1620.
The crook of land at the tip of Cape Cod is a hardscrabble place, suited to those who can sense a dangerous shift in the wind, as well as appreciate its geography and lusty spirit. The Puritans did not like the town too good for Burger King. They may have recognized it as a place that would always resist regimentation. They may have sensed the danger of joy. After just six months they lit out for Plymouth, presumably choosing the predictability of bedrock over the feel of Provincetown sand in their shoes.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Upjohn and Pharmacia Plan $13 Billion Merger
In the latest giant merger of drug makers, Upjohn and Pharmacia of Sweden said they would combine in a $13 billion stock deal, creating the world's ninth-largest pharmaceuticals concern.
In contrast with other recent mergers in the industry, the deal, which would create a company with $6.8 billion in annual sales, is a friendly one. But like the others, it will result in fewer jobs. [Page A1.]
 
Bank Industry's Consolidation Is Shifting Into a Higher Gear
The consolidation in the nation's banking industry is accelerating, with 5 mergers among the top 50 banks so far this year.
While industry executives say the deals are creating stronger institutions, the short-term effect will be more corporate name changes, branch closings and job losses. [A1.]
 
The Competitor as Cover Boy
John F. Kennedy Jr. and his new magazine, George, are getting much attention on the covers of other publications. The spectacle of Mr. Kennedy's joining the media horde he has spent his life avoiding has been too much to pass up. Magazines. [D5.]
 
Advanced-TV Plan in Britain
Within two years, the British Government wants to adopt technology for high-definition television. If it succeeds, Britain could become a test market for the next generation of television. [D4.]
 
The Foundation Behind the Book
Private foundations have long bankrolled books they view as important. But many publishers say economics and a desire to see a field covered -- not politics -- are the motives behind most foundation support. [D5.]
 
Wood Siding Under Attack
Siding made by Louisiana-Pacific is doomed to failure in wet weather, leaving homes rotting away across North America, The Oregonian of Portland reported after an investigation. Louisiana-Pacific defended its Inner-Seal wood siding and said that 99 percent of the houses with it do not have any problems. [A9.]
 
Protection for Patent Holders
In a surprising ruling, the nation's highest patent court has potentially strengthened the power of patent holders. The court bolstered a principle known as the doctrine of equivalents, which is meant to protect inventors from poachers who appropriate the essence of a patent without trespassing its literal borders. [D2.]
 
Who's on Line, Anyhow?
As they consider the use of advertising on the Internet, companies are awaiting a Nielsen study on the demographics of on-line users. Denise Caruso: Digital Commerce. [D3.]
 
Custom Textbooks on Demand
Digital printing is giving professors a way to customize the textbooks they use in their classes, and to make quick changes in them from semester to semester. [D3.]
 
A New I.B.M.-Microsoft Dispute
Simmering hostility between I.B.M. and its former partner, Microsoft, has burst into the open. I.B.M. said that Microsoft had put pressure on trade-show organizers to remove an I.B.M. executive from the program. [D7.]
 
For a Magazine, The Start of Act 2
The reincarnated Mirabella magazine, which reaches newsstands next week, still sees itself as a fashion magazine that isn't really a fashion magazine. But Hachette Filipacchi Magazines, the new owner, says the previous version faced problems that will not exist this time. [D5.]
 
Gay Services From Planet Out
Planet Out, a new electronic media company, wants to become the "gay global village" of cyberspace. It will make its debut on the Microsoft Network later this week. [D3.]

In a high-tech traveling show, an 18-wheeler truck will visit 75 cities, offering demonstrations of Microsoft's Windows 95. Microsoft is not a sponsor. Advertising. [D7.]

HEADLINE: For Clinton and Family, a Vacation Of Golf, Hiking and Breathless Views

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: JACKSON, Wyo., Aug. 20

 BODY:
"I wish," the President of the United States said today, "we all had a moose."
Bill Clinton may not have a moose, but here in the late summer splendors of the Tetons, he is surrounded by plenty of them -- and not just the stuffed, stick-figure variety straddled by a 3-year-old tourist named Kelsey Scott, who prompted his whimsical musing on a lakeside hike today. 
 Indeed, Mr. Clinton lacks almost nothing on this vacation, and the mood so far is decidedly loose. After four days on lush valley fairways, the First Golfer is at 91 holes and counting. He has at least two heaping helpings of barbecued beef shortribs under his belt, a couple of good walks under his boots, and on Saturday night he stopped for a free cup of 49th birthday lemonade from a neighborhood stand before attending a "surprise party" that was the worst-kept secret in town.
He has run the gamut of low-key recreation, from Indiana Jones (the actor Harrison Ford, who held a small dinner for the President at his big ranch here on Thursday night) to Robert Trent Jones (the legendary golf architect whose breathtaking Jackson Hole Golf and Tennis Club course Mr. Clinton has played twice).
"It's wonderful," Mr. Clinton said as he and his wife, Hillary, and their daughter, Chelsea, took an hourlong walk around Jenny Lake in Grand Teton National Park this afternoon, with Mrs. Clinton setting a brisk pace in the lead. "It's a great thing for our country to have something like this. Fabulous."
Asked if hiking was harder now that he was starting his 50th year, Mr. Clinton looked over his shoulder at the reporters following him, laughed and said, "Yeah!" before reaching ahead to Mrs. Clinton's shoulder and letting her lead him along.
Mr. Clinton is staying here in the valley home of Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia. He celebrated the end of his 40's at a party for 60 people at the nearby home of James D. Wolfensohn, the financier who is president of the World Bank. The guests included former Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and his wife, B. A., Senator Alan Simpson of Wyoming, the lawyer Gerry Spence, and Mr. Rockefeller's uncle and aunt, Laurance and Mary French Rockefeller, whose ranch is in the park here.
"The President is having a wonderful time," said the traveling White House spokeswoman, Ginny Terzano. "He was as surprised as one can be after having the surprise party reported on as much as it was in the national and local press, but he was not any less gratified by the gesture."
Indeed, Mr. Clinton's enthusiasm for the wonders at his doorstep seems boundless, and catching. As the First Family stopped to gaze at the Teton range before having lunch in the rustic elegance of the Jenny Lake Lodge today, the President made it clear that he had mountains on his mind.
"You want to go tomorrow?" he asked Chelsea after Linda Oloson, their park ranger guide, suggested a hike on the Cascade Canyon trail, which skirts the 13,770-foot Grand Teton, the highest of the dramatic peaks that French explorers named for their breastlike configurations. Chelsea slapped the President a high-five in return, but Mrs. Clinton reminded them: "No, you can't do it tomorrow. You have your last golf game tomorrow."
Could the President really plan just one more day of golf with 10 days remaining here?
"Well, that's the plan," Mrs. Clinton said with a smile and shrug. "I'm not going to hold him to it, but that's the plan."
In fact, Mr. Clinton has packed in round after round of golf since arriving here last Tuesday, abetted by flown-in partners including his deputy chief of staff, Erskine B. Bowles. Mrs. Clinton has worked on her forthcoming book on child-rearing, "It Takes a Village," while waiting for Chelsea to arrive on Friday from a camping trip in Alaska. But now, aides said, the First Family is determined to enjoy the tens of thousands of acres of wilderness that stretch from here to the Montana border, and to make a few points about the need to protect the environment from Republican budget cuts to boot.
Today, in Rockport hiking boots, blue jeans and a navy blue pullover, Mr. Clinton bought a $25 "Golden Eagle" passport that allows him entry into any national park in the country for a year, and later in the week the Clintons plan more expeditions here and in Yellowstone National Park to the north.
Before their walk, they attended church services in their hiking clothes this morning in the tiny log Chapel of the Transfiguration in the Snake River valley, where a picture window behind the altar perfectly frames a view of the range.
The Episcopal pastor, the Rev. Franklin Johnson, told the parishioners, "This is a Sunday just like any other Sunday," but he acknowledged that they were singing "Amazing Grace" because it was one of the President's favorite hymns, and the service ended with a rendition of "Happy Birthday."
The First Family's hike did not stop other visitors from trooping through the park, but conditions were not exactly typical. They had a heavy Secret Service escort, with other agents stationed in the woods to the side of the trail, supplemented by mounted National Park rangers, and trailed by reporters and photographers.
Mort Engelberg, the Hollywood producer of movies like "Smokey and the Bandit" who choreographed the Clinton-Gore bus tours of 1992 and is omnipresent at the Clintons' side here, could not resist a moment of slightly exaggerated exultation.
"I see this," he told a reporter as the party moved through a lakeside stand of lodgepole pine, "as a forest trail, lined by thousands of well-wishers, shouting encouragement."

It served 60. (Photographs by Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Press Fad, or Future, in Minneapolis?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS

 BODY:
Joel R. Kramer, the publisher of The Minneapolis Star Tribune, would like to answer his critics. He says he is shaking up journalistic traditions to save big-city newspapers from extinction.
And Mr. Kramer has plenty of critics to answer. The paper, where he was once editor, has a long tradition of solid journalism. But with Mr. Kramer as publisher since 1992, it has also become perhaps the most ridiculed newspaper in the country, described by critics inside the paper and out as a headquarters of political correctness and New Age journalism jargon. 
 The Star Tribune has dived into just about every experiment being tried by any newspaper, anywhere. The paper is dividing its reporters into teams; trying "employee empowerment" techniques to get journalists involved in decision making; using focus groups to measure what readers want; experimenting with "interactivity," and redesigning the paper to be more reader-friendly.
"I'm not sure there's a current journalism fad that our managers have not embraced," said Robert Franklin, a longtime reporter and a former city and state editor.
The Star Tribune, which is owned by the Cowles Media Company, is financially healthy and has a steady circulation. Nonetheless, the paper is in the process of reorganizing just about everything in sight, from its corporate and newsroom structures to the look of its pages.
Mr. Kramer has said he is searching for new solutions to the problems that are threatening dailies across the country. In the process he has, in effect, opened a debate inside The Star Tribune over how America's midsize newspapers are to cope with such challenges as declining readership and shrinking advertising.
"My No. 1 goal is to keep the institution of metropolitan journalism healthy and financially viable so it can continue to be done," he said.
Mr. Kramer's moves to improve service to what he calls the paper's "reader-customers" have brought skewerings from national writers, local critics and many of the paper's own staff members. The Wall Street Journal and The Washington Post have poked fun at the changes, especially the cultish new titles given to nearly everyone in authority. (Yes, the managing editor is now the news leader and there really is a newsroom director of player personnel and a leader of strategic integration.)
Mr. Kramer has also broken down the traditional wall in journalism between newspapers' business and news staffs, giving his top editor bottom-line responsibility for the paper's revenue from readers, including circulation. "The people responsible for news should also be responsible for success with readers," he said.
In a savage critique, an alternative paper here, The Twin Cities Reader, recently parodied The Star Tribune's message. "We're so terrified of losing subscribers, we're willing to try anything," said one invented memo The Reader asserted could have been written by Tim J. McGuire, the Star Tribune's editor, who now has the added title of general manager of the reader-customer unit.
Among the management's other changes has been a ban on the use of what it says are offensive American Indian nicknames like Redskins in sports articles; working to increase cooperation between the news and business staffs; inventing new publications like one aimed at real estate brokers, and giving reporters new assignments to meet what are said to be the interests of readers.
At a time of closings, layoffs and consolidations in the newspaper industry, Mr. Kramer and his supporters at the paper say print journalists need to keep doing the best of their traditional work, like investigative reporting. But they say journalists also need to be flexible enough to try new ways of doing their jobs.
Being the butt of jokes and the object of derision, they say, may be the price of confronting the threats to the entire newspaper industry. "There's trouble out here in River City," Mr. McGuire said, "and we as an industry are trying to forge a future. We here are trying to take hold of that future, rather than having it take hold of us."
Many journalists, Mr. McGuire said, naively insist that they do not want to worry about whether readers want their journalism. "The only way we're going to be independent and strong is if we understand we've got to make some money," Mr. McGuire said. "That's how this works. That ideological purity is not going to work any more."
But some critics at the paper say the frenzy for change and the focus on internal organizational issues have made The Star Tribune wander too far from simply gathering the news and printing it. "Just as politicians are being led by polls, we're being led by focus groups and market research," said Mike Meyers, an economics writer at the paper.
Joe Rigert, an investigative reporter and a former city editor, said repeated meetings about collaboration and the team approach had distracted reporters. "I don't get it," he said. "I don't understand how this is going to serve readers. You serve readers when you've got reporters out in the field talking to people."
Mr. Rigert and some other critics say one of the main functions of journalism is to inform readers, even if that sometimes means annoying or offending them.
But there are some at the paper who say the grumbling is just obstructionism. Susie Eaton Hopper, the features coordinating editor, said she often encountered resistance when she tried to get reporters, photographers, graphic artists and editors to collaborate.
She said the changes were healthy because they forced journalists to focus together on how to better serve readers.
The Star Tribune has had operating profit margins of more than 18 percent for the last three years, several percentage points higher than averages at some similar newspapers.
It is also relatively stable in circulation, despite some sharp price increases at newsstands and for home delivery. For the six-month period that ended in March, average daily circulation was 404,757, down about 7,700 from the corresponding period a year earlier, while Sunday circulation was about the same, at 695,548.
Mr. Kramer said he was sick of "crepe hangers" who proclaim the death of the newspaper business. And he said newspaper publishing could still be a growth business if it gave up journalistic inhibitions while remaining protective of its integrity.
He said, for example, that through all the changes at The Star Tribune he had insisted that business executives be forbidden to discuss news judgments with editors or how advertisers react to news coverage affecting their interests.
But, Mr. Kramer said, journalists are too quick to assume there is something impure about trying to give readers what they want.
"Don't assume that appealing to your readers means pandering," Mr. Kramer said. "A lot of them want good journalism."
Journalists, he said, are often too quick to insist that the problems of newspapers are not their responsibility.
"Some people will say, 'It's the readers,' " he said. "I just don't buy that. I say it's our problem. I believe in the public service of what we do, but if we can't get readers to care, what do we accomplish?"

HEADLINE: WAVE OF MERGERS IS TRANSFORMING AMERICAN BANKING

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Long pillars of their communities, the nation's banks are merging with each other, moving their headquarters across the country and leaving in their wake disruption, layoffs and potentially higher costs for customers.
The consolidation is now at cruising speed -- with 5 mergers among the top 50 banks this year -- and the pace is expected to accelerate. And while industry executives say the mergers are creating stronger institutions, big enough to offer innovative services, the practical effect in the short term will be to confront bank customers and employees with corporate name changes, branch closings and job losses. 
 Indeed, between the rising incidence of mergers and the increasing use of technology, a study by Deloitte & Touche predicted that over the next 10 years half of the nation's 59,000 bank branches will close and 450,000 of the 2.8 million jobs in the banking industry will disappear.
What is more, the deals in the current wave often combine banks in different states and even different regions. That means a bank headquarters, with the employment and community support that it entails, is uprooted.
Unlike the media magnates buying television networks and movie studios in hopes of profiting from the exploding entertainment industry, bankers are merging to survive in a business that is rapidly losing its share to rivals like the Fidelity family of mutual funds and the AT&T Corporation's credit cards.
The banking companies making acquisitions hope to increase profits by eliminating competitors and cutting costs. The sellers want to cash out while they can.
In Boise, Idaho, the banking business could not have looked better to Daniel R. Nelson, chairman of the West One Bancorp. Profits were up, loan losses down and new business brisk.
So why, in May, did Mr. Nelson decide to sell the bank to U.S. Bancorp of Portland, Ore., for $1.57 billion?
"Timing is everything," Mr. Nelson said. "Our board had been considering whether to sell for several years. We decided our earnings were not going to get any better than they had been." And with new competition and changing technology, he faced the prospect that the bank's profits and the price it could fetch would only decline.
With big banks like the Banc One Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, and the Nationsbank Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., scouring the country for acquisitions, there was hardly a bank big or small that had not considered selling. But until recently there was no hurry. In fact, with hostile takeovers rare in banking, executives were able to relax in executive suites, without pressure to cash out until they wanted.
This year, though, more banks like West One decided that the timing was right to sell. Three reasons stand out for the wave of bank mergers.
First, it is harder for bankers to increase their profits, now that they have finished cleaning up the problems of the late 1980's and have cut costs as much as they could. As for new lines of business, all but the largest banks have been wary of investing in such avenues as computer banking and mutual funds.
Second, the big banks like Banc One, which were already hungry for acquisitions, have been turning up the heat. Instead of waiting for their targets to decide to sell, as used to be the case, the acquiring banks have tried to force their hands with aggressive bids. The big banks especially want to prevent medium-sized banks from merging with each other and creating institutions too big for their grasp.
And third, stockholders have agitated with managements to sell at a premium rather than pursue defensive mergers, which do not carry a premium.
"Stockholders are becoming more active, with no tolerance for any kind of mistake or problem," said Richard M. Kovacevich, chairman of the Norwest Corporation of Minneapolis. "Banking is still more cozy than other industries, but it is a lot less cozy than it was three or four years ago, or even a year ago."
Some bankers, like those at New Jersey's two biggest banks, First Fidelity and Midlantic, decided it was time to cash out. Their buyers, the First Union Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., and the PNC Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh, respectively, decided it was worth paying a steep price to maintain their rapid growth. Similarly, First Bank System of Minneapolis bought Firstier Financial of Omaha earlier this month for $700 million.
At other banks, like First Chicago and NBD Bancorp of Detroit, the managements have chosen "mergers of equals," in which similarly sized institutions combine to create a far larger entity less vulnerable to a hostile takeover.
Even some banks with stock prices high enough to fend off hostile suitors have become interested in such combinations as a way to expand without either bank having to pay a huge takeover premium.
"There are some mergers of equals that make sense," John F. Grunhofer, chairman of First Bank Systems, said. But many of those never get off the ground, he added, because the two banks cannot agree on such "social issues" as who will be in charge, where the headquarters will be and what name to use.
That was what torpedoed the Bank of Boston's various efforts to merge with the regional rival Fleet Financial Group, with the Mellon Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh and, more recently, with the Corestates Financial Corporation of Philadelphia. That merger was abandoned last month before it was announced, after word of the deal was leaked and prompted criticism by investors and a brief hostile bid for Bank of Boston by Banc One of Ohio, which was withdrawn after the Corestates deal collapsed. The string of botched mergers cost the Bank of Boston chairman, Ira Stepanian, his job.
Mergers can be tough on the employees and communities, and will affect consumer habits.
A year ago, for example, Detroit had three major independent banks. Now NBD will be run from Chicago, and Michigan National was bought by National Australia Bank, leaving only Comerica Inc.
Not every bank executive feels the pressure to do something. Many who have found some profitable source of growth should be able to preserve their independence.
"I think the sellers are more pessimistic about the banking industry than I am," said Stephen A. Hansell, chief executive of the Hibernia Corporation in New Orleans, which has $6.3 billion in assets.
In many ways, the deals signify a changing of the guard. The current generation of bank chiefs came to power in the late 1980's and early 1990's, when banks were failing. The victims were mostly the highfliers who got too loose with their lending, especially to real estate developers. Then the industry rediscovered caution.
With a recovering economy and falling interest rates, bankers could look like heroes simply by cutting costs and not making new mistakes. Today, the industry seems to be in its best shape in decades.
But as suddenly as it arrived, that era is coming to a close. Many bankers have found they cannot increase their profits simply by cutting costs; they have to increase revenue somehow, and not all bank executives are up to the task.
As bright as the profits are today, most bankers see their industry's prospects as bleak, leaving room for only a few to thrive. Banks continue to lose their share of the nation's financial assets to mutual funds and other investments.
Moreover, what was once a bank's biggest advantage -- a branch on every major street corner -- has increasingly been viewed as an albatross in an era of automated banking. "At some point the cost of bank branches will be harder to justify," Mr. Nelson of West One said.
By selling now, not only did Mr. Nelson secure a high price for his shareholders -- nearly twice the bank's book value -- but also jobs for many of West One's executives in the combined company. Mr. Nelson became president and chief operating officer.
For many years the big banks played a waiting game, leaping to acquire smaller institutions when they got into trouble or when their chairmen neared retirement age.
"There are hundreds of banks out there we are talking to at any point in time," Mr. Kovacevich of Norwest said. "At any point, we are in negotiations with 40 or 50 banks, but we may buy 5 or 6 of those."
But now these big banks are getting itchy. Their stock prices have run up during the bull market, making it possible for them to buy banks for stock without diluting the earnings of existing shareholders. With that advantage, "the big guys are trying to figure out how quickly they have to move before they find all the good franchises gone," said John Duffy, the head of the bank merger practice at Keefe Bruyette & Woods.
More pressure has come from big investors in bank stocks.
Michael Price, an investment manager, put the squeeze on Michigan National until its management sold to National Australia. And now he has a big position in Chase Manhattan and has called on the bank to take steps to benefit shareholders, including a possible breakup.
Shareholders are becoming reluctant to take no for an answer. "If your four or five biggest shareholders start pressuring you to sell," said Doug Mercer, an investment banker at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, "as a board member you better have a pretty good reason why you aren't going to sell."

HEADLINE: Merchant Feud Sheds Light On Fish Market's Workings

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB 

 BODY:
Fulton Fish Market merchants boast about a legendary tradition: that their word on a business agreement is an unbreakable pledge, better than a signed contract.
But a real estate arrangement among three merchants that went awry has provoked a rare public feud at the insular market and provided an unusual look at how deals are made to do business on property owned by New York City. The dispute has erupted as the Giuliani administration is trying to end chaotic business practices, corruption and Mafia influence in the rough-and-tumble market in lower Manhattan. 
 The conflict has led to scuffles in the aisles of the narrow 15-by-100-foot stall, insults scrawled on the walls, claims of harassment of customers and a potpourri of legal problems for the merchants, two of whom are facing eviction. One was arrested on a charge that he illegally turned off the power to a refrigerator that his rival used to store seafood.
The feud has also spotlighted a widespread practice in which some licensed wholesale seafood dealers lease and sublease property without the city's knowledge and without the city's profiting from the higher rents obtained through the private deals.
Under new regulations that go into effect next month, the city will have the right to ban any dealer and to approve any sublease. The object is to ban unauthorized dealers, known as phantoms, who have been subleasing space from dealers registered with the city. Giuliani administration officials say dozens of phantoms, some with organized-crime connections, have operated in the market for years without any attempts by the city to oust them.
"The new regulations are designed to knock out the phantom tenants and to stop tenants, subtenants and sub-subtenants from profiteering through a gray market," said Randy M. Mastro, chief of staff to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. "Some people are making huge profits by leasing space without a penny going to the landlord of the market -- the city."
Subleases became highly profitable for the primary tenants because they could charge as much as they liked while their own low rents were frozen. In June, higher rents were imposed by the Giuliani administration for the first time since 1982. The Koch and Dinkins administrations had chosen not to negotiate new leases while the market was under criminal investigation.
An important economic cog for the city, the market -- the nation's largest wholesale seafood distribution center -- generates about $1 billion annually in sales and wages and 800 jobs.
The dispute among the three merchants is over Stall No. 21 in the New Building, one of two shed-like structures in the market on South Street just north of Fulton Street.
For 60 years, a trade organization, the New York Wholesale Fish Dealers Association, has negotiated with the city a group lease for the entire building. The 10 companies that are members of association do not pay rent directly to the city. Each pays a monthly charge to the association based on the number of stalls it has acquired.
In December, Albert Hakim, the owner of the Uniko Fish Company, obtained a lease as a subtenant for No. 21 from Clear Sailing Seafood Inc., a member of the association. Clear Sailing holds the primary rights to use the stall, but it has not sold seafood in the market for several years and leases its rights to dealers, even if they are not association members.
A lean and energetic 43-year-old, Mr. Hakim has leased space at various stalls for 10 years. In an interview, he said that when he negotiated the lease for No. 21 he knew that the C. G. Dino's Seafood Company, owned by Corrado Fiorentino, had been operating there for some time.
Mr. Hakim said that JoAnn La Rocca, the president of Clear Sailing, and her husband, Anthony LaRocca, assured him that C. G. Dino's would vacate the stall.
Under the sublease terms, Mr. Hakim agreed to pay $5,000 a month in rent to Clear Sailing starting in January and to raise it if the city increased the association's overall rent. Clear Sailing had been paying the association $3,150 a month, making an automatic profit of $1,850 a month from the sublease.
But Mr. Hakim asserted that in January Mr. Fiorentino refused to budge from the front of the stall. Asserting that eviction proceedings against C. G. Dino's would cost about $15,000 in legal fees, Mr. Hakim said that he permitted Mr. Fiorentino to remain and that Mr. Fiorentino agreed without a signed contract to pay him $4,000 a month in rent.
"It was a business judgment," said Mr. Hakim, who used the rear of the stall for his company. "If I tried to evict him, I would make a lot of enemies for kicking someone out of the market, and I thought I could operate with him on the premises."
Mr. Hakim said that his Uniko company at another stall last year had sales of $1.5 million and that he expected to gross about $3 million this year in his new quarters. All went smoothly, Mr. Hakim said, until April when the Giuliani administration said it would raise the rents at the market, which were then a total of $260,000 a year, in gradual steps to $2 million by June 1998.
Anticipating a rent increase, Mr. Hakim said he told Mr. Fiorentino his rent would also go up. Mr. Hakim said that in May Mr. Fiorentino stopped paying rent and that his employees interfered with Uniko's business by blocking aisles and making it hard for his customers, retail fish merchants and restaurateurs, to seek him out. Mr. Hakim said he had stopped paying rent to Clear Sailing, asserting that C. G. Dino's had ruined his business.
Mr. Hakim said that when Clear Sailing and the fish dealers' association did not respond to his pleas to remove C. G. Dino's, he warned Mr. Fiorentino that on July 3 he would shut down a refrigerator shared by his company and Mr. Fiorentino's.
On July 5, Mr. Hakim said he found that his office had been broken into and his equipment and records largely destroyed. Police officers, who responded to the break-in, however, arrested Mr. Hakim, after Mr. Fiorentino's employees complained that Mr. Hakim had mangled the refrigerator's electrical wiring.
Mr. Hakim has pleaded not guilty to misdemeanor charges of criminal mischief and criminal tampering.
In an interview, Mr. Hakim acknowledged that he had turned off the refrigerator's main switch. He said that was his right because he paid the electric bills and his company was doing little business.
Last month, Mr. Hakim began civil court proceedings to evict C. G. Dino's for nonpayment of rent. And, Clear Sailing, the primary tenant of the stall, is trying to evict Mr. Hakim for his failure to pay rent.
Mr. Fiorentino, a portly man in his early 50's, who on steamy days in the congested market works shirtless and in shorts, declined to discuss the quarrel with Mr. Hakim.
"This is a good place," he said. "Everyone's making a living."
Mr. LaRocca held Mr. Hakim responsible for the discord. "Dino was going to leave," he asserted. "But Albert Hakim needed a tenant to subsidize the rent and he ended up keeping Dino."
"Subleasing? That's the way everybody does business here," he added. "There's nothing unusual about it."

HEADLINE: How Ted Turner Plans to Play For a Network

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
When the aspiring television magnate Ted Turner bought his second station, WRET-TV in Charleston, S.C., in 1972, it was bargain-basement property in financial peril.
Desperate to keep it afloat, Mr. Turner, then better known as an outdoor-advertising entrepreneur with a flair for the burlesque sales pitch, had the station run an on-air "beg-a-thon." Announcers beseeched viewers of the mostly old-movie channel to donate the price of two theater tickets. The ploy raised more than $30,000 and helped keep WRET-TV on the air. 
 These days, Mr. Turner's beg-a-thon may be tonier. He is still the enfant terrible of entrepreneurs, but the 56-year-old executive is traveling by private jet in his quest for cash. And these days when Mr. Turner launches into one of his legendary harangues, he is seeking billions, not thousands, of dollars.
But Mr. Turner, who declined to be interviewed for this article, is as obsessive about getting CBS as he was a decade ago. And his strategy is no less piecemeal.
At a time when the global entertainment business is consolidating into giants like Disney-ABC, Time Warner, Viacom and Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, Mr. Turner believes that his $2.8 billion Turner Broadcasting System needs to grow, and quickly, if he has any hope of running with the big boys. That is why he is trying to cobble together a takeover bid for CBS Inc., which would require topping the $5.4 billion purchase price that the Westinghouse Electric Corporation has agreed to pay.
Mr. Turner's board is to hold a special meeting by telephone this afternoon in Atlanta to debate the game plan.
But unlike Michael D. Eisner of Disney, who could agree to pay $19.2 billion for Capital Cities/ABC Inc. without worrying about where the money would come from, Mr. Turner does not have the resources to top Westinghouse's $5.4 billion bid for CBS on his own. Nor does he have the authority. Mr. Turner cannot spend more than $2 million without the approval of his board, where two seats are held by one of Turner Broadcasting's biggest shareholders, Time Warner, which until now has opposed his network ambitions.
"It's really a hard one because Ted has to climb three high mountains in a row: he has to satisfy Time Warner, get the financing in place and convince his board that the deal that he wants to do for CBS makes sense," said Emanuel Gerard, a partner at Gerard Klauer, Mattison & Company, an investment firm.
Until recently Time Warner, which is trying to raise money to pay off its $15 billion in debt, had indicated that it wanted to sell its 17.4 percent holding either for $1.6 billion in cash or for a Turner asset like the Cartoon Network. Time Warner was reluctant to approve any network acquisition because Turner would not meet its buyout price.
But now Time Warner is considering supporting a Turner bid for CBS as a means of increasing the value of its Turner stake. Time Warner, however, still wants assurance that it can eventually sell its stock back to Turner at a guaranteed price -- a technique known on Wall Street as a "put" -- according to several people familiar with the discussions.
Such an understanding would give Turner the latitude to organize a bid for CBS, the sources said.
While Turner's reported cut-and-paste strategy seems risky to many people, "Ted Turner has been a pre-eminent and extraordinary risk- taker before," Sumner M. Redstone, the chairman of Viacom, said yesterday. "The world thought he was mad when he attempted to create CNN and mad when he bought the M-G-M library, but he turned out to be successful."
One cornerstone of Turner's possible strategy will be voted on today: the $1.7 billion buyout of the cash-rich King World Productions, which distributes syndicated television programs like "Oprah Winfrey" and "Jeopardy." Some people once believed that this cash would enable Mr. Turner to meet Time Warner's original price. While that option remains, doing so would divert funds Turner badly needs to fight for CBS.
But executives close to the talks reiterated late yesterday that the situation was fluid. Even if Time Warner supports Mr. Turner's CBS obsession, he needs more money, which is why he has approached people like William H. Gates, chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, about chipping in $1 billion or more.
But a bidding war could be perilous to both sides. Many analysts already consider Westinghouse's $83-a-share offer overpriced. Even Mr. Turner, in announcing his intention to go after CBS in a recent speech at a broadcasting convention in Pasadena, Calif., characterized his effort as a long shot.
Some industry executives wonder why Mr. Turner is so determined to take CBS, when they do not believe he needs it. They say he is under far less pressure to strike a strategic alliance than was the Walt Disney Company, for example. Disney, a major producer of network programming, agreed to buy Capital Cities/ABC partly from fear that it would have trouble selling its programs, now that the broadcast networks are no longer bound by Federal regulations that limited their ability to produce in-house programming.
"With Ted, what is missing is the economic equation that drives the other buyers," said Frank J. Biondi Jr., the president of Viacom Inc. "Turner produces very little network TV programming."
But he added: "There is some rationale for a merger. What Turner does bring are unique vertical-integration possibilities in news. That could justify the purchase, if the price is right."
The centerpiece of the Turner empire is the Cable News Network, which has an extensive web of bureaus and reporters within the United States and around the globe, but is coming under new competitive pressure internationally from NBC and European rivals. CBS, meanwhile, has a once-vaunted news operation, here and abroad, growing threadbare after years of budget cuts.
Executives close to Mr. Turner estimate that the combined budgets of CNN and CBS News are about $700 million annually, and that if they were merged the new operation could save at least $100 million a year. News, of course, is only part of Turner Broadcasting, which also includes cable channels like the TBS Superstation, Turner Network Television and Turner Classic Movies; the film studios New Line Cinema and Castle Rock Entertainment, and the Hanna-Barbera cartoon studio. Mr. Turner is even now hoping to buy the Samuel Goldwyn Company, owner of movie theaters and a film library.
"Turner can use its news, sports and entertainment programming to make a TV network better," said an executive familiar with the company's CBS strategy, speaking on the condition of anonymity. And in turn, he said, Turner can afford to make better programming because it would have better access to a larger audience and larger advertising revenues.
It is the same the-rich-get-richer philosophy on which Rupert Murdoch has based the growth of the Fox Network and other pieces of the News Corporation's global sprawl. "Rupert Murdoch has changed sports," this same executive said. "He could pay more for sports such as Wimbledon Tennis, for instance because he could carry the games in the U.S. as well as on Sky TV in England and Star-TV in Asia."
With CBS, Turner Broadcasting might be able to expand his potential audience for sports beyond Atlanta Braves games on TBS and the patchwork of professional football and basketball games that sometimes appear on Turner Network Television.
Today Turner's entertainment companies -- Hanna-Barbera, New Line Cinema and Castle Rock -- produce little programming for the networks. However, if Turner owned CBS, it would give Hanna-Barbera a ready-made network customer. New Line and Castle Rock, which already produces "Seinfeld" for NBC, could become more aggressive in television production.
But some television executives see no need for Turner to buy CBS. "You can always sell good programming," said one industry executive, intrigued by Mr. Turner's strategy. "You don't have to own a network to get programming on the air."
Such arguments may find a voice today among Turner board members. Turner's two leading shareholders are Time Warner and Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable operators. On the issue of a network purchase, they must weigh both Turner's interests and their own. While Time Warner seems to be waivering in its strategy, the Tele-Communications Inc. president, John C. Malone, has said he would support a bid for a network. As a cable operator, Mr. Malone has an interest in access to programming, and talk in the industry has it that Mr. Malone believes he would play a stronger role at Turner, if the company were weakened by additional debt.
What is more, even if King World's cash was not used to buy out Time Warner's stake, Turner's acquisition of King World would contribute only a portion of the $2 billion or more in capital that media analysts say Mr. Turner would need to make a credible bid for CBS.
Despite reports that Microsoft might pony up at least $1 billion of the money Mr. Turner needs, a Microsoft spokeswoman said Friday that no deal with Turner was imminent. In theory, Microsoft needs access to "content" like the Cable News Network for its new on-line Microsoft Network. But media industry experts said Microsoft could easily make a deal for those rights without making an equity investment in Turner itself.
Mr. Turner first approached Mr. Gates of Microsoft in July, at the annual conference that the Allen & Company investment firm holds in Sun Valley, Idaho, for media-industry deal makers. It was Mr. Turner's first visit to the conference, where billionaires are almost commonplace and even the brash, fast-talking Mr. Turner could be overshadowed by power brokers like Mr. Gates, Mr. Malone, Mr. Eisner, Mr. Redstone and everybody's favorite shareholder, Warren E. Buffett.
True, none of them have ever won the Americas Cup yacht race or married Jane Fonda. But many of them play in far larger sandboxes than Mr. Turner's. And Mr. Turner is determined to change that.

Some obstacles he might encounter: a drop in Turner's stock price, which could cripple his financing, or a bidding war with Westinghouse that could put CBS beyond his reach. (pg. D1)

HEADLINE: British Government Wants Big Push for Advanced TV

BYLINE: By RICHARD STEVENSON 

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
The Government of Prime Minister John Major has announced it wants to push the country within two years into adopting the digital technology to carry high-definition television, with its crystal-clear pictures, wide screens and crisp sound.
If the effort succeeds, it would probably make Britain the first big nation to put mass-market digital technology to use, potentially making the country a test-bed for the next generation of television. 
 Earlier this month the Government announced plans for over-the-air broadcasters to begin using digital signals -- the transmission system for carrying high-definition pictures -- for their transmissions as soon as 1997. Digital signals are composed of a binary code, and carry more information than the analog, or wave, signals that television is carried on today.
The United States and other nations are also well along in planning for digital broadcasting. But the regulatory outlook for the technology is still muddled in the United States, and it has been unclear how much enthusiasm there would be for high-definition pictures among American broadcasters and viewers, or how soon any service might start.
If the British plan comes to fruition, the country could become a laboratory for American regulators and the broadcasting industry. There is some skepticism in the television business here about the Government's timetable being realistic, and some trepidation, too, that digital television might be a case of technical capabilities getting ahead of viewer demand and the industry's financial capabilities.
The British Government, by contrast, has unreservedly tried to promote digital broadcasting in the hope of giving the nation's broadcasters, program producers and television-equipment manufacturers a head start in what it sees as a promising worldwide business. Last week the Sony Corporation said it was in talks with the BBC, British Telecommunications P.L.C. and other British companies about deals to develop equipment for the new system.
"Digital broadcasting could transform the viewing and listening habits of the nation, as well as providing thousands of new jobs," said Virginia Bottomley, who as National Heritage Minister oversees broadcasting policy and regulation. "Britain stands poised to take a world lead, reaping immense benefits for U.K. viewers and listeners and U.K. industries."
As recently as a decade ago, the British broadcasting industry was dormant by American standards, with viewers limited to the two BBC stations and a single commercial network, ITV. In 1982, Channel Four began operation.
Now, encouraged by the Conservative Government's free-market policies, Britain has become one of the world's most dynamic television markets. Not only is a third commercial outlet likely, but Britain is home to one of the world's most ambitious direct-to-home satellite broadcasters, British Sky Broadcasting, controlled by Rupert Murdoch.
B Sky B currently offers 21 channels to its 4.2 million subscribers, and although its ratings are relatively low, Mr. Murdoch has continued to invest heavily in its growth, in part through heavy spending to secure rights to sports events and movies. (He is also planning to shift his satellite transmission to digital signals, greatly increasing the number of channels he would be able to offer, although, in the case of digital television, quantity has often been achieved at the expense of quality.)
At the same time, cable television has grown rapidly after a slow start. Britain set up a far more liberal regulatory regime for cable than the United States or any other country, allowing, for example, the delivery of both telephone and television service over the same fiber-optic lines.
As a result, the cable industry here, which delivers everything from Britain's home-grown channels to services like the Discovery Channel and all-news networks, is dominated by large American telephone companies, including Nynex and U S West. These companies were attracted not only by the chance to make money, but by the opportunity to gain experience for the day when the last barriers fall between telecommunications and entertainment in the United States.
The Government has applied the same market-oriented approach to digital television. It said earlier this month it would award six blocks of frequencies next year to broadcasting groups, each of which could use the frequencies to broadcast up to three channels. Each group, known as a "multiplex" operator, could bring together several broadcasters or program suppliers to fill its channels; the two BBC networks, the two commercial networks and a soon-to-be-licensed fifth network are guaranteed slots by the Government's plan, and would have to transmit at least 80 percent of their current broadcasts.
The licenses would be awarded on the basis of bids detailing the types of programming the operators would make available and how much investment they would make in developing the services. Existing analog broadcasts would continue for years, allowing for a gradual changeover.
The Government left many of the economic and technical details to be worked out by industry. Among the key questions to be resolved are the cost of the decoder boxes or new television sets needed to receive digital signals; what sort of programming should fill the 18 new channels; whether all the new services would be free or whether some would be by subscription or pay-per-view, and the extent to which programming would be combined with interactive services like home shopping and banking.
The Government did make a crucial policy decision: It said use of the digital frequencies for nonbroadcast, telecommunications or interactive services would be limited to 10 percent of the available capacity, insuring that most of the frequencies would be used for higher-quality pictures.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Sell Notes This Week

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financings this week includes today's weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, and auctions of new two-year notes on Tuesday and five-year notes on Wednesday.
By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.42 percent, and on the six-month bill, 5.45 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.12 percent and the five-year note at a price to yield 6.36 percent. 
 The following taxable and tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week:
