HEADLINE: In Congressman's District, Conviction Evokes Regret

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 23

 BODY:
This is a South Side neighborhood as jagged as broken glass, where salvation is offered in darkened taverns and storefront churches, but scarcely anywhere else.
And yet, many people here found hope in the example of Mel Reynolds, a homeboy who achieved political stardom. Here was a Rhodes Scholar who had known the sting of the hot sun in Mississippi cotton fields, who had known the sting of poverty in Chicago public housing. 
 Now Mr. Reynolds, 43, stands convicted of sexual misconduct and obstruction of justice. On the crumbling sidewalks along South Halsted Street, where police sirens scream past every few minutes, people greeted his downfall with a sense of mourning.
"It is so disappointing," said a 26-year-old unemployed man, Isaac Williams, who was coming out of a grocery after applying for a job. "Mel's been through what we've been through. He was supposed to be there for us. But he threw it away."
While some people said they felt sorry for the Congressman, others reacted with anger toward Mr. Reynolds, who was convicted of having sex with a 16-year-old.
"Mel Reynolds should have been a father figure to these kids living down here," said Yolanda Dixson, as she walked along a sidewalk with her young children. "A 16-year-old isn't old enough to have sex with another 16-year-old, let alone a man in his 40's."
She added: "He let us down. And I think he ought to go to jail for it. With all his degrees, he should have been smarter than that. I know if somebody did that with a 16-year-old daughter of mine, I'd kill him. Doesn't Mel Reynolds know that's what's wrong today -- all these teen-agers having sex and having babies? We expected better from him."
Mr. Reynolds, who faces a minimum of four years in prison, has not announced whether he will step down from Congress. But a friend, Nate Clay, a Chicago journalist, said Mr. Reynolds told him this morning that he did intend to leave his seat.
The conviction has set off jostling among those interested in the seat. Among those said to be weighing a bid is Jesse Jackson Jr., the son of the former Presidential contender.
But in the Second Congressional District, which stretches from the South Side of the city into the southern suburbs, the talk mostly centered on the terrible fall from grace for a man who seemed to have so much potential.
"He had everything going for him -- everything," said Robert Ray, a 64-year-old retired concrete laborer. "We were all so proud of him."
Even now, Mr. Ray said he was not sure of the Congressman's guilt. He said he could not help but wonder whether the Cook County State's Attorney, Jack O'Malley, who is a Republican, was after a political prize in taking down a high-profile Democrat, and a black man.
For his part, Mr. O'Malley said that Mr. Reynolds had not been targeted but that his accuser had come to the authorities with damning charges and the police and State's Attorney's office had an obligation to investigate. "I never saw the political upside to this case," he added.
When Mr. Reynolds won office in 1992, he was cheered by voters well beyond this district for defeating Gus Savage, a politician who was given to anti-Semitic diatribes and generally anti-white speeches.
Mr. Reynolds was seen as a refreshing change in Chicago politics, a man who could appeal to both races. During the election, Mr. Savage attacked him for receiving "pro-Israeli money," among other things.
Mr. Clay said Mr. Reynolds was "philosophic" about the verdict, "even talking about life after prison." Mr. Clay said he hoped people would not forget the achievements of Mr. Reynolds's career in office. He kept his campaign headquarters open after the 1990 primary, using it for raising money for food programs, securing college scholarships and holding Halloween parties for children. He used his own money to travel to Somalia, where he supervised a famine relief effort.
He was born in Mound Bayou, Miss., where he picked cotton with his grandmother. He moved to Chicago at age 8 or 9, and lived in a public housing project. He graduated from the University of Illinois, and won a Rhodes scholarship to study at Oxford University. He also studied at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard.
Some in the Second District took aim at Mr. Reynolds's accuser, Beverly Heard, who is now 19.
"If it really happened, why didn't she come forward then, when she was 16?" said Doris Stewart, a security guard. "And even if it did, well, when you're 16, you're old enough to know what you're doing."
Mr. Williams, the unemployed man, said he had often looked to Mr. Reynolds for inspiration.
"I always figured that he was really strong, since he was able to overcome all of this," Mr. Williams said, casting his arms toward the rough neighborhood.
But he said he had lost all respect for Mr. Reynolds.
"A lot of older guys have fallen for young girls, so I guess it's not surprising that he could be tempted," said Mr. Williams, whose broken eyeglasses had been patched together with white tape.
"But you've just got to pass it up, not give in to temptation. There's plenty of us guys struggling around here to get by, and we don't give in. So I think, with all he's got going for him, all the money and big house and nice wife, he should have been able to be a little stronger."
George McRae, a substitute teacher, said he could not accept the charges against Mr. Reynolds, at first. "We believed in this guy," Mr. McRae said. "But then you started watching the trial, and it was becoming obvious that he was guilty.
"It's such a sad thing, you know," Mr. McRae added. "Who knows where Mel could have gone? Now, he's not going anywhere but to jail."

HEADLINE: U.S. Bid to Topple Iraqi Falters, Lacking Support in Arab World

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Two weeks after the defection of two top aides of President Saddam Hussein, Washington's hope of seizing the opportunity to weaken or topple the Iraqi Government is rapidly receding.
For one thing, Iraqi and Arab officials say, President Hussein has moved ruthlessly to consolidate his remaining power, arresting hundreds and shuffling his personal security apparatus. 
 But more important, the United States has little prospect of mustering the kind of anti-Hussein consensus in the Arab world that existed during the 1991 Persian Gulf war.
For their own reasons, the other countries in the region have been reluctant to join in the new American effort to move from a policy of simply containing Iraq to one of outright strangulation. For example, Saudi Arabia's economic interest in keeping Iraqi oil off the world market would suffer if President Hussein was ousted and United Nations sanctions against Iraq lifted.
Since the defections, the United States has significantly increased pressure against the Iraqi Government. The campaign includes the stepping up of military maneuvers and the sending of an American diplomatic delegation to try to persuade Saudi Arabia, Jordan and Kuwait to help rein in a country that is seen by Washington as a threat to regional stability.
By all accounts in the Middle East, the American diplomatic mission has failed. Underscoring the doubts about Washington's goal, King Hussein of Jordan said in a nationally televised speech tonight that he would not contemplate closing his country's borders with Iraq.
"As far as closing the borders with Iraq, this is unthinkable," the King said, although he criticized what he described as unwise policies of the Iraqi leadership. He said a border closing would shut off essential supplies of food and medicine to the Iraqi people.
In the meantime in Iraq, opposition figures and some members of the Government say, President Hussein has moved swiftly to reorganize the Government, shifting some power from his tightly knit family circle to old figures of the governing Baath party.
"Saddam used to say, 'Don't blame me if I ally myself with the family against the party, because the party betrays me,' " said an Iraqi still in the service of President Hussein. "Now, it is the family that is conspiring against him. We will see how far the pendulum will swing back."
Hundreds of people have been arrested since the escape on Aug. 8 of Lieut. Gen. Hussein Kamel, said his nephew Ezzedine Mohammed Hassan al-Majid, a commander in the presidential security detail who was among the 22 family members and aides who fled from Baghdad to Amman, Jordan.
"Anybody who ever shook hands with Hussein Kamel has been arrested," Mr. Majid said in a telephone interview from Amman. "They are cutting off all the branches of the tree connected to him, in the family and in the Government".
Virtually all opponents and supporters of President Hussein agree that much depends on how he will handle his son Uday, who has become the most hated person in Iraq but who continues to enjoy his father's support.
Considerable doubts about the prospects for success of the United States strategy have been expressed in interviews in the last week with Iraqi dissidents, officials and Arab experts on Iraq in Amman, London, Vienna and Cairo.
Beyond Mr. Hussein's internal measures, the doubts stem from the lukewarm reaction in much of the Arab world, as well as in Turkey and Iran, to the American campaign and from the Washington's failure to rally the broad coalition that existed in the gulf war.
There is also an increasing reluctance among Arabs and Muslims to impose more sanctions on millions of Iraqis who are already suffering under United Nations sanctions as a result of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990.
Yet despite the potential threat from the defectors, experts on Iraq say they do not believe that dissidents outside the country have much influence.
After five years in oppositon from abroad, the experts say, half a dozen groups have yet to agree on a common program of action despite receiving millions of dollars in financing from the United States.
Far from being considered an ally, General Kamel is viewed by much of the Iraqi opposition as a war criminal because he took part in military operations to suppress the Kurds in the north in the late 1980's and directed violent campaigns of suppression against the Shiites in the south in 1991, after the gulf war.
"This American escalation needs a catalyst," said Ghassan al-Attia, editor of the London-based Iraqi File, an authoritative monthly bulletin that meticulously monitors Iraq's economy and politics. "Who will take part in it? Who will actually overthrow Saddam? Every moment that goes by is in his interest. This a police state, a mafia. The more it has time to rally, the more resistant it becomes."
Echoing a view widely shared around the Arab world, Mr. Attia said Jordan had little incentive for being a key player in the American strategy, among other reasons because the United States was seen as failing to secure the minimum financial help for the Jordanians in getting debt relief and in reviving economic activities that were severely set back with the defeat of Iraq.
Until 1991, Iraq ranked as Jordan's most lucrative market. But even after Baghdad's defeat, the economic ties lingered, particularly as Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and other gulf countries severed their ties to Jordan to protest its close ties to Iraq.
Over the past week, the Jordanian Prime Minister, Zeid Bin Shaker, made that point repeatedly, emphasizing Jordan's unwillingness to cut off all trade and commercial ties with Iraq as the United States has requested of Amman.
Among other things, Iraq sells some 75,000 barrels of oil a day to Jordan at much reduced prices in repayment for debts in an arrangment authorized by the United Nations. Jordanian merchants are owed close to a billion dollars in unpaid bills from Iraq, payments they could have to forsake if commercial ties were severed.
There is also some question over how fervently a fall of the Iraqi Government is desired in Saudi Arabia. A senior Saudi official said in a lengthy conversation today that any such change would mean that Iraq could start to sell oil, a situation that would immediately hurt Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter, by lowering world prices.
In the absence of Iraq's exports of three million barrels a day since 1991 because of United Nations sanctions, Saudi Arabia has raised its output to eight million barrels a day, taking Iraq's share of the world oil market and securing higher revenues.
"Nobody is interested right now in any serious change in Iraq," the senior Saudi official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "For us the status quo is best. For one thing, we cannot afford it. It means we will have to sell less oil or sell it at lower prices. For another, there is no alternative to Saddam except chaos on our borders, with Iranians, Turks and others playing a role that leads to the unknown."
In Turkey, there is a fear that if the Iraqi Government collapsed, Kurds in the northern Iraq would join with those fighting Turkey to create even more turmoil for a Turkish Government that has been fighting against Kurdish separatists for decades.
For Arab countries in general, the wariness in joining the American effort is rooted in the weight of public opinion that sees the United States as throwing its weight around the Middle East to the detriment of Arab interests.
This skepticism in the Arab world is is based on Washington's credibility, said Jordanian, Egyptian and Saudi officials as well as Iraqi opposition figures. One question concerns the underlying message from the United States in its assertive military actions in the region.
"Are they putting the word out to some officers inside to move in on the regime with a promise, this time, to protect them?" asked a prominent independent opponent of the regime. "Or are they really accepting General Hussein Kamel's assertion that Iraq was planning to invade Kuwait and Saudi Arabia and therefore are moving forces to the region?"
Kamran Qarahdaghi, a prominent Kurdish writer in London who is a fierce opponent of President Hussein's Government, wrote today in the Arabic daily Al Hayat: "Long experience in dealing with the Iraqi regime shows that it can be most dangerous and devious when it is weak. These experiences also show that the other side makes its biggest error when it hesitates to finish the regime off."
Mr. Qarahdaghi was apparently referring to the retreat from supporting Kurds and Shiites who rose in revolt in March 1991 after the gulf war but were abandoned by the allied forces.
On Tuesday, after saying there were indications of hostile Iraqi troop movements, Defense Secretary William J. Perry told reporters in Washington that "nothing leads us to believe that any invasion is under way or planned."
In fact, most Arab experts now say Iraq's Government is the only force capable of destroying itself -- or of reforming itself to stay in power.
"There is a notion of a sinking ship in Iraq," said Latif Rasheed, a Kurdish representative and vice president of the London-based Iraqi National Congress opposition group. "Just look at who's leaving. These are the very people who are secure themselves, and their families -- people who are part of the ruling elite, and they are leaving."
But Mr. Rasheed added that with a Government headed by President Hussein, there is no telling. "Sometimes people with cancer can live 10 years," he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Durable Goods Orders Fall, Signaling Broad Weakness
Durable goods orders fell 1.7 percent in July, the Commerce Department said, signaling that factories were far from showing the strength that has been popping up in some other parts of the economy. More than 75 percent of July's slide came in the auto industry, but analysts saw some broad weakness, as well. First-time claims for unemployment benefits climbed by 10,000, to 348,000, for the third straight weekly rise.
These reports should dispel any "notions that the U.S. economy can rebound sharply anytime soon," Merrill Lynch said, and should make it more likely that the Federal Reserve will further relax monetary policy. [Page D2.]
 
Bond prices soared on the reports suggesting that the economy was slowing enough to contain inflation, with the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond slipping to 6.81 percent. [D16.]
 
Competitors Seeking Unity On Format for Videodisks
The two rival camps developing competing videodisk systems -- one led by Sony and Philips Electronics and the other led by Toshiba and Time Warner -- are negotiating on a unified format to prevent a costly war over standards.
Disks the size of a musical compact disk can store a two-hour movie and be used by the computer industry to store vast quantities of data, sound and images. [D5.]
 
U.S. Raids 3 More Sweatshops
Three Los Angeles sweatshops were raided by immigration officials, who found 56 illegal immigrants, mostly Thais who were apparently recruited to cut and sew garments destined for American department stores, possibly including J. C. Penney. It was the second time this month that raids had turned up evidence that organized-crime rings were bringing in foreign workers illegally -- and Presidential politics quickly reared its relentless head. [A1.]
 
Microsoft's Virtual Blast
The place was Redmond, Wash. The jokes were by Jay Leno. The Windows 95 theme song was sung by Mick Jagger. It was a beautiful day on Lake Bill. And all you had to do to join Microsoft's party was, of course, log on and head for the Internet. [D4.]
 
Oh, Have a Coke, Bill
Bill Gates wants a Coke. He walks to a Coke machine -- past a screen displaying, naturally, Windows 95 -- but has no money. And so on, in a new TV commercial. Windows promotion continues. [D4.]
 
Technology Stocks Fall
Technology stocks fell -- even Microsoft, on glorious Windows 95 Day, lost $1.75 -- pushing the Nasdaq down 7.26 points. The Dow industrials edged down 4.23 to 4,580.62. [D6.]
 
Matsushita Loss Tied to MCA
Matsushita lost $1.5 billion for the quarter, it said; without the sale of MCA, it would have had a profit. In dollars, it made about $1 billion on MCA. But the dollar fell steeply while the Japanese company owned MCA. [D16.]
 
What Makes Polaroid Run?
Polaroid shares have been hitting new highs, perhaps because investors subscribe to the theory that if a stock's down long enough, it's got nowhere to go but up. But most analysts are skeptical. Market Place. [D6.]
 
Ads, the Old-Fashioned Way
"They make money the old-fashioned way. They earn it." Thus spake John Houseman for Smith Barney from 1979 to 1986, and though Houseman died in 1988, the words in ads created by Ogilvy & Mather New York lived on in people's memory. So McCann-Erickson is reviving them. "It's a timeless message," a McCann executive said. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D5.]
 
Ceridian to Acquire Comdata
Ceridian, which has huge banks of computers, will acquire Comdata Holdings for $900 million in stock. Comdata provides cash and data for gamblers and truckers. [D4.]
 
Boca Will Not Buy Hayes
Boca Research abandoned talks to buy Hayes Microcomputer, once the leading modem maker, now in bankruptcy. [D6.]

HEADLINE: Raids Link Organized Crime to Sweatshops

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24

 BODY:
Raids by Federal officials this week have turned up evidence that Asian organized crime rings may be bringing Asian and other foreign workers into Southern California illegally, specifically to work in sweatshops in the area's booming garment manufacturing industry.
This is the second time in three weeks that such evidence has been turned up, Government officials said. The raids, which were carried out on Wednesday by the Immigration and Naturalization Service, found 56 illegal immigrants at three sweatshops here. Most were Thais who appear to have been recruited to cut and sew garments destined for major American department stores, Labor Department officials said. They also said it appeared that some of the garments might have been shipped to J. C. Penney. 
 In the latest case, the abuses have been swept up in Presidential politics, inciting bitter exchanges today between officials of the Clinton Administration and Gov. Pete Wilson of California -- not over how the abuses can be stopped or their ominous economic significance, but over who is to blame.
Mr. Wilson, who is staking his bid for the 1996 Republican Presidential nomination in part on his battle against illegal immigration, asserted in a letter to Attorney General Janet Reno that the Clinton Administration had "allowed slavery to exist for years in the United States and ignored it."
The Governor called for an investigation of the authorities here who oversee immigration matters, but the Justice Department insisted that it was effectively enforcing the laws.
In the earlier case, 72 Thai womean who immigrated here illegally were found being held in slave-like conditions in a factory in El Monte, in eastern Los Angeles County, some for as long as seven years.
Those raids were conducted by the state authorities after Federal immigration officials, first in the Bush Administration and then in the Clinton Administration, investigated but refused to act.
"There's a sense that this is the tip of the iceberg," said Julie Su, a lawyer at the Asia Pacific American Legal Center who is representing most of the Thai women found in the El Monte raid. "There are indications that these kind of labor law violations are rampant here."
William Slattery, the immigration agency's executive associate commissioner for operations, said there was a pattern of Asian-based crime groups recruiting Asian workers with promises of high wages, and then transporting them illegally to the California sweatshops.
"These Asians are not here by accident," he said. "They are here because of Asian organized crime groups."
The raids carry troubling economic implications. While Southern California has been losing tens of thousands of high-paying jobs in the aerospace industry and with military contractors, the garment industry has been applauded for adding jobs nearly as fast. But now there is concern over what kinds of jobs are being created and how they may be distorting the economy here.
Southern California has surpassed New York City as the nation's largest garment manufacturing center, with about 125,000 workers cutting and sewing apparel. The Labor Department estimates that there are 4,000 legally registered garment contractors in the area, and perhaps 1,000 illegal shops.
The industry has been known as a persistent violator of labor laws for some time. A survey done by the Labor Department 14 months ago found that 79 percent of the shops investigated were failing to pay workers properly for overtime, and 69 percent failed to pay the minimum wage to all their workers.
William C. Buhl, the department's regional administrator here, said today that it appears that some of those jobs are going to illegal immigrants who are being recruited by organized crime rings.
Mr. Buhl said department officials found that the illegal workers caught on Wednesday were apparently owed back wages totaling more than $200,000. He also said the shops might have fabricated time cards in an effort to show compliance with the labor laws.
Authorities on the garment industry said there were several deeper economic problems at work. One is the fact that, with more and more garments produced in places like China, where wages are a fraction of those in the United States, American factories are finding it harder to compete except in small niches. Some manufacturers accuse the retailers of applying too much pressure on them to keep prices down.
"The retailers in the past turned a blind eye to the effect of their insisting always on rock-bottom prices from the manufacturers," said Richard Reinis, a lawyer who represents eight large manufacturers who have initiated a voluntary labor law compliance program.
Some manufacturers maintain that the real problem is lax enforcement of the labor laws, which has created an incentive for sweatshops -- most of them sub-contractors to the larger manufacturers -- to hire illegal workers and pay them less than the minimum wage.
Ms. Su, the lawyer at the Asian Pacific American Legal Center, also points to the labor law enforcement problems, saying the raids will only push these shops farther underground.
The immigration agency said Wednesday's raids were the result of a tip it got from someone who had been emboldened by the publicity over the raid on the El Monte factory. Of the 56 people being held today, 39 are Thai, 9 are Mexican, 6 are Salvadoran, one is Honduran and one is Laotian, the agency said.
No criminal charges have been brought yet, but Federal officials said they were likely soon. In the El Monte case, nine Thai citizens were indicted on criminal charges that they brought the women here and held them illegally.
State officials identified only J. C. Penney as a destination for garments made at the three shops, although they said there were others.
Hank Rusman, a spokesman for J. C. Penney, said that the company had not yet determined whether it had bought garments from the sweatshops, but added that it "will take appropriate action" if that was borne out.
But the discussion today about the problem quickly degenerated into finger-pointing by Federal and state officials eager to score political points.
Virginia Bradshaw, the California Labor Commissioner, complained that Federal officials had acted improperly by not notifying the state of its actions beforehand.
She added: "Was this for political purposes? There doesn't seem to be any other conclusion you can draw."
Ms. Bradshaw suggested that Federal officials had moved swiftly this week after being embarrassed by the Government's lack of action in the El Monte case. Not only had the immigration agency failed to initiate a raid after receiving a tip about the Thai workers several years ago, but it had also withdrawn from the state-run raid at the last minute, saying it could not obtain a warrant.
Mr. Slattery of the immigration agency rejected those charges. He said the agency had acted properly at all times, was not embarrassed by its previous failure to act in the El Monte case and had not deliberately excluded state officials this time.
In his letter to Attorney General Reno, Governor Wilson characterized the Clinton Administration's handling of the case as "unspeakable." But it failed to say that the initial failure to shut down the El Monte sweatshop had taken place under President George Bush, a Republican. The letter sought to make the case that the Justice Department under President Clinton had shown a pattern of indifference to illegal immigration.
"She has seen the letter," Ana Cobian, a spokeswoman for the department, said of Ms. Reno. "She will review his concerns. The United States Attorney's office is prosecuting the nine individuals to the fullest extent of the law."

HEADLINE: Snubbed at Windows Party? Log On the Internet

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
It was a beautiful day in Redmond, Wash., where Microsoft's Windows 95 was officially introduced. In the main tent, Jay Leno's quips with William H. Gates were amusing. Outside, waterfowl paddled on Lake Bill, a pond in the middle of the Microsoft office campus. Commemorative T-shirt sales were brisk. Mick Jagger sounded great on "Start Me Up," the Windows 95 theme song.
And best of all, one did not have to travel to Washington to take part in the festivities. All the events, except the day's sunshine and cool breezes, were re-created on the global Internet almost as soon as they happened, letting thousands of people who wanted to attend the software party -- whether to cheer or jeer -- do so via PC. 
 Using digital cameras, sound digitizers and other tools of the computer age, 45 Microsoft Corporation employees acted as virtual tour guides for the much-anticipated Windows 95 product introduction, capturing the day's sights and sounds and conveying them electronically to millions of residents of cyberspace via the Internet and the new Microsoft Network.
"There was so much interest in this product launch that we knew we couldn't reach everybody," said Brad Chase, the Microsoft executive responsible for marketing Windows 95.
The Microsoft Network, widely known as M.S.N., officially made its debut yesterday, after months of testing by tens of thousands of consumers, and equal months of Justice Department scrutiny.
The network can be reached by clicking a button on the Windows 95 operating system screen, and that had prompted rivals, including America Online, Compuserve and Prodigy, to complain to the Justice Department that Microsoft would have an unfair competitive advantage.
Attorney General Janet Reno, said yesterday at her weekly news conference in Washington that the Government would continue its antitrust investigation of Microsoft, but gave no details. The Justice Department is expected to disclose its stance on the Microsoft Network issue in several weeks; it may do nothing, or it may also demand that Microsoft sever the link between its on-line service and the operating system.
Dataquest Inc., a computer industry market research firm in San Jose, Calif., reported yesterday that it expected Microsoft to sell 30 million copies of Windows 95 by the end of this year. If 10 percent of those customers click on the M.S.N. icon, a percentage Microsoft officials said was a reasonable expectation, M.S.N. would gain in just a few months an audience almost equal to what America Online has amassed over nearly a decade.
But Microsoft officials said earlier this month that they would initially limit enrollment in the Microsoft Network to 500,000 subscribers.
It was difficult to judge the new on-line service yesterday. For many attending the product introduction, the network commonly displayed the message, "This task cannot be completed at this time, please try again later."
Some 250 people were able to enter an electronic auditorium on the Microsoft Network to type questions to Jay Leno, host of the NBC-TV Tonight Show and of the real-world festivities in Redmond.
"Now that I've been paid, in true show-biz tradition, I can blatantly attack Bill Gates on the air," Mr. Leno quipped from the keyboard. But rather than attacking the Microsoft chairman on line, he told his virtual audience that he had personally installed Windows 95 on his home computer.
While the official real-world party ended this evening, the cyberspace party will continue on line until Sept. 14. Directions: Head toward the World Wide Web and turn left at (http://www.windows.microsoft.com). Unlike the Microsoft Network, which restricts attendance to Windows 95 users, the Internet sites will also admit Macintosh, Unix and OS/2 users.
Meanwhile, scores of commentators on competing on-line information services offered their views of Windows 95. There were games, pre-parties, post-parties and group discussions in which people praised, criticized and asked questions about the new software.
Elsewhere on the Web, remote video cameras and electronic sensors situated at strategic locations in Seattle delivered images of weather and traffic conditions. Other areas offered information on entertainment and outdoor activities.
Witnesses at the scene say apparently none of the cameras was aimed high enough to see a radio-controlled balloon hovering near the fringes of the Microsoft campus, displaying a rival's name: America Online.Sports Desk

HEADLINE: Vatican Picks U.S. Woman As Delegate to U.N. Parley

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 24

 BODY:
Taking a shrewd new tack in its international diplomacy, the Vatican has chosen an American woman, Mary Ann Glendon, a Harvard law professor, to lead its delegation to the Fourth World Conference on Women in Beijing next month.
The Vatican, which found itself nearly isolated on issues of abortion, contraception and the rights of women at the United Nations Population Conference in Cairo last September, has apparently decided to put a new face on its international team. 
 For the first time its delegation to a major world conference will be led by a woman, in this case an articulate, respected conservative legal scholar.
The Vatican has only observer status at the United Nations, but its strong voice has often influenced the course of debate on social issues.
Ms. Glendon, one of a handful of female professors at the Harvard Law School, is a prolific writer on comparative family law and social policies and a strong supporter of the Vatican's stand against abortion.
In an interview today, she said she could understand the opposition to the church's ban on artificial methods of contraception. But she questioned the use of family planning programs as a primary way to combat poverty in crowded developing nations, which she describes as "getting rid of poverty by getting rid of poor people."
The appointment of Ms. Glendon, who favors debt reduction and other economic policies embraced by the developing world, is seen as a political move to build bridges to delegations from poorer countries, whose numbers Pope John Paul II has sought to marshal behind the church's conservative views on women and the family.
She is the author of nine books, including "Abortion and Divorce in Western Law," which made her a leading intellectual voice in the American anti-abortion movement and a strong defender of the economic interests of women and children in divorces.
The announcement of Ms. Glendon's appointment is expected to be made in Rome on Friday, a spokeswoman for the National Conference of Catholic Bishops in Washington said. The Vatican will then also make public the names of the other members of a 20-member delegation likely to be dominated by laywomen from around the world.
The Beijing conference and the parallel forum of independent organizations that opens in China next week will be the largest meeting ever convened on the status of women, and many delegations will be seeking firm committments from governments to deal with issues of violence, economic development and political empowerment.
In some areas, Vatican delegates to preparatory meetings have balked over definitions of reproductive and sexual health that it deemed too broad and saw as opening the door to policies on abortion and contraception that it finds objectionable. They portrayed the conference agenda as the work of Western feminists.
In an interview from her office at Harvard, the 56-year-old Ms. Glendon, the Learned Hand Professor of Law, said that she did not expect the Beijing conference to "reopen the Cairo issues."
"A lot of people forget that this is the Fourth World Conference on Women," she said, stressing the number, "and that the specific theme of this conference is action for equality, development and peace. I feel very pleased about a conference where the primary item on the agenda is to move from talk and good intentions to action."
Critics of Professor Glendon say that in her writings and associations she has been too close to the conservative end of Catholic thinking and out of touch with mainstream women's movements not only in the United States but also increasingly in developing countries.
Frances Kissling, president of Catholics for a Free Choice, said in an interview today that Professor Glendon, whom she described as "a very respected lawyer" and an articulate defender of the Vatican's positions, had on occasion taken positions that were more conservative that the Pope's.
Ms. Kissling said that the appointment of Ms. Glendon "undercuts the the letter of apology the Pope wrote recently to the world's women in which he acknowledged the church's part in discrimination."
Professor Glendon, who is married to a lawyer and has three grown daughters, says she draws on experience at home and at work and on the writings of Pope John Paul II in framing her understanding of equality.
"Real equality involves an affirmation of motherhood and family life," said Ms. Glendon, who has served on several Vatican committees and boards and is considered a founder of the new American "communitarian" movement, which for the last few years has been arguing for the strengthening of civil institutions as well as the family.
"We should not devalue the work women do as mothers and caretakers," she said. "Any kind of equality that does not take into consideration women's legitimate aspirations to have a decent family life, workplace equality and roles in public life is going to be an elusive kind of equality."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Prof. Mary Ann Glendon of Harvard, who will head the Vatican delegation to next month's United Nations women's conference. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Orders for Durable Goods Drop as Weakness Persists

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24

 BODY:
The economy may be rebounding from a flat performance in spring, but factories, at least, are showing hardly any bounce at all.
The Commerce Department reported today that orders for long-lasting manufactured goods fell 1.7 percent in July, a markedly weaker result than was expected and another indication that economic growth should remain slow well into fall. 
 A separate set of Government figures showed that the number of first-time claims for unemployment benefits last week climbed by 10,000, to 348,000, the third straight modest rise, following back-to-back declines in late July.
Taken together, Merrill Lynch told clients, today's reports belie "notions that the U.S. economy can rebound sharply anytime soon" and raise the chances that the Federal Reserve will relax monetary policy and cut interest rates.
The bond market reacted favorably to the signs of economic weakness, with the 30-year Treasury bond rising more than a point in price while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.81 percent from 6.91 percent.
The Fed's Open Market Committee, which cut interest rates in early July but decided not to make another cut on Tuesday, is scheduled to meet again on Sept. 26.
While more than 75 percent of July's slide in orders for durable goods was accounted for by the automotive industry, analysts noted weakness, though less pronounced, on a broad front.
Of particular concern, they said, was a drop of 6.6 percent in orders for capital goods other than aircraft and military equipment. That could be a precursor to lower spending by businesses on new plants and equipment, a principal source of growth during what has become a mature business recovery and expansion.
In fact, in one of the most sober reactions to the data, Elliott Platt of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette said that today's report "may very well mark the beginning of the end" of this upswing, which dates to March 1991.
In Philadelphia, Veronika White, an economist at First Fidelity Bancorporation, said that the drop in orders for durable goods, those intended to last at least three years, might have been overstated because of statistical inadequacies but that orders were far from robust.
"Manufacturing is still pretty much dead in the water," she said.
The Commerce Department said the $2.7 billion drop in orders in July was heavily affected by the growing practice among auto makers of shutting plants for two weeks during the month. In the past, summer shutdowns had been spread over a longer period, and the department, one specialist acknowledged, has not fully conformed its seasonal adjustment process to the industry's shift.
Orders for transportation equipment slumped 7.7 percent in July, while those for industrial machinery and equipment fell 4.8 percent, in the first decline since April. Orders for primary metals showed virtually no change, the report showed.
In sharp contrast, orders for electronic goods and other electrical equipment posted an increase of 6.5 percent, more than offsetting a 1.9 percent decline in June. But the introduction of the Microsoft Corporation's Windows 95 computer operating system software today played no role in this, because stand-alone software is not classified as a durable good.
Orders for military equipment, a volatile category, fell 2.9 percent, accounting for one-tenth of a point in the overall 1.7 percent decline in orders to $156.4 billion, seasonally adjusted.
Shipments of durable goods fell 2.7 percent, or $4.4 billion, last month after a rise of eight-tenths of 1 percent in June. It was only the second decline since October, with shipments this year running 8.6 percent ahead of the comparable period in 1994.
The value of unfilled orders fell for the fourth straight month, to $434 billion, but the latest decline was less than one-tenth of 1 percent.
Although jobless claims climbed last week, the four-week moving average eased by 6,000, to 334,750. Mr. Platt said the level of claims showed "a very modest trend of deterioration" in the labor markets.

HEADLINE: Lord White, 72, Who Liked Role As a Business Buccaneer, Is Dead

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

 BODY:
Lord White, a co-founder of the British conglomerate Hanson P.L.C. and one of the most successful takeover artists of the 1970's and 1980's, died on Wednesday at the U.C.L.A. Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 72.
A spokesman for Hanson said Lord White died of a respiratory ailment. He had been hospitalized last month after collapsing on a flight from London to Los Angeles. 
 By combining an eye for undervalued companies with a take-no-prisoners approach to boardroom battles, Gordon White built Hanson into one of the largest British-owned companies. In 1994, Hanson had revenues equivalent to $17.2 billion, at current exchange rates.
For many years Lord White headed Hanson's extensive operations in the United States. His public profile never matched that of Lord Hanson, his close friend and partner. But within the company, the two men operated more or less as equals. And when it came to buying companies -- the main way in which Hanson grew -- Lord White by all accounts was in charge.
"He was the leading takeover expert in the world and I met no businessman, in the U.S.A. or the U.K., with his instinct for opportunity," Lord Hanson said in a statement yesterday.
Lord Hanson called Lord White a "bold, brave and utterly charming latter-day buccaneer, as he liked to think of himself."
It was Lord White who masterminded the company's rapid growth in the United States, to which he moved in 1973. He started by buying relatively small, nondescript industrial companies, but by the mid-1980's had moved on to bigger prey, including the SCM Corporation, the typewriter and chemical company, which he acquired in 1985 for $930 million after a bitter takeover battle.
That deal, in which Hanson subsequently sold off most of SCM's parts, earning a big profit in the process, gave Lord White a reputation as an "asset stripper," a designation that grated on him. He told interviewers that he much preferred to be thought of as a builder of companies, not an industrial deconstructionist.
Lord White also played a key role in many of the company's biggest deals in Britain, including its $2.5 billion acquisition in 1985 of the Imperial Group, a food and tobacco company. But along with Lord Hanson, his reputation took a beating when Hanson lost a hard-fought effort to take over Britain's Imperial Chemical Industries in 1991.
"Although the company carries the Hanson name, it is Gordon White who in some respects has been the surrogate brother -- the intelligent sophisticate, who has carried the more prudent and less instinctive James Hanson along with him," Alex Brummer and Roger Cowe wrote in "Hanson: A Biography" (Fourth Estate, 1994).
The biographers quoted Lord Hanson as saying of Lord White: "Gordon was the buyer. Gordon was the one who sniffed out the possibilities and then went on to conduct the takeovers. He's certainly the brightest person I've ever met in that way."
Born Vincent Gordon Lindsay White on May 11, 1923, in Hedon, England, he served during World War II in the Royal Air Force and then in a clandestine intelligence unit in India, Burma and Siam. After the war he took over his family's publishing company.
He began working with James Hanson in 1964, when both were board members of a truck dealership. By the early 1970's they had built their company, then called Hanson Trust, into a medium-sized conglomerate. But feeling that the weak economy and the political atmosphere in Britain at the time were not conducive to the kind of freewheeling free enterprise he supported, Lord White moved from London to New York, believing that the prospects for making money were much better there.
Like Lord Hanson, he enjoyed his reputation as a playboy, dating models and movie stars -- Mary Tyler Moore, Cheryl Tiegs and Joan Collins among them. After his third marriage, in 1992, to Victoria Ann Tucker, who is 40 years younger than he, he was quoted as saying: "Never marry a young girl. They only want babies."
A horse-racing enthusiast, he persuaded Hanson to invest in a string of thoroughbreds -- an investment that, much to his later embarrassment, lost the company and its shareholders millions of dollars.
He was a big admirer of Margaret Thatcher while she was Britain's Prime Minister. She knighted him in 1979, and gave him a life peerage in 1990. He lived in recent years in Los Angeles.
In addition to his wife, he is survived by two daughters, Carolina and Sita, from his first marriage, to Ann Elisabeth Kalen, and a son, Lucas, from his second marriage, to Virginia Ann Northrop.

HEADLINE: New Tolerance Sprouts Among Cuban Exiles

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Aug. 24

 BODY:
When Kenia Serrano Puig, a 21-year-old Communist from Havana, spoke at Florida International University here recently, five police officers shielded her from hecklers in the audience. She was hissed, called a liar and shouted down.
Her sponsors called the event a success. 
 "We were able to hold the meeting and there was no violence," said Ivan Rosero, a student organizer of the event last April. "Ten years ago, that would have been impossible."
Ten years ago, the Puerto Rican singer Lucecita Benitez said, she could not have performed in Miami. Like other Latin American artists who have worked in Cuba or expressed sympathy for its Government, Ms. Benitez was labeled a Communist and shunned by local radio stations.
But two weeks ago, Ms. Benitez made her South Florida debut in Miami Beach. "I just let time go by," she said.
To many Cuban Americans here, the appearances by Ms. Serrano Puig and Ms. Benitez are signs of increasing tolerance for political dissent about Cuba. Exiles who have been fiercely hostile toward Fidel Castro's Government have long dominated political discourse, and those who deviated from the hard line have suffered virulent verbal attacks, ostracism and sometimes violence. But many Cubans here say that political and demographic changes have stretched the parameters of acceptable debate, weakening the hard-liners' message and allowing other views.
Increasingly, moderates are willing to organize and voice opposition to the American trade embargo and other sanctions to avoid further hardship on Cuba. On Spanish-language radio, the standard anti-Castro fare is now complemented by programs like that of Alvaro Sanchez Cifuentes, a commentator on WWFE-Radio Fe who skewers both Cuba's Government and what he calls the "many little Castros" of Miami's exile political groups.
Polls of Cuban-Americans have shown that many, particularly younger adults and those who came in more recent waves of immigration, support the use of various tactics to bring democracy to Cuba. Many more are willing to entertain negotiation, as well as military options.
Since the collapse of the Soviet bloc and after 35 years of exile, many also regard the hard-line posture as a failure. "There's now a political and historical context for an alternative voice to have some legitimacy," said Lisandro Perez, director of the Cuban Research Institute at Florida International University.
But if there is more openness, there is yet to be a breakthrough; the improved climate is still exceptionally limiting of free expression, many exiles say. As recently as last November, Human Rights Watch/ Americas, a group that monitors human rights internationally, concluded in a report about Dade County, Miami's metropolitan area, that when the subject is Cuba, "only a narrow range of speech is acceptable, and views that go beyond these boundaries may be dangerous to the speaker."
Although elected officials and exile political leaders say this view is exaggerated, the Human Rights Watch reports detailed incidents that have long been associated with exile politics: bombings and vandalism of political targets, verbal attacks and name-calling on Spanish-language radio, economic pressure and death threats. The violence has subsided, many exiles agree, but they say that threats are still common and that many people are still gripped by fear of reprisal if they speak up.
The mere mention of Fidel Castro's name still touches off such emotions that last April a local television weatherman changed his professional name from Fidel to Felipe so as not to offend.
"We felt that in the environment we were in, Fidel may not go over very well, " said the weatherman, Fidel Ferro, a Cuban-American who works for WSCV-TV Channel 51.
Human Rights Watch/Americas found that radio was crucial in repressing the free exchange of ideas by allowing denunciations that "have the effect of identifying targets for violent and unstable persons in the listening audience." The group also took local law-enforcement and government officials to task for failing to make arrests in most of the incidents of violence or to publicly defend rights to free speech.
In April 1994, the group said, participants at a conference in Havana sponsored by the Cuban Government were identified by name on the air and vilified as "dogs," "whores" and "spies for Cuba." One program recommended that participants be denied business services, and another invited listeners to single out those who deserved "an act of repudiation," the report said.
Tomas Garcia Fuste, the news director of WCMQ, said he did not censor callers because that would be "the same as in Cuba." But he said, "We promote a hard line, but we don't agree with persecuting people."
More than a year after she attended the Havana conference, and kissed Mr. Castro and called him "a great teacher," Magda Montiel Davis, 42, said she was still paying for it. An immigration lawyer and Democrat who ran unsuccessfully for Congress in 1992, Ms. Montiel Davis was abandoned by her staff and even lifelong friends, kicked out of her dance class and harassed in a way that still makes her avoid crowded places and use bodyguards occasionally.
"Magda, why don't you shop in Cuba?," a young woman taunted in the latest incident when she sighted Ms. Montiel Davis window-shopping at a mall.
Miami, Ms. Montiel Davis says, has not changed.
"Even assuming some improvement," she said, "it's not in the range of what's acceptable for American mores."
But more often free speech is endangered in less striking ways. For the event where Ms. Serrano Puig spoke, the university asked sponsors to pay $3,000 for security. The fee was lowered to $400 when the American Civil Liberties Union threatened to sue, saying the larger amount would have the effect of restraining speech.
At the University of Florida in Gainesville earlier this year, a group of Cuban-American state legislators intervened when students scheduled the appearance of three professors from Havana to talk about investment in Cuba. The lawmakers compared the Cubans to Nazis and Colombian drug traffickers and asked that plans for the event be dropped. But a compromise was reached when opposing speakers were invited.
Cuban-American political leaders say that a small minority is responsible for the worst behavior and that no harm has come to most who adopt a conciliatory stance toward Cuba. They note there is no better evidence of tolerance among exiles than the help they offer to those who only now are leaving Cuba.
"Every day people arrive, and they are welcomed with open arms," said Representative Lincoln Diaz-Balart, a Republican from Miami.
Many say it is understandable that people who have gone through the trauma and frustration of exile and whose friends or family have been jailed or killed by the Cuban Government would react emotionally to anything that smacks of approval of Mr. Castro. Many exiles compare their experience with the Holocaust. Many also view disunity in their ranks as a gift to Mr. Castro.
Some Cuban-Americans express fear that if the Clinton Administration decides to negotiate with Havana beyond immigration matters, the most extremist exiles might resort to violence. But others note that early militants have grown old or died, and that exile politics have matured.
"We've realized more is achieved with peaceful militancy," said Pedro Reboredo, a member of the Dade County Commission, who last month took part in a flotilla that tried to drop flowers where a tug boat crammed with refugees sank last year. Mr. Reboredo ended up losing a toe when his foot got caught between his boat and a Cuban gunboat that expelled the exiles from Cuba's waters.
Eloy Gutierrez Menoyo, a guerrilla commander in the Cuban revolution who turned against Mr. Castro and was imprisoned for 22 years, said he represented a silent majority who wanted a negotiated transfer of power in Cuba, what he called "the thesis of a peaceful solution."
Last June, he met with the Cuban leader and asked that his group, Cuban Change, be allowed to function as an opposition political party in Cuba. Upon his return here, a few hundred supporters met him at the airport. There were no protesters.
"Miami has undoubtedly changed," he said.

HEADLINE: Germany Cuts Key Interest Rates to 6-Year Lows

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: BONN, Aug. 24

 BODY:
Germany's central bank, seeking to reduce the value of the mark and lift the country's economy, cut each of two key lending rates by half a percentage point today, setting their lowest levels in more than six years.
The impact of the cuts in the Bundesbank's discount and Lombard rates could be felt well beyond Germany. Because the Bundesbank effectively sets monetary policy across the Continent, today's action resulted in rate cuts in other European countries. And if the rate reductions do weaken the mark against the dollar in coming weeks, the Federal Reserve would have more leeway to lower interest rates in the United States. 
 Today's rate cuts were announced following the biweekly meeting of the bank's policy-making Central Bank Council. The discount rate was lowered to 3.5 percent from 4 percent and the Lombard rate to 5.5 percent from 6 percent.
The discount rate is the lowest rate at which banks can borrow from the central bank to meet their short-term liquidity needs. It puts a floor under short-term German interest rates. The Lombard rate is applied to loans that banks request only in emergencies, when they need additional funds. It is the highest rate the central bank charges on loans -- a punitive rate -- and puts a ceiling on short-term rates.
The dollar initially rose, then fell against the mark following the Bundesbank's announcement. Some traders, who had been expecting the Bundesbank action, sold dollars to take profits from the American currency's recent rebound against the mark. And the dollar was pulled down further by the release of weak economic data in the United States, which many traders regarded as pointing toward a possible cut in American interest rates as well. [Page D13.]
Interest rate reductions tend to weaken a currency, and economists in Germany said the Bundesbank's rate cuts reflected its growing concern that an excessively strong mark was hurting the German economy. Until the dollar's recent rebound, the mark had risen almost 10 percent against other European currencies and the dollar this year. A strong mark makes German exports more expensive in terms of other currencies, and exports account for more than 30 percent of German economic activity.
"We have seen the mark peak in mid-March," said Gunther Thurman, chief economist at Salomon Brothers in Frankfurt, with the currency on a "downward trend" since then. "I think the Bundesbank is clearly signaling that it wants that downward trend to continue."
Mr. Thurman said that in coming months, the mark could fall as low as 1.60 to the dollar, down from its high of 1.37 earlier in the year. In late New York trading today, the mark stood at 1.4757 to the dollar.
Today's action by the Bundesbank was the latest step taken by the world's three most powerful central banks -- the Fed, the Bundesbank and the Bank of Japan -- to try to increase the dollar's value. Like Germany, Japan's economy has been hurt by the dollar's weakness.
Since the start of July, all three central banks have pushed down interest rates. Last week, for the first time in years, the Bundesbank joined the Fed and the Bank of Japan in a coordinated intervention effort to push up the dollar. The German bank bought an estimated $2 billion of the American currency in the foreign exchange market.
The Bundesbank cuts prompted reductions by the central banks of Austria, the Netherlands, Denmark and Belgium. Those countries peg their currencies to the mark. The central banks of France and Switzerland left their rates unchanged.
The discount rate cut was the second this year. In March, the Bundesbank lowered the rate to 4 percent from 4.5 percent. The Lombard rate had not been cut since May 1994.
The Bundesbank's rates are now at their lowest levels since December 1988. The bank subsequently raised rates sharply because of concern that the vast amounts of money being poured into eastern Germany for German reunification in 1990 would set off runaway inflation.
Though the Bundesbank had been expected for weeks to cut rates, economists had been split about the timing, with some saying the bank would not act until next month.
The timing had been especially uncertain given the Bundesbank's concerns about German inflation. Central bankers are always caught between concerns that a rate cut will spark excessive inflation and that interest rates that are too high will push an economy into recession. Many often opt for too much inflation for the sake of growth and political considerations about maintaining employment.
But the Bundesbank's mandate requires that it first maintain price stability, rather than protect jobs, so it has tended to set a very tough inflation target -- now 2 percent a year -- and to be slower to cut rates than other central banks.
Data released this morning seemed to indicate that inflation would be exactly 2 percent for the year or slightly higher, giving the bank an opportunity to reduce rates.
The Bundesbank said today's rate cuts came in response to "persistently weak development of the money supply," a statement that economists said obliquely referred to fears that the strong mark has pushed the German economy perilously close to recession.
Richard Reid, chief economist at UBS Global Research in Frankfurt, noted that"in the last few days we have seen a lot of negative news about the economy, sliding business confidence, weak new orders for factory goods, and very poor labor-market data. We are going to see a fall in employment this year, and that is very, very poor performance in the second year of a recovery."
Germany's economy grew more than 3 percent last year, but some economists expect an expansion this year of as little as 1.5 percent. Scores of companies have released second-quarter results showing that their profits have been substantially weakened by the strong mark's effect on exports.
The dollar isn't the only currency whose weakness has worried German industry and the Bundesbank. The levels of Italy's lira, Spain's peseta and Britain's pound -- considered the weak currencies of Europe -- have cost German businesses hundreds of millions of dollars in lost sales by making manufacturing in those countries much less expensive than it is in Germany.
The German Government, which has no control over Bundesbank policies, welcomed today's action. "As a result of today's decision by the Bundesbank, the forces for inflation-free growth in Germany will be strengthened further," said Theo Waigel, the Finance Minister.
Amid the general enthusiasm about the Bundesbank's action, some economists argued that German interest rates might be too low. The German Association of Cooperative Banks said in a statement that rates were now at levels that had triggered faster inflation during previous business cycles.
"Especially after the latest rate cuts, price stability must be the primary goal in the forefront of all activities of monetary policy," the group said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities' Prices Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The latest Government reports suggesting that the economy is slowing enough to contain inflation turned bears into raging bulls yesterday and sent the prices of Treasury securities sharply higher. Adding to the market's upward direction were sizable rate cuts by Germany's central bank.
Bond prices rallied after the Commerce Department reported a surprising decline of 1.7 percent in July durable goods orders. The drop for big-ticket items as diverse as washers and automobiles compared with the previous month's decline of 0.3 percent. The report contrasted with expectations of a 1.2 percent gain. While the report spelled some disappointment for the economy, it was good news for bonds, because it again raised expectations of another rate cut by the Fed this year, possibly at its next monetary meeting, analysts said. 
 The 30-year bond rose 15/32 to a price of 10025/32 for a yield of 6.81 percent, down from 6.91 percent on Wednesday. For bondholders it meant that for every $1,000 of bonds held they made about $12.19 yesterday.
Traders noted that investors playing the market with borrowed securities and betting that bond prices would fall further found themselves in the middle of a market rally that forced them to cover those short positions, in other words to buy back those borrowed securities to limit losses. And this helped to generate even more buying.
Discussing the German rate cut, Anthony Chan, chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said: "The bottom line was that the action improved the prospects for a stronger dollar, making dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities that much more attractive.
"Given that the Fed did not ease short-term rate this time around, the German rate cut is that much more significant for the Treasury market."
Also out yesterday was the weekly jobless claims report for the period that ended on Aug. 19; it showed a 10,000 increase in claimants to 348,000, from an unrevised 338,000 the week before. While the weekly data track how many people are filing first-time unemployment claims at state offices, next week's more comprehensive monthly employment report will survey households and businesses to measure the number of new jobs as well as unemployment.
Other investors took advantage of the early gains in the market to sell Treasuries, betting that prices will not be rising much higher, keeping the market's gains limited.
Mr. Chan said the weakness in the durable goods number was dominated by the temporary shutdowns in the auto industry for changeover and retooling; the Commerce Departmenmt reported that more than 75 percent of the decline in the overall number resulted from softness in the auto sector.
Gerald A. Guile, senior vice president of the taxable fixed income department at Advest Inc., said the much lower goods number confirmed his belief that the rebound in the third quarter would be below expectations.
"Over all, despite the summer doldrums, I think the market is poised to resume the yearlong rally, which will result in new lows in interest rates," Mr. Guile said.
However, he said, any further easing by the Fed at this point would be counterproductive to the bond market rally. "And of course," he said, "the German central bank's lowering of short-term rates is bullish for all worldwide capital markets, including ours."
David Ader, managing analyst at Technical Data in Boston, said the market put in a performance that caught much of Wall Street by surprise. "No one expected the upper end of the recent range to be challanged today," he said, "and it looks like more gains can be made."
Mr. Ader says the question being raised now is whether the Fed may ease next month. The market is in a good position, he added, given a helping hand by aggressive buying from hedge funds and central banks in the shorter maturities.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Falls After Rate Cuts In Germany Spur Early Gains

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Despite cuts in German interest rates, the dollar ended lower against the mark yesterday in a day of volatile trading.
Interest rates can help to determine the value of a currency; lower interest rates make deposits of the currency less attractive. Thus, the mark would normally fall against the dollar after a rate cut by the German central bank, the Bundesbank, because dollar-based investments would seem a better value. 
 And indeed the dollar rallied after the Bundesbank cut the discount rate to 3.5 percent from 4 percent and the Lombard rate, which acts as the ceiling on money-market rates, to 5.5 percent from 6 percent.
But the dollar later fell, pulled down by a weak United States durable-goods report suggesting that lower American interest rates might be in the offing.
Profit-taking also held down the dollar. Many traders had bet that the Bundesbank would push short-term interest rates lower at its policy council meeting yesterday, particularly after it cut its 14-day securities repurchase agreement rate, known as the repo rate, on Wednesday.
In late New York trading, the dollar settled at 1.4757 marks, down from 1.4833 marks on Wednesday. The dollar also fell to 96.54 Japanese yen from 96.61. The British pound edged up to $1.5454 from $1.5416.
The dollar surged as high as 1.4962 marks, its highest since Feb 16, after the Bundesbank cut the two rates more sharply than many traders had expected.
Other central banks followed the Bundesbank's lead, with rate reductions in Austria, Denmark, the Netherlands and Belgium.
"There was a flurry of dollar buying on optimism" that funds would find their way to high-yielding currencies and assets, said Wayne Grigull, director of foreign exchange sales at Merrill Lynch & Company.
But the dollar fell more than 2 pfennigs, or 1.6 percent, after a report revived fears that the Federal Reserve could cut interest rates to bolster the economy.
The Commerce Department reported that orders to factories in the United States for durable goods fell 1.7 percent in July, suggesting continued slow growth. Many economists had expected a rise in orders.
In addition, the number of first-time jobless claims fell yesterday by a greater-than-expected number for the week, further pointing to a weak economy. As the dollar fell, traders started taking profits.
"As a result, the market is a little nervous about what this means," said Peggy Reed, a vice president at Credit Agricole.

HEADLINE: Ceridian to Acquire Comdata Holdings for $900 Million in Stock

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The Ceridian Corporation said yesterday that it would pay $900 million in stock to acquire the Comdata Holdings Corporation, which provides information services and cash advances to casino gamblers and truck drivers.
The acquisition lets Ceridian, which processes millions of paychecks and employer tax filings, run more transactions through its huge banks of computers. 
 The deal is another example of consolidations in the data-processing industry. Two months ago, another data processor, the First Data Corporation, said it would pay $6.63 billion for the First Financial Management Corporation. Size is crucial to profitability in data processing as more companies farm out their payroll, money-transfer and data operations.
"Size and mass are going to be important in the information services business," said Lawrence Perlman, Ceridian's chairman and chief executive.
Joel Krassner, an analyst with Southcoast Capital, said: "Ceridian has had a strategy of expanding in the information services business. This is part of that move."
Comdata, based in Brentwood, Tenn., provides information services, including money transfers, fuel purchases, cash advances and permits for the trucking industry and casinos. The two companies expect to have combined annual revenue of $1.3 billion.
Under the agreement, each Comdata common share will be exchanged for 0.57 Ceridian common share. Based on Ceridian's closing stock price of $44.125, up $2.25, the deal is valued at $25.15 for each Comdata share. Comdata shares rose $4.3125 yesterday, to $24.1875.
For Ceridian, formerly known as the Control Data Corporation, the acquisition marks a stunning recovery from the 1980's, when it posted hundreds of millions of dollars in losses. The company, based in Minneapolis, shed many of its biggest operations, and under the guidance of Mr. Perlman focused on services like payroll accounting and tax filing, military electronics and radio surveys.
Ceridian said it would take a fourth-quarter charge of $60 million to redeem Comdata's debt.
Comdata's principal stockholders, the venture capital firms of Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe and Charterhouse Equity Partners, said they favored the acquisition. Welsh, Carson, Anderson is credited with bringing the companies together.

HEADLINE: Rabbi Isaac Lewin, 89, Teacher Of Jewish History at Yeshiva U.

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Rabbi Isaac Lewin, a scholar of Jewish history and the history of Jewish law who often spoke for Orthodox Jewry before international bodies, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 89 and lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.
Rabbi Lewin was professor emeritus of Jewish history at the Bernard Revel Graduate School of Yeshiva University. He taught at Yeshiva from 1944 until his retirement 10 years ago. 
 His writings were published in English, Hebrew, Yiddish, Polish and German. He was an architect of the Declaration on the Elimination of All Forms of Intolerance and Discrimination Based on Religion, which was adopted by the United Nations General Assembly in 1981. For this, he was awarded the United Nation's Medal of Peace.
Rabbi Lewin was born in Wieliczka, near Cracow, was ordained as a rabbi in Poland in 1935 and received a law degree two years later. He served two terms on the City Council of Lodz, Poland's second-largest city.
He arrived in the United States in 1941 and worked for the rescue of Jews left behind in Nazi-occupied Europe. After V-E Day he promptly went on a relief mission to help Holocaust survivors and displaced persons.
After the war, he became the spokesman for the Agudas Israel World Organization before the United Nations Social and Economic Council. A collection of his addresses there and in other international forums was published in 1953.
He was the editor of "These I Will Remember," two volumes in Hebrew of biographies of Jewish leaders who perished in World War II. He was among a delegation of Orthodox rabbis who obtained a 1983 agreement from the Polish Government to help restore the Jewish cemeteries that were neglected since the war.
The city of Warsaw presented its Golden Badge of Merit to him in 1988, honoring him for promoting international relations and cooperation among peoples.
At Yeshiva, he also served as principal of Jewish studies at the university's high school for girls.
Rabbi Lewin is survived by two sons, Nathan Lewin of Washington and Rabbi Naftali Lewin of Manhattan, and two granddaughters. His wife of 45 years, Peppy Sternheim Lewin, died in 1980.

HEADLINE: Guilty Plea By Murderer Represents About-Face

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 24

 BODY:
With jury selection about to begin in his second murder trial, Joel Rifkin, the unemployed landscaper who has confessed to killing 17 women, pleaded guilty today to strangling two women in early 1993 and burying their bodies in shallow graves on the East End of Long Island.
The plea was a surprise turnabout by Mr. Rifkin and his lawyers, who for the last year have said they would pursue an insanity defense supported by hypnosis and a theory that he killed because, as an adopted child, he suffered irreparable psychological harm. 
 Mr. Rifkin, 35, ran through a succession of lawyers and at one point indicated that he might defend himself.
"He apparently ran out of options," said Michael Ahearn, the Suffolk County assistant district attorney who prosecuted the case. Mr. Ahearn said that he was surprised by today's "total admission of guilt" by Mr. Rifkin and that he would ask the court for a sentence of 50 years to life in prison. Sentencing is scheduled for Sept. 18.
It was unclear whether Mr. Rifkin's plea today meant that he would not contest the other murder charges he still faces in Brooklyn, Queens and elsewhere. But his lawyer, Kathleen K. Trum, indicated that his legal battles were not over yet.
Her office released a statement saying that her client had no choice but to plead guilty after the judge, John J. Jones Jr. of Suffolk County Court, denied defense motions on Wednesday to have Mr. Rifkin's mental state further evaluated by psychiatrists.
"The denial of this motion rendered it impossible to prepare a thorough defense," Ms. Trum said, adding that Mr. Rifkin would appeal the matter after sentencing. She said the denial deprived Mr. Rifkin of his constitutional rights to a fair trial.
Mr. Ahearn rejected such claims. He said Mr. Rifkin had 15 months to prepare a defense and had been examined by two psychiatrists, a psychologist and a neurosurgeon at a cost to the county of $50,000.
"He's just looking for someone to come up with something he could use as a defense," Mr. Ahearn said.
He said he would ask that the sentence in the Suffolk case run consecutively with the 27-year-to-life sentence Mr. Rifkin received after his first trial in Nassau County in the murder of Tiffany Bresciani, 19, of Manhattan. Ms. Bresciani's body was found in the back of Mr. Rifkin's pickup truck on June 28, 1993, when he was stopped for a traffic violation.
After his arrest, Mr. Rifkin signed a detailed confession in which he admitted to killing not only Ms. Bresciani, but 16 other women and disposing of their bodies in graves and waterways throughout the New York metropolitan area.
He told investigators that his victims were prostitutes whom he picked up in Manhattan and strangled during sex.
The victims in Suffolk were Leah Evens of Brooklyn and Lauren Marquez of Sunnyside, Queens.
Ms. Evens's body was discovered on May 9, 1993, beneath brush near County Road 51 in Northampton, L.I., by a group of hikers looking for edible ferns in the woods. Ms. Marquez's body was found in a shallow grave in Southampton as a result of statements Mr. Rifkin made to the police.
Property belonging to both women was found in Mr. Rifkin's home in East Meadow, which he shared with his mother, Jean Rifkin, who did not appear in court today.
Mr. Rifkin sought to have his confession ruled inadmissible, contending that the police had not properly informed him of his right to remain silent. The defense move was rejected by the courts in Nassau and Suffolk.
During his trial in Nassau, Mr. Rifkin pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity, contending that he was schizophrenic and could not tell the difference between right and wrong. But a jury rejected that contention.
Mr. Rifkin is next expected to face trial in Brooklyn, where a pretrial hearing is scheduled for Sept. 11 in Brooklyn Supreme Court before Justice Francis X. Egitto. Another pretrial hearing is scheduled the following day in Queens, where Mr. Rifkin faces a one-count murder indictment.
He is charged in Brooklyn with the deaths of three women whose dismembered bodies were found in 55-gallon drums that were dumped in Newtown Creek and Coney Island Creek. One victim was given the name Jane Doe. The others were identified as Lorraine Orvieto, 30, of Stony Brook, L.I., and Mary Ann Holloman, 42, of Manhattan.
