HEADLINE: THE REAL CHINESE THREAT

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF; Nicholas D. Kristof is the Tokyo bureau chief for The New York Times and author of "China Wakes: The Struggle for the Soul of a Rising Power."

 BODY:
ALMOST NO ONE NOTICED, BUT THIS summer the Pentagon drew a line in the sand. Washington committed itself to using American military force, if necessary, to keep international shipping lanes open in the South China Sea.
International, at least, in American eyes. But Beijing's maps put the entire area within China's territorial waters. If a stronger China eventually tries to enforce its national law, which governs shipping in the area, then American forces could be called upon to confront a China that has developed enormously since its troops battled ours to a stalemate in Korea. 
 The underlying problem is the oldest one in diplomacy: how the international community can manage the ambitions of a rising power -- and there has never been a rising power quite like China. It has 1.2 billion people; it has a nuclear arsenal; it has an army of 3.2 million, the world's largest; and now it has what may be the world's fastest-growing military budget.
For now, China's conventional forces are no match for America's. One of my Chinese friends, the son of a general, attended a meeting in which a group of senior Chinese military officials reviewed films of the American air war against Iraq. "They sat around the room, moaning about China's lack of preparation, asking what we could possibly do to modernize," he reported. "I felt like piping up and saying there was one thing we could do: go capitalist."
Yet given the rate at which China is pouring money into its armed forces, the situation may eventually be different. The United States Naval War College conducted computer simulations last year and again this year of battles in Asia between China and the United States in the year 2010. To everyone's surprise, China defeated the United States in both. It is said that the Central Intelligence Agency recently conducted its own simulation of such a battle, set in the year 2005, and China won that, too.
Simulations don't prove anything. Still, China and Vietnam have both showed, in Korea and Vietnam, how much damage even a backward army can do, particularly when fighting on its own turf. And unlike Vietnam, China has nuclear warheads aimed at the United States. (The United States has stopped targeting China with nuclear missiles, but China has refused to stop targeting America.) China is also believed to be developing biological warfare agents.
In Asia, there is now a real fear about what the rise of China will mean. "The immense presence of China is itself a threat -- whether the Chinese are conscious of it or not -- that certainly Japan cannot deal with alone," Morihiro Hosokawa, the former Prime Minister, said recently.
In the United States, the expression "containment" is applied increasingly to China. The Administration's position is that it wants to engage China, rather than contain it, but that if necessary in the future it can switch to a containment policy. "We're not naive," Winston Lord, the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, told a congressional committee in June. "We cannot predict what kind of power China will be in the 21st century. God forbid, we may have to turn with others to a policy of containment. I would hope not."
In the meantime, there is growing alarm in Washington and other capitals at China's military spending and policies. While most countries in the world have been cutting back, China has raised its published military budget by 75 percent since 1988, after adjusting for inflation. And the published budget vastly understates reality. It does not even include weapons procurement. The real figure is probably something like $20 billion, which, when adjusted for purchasing power, may buy as much as a $100 billion defense budget in the West.
Most disturbing, China is pouring money into those activities that allow it to project power beyond its traditional borders. In particular, it is building a blue-water navy and developing an air-to-air refueling capability. China is also becoming more aggressive in the South China Sea and even in the Indian Ocean -- far from its traditional sphere of influence.
All of this notwithstanding, it would be a mistake to think that China is somehow a ferocious aggressor. It is not. It shows no interest in seizing areas that it never controlled, like Nepal or Indonesia, and its claims to disputed areas like some islands in the South China Sea do have some merit to them. The risk of conflict arises in part because of stirrings of Chinese nationalism. Nobody believes in Communism anymore, so the Communist Party is trying to use nationalism as the new glue. To some extent, it is working. In five years of living and traveling in China, I met innumerable ordinary people who didn't give two yuan for Communism but who argued passionately that China needed to reclaim its territories.
Just a couple of weeks ago, I was chatting with an elderly woman from Shanghai -- not a Communist by any means -- and I asked her what she thought of Mao. "You know what his biggest mistake was?" she asked, and I thought of the Great Leap Forward, which led to the deaths of 30 million people. "It was giving up Mongolia. That's our land, that's part of China! And he allowed Stalin to take it. What we need to do is get Mongolia back."
I can't say that this woman is representative, although I have occasionally heard other Chinese say they want to recover Mongolia, which is now an independent country. But I have heard many Chinese say that they want their navy to control the entire South China Sea, to seize the Diaoyu Islands from Japan, even to recover Taiwan.
Moreover, the likely successor to the present regime in Beijing is not a democracy but a military government. President Jiang Zemin is terrified of a coup d'etat -- he has appeared before military units behind a bulletproof shield. If the generals take over in the years following Deng Xiaoping's death, they may be more aggressive than any Communists.
The placid waters and palm-lined islets of the South China Sea may be the site of Asia's next war. The Government in China refuses to clarify whether it claims the entire South China Sea or just the islands in the sea. But in any case, some of the islands are also claimed by five other countries.
China erected a permanent fortress on a reef near the Philippines earlier this year, leading to a tense confrontation at sea between naval vessels for the two sides. Now Americans are training Philippine naval commandos. And Vietnam and China are jostling each other over rival oil exploration programs, by American oil companies, in the disputed area.
The worst nightmare in Asia is a Chinese invasion of Taiwan. China regards Taiwan as a renegade province, while many Taiwanese now hope for a country of their own. The authorities in Beijing repeatedly warn that they reserve the right to use force to recover Taiwan. China underlined its threats in July when it conducted missile tests in the open sea 80 miles from Taiwan, forcing the closure of fisheries and the diversion of commercial flights. The Taiwan stock market promptly plunged 6.8 percent amid jitters about a Chinese attack.
In any case, the possibility of clashes in the Taiwan Strait may be increasing rather than decreasing. For now, it is not clear that China would win if it attacked Taiwan, but the odds will change as China upgrades its forces. It is impossible to imagine that an island of 20 million could indefinitely defend itself against a country of 1.2 billion.
There is, in short, a potential Chinese threat and that drives the question: How should America deal with it?
The first step is simply to acknowledge that threat and to pay far more attention to China. America also needs to expand conversations with Chinese leaders, even if that means boosting their legitimacy at times. President Clinton has been reluctant to meet with President Jiang because of Chinese human rights abuses and other problems. But it would be more effective to invite Jiang to Washington and have him listen to hundreds of demonstrators screaming outside his hotel all night. This would convey not only America's willingness to discuss problems but also the seriousness with which Americans take China's misconduct.
Washington's aim in such talks should be to promote American interests, and that is not necessarily the same as creating a good relationship with China. There is no reason to provoke a dispute just for the sake of being surly. But the White House has to be willing to risk a dispute when China tests its resolve. For example, China has repeatedly promised not to sell M-11 missiles, which are capable of carrying nuclear warheads, to Pakistan. Each time China makes such a formal pledge, Washington claims credit for a major breakthrough. And each time, China has apparently gone ahead and sold M-11's to Pakistan anyway.
These days, the Administration is reluctant to acknowledge what appears to be the latest sale -- despite satellite evidence and the best judgment of intelligence analysts -- because it is reluctant to worsen relations. The lesson Beijing draws from this is that it can continue violating its pledges as long as it acts greatly offended when someone complains. It would be is better to risk a deeper chill in relations than to keep on backing down.
America also needs to work with Asian countries to apply joint restraints on China. The Asean group of Southeast Asian countries, for example, has become increasingly effective in pressuring China to go slow in the South China Sea. And whatever the risks of confrontation, I think the United States was right to declare its willingness to use military force to escort shipping in the South China Sea. If China were to interfere with those shipping lanes -- blocking the flow of oil to Japan, for example -- the global economy would be thrown into crisis.
Americans also need to use the right historical model. China is not bent on international conquest. Beijing may wish to dominate the region, but it does not wish to raise the Chinese flag over Jakarta or Tokyo. Rather, it is like Germany in the run-up to World War I, yearning for greater importance and testing to see what it can get away with. There could be a major war with China, but if so, it will be because of ignorance and miscalculation -- in substantial part on the western rim of the Pacific.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 27, 1995, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A note identifying the author of an article on page 50 of the Magazine today, about military expansion in China, omits the name of a co-author of the book "China Wakes: The Struggle for the Soul of a Rising Power." The book was written by Nicholas D. Kristof and Sheryl Wu Dunn, not by Mr. Kristof alone.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Travelers Enjoying The Dollar's Comeback

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
It has been an expensive year-and-a-half for Americans traveling abroad. The dollar dropped precipitously in value starting early in 1994, effectively making hotel rooms, restaurants, souvenirs and anything else purchased in a foreign currency costlier. It was not a matter of nickels and dimes, either. In many European nations, for example, the dollar lost more than 20 percent of its value.
But now the dollar is bouncing back, giving American travelers a bit of relief. The dollar has by no means recovered all the ground it lost. By mid-August, though, it was enjoying its strongest gains in years against the other two benchmark international currencies, the Japanese yen and the German mark, and had risen correspondingly against other major currencies as well. 
 On Aug. 18, the dollar was worth around 97 yen, up from just over 80 yen this spring, a gain of more than 20 percent. At the same time, the dollar was worth 1.48 German marks, compared with about 1.38 marks in April, a gain of 7.2 percent.
Because most of the other major European currencies are formally or informally linked in value to the German mark, the dollar also posted gains against them. Against the French franc, for example, the dollar stood at 5.09 French francs, up from 4.79 francs in early April. It cost just over $1.53 to buy a a British pound on August 18, compared with $1.60 in April. (All the rates cited are from trading among banks and investment houses. The actual rates charged to individuals by currency exchanges, hotels, banks and credit card companies are invariably less advantageous.)
Whether the dollar can continue to claw its way back up is hard to tell. In a world in which international finance has become bewilderingly complex and fast-paced, currency movements are among the most difficult trends to predict. The dollar's resurgence could easily accelerate, stall or reverse -- making it difficult for tourists to count on any particular exchange rate when budgeting for a trip.
Still, most signs are that Americans will get more bang for their buck for the rest of the year. One reason is that the world's most economically powerful nations -- the United States, Japan and Germany -- all want it that way. Believing that the dollar had become so weak that it was destabilizing the international economy, they have been instructing their central banks to buy dollars in the currency markets to push its level up toward what they consider a more realistic value. (The central banks never give away their hand to the markets by saying what they think a realistic value should be.)
The economic factors behind the dollar's gyrations of late can be dense and sometimes contradictory. But the effects of a stronger dollar for travelers are clear and simple.
A double room at the Westin Hotel in Tokyo starts at 30,000 yen a night, or 150,000 yen for five nights. At 80 yen to the dollar, the five-night tab would come to $1,875. At 97 yen to the dollar, the bill would be $1,546.39 -- a savings of $328.61.
An unrestricted round-trip coach ticket on the Eurostar train through the Channel Tunnel from Paris to London and back costs 1,290 French francs. At an exchange rate of 4.8 francs to the dollar, that is $268.75. At 5.09 francs, it is $253.44 -- a reduction of $15.31.
Renting a Volkswagen Golf from Avis in Bonn for a week runs about 1,050 marks. At 1.38 marks to the dollar, that equals $760.87. At 1.48 marks to the dollar, the total is $709.46, a savings of $51.41.
The dollar is not universally stronger. In April, a dollar would buy 1,709 Italian lira. On August 18, the dollar was worth 1.631 lira. In Mexico, the dollar was worth 6.33 pesos in April. In mid-August, it was worth 6.17 pesos.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Insurance Rules On Illness Eased

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
THE "pre-existing conditions" clause, a bane to consumers who buy trip-cancellation insurance only to find that they cannot collect benefits when they are unable to travel because of illness, appears to be on the way out. Most insurance companies are following the example of Mutual of Omaha, which announced in May that it would waive this restriction for clients who buy their policies immediately on making deposits for tours or cruises.
Trip-cancellation and trip-interruption insurance is important to people who buy expensive cruises or tours, because emergencies, particularly health emergencies, may make it impossible to take a trip that has already been paid for. The old pre-existing conditions clauses generally held that claims to recover payments on the basis of illness of a traveler, a family member or a traveling companion were invalid if the illness "manifested itself" -- or some similar phrase -- in the 60 days before the insurance was bought. Often enough, this meant denial of a claim made, for example, because someone's heart condition flared up. One big company estimated that 6 percent of claims were denied on the ground that the conditions were pre-existing. 
 The Commercial Union Insurance Company in Boston is among those that have dropped the pre-existing conditions clause. It acted last month. Carroll B. Smith, vice president for custom products, said the exclusion of people with pre-existing conditions was a source of misunderstanding and of complaints to state insurance departments. "It is something we have been thinking about for some time," he said, "and when Mutual of Omaha dropped it, it pushed us off the dime."
The companies dropping the pre-existing conditions clause have not raised their prices, but all have set one condition and sometimes more. These are manageable, and the possibility of buying trip-cancellation and trip-interruption insurance will be welcome in families where such chronic illnesses as diabetes, heart trouble and arthritis add difficulties to scheduling travel. Estimates of how many travelers buy such insurance range from 15 to 70 percent, depending on the cost of a trip, the penalties for cancellation and the age of the travelers.
The major requirement for waiving the pre-existing conditions clause is that the insurance be bought within one day of the first deposit for a trip. If it is bought after that, it retains the exclusion.
 
 
Chance of Forfeit
 As an example of a problem the 24-hour purchase requirement creates, assume that a couple is buying a 15-day cruise at $3,550 a person, for a total of $7,100. In this price bracket, one insurance company charges a per-person premium of $199. The cruise line requires a deposit of $500 a person; full payment is due eight weeks, or 56 days, before departure. This couple puts down the deposit and buys an insurance package immediately. If they cancel after that but more than 60 days before departure, the cruise line's rules say they forfeit $200 a person. This loss would be covered by the insurance, but the benefit is almost exactly equal to the premium. It is this aspect of the new provision that makes an officer of one insurance company characterize it as "not ideal."
The value of the change, however, appears in the period after the full payment is made -- in this case, 60 days before departure. If illness should force a cancellation, the $199 premium would bring a refund of the $3,550. The "loss" would then be only the premium.
The companies have not all printed new application forms, and some are using stickers or inserts to call attention to the change.
Because of the one-day purchase requirement, the easiest thing to do is buy the insurance from the travel agent who sells the cruise or tour. But the protection provisions on default of agents or tour operators do not cover the default of the organization selling the policy. So if a traveler has anxieties about the financial stability of the travel agent and the coverage cannot be bought elsewhere, a credit card should be used for the trip deposit, which will provide some protection if the travel agent defaults.
Since not all travel agents are authorized to sell all brands of travel insurance, a client seeking a particular policy should ask the travel agent to get in touch with the company ahead of time. Sandy Bolz, a marketing official for the Noel Companies' Travel Guard, said that despite agents' sales efforts, customers who in the past have bought coverage by telephone direct from her company have usually done it at the last minute. If they do this now, they will still be subject to the pre-existing conditions clause.
Mutual of Omaha Companies' Cruise and Tour Insurance is underwritten by Omaha Property and Casualty Insurance. The insurance must be bought within 24 hours of the initial deposit and must cover the full cost of the trip, with a limit of $20,000. A policy with several types of coverage for a cruise priced from $1,501 to $2,000 costs $99 a person; for a tour of the same price, $107. A mail-in form is on the flier, or calls can be made to (800) 228-9792.
 
 
Domino Effect
 The C.S.A. Company in San Diego dropped the exclusion clause for three of its policies last month. The underwriter is the Commercial Union Insurance Company. Coverage, for the full amount of the cost of the trip to a maximum of $20,000, must be bought by the end of the next business day after the initial deposit. A policy for a cruise costing $1,501 to $2,000 would be $97 for a family or those sharing a cabin; for a tour, the premium is 5 percent of the cost. Applications may be phoned to (800) 348-9505 or faxed to (800) 336-6409.
Globalcare Insurance Services in Lynnfield, Mass., also sells a Commercial Union policy, Economy Plan for Cruise and Travel. It also requires purchase the next day, for the full amount of the trip, up to $20,000. Coverage for a family or people sharing a cabin on a cruise for a trip costing $1,501 to $2,000 is $110. Applications may be telephoned to (800) 779-1017 or faxed to (800) 336-6409. The Commercial Union policies are not available in Texas, South Carolina, Kansas and Connecticut.
Travel Guard's Cruise and Protection Plan dropped its exclusion June 1, but at the moment only travel agents can sell such policies, according to Ms. Bolz. Its underwriter is the Continental Casualty Company of Chicago. The premium for a policy with varied coverage for a trip costing $1,501 to $2,000 is $109. Information: (800) 826-1300.
Travel Insured's Travel Insurance Pak dropped its exclusion Aug. 16. The underwriter is Travelers Indemnity of Hartford. The premium for a policy on a trip costing $2,000 is $110 a person. Information: (800) 243-3174.
World Access will drop the exclusion from its Access America policy on Friday, according to Beth Godlin, senior vice president. The underwriter is B.C.S. Insurance Company. Information: (800) 284-8300.
Robin Levine, executive vice president of the Berkely Group on Long Island, which designs insurance for cruise and tour companies to sell under their own names, as well as freestanding policies, said her company was looking at the issue.

LENGTH: 1494 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: The Decline of the Prestigious Address;
'Location, Location, Location'? It's 'Cost, Cost, Cost'

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
ITEM: FCB/Leber Katz, the advertising agency, moves from 767 Fifth Avenue, the ever-so-fancy General Motors building at 59th Street, to the 40-year-old, plain vanilla Mobil Building, at 150 East 42d Street.
"Our marching orders were to reduce their occupancy costs, because they realized that image for image's sake is simply passe," said I. Keith Ellis, a managing director at the Edward S. Gordon real estate firm who found FCB the space. 
 Item: Avon Products abandons 9 West 57th Street, a true trophy building, for 1251 Avenue of the Americas, one of numerous glass-and-steel skyscrapers along what was once Corporate Corridor. And, it takes floors three through six, base floors that used to appeal only to back-office operations.
"Large floorplates, reasonable prices, the ability to link floors with internal staircases, all were a lot more important than great views or being in a trophy building," said Brian Martin, an Avon vice president.
Item: Orrick Herrington & Sutcliffe, the big San Francisco law firm, comes "within a hair's breadth" of signing for space at the G.M. building, recalls Richard Weidman, a senior partner. It also comes pretty close to signing at 375 Park Avenue, the elegant Seagram Building at 52d Street.
But it lands instead at 666 Fifth Avenue, the 52d Street building that Mr. Weidman concedes will need a lot of spiffing up before it can be considered true A-quality space.
"The dollar difference wasn't that significant," Mr. Weidman said. "What mattered was that 666 Fifth was the only place that could give us four contiguous floors with options to expand."
It seems that the days when a fancy address was paramount really did go out with the free-spending 1980's. Today, many companies are spurning ultra-expensive, high-status buildings for more serviceable and affordable space. In doing so, they are signaling an end of the flight to quality, that flow of tenants from lower-quality buildings to higher ones that happens when a recession pulls rents in fancy buildings down.
Apparently, the cost differential between the ultra-new and the still-serviceable old remains wide enough to turn off the cost-conscious, 1990's tenant.
"The determining factor is cost," said Jack D. Rehm, chairman of the Meredith Corporation, the publishing company that just took 105,000 square feet at 125 Park Avenue, a 73-year-old building at 42d Street. "If the elevators run, the lobby is O.K., the space you occupy is right, it just doesn't matter if the address is prestigious."
The list of corporate tenants that seem to agree is getting longer. First Boston is leaving Park Avenue Plaza, a highly regarded modern building at 55 East 52d Street, for 11 Madison Avenue, an old building at 24th Street, well south of high-prestige territory. Equitable Life is moving from Equitable Tower, its 10-year-old headquarters monument at Seventh Avenue and 51st Street, to 1290 Avenue of the Americas, a 34-year-old building at 51st Street.
And converts to the new austerity keep cropping up. Michael T. Cohen, president of Williams Real Estate, tells of one client who asked him to find fancy Park Avenue space. He found it, at an annual rent in the low $30's a square foot, $10 less than they were paying in the prewar, Grand Central Terminal-area building they currently occupy. At the last minute they renewed in their current building, for less than $25 a foot.
"The opportunity to fly to quality was there, but they chose economic conservatism over that intangible you get for being in a snazzy building," Mr. Cohen said.
Most of these companies still care about the image they project. But, in an era of cost-cutting and downsizing, an image of reckless spending is not what they want. Rather, they want to seem concerned about their own bottom lines -- and, by association, those of their customers and shareholders. Thus, they are trading down space, with the confidence that clients and Wall Street will smile on their new Spartan outlook.
"Everyone's corporate objective is to reduce operating costs and increase productivity and efficiency," said Barry Gosin, chief executive of Newmark Real Estate.
"TRADING down has become a sign of financial discipline, not financial weakness," said Mary Ann Tighe, executive managing director of Edward S. Gordon, who says that when she financially analyzes a deal for a tenant now, she routinely includes the impact of that deal on earnings per share.
Of course, tenants do still care about how their space looks. But, just as some homeowners get great satisfaction out of creating splendid interiors in rundown old houses, many of these corporate tenants get the same satisfaction out of spending their occupancy dollars on their furnishings and equipment, not on a fancy address.
"Great images are just no longer determined by being in A-plus buildings on the East Side," said Carol Nelson, an executive vice president at the Gordon firm. "You can get the same incredible image from being in wonderfully designed space in a loft building in midtown south."
Of course, for big space users, few loft buildings are practical. FCB, for one, would have loved space in what Mr. Ellis calls the "creative districts," but few buildings in Midtown South or SoHo can accommodate a 175,000-square-foot user with lots of computers. "From a logistical point of view, the search became nightmarish when we tried to leave midtown," Mr. Ellis recalled.
In fact, the new emphasis on practicality has not done much good for owners of outmoded buildings in inaccessible locations. But it has given new hope to owners of buildings that, during the flight to quality, were spurned by tenants hankering for glitz. Many of these owners are pouring money into their buildings to raise them from marginal status to the A -- or at least, A-minus -- ranks to woo those tenants back.
Last year, when Leucadia National bought 685 Third Avenue, the 615,000-square-foot former American Home Products headquarters building filling the block from 43d to 44th Street, it was two-thirds vacant. It was also weird-looking: Built in two stages, it was half traditional wedding-cake architecture with glazed white and pink brick, and half modernistic dark gray skyscraper with tinted windows.
Leucadia is pumping between $8 and $10 million into re-skinning and modernizing the building, and stands ready to offer a large-space user its own elevator bank, its name on the door, and a good contribution to customizing space. It expects to start marketing the building in early 1996.
"We're not the G.M. building or the I.B.M. building, we don't have newness or a fancy address," said Mark Hornstein, a Leucadia vice president. "But we're a good building right near Grand Central, and we're already getting active interest from publishing houses, law firms, accounting firms, all kinds of companies that were a lot more image-conscious in the 1980's."
Similarly, Sumitomo Realty is refurbishing the lobby and otherwise fixing up 666 Fifth to make firms like Orrick Herrington feel that they are not trading down too far. Arthur L. Bocchi, a Sumitomo vice president in charge of leasing the building, says that, with word of the refurbishing out, several tenants who, a year ago, turned down space he had available are now back at his negotiating table.
"Until fairly recently we still lost deals when potential tenants opted to pay extra for a newer building," Mr. Bocchi said. "But we've noticed that things like views and newness don't drive deals anymore."
This new practicality may even offer a ray of hope to landlords in the vacancy- plagued financial district -- to the disgruntlement of their midtown counterparts.
"The large blocks of space and unfair tax incentives available downtown are starting to induce large tenants to move there," complained Anthony E. Malkin, president of W&M Properties, which manages several buildings. He reports that a large tenant at 1185 Avenue of the Americas, the building at 46th Street that W&M manages, is leaving for older, but cheaper, space downtown.
Of course, there are still corporate tenants that want fancy space and fancy addresses, and will pay heavily for it. But even they are starting to distinguish between space that identifies them to the outside world, and space that only they see.
Sony, for one, has spent millions turning 550 Madison, the former AT&T headquarters building at 55th Street, into a signature place that its Japanese owners, its entertainment industry clients, and others will be delighted to see. But when it needed expansion space recently for some less visible functions, it took it across the street, at 555 Madison, a perfectly nice but no-frills, utilitarian building.
"Companies like Sony are keeping the dealmakers in the fancy house," said George H. Keller, a senior managing director at Cushman & Wakefield. "But they have no problem with moving support functions to lesser quarters."

HEADLINE: Unmarried Pairs: Let the Buyers Beware

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
THE minute Howard Mimnaugh saw the run-down, century-old, two-family victorian in Hightstown, N.J., he realized it was just the house he was looking for. The building needed work, Mr. Mimnaugh said, but he figured that he and his female friend of many years could buy the property as a tax shelter and work as a team to restore it to its former glory.
With each contributing equally to the purchase and renovation, Mr. Mimnaugh estimated it would take three years of nights and weekends for the couple to complete the project. About seven months after they bought the house, however, Mr. Mimnaugh's partner decided to divest herself of both the house and Mr. Mimnaugh. 
 "She basically said, 'I'm out of here,' and then she picked up and left," Mr. Mimnaugh said. He was able to salvage his investment -- and keep the house -- only after delicate negotiations with his former girlfriend's father, who had provided some of the money, he said.
"It's hard enough to have a business deal go bad," said Mr. Mimnaugh, a Princeton, N.J., tax accountant. "But when there's an emotional side too, it becomes really terrible."
Real estate experts say that the arrangement that gave rise to Mr. Mimnaugh's situation -- joint ownership of residential real estate by unmarried individuals -- is becoming increasingly common. And they say that gay couples, elderly couples, and heterosexual couples deferring marriage all contribute to the trend.
The implications of such arrangements, however, are daunting. In addition to the obvious question of what to do with a house if a partnership -- or a couple -- breaks up, there are other vexing issues that often arise. Among them are questions regarding the manner in which title should be held, which will have significant consequences if the house is sold or one party moves out or dies; the use and occupancy of the property; the potential for liability for a partner's debts; the difficulty of removing a former partner's name from a mortgage and deed, and the arcane and sometimes costly tax problems that haunt even the most well-planned investment endeavor.
Lawyers say that most potential problems can be avoided by the use of a carefully drafted written agreement that clearly defines the rights and obligations of the parties. But getting to such an agreement isn't necessarily simple. To avoid a problem one has not only to anticipate it but also to confront it. "Very often, a couple is overwhelmed by their relationship and they don't think through about everything that could happen," said David Clurman, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, referring to unmarried partners planning to purchase a home. Even when the parties remain clear-headed enough to anticipate potential pitfalls, there is a natural tendency to avoid talking about them.
Bonnie Orenstein, a Manhattan advertising executive, said that she was somewhat timid about raising the issue of an agreement when she was about to purchase a Manhattan co-op with her boyfriend.
"Was it hard? I'd have to say yes," Ms. Orenstein said. "But it was also one of those necessary evils."
The agreement Ms. Orenstein and her boyfriend ultimately signed, she said, focuses on what happens if they split up or one of them dies. But the agreement was drafted for the unmarried couple by the attorney who handled the closing, a relatively common occurrence that makes some lawyers uncomfortable.
"This is a delicate issue," said William Selsberg, a Stamford, Conn., real estate lawyer. "Both parties should be represented by separate counsel. But the hardest thing in the world to do is to tell two people you know very well that they each have to have their own lawyer." Nevertheless, Mr. Selsberg said, if the parties don't raise the issue of independent representation, the lawyer should.
Ted Bohn, a New York and New Jersey lawyer who is also president of the New Jersey Lesbian and Gay Law Association, agreed, and said that written agreements negotiated by independently represented parties are critical because of the difference in the way the laws deal with married and unmarried couples who own real estate.
"When people are married and then get divorced, the courts decide equitably who should get what," Mr. Bohn said. "Usually, they say, 'He gets half, she gets half, good luck and goodbye.' "
But increasing numbers of unmarried couples -- particularly gay couples -- are now buying property in both partners' names. If the couple subsequently breaks up, the distribution of the assets of such a relationship can be a complicated and costly affair.
"Since you cannot use a divorce procedure to allocate or distribute the property, you must use a generic civil lawsuit called a partition action to allocate the property rights," Mr. Bohn said.
In such litigation, Mr. Bohn said, the parties are often called upon to prove their respective contributions to the partnership property over the years.
"That means pulling out checkbooks and showing what each party has contributed," he said. "And you've got even bigger problems if the checks were paid out of a joint account because then you have to prove how much each of you contributed to the joint account."
Another issue that inevitably arises when two people buy property together is what happens to the property if one of the parties dies. And closely associated with that concern is the issue of how to minimize the taxes on the estate of the deceased partner.
Typically, a married couple takes title to real estate as "tenants by the entirety," said Eric Davis, a real estate lawyer who has offices in New York and New Jersey. This means that each has an equal interest in the property and if one spouse dies the property passes automatically to the surviving spouse -- tax free.
In the case of an unmarried couple, however, to obtain a similar form of ownership -- known as a joint tenancy with right of survivorship -- specific words to that effect must be included in the deed. Otherwise, in most states, the parties will be considered "tenants in common." Under that form of ownership, each party owns an independent interest in the property that passes to his or her heirs at death -- usually subject to estate taxes.
Accordingly, the most significant question an unmarried couple confronts when buying property is how they will hold title to the property -- as joint tenants or as tenants in common. And since the question inevitably raises tax and estate-planning issues, its answer often necessitates yet another level of legal expertise.
"There's no question that the law does not treat live-ins the same as married couples for estate planning purposes," said John Spitzmiller, chairman of the trusts and estates law section of the New York State Bar Association.
Accordingly, Mr. Spitzmiller said, when an unmarried couple buys property -- particularly as tenants in common -- careful estate planning is necessary to minimize taxes and avoid the potential for emotion-laden confrontations between a surviving partner and the heirs of the deceased partner.
Generally, he said, even a last will and testament -- by itself -- does not adequately protect each of the parties because a will can be destroyed or changed at any time by the person who made it. As a result, Mr. Spitzmiller said, if wills are used they should be supplemented by written agreements that contain the entire understanding of the parties.
As a practical matter, however, hiring batteries of individual lawyers with expertise in real estate, partnerships, taxation, estates, trusts and at least passing familiarity with the psychology of romance is a luxury most people can ill afford.
That being the case, however, real estate experts say that many unmarried couples who own property together probably do not know how they hold title -- a potential nightmare in the making if one partner dies.
One New Jersey homeowner interviewed for this article, for example, is a licensed real estate agent who has owned a house with a companion for more than a decade. When asked how he and his partner held title, he replied: "As tenants in common with the right of survivorship," a form of ownership that does not exist in New Jersey.
AN unmarried couple who bought a house together in Connecticut a little over a month ago disagreed when each was asked how they held title.
"As tenants in common, I think," the man said.
"As joint tenants, I hope," said the woman.
Moreover, the couple -- both small-business owners -- were advised by their lawyer that it would not be necessary for them to have a written agreement as long as they both had wills. At the time of the interview, the wills had not yet been drafted.
With a co-op, the need to have a documented understanding between unmarried partners is even more critical.
"You must treat a co-op as a unity," said Arthur Weinstein, a Manhattan lawyer and vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives, explaining that while two or more people can jointly own shares to a co-op, the co-op considers the owner a single entity. As a result, Mr. Weinstein said, unmarried cooperators must be particularly careful to plan for what will happen if the relationship breaks up or if one of the parties dies.
"You cannot subdivide a co-op," Mr. Weinstein said. "And you can't leave occupancy of a co-op to a third party when you die." Some proprietary leases, he said, make exceptions for immediate family members.
Moreover, he said, the co-op is under no obligation to allow one partner to remain in the apartment if the partnership breaks up -- even if the two partners have reached an agreement that satisfies them.
"The co-op is entitled to review the financial resources of the remaining owner to assure that maintenance and other obligations can be met," Mr. Weinstein said.
He added that some proprietary leases grant "special considerations" to marital partners remaining in an apartment after a divorce or the death of the other partner. "And the courts have held that any such special considerations must also be accorded to a life partner in a gay relationship," he said.
"Still," Mr. Weinstein said, "when unmarried partners make any economic deal between themselves, they must be sure that it is enforceable under terms of their proprietary lease."
In fact, even partners who have written agreements find that there are subtle but compelling differences between being mere business partners and partners in an enterprise as personal and infused with emotion as a home.
"It would sure be nice not to worry about what is going to happen if I decide to leave this house," said Dr. Joelna Marcus, a college professor who bought a Jersey City, N.J., brownstone with a male colleague about 20 years ago.
Though the partnership has worked admirably so far, she said, she is a bit apprehensive about what will happen if it dissolves. In addition to the inevitable question of "who put how much where" in the house, she said, there is also the potential for confusion if one partner wants to sell and the other doesn't.
"We could really mess each other up with that one," Dr. Marcus said. The agreement she and her partner signed 20 years ago provides that either partner can block the sale of the other's share to someone else. "That's probably one of the reasons we're both vested in making this work," Dr. Marcus said.
Kevingerarrd Cannon, a New Jersey resident, is now at the point that Dr. Marcus anticipates with trepidation.
About 12 years ago, Mr. Cannon and a male companion bought a house together in Hoboken. The relationship ended a few years ago, but Mr. Cannon and his partner have both continued to live in the house, which has two separate apartments. Mr. Cannon is now in a new relationship and is planning to sell his share of the first house to his first partner and then buy the house next door with his new partner.
MR. CANNON has two potential problems: If he were to die unexpectedly, his share of the first house would automatically go to his former partner because they hold title as joint tenants.
Moreover, in order for Mr. Cannon to buy the house next door, he needs the money he has invested in his current home. And while his first partner has agreed to buy out Mr. Cannon's interest, that may be more complicated and costly than it appears because it is unlikely that the bank will release Mr. Cannon from his obligations under the note and mortgage unless the first partner takes out a new mortgage in his name alone.
"Mortgage companies are happy to add names to a mortgage but they rarely take names off," said Mr. Selsberg, the Connecticut real estate lawyer.
As a result, Mr. Selsberg said, without the consent of the mortgage holder, it is difficult for one partner to "buy out" another partner without creating considerable risk for both. The reason is that signing away ownership rights does not necessarily relieve a party of obligations under the original note and mortgage, he said.
Conversely, Mr. Selsberg said, the partner who is buying is also at risk because nearly every mortgage instrument prohibits the "sale or transfer" of any ownership interest -- even from one co-owner to another -- without the consent of the mortgage holder. That even holds true for parents who agree to "co-sign" for a property with a child and then later seek to transfer their interest in the property to the child.
"It's in paragraph 17 of all standard mortgages," Mr. Selsberg said. The clause provides that if the bank learns of an unauthorized sale or transfer it can "accelerate the loan" and demand immediate full payment of the mortgage. "People ignore paragraph 17 all the time," Mr. Selsberg said. "And when they do, they're playing with fire."
Even the most carefully drafted agreement means little if one of the parties ignores it. If that happens, the parties may find that they're "married" to each other whether they intended it or not.
"In most cases, each party to a mortgage is jointly and severally liable," said Eliot Zuckerman, a Manhattan real estate lawyer. "That means that each party is personally obligated for the entire debt. So, if one party just walks away, that means that the remaining partner can be stuck with the entire obligation."
Moreover, Mr. Zuckerman said, any lien or judgment against an owner of real estate usually ends up as a lien against the property -- even if a co-owner has nothing to do with the debt.
AT the same time, an unmarried couple buying property together should be aware that one partner's credit history can affect the couple's ability to qualify for a mortgage.
"If one of the two parties has strong credit and the other party has bad credit, then the property should probably be put in the name of the person with the strong credit," said Stanley Greenstein, president of the Seldin Organization, a mortgage broker in New Hyde Park, N.Y. Mr. Greenstein added that as a practical matter, however, an unmarried couple is treated no differently than a married couple for purposes of obtaining a mortgage.
Even couples planning marriage, it seems, must exercise caution if they buy property together before they are married.
Kenneth B. Goldstein, a Manhattan lawyer who specializes in matrimonial law, said that such a couple might have an expensive legal problem if the marriage ends in divorce.
"When you have a piece of property that was not acquired during the marriage, the court in a divorce case can't decide what happens to that property," Mr. Goldstein said. As a result, he said, if the parties can't settle the matter of the prenuptial property themselves, they would have to file a separate civil action to resolve the issue.
Moreover, he said, all people who jointly own real estate should be exceedingly careful about taking out "equity lines of credit" on the property.
"I've seen matrimonial cases where a spouse will write a check for the total amount available on a home equity loan, spend the money, and leave nothing for the other spouse," Mr. Goldstein said.
Ralph Warner, a Berkeley, Calif., lawyer who is also co-author of "The Living Together Kit," a do-it-yourself manual for drafting agreements between unmarried individuals, said that even elderly couples are now more frequently buying property together without bothering to marry.
"With people in their 60's and 70's it's an accelerating trend," Mr. Warner said. "They don't want to confuse their relationships with their kids. And though the kids may be supportive of mom or dad having a new partner, they don't want to lose their inheritance, either."
 
 
Advice for Husbands and Wives
 In most cases, a husband and wife own real estate as "tenants by the entirety," a form of co-ownership available only to married couples that results in property passing automatically to the surviving spouse when one spouse dies.
At times, however, it might be preferable for a married couple to hold title individually or as tenants in common, even if the property is now owned as a tenancy by the entirety. "It's usually done for estate planning purposes," said Joel E. Miller, a New York City tax lawyer.
In general, he said, the determining factor is the value of the couple's assets. If total assets exceed $600,000 -- the amount an individual can pass "tax free" to another person -- then it might be worth holding property individually or as tenants in common. Accordingly, Mr. Miller said, couples with total assets of more than $600,000 should consult a tax expert to determine what is best for them. "You might want to divide up your assets, do away with rights of survivorship, and have each spouse direct the first $600,000 to a trust for the kids," he said.
Another reason to hold property individually rather than in both names is to protect the property from potential creditors, said Harold Lubell, a Manhattan real estate lawyer. "If one spouse is in an occupation that has a high risk of personal liability, it might be wise for a couple to keep as many assets as possible in the name of the other spouse," he said.

HEADLINE: Habitats: 135 Lafayette Avenue;
Architect Renovates a Home for Himself in Brooklyn

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
YVES FRANCOIS, all 6 feet, 4 inches of him, hoisted himself up on the foot-high brownstone base of the iron railing, and, clinging to the railing's wicked-looking spikes, edged himself across the precipice: a wet cement walkway.
Mr. Francois is not an easy person to keep up with. At 30, he has already spent four years working as an architectural consultant to the Pepsi Cola Company in Somers, N.Y., working his way up to project manager. And he has just bought his first house: a massive three-window-wide Second Empire brick rowhouse in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn. 
 More than three years ago, he moved from Clinton Hill in Brooklyn out to Katonah, five minutes from Somers, where he stayed for two years. "But I always had an idea to do this scale of renovation," he said, walking around surveying the bare wood framing of his town house. "First, of course, it's a great place to live. Second, I want to use the renovation as a marketing tool to show prospective clients. Isn't it much better than just saying: 'Oh, yeah, I did an addition for so-and-so; let's see if they're around this weekend."
Last November, Mr. Francois' parents moved back to Haiti, their native country, from the Canarsie section of Brooklyn, where they had lived for 30 years. Mr. Francois moved into their house and started saving money. "Instead of paying the $1,200 in rent a month," he said, "I started putting it away for a house. Yes, it's great -- except for the one and a half hour commute."
During the last year and a half, Mr. Francois saw about 100 buildings "from Brooklyn to Harlem."
"The thing about Harlem, the interiors had a lot of details, but they wanted a lot of money for those details: $200,000 to $300,000," he said. "But I felt that certain areas in Harlem were not as stable as here in Fort Greene -- they weren't bad, but they weren't as stable." Mr. Francois recalled looking at several houses in the Mount Morris Park neighborhood.
"Lots of times, the owners try to make a quick dollar," he said. "They'll say: 'This house is great -- you don't have to do a thing to it,' and I'd say to myself: 'You must be kidding.' Or they'd say: 'There's great schools here' -- but since I don't have kids, it's not a concern."
Mr. Francois, who is divorced, was simply looking for a great deal.
"This house was probably one of the first of the hundred I looked at," he said. "But at the time, the owner was looking for $250,000, which was completely out of my ballpark."
Besides the 5,000-square-foot four-story house, the property included an 800-square-foot two-story brick rear house, which Mr. Francois immediately thought of for his office/design studio.
But it was still too much money.
"The house had been empty for eight years and was all boarded up," he said. "I remember when I came to see it -- oh, maybe for the third time -- there was a homeless guy who lived downstairs. He got in from going upstairs next door and somehow climbing down through the hatch. The guy was really all set up here. The water had never been turned off and neither had the electricity; either that, or he was able to tap the electricity because he had a toaster; he even kept a couple of cats."
After Mr. Francois bought the house at 135 Lafayette Avenue, between Cumberland and Carlton Avenues, and started reconstruction, the new owner told the homeless man he would let him stay as long as he kept his living space clean.
"I even gave him a couple of dollars to clean the steps," he said. "I haven't seen him lately; a neighbor told me he actually has a renovated apartment somewhere around here, but that he hates it."
ANYWAY, even though Mr. Francois had looked at all these other houses, he kept thinking about the one on Lafayette Avenue.
The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission report, issued when it designated the Fort Greene historic district, says that the house was probably built around 1865, and that besides its mansard roof with two dormers, it has "a lovely round-arched stone doorway . . . and is further enhanced by bracketed table sills and flush stone lintels; an unusual bracketed cornice supports the slate mansard."
"About a year after I first saw it, I called the agent and asked whether it was still for sale," Mr. Francois recalled. "You see," he said, grinning, "I drove by it every chance I got." The agent told him it was still for sale.
Just before he called the agent, he learned that another house he had looked at -- and just missed buying because someone signed the contract first -- had just sold for $150,000, so he submitted his first offer on the Lafayette Avenue house: $160,000.
That was summarily turned down, but the seller did accept $180,000, and the deal was set -- except for the cold feet Mr. Francois suddenly experienced.
"Gosh, why am I paying $30,000 more than that other guy," he said. "I didn't want to be a fool. But then I figured I'm paying $30,000 for the extra two-story building in the back -- I sold myself on it all over again."
In the meantime, Mr. Francois was making friends in the neighborhood. Even before he bought the house, he had called Errol Hines, the man who bought the other house for $150,000. He said he called just to chat -- the man had beaten him to two houses he had looked at -- and came away with the design commission for Mr. Hines's house, which is around the corner on Clinton Avenue.
Now that he has bought the house, his new neighbors keep watch for him.
"They know that I work and that my brother, who is handling the construction, is away from the site a lot," he said. "So they call me to tell me the workers are just standing around in front talking, not working. Or there was one guy who didn't work out, who was back hanging around -- they called me."
At the corner, the grocery store lets Mr. Francois leave stuff -- like checks or packages -- for his workers to pick up. The store opens early -- 6:30 in the morning -- so it's a convenient dropoff spot as Mr. Francois speeds through just after dawn on his long drive to Somers.
To make the project work economically, Mr. Francois took out a special Federal Housing Administration 203K loan that covered both the cost of purchase and construction. Although he pays two percentage points more than he would for a conventional mortgage, he really had no choice: regular bank mortgages do not cover construction costs. Altogether, he financed $292,500 -- which he says is far less than the $400,000 total he would have to spend if he turned the project over to a general contractor.
But with his brother's help -- his brother just graduated from school in architecture but has deferred his job hunt until January, when his brother's house should be finished -- and with the help of engineer and landscape-designer friends, and with his own weekend sweat equity, he hopes to pull off the renovation within budget.
THE other day he walked the tightrope -- edging along the two-inch edge of brownstone under the spiked railing -- to pull an 18-inch square model out of his Nissan Pathfinder.
The model shows the main house and the back house, linked by a rather ambitious glassed-in round-topped walkway leading from the parlor floor of the house to his two-story office.
"My parents think I'm crazy," Mr. Francois said. "They said: 'Why would you put yourself through all this hassle, when you could go out to the Island or to Jersey and buy yourself a nice house?' "
"I'm kind of glad my father moved back to Haiti," said Mr. Francois, who designed his parents' new home there, "because he would've discouraged me; the only person I really confided in was my brother -- and I don't know what I would've done without him."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Yves Francois outside the 19th-century brownstone he is renovating in the Fort Greene Historic District in Brooklyn. (Chang W. Lee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
The Old Tax Debate Is New Once More

BYLINE: By Joseph F. Sullivan; Joseph F. Sullivan is a reporter in the Trenton bureau of The New York Times. Iver Peterson is on vacation.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
With Assembly Republicans preparing to defend their majority rule on the basis of Governor Whitman's income-tax rate cuts, Democrats are taking every opportunity to try to link the cuts to higher property taxes.
The debate isn't new, but it has begun to heat up, with the release of a report by the Governor's office claiming that the rate of increase in property taxes for both school and municipal purposes this year was lower than last year's, and that the local tax increase for schools was the second lowest in 17 years. 
 Democrats countered that the property-tax increases were still higher than the rate of inflation and that the report was incomplete because it didn't include municipalities that operate on a July-to-June fiscal year instead of a calendar year.
Leo Klagholz, the State Education Commissioner, said the property tax increase attributable to school costs was 3.5 percent, almost 2 percentage points lower than last year. In a statement he said this "reflects a conscientious effort to hold down expenses" on the part of local school districts.
Harriet Derman, Commissioner of Community Affairs, said the increase in the tax for municipal purposes was 2.8 percent, a number that was met with skepticism, not only by the Democratic leadership in the Legislature, but by the state organization that represents local governments.
Assemblyman Joseph J. Roberts Jr. of Brooklawn, who carries the title of budget officer for the Democratic Assembly minority, said that even if the administration's claims were to be believed, local property taxes still rose $222 million so far this year -- a number that will increase when the fiscal-year communities are added to the report.
Neither the Democrats nor the New Jersey State League of Municipalities were able to get any documentation of the administration's claims about holding down the increase in municipal taxes. The Education Department provided more detailed information about the school figures.
William G. Dressel, executive director of the league, said he thought the increase for municipal purposes would be a little higher than 2.8 percent. "Based on what I've been hearing around the state, I expected it to be between 3 and 5 percent," he said. "What we were given was only a partial snapshot of the property tax situation at this time, and when the fiscal-year municipalities are added to the mix I think we'll be closer to the 3-to-5-percent figure."
"It's difficult for me, based on the summary, to start passing out bouquets to the administration," Mr. Dressel said. "If there are any bouquets they should go to the mayors and council members for keeping the tax increases at a modest level."
Mr. Dressel said he was concerned about the future, since state aid to municipalities has remained constant for the past three years while the costs of labor, fuel, pensions and benefits continue to rise. The Whitman administration was able to match last year's aid level only by adding $85 million to the amount the towns receive from the excess gross-receipts tax on utilities. "Local taxes clearly would have soared without it, but we've been told that we won't get it next year," he said.
Mrs. Whitman, who has repeatedly claimed that decisions by local officials, and not state aid levels, are responsible for property tax increases, said the small increases in local taxes this year show that local officials "have responded appropriately and with the best interests of the taxpayers in mind."
The Senate Minority Leader, John A. Lynch, a New Brunswick Democrat, said in a statement that the Governor was trying to mislead the public by releasing "piecemeal information."
"People are too smart," he went on, "to buy the spin that the Whitman administration's borrow-and-spend fiscal agenda doesn't have a direct link to rising property taxes."

HEADLINE: DESTINATIONS;
Camden's Changing Waterfront Resounds With Music and Hope

BYLINE: By KAREN DeMASTERS 

 BODY:
Last fall, truckloads of dirt were dumped on a flat, vacant lot on the Camden waterfront at a rate of one a minute, 10 hours a day, for three months. The 475,000 cubic yards of dirt formed an outdoor amphitheater capable of seating 18,000 people on lawn chairs.
That was the beginning of what has become known as the E-Center. The outdoor seating supplements the 7,000 seats under the roof of the amphitheater, the latest in this city's redevelopment efforts. 
 The E-Center, formally known as the Blockbuster-Sony Music Entertainment Center at the Waterfront, had its grand opening in June, with "Music of Andrew Lloyd Webber," and went on from there to Barney the purple dinosaur in July to a sold-out Jimmy Buffet concert on Aug. 19. That was the only sold-out show so far, although several others came close.
The first summer season, which wraps up in September, is expected to contribute 400,000 of the 750,000 people the theater hopes to draw this year. Lawn-seating tickets are sold first come, first served. Patrons may bring their own blankets; lawn chairs must be rented, for $3. Unlike similar amphitheaters, the E-Center discourages pre-concert picnics.
Unlike most other outdoor theaters, including the Garden State Arts Center in Holmdel, the E-Center will have a winter season, made possible by enclosing the 7,000 seats under a roof for year-round use. The indoor section of the theater can be divided to form a 3,700-seat forum for contemporary music; two theaters, with 3,200 and 2,600 seats, for touring productions of Broadway shows, and the 1,700-seat Walter Rand Theater, named for the former State Senator from Camden, for the South Jersey Performing Arts Center's productions.
This winter's bookings range from the violinist Itzhak Perlman as soloist with the Haddonfield Symphony to a touring stage show based on New Line Cinema's "Mortal Kombat" to "The Magic of David Copperfield."
"We are redefining the live-music experience for the Delaware Valley," said Dominic Roncace, general manager of E-Center. "The Entertainment Center is big enough to attract major artists, but still intimate enough to let you enjoy the show."
Once a thriving industrial and commercial hub, the Camden waterfront had long been virtually abandoned until redevelopment began.
The E-Center was built with $31 million from Pavilion Partners, which runs concert halls in the United States and Britain, and $26 million in state money. It continues as a joint public-private operation, with the buildings and grounds still owned by the state. The theater is operated by Pace Entertainment Group of Houston, Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Sony Music Entertainment Inc. of New York City.
With a spectacular view of the Delaware River and the Philadelphia skyline as a backdrop, the E-Center is drawing about 70 percent of its patrons from Pennsylvania.
"We see ourselves as the catalyst for the redevelopment of the waterfront," Mr. Roncace said. "We'll be the spur for restaurants and shops to locate here."
Similarly optimistic predictions have been heard before when the future of this city of 87,000 was discussed. But unemployment still hovers around 20 percent; 68 percent of the population still receives some public assistance, and the most prominent features are boarded-up buildings and abandoned stores.
The Thomas H. Kean Aquarium opened on the waterfront in 1992 with similar grandiose predictions, but $3.7 million has already been pumped into renovating it after outstanding initial attendance figures fell off drastically. The decrease in interest may have had as much to do with the nature of the exhibits as it did with the aquarium's location. Originally planned as a tour of New Jersey waters and aquatic life, which turned out to look rather dull, the aquarium has been brightened with the addition of tropical fish and colorful exhibits and decorations.
There are other signs of life along the waterfront and throughout the city, even if some of the plans that have been floated over the years turned into pipe dreams.
"Some things don't materialize, but enough works out so that progress is being made," said Thomas A. Roberts 2d, the executive director of the Camden Redevelopment Agency.
On the waterfront, a 120,000-square-foot headquarters for the Delaware River Port Authority was built, along with a 60-slip county-owned marina and three-acre Wiggins Park. The Martin Marietta Corporation built an office complex nearby, and a new parking garage was built in conjunction with the E-Center, bringing available parking in the area up to 8,400 spaces.
About 400 new housing units have been built in small developments throughout the city, and other residential and commercial projects are in the talking stages.
In addition to 800 construction jobs, the E-Center has generated 20 permanent full-time jobs and about 400 part-time jobs, with an annual payroll of slightly less than $1 million. The theater is expected to bring in $20 million a year in gross sales.
Even though people stay at the theater for only a few hours, its presence "is positive in terms of changing the image of the city," Mr. Roberts said, adding: "It makes the city a more attractive place for investment. The city has a tough image. If people can come in, have a good time and leave safely, it shows Camden is not a terrible place to be."
