HEADLINE: RISE IN UNINSURED BECOMES AN ISSUE IN MEDICAID FIGHT

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26

 BODY:
Since President Clinton's plans for universal health care coverage collapsed a year ago, another million Americans have lost their health insurance, a trend the Clinton Administration and some private analysts say would be almost doubled by Republican proposals to rein in Medicaid spending.
Estimates of the number of uninsured Americans now run as high as 43.4 million, more and more of whom are from the working poor. The rate at which the ranks of the uninsured have been growing has increased slightly but steadily in recent years, to a current annual rate of 1.2 million, by the latest estimates. 
 But Administration officials say Republican plans to cut projected Medicaid spending by $182 billion over the next seven years could deprive as many as nine million additional Americans of Medicaid coverage by 2002, leaving the bulk of those people with no health insurance at all.
While that projection could be labeled partisan because it is part of the Administration's preparation for the budget battle that will open when Congress returns after Labor Day, a number of outside groups and analysts agree that Medicaid's soaring growth in recent years has acted as a brake on the rising number of the uninsured. Cuts in the program, which provides health coverage for low-income Americans, could well lead to an increase in the number of people without health coverage, they say.
Congressional Republicans contend that by transferring Federal money directly to the states with reduced regulation, they can expand the number of people served while limiting the growth in spending. "We're going to change Medicaid," said Representative Dennis Hastert, the Illinois Republican who is the vice chairman of the Commerce subcommittee on health, which oversees Medicaid. "We think by changing it, knocking out some of the dual Federal-state bureaucracy, we can expand it."
Republicans also fiercely contest Democratic descriptions of their Medicaid plans as cuts. Under the budget resolution passed by the House and Senate this summer, Medicaid spending would increase to $124.3 billion in the 2002 fiscal year. That would be up from $89.2 billion in the current fiscal year, which ends on Sept. 30, but well below the $177.8 billion that the Congressional Budget Office projects would be needed in 2002 to maintain existing levels of service for everyone who meets the eligibility standards in current law.
This new debate is a stark contrast to the arguments heard here last August, when President Clinton was pushing universal health care coverage. Back then, Democrats wondered whether settling for covering 95 percent of Americans was too great a compromise, while many Republicans argued that the Clinton health care plan was moving in the right direction but too far, too fast.
A number of senior Republicans joined moderate Democrats last year in supporting limited changes in health care legislation. When President Clinton's plan failed last year, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas said that legislation addressing the cost and quality of health care would be "at the top of the Senate's agenda" this year. But as majority leader this year, Senator Dole has instead emphasized cutting the Federal budget deficit and other issues.
Hearing little public clamor for change, Republicans put health care low on their agenda, except for proposing reductions in Medicare and Medicaid in their drive to balance the Federal budget by 2002. Democrats have reacted with dire predictions of the effects of Republican cuts in Government insurance programs.
The only significant exception is a bipartisan Senate Labor Committee bill that would help some people who lose their insurance when they change jobs. But its immediate prospects appear dim, particularly in the House, where it ranks far down the Republican list of priorities.
Democratic warnings on Medicaid cuts are echoed by many private health care experts, who are skeptical that the Republican initiatives would reduce the number of uninsured and who argue that the number may begin rising even faster.
"You're talking about a situation that is likely to deteriorate even if the Medicaid program is not cut," said Robert D. Reischauer, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution and former director of the Congressional Budget Office. "With cuts, the ranks of the uninsured will swell much faster."
The most widely used estimates of the number of uninsured Americans come from the Employee Benefit Research Institute in Washington, a nonprofit, nonpartisan group supported by a range of large corporations, law firms, trade associations and labor unions. Paul Fronstin, a researcher at the institute, said calculations from Census data show that 40.9 million Americans under the age of 65 lacked health insurance in 1993, along with several hundred thousand older Americans who did not qualify for Medicare for various reasons.
The number of uninsured Americans has been steadily rising as employers have stopped offering coverage or have begun charging fees that some people felt they could not afford. These trends appear to have continued over the last two years, so that the number of uninsured probably rose to slightly more than 42 million last year and to as much as 43.4 million this year, or 18.7 percent of those under 65, Mr. Fronstin said.
Medicaid covered nearly 32 million people in 1993, up from 21 million in 1989, according to the institute. Another 33 million Americans had Medicare coverage in 1993, compared with 31.5 million in 1989.
Social researchers have long approached figures on the uninsured with caution because they are based on large annual surveys by the Census Bureau. Some analysts have argued that many respondents misunderstand the questions and indicate that they have been without health insurance for the entire preceding year when they have actually lacked coverage only part of the time.
Studies by the Employee Benefit Research Institute and a new study this summer by the Urban Institute, a liberal Washington research group, have concluded that the rise in the number of people without health insurance has come mainly among the working poor.
A series of legislative changes in recent years have meant that Medicaid covers a steadily rising percentage of poor Americans. At the same time, the number of poor Americans is increasing as the gap between rich and poor widens. But Medicaid is not available to many families whose earnings are slightly greater than the official definition of poverty -- $14,764 for a family of four in 1993.
Clinton Administration officials relied heavily on the Urban Institute's analytical techniques in forecasting that nine million Americans would be denied Medicaid in 2002 if the current Republican budget were approved. They assumed that the Republican plans would cut the annual rate of increase in Medicaid's cost per beneficiary to 1.9 percent above the rate of inflation in consumer prices, from the current 3.8 percent.
The Administration officials used the Congressional Budget Office's assumption that the number of people eligible for Medicaid would continue to rise briskly as the ranks of the poor continued to expand. They then calculated that most of those extra people would be denied Medicaid coverage under the Republican budget plans. Private studies suggest that considerably less than half of those denied Medicaid coverage would be able to find health insurance elsewhere, such as by joining a relative's insurance plan.
The Republicans assume that the cost per beneficiary will grow more slowly or that the demand for Medicaid services will rise more slowly, or both.

HEADLINE: COMPANIES PRESS CLINTON TO LIFT EMBARGO ON CUBA

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

 BODY:
A growing number of American businesses have for the first time begun pressing Washington to reconsider the trade embargo against Cuba, complaining that it forces them to stand by as foreign competitors lock up an attractive emerging market.
A handful of corporate executives have spoken out publicly against the embargo in recent months, and others have testified before Congress. But most of the pressure has come in private meetings with Clinton Administration officials. 
 The emergence of a fledgling private-sector lobby against the Cuban embargo adds an influential new element to a debate in which economic interests have taken a back seat to political ideology.
"Pressure is growing," a Clinton Administration official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "Businessmen are expressing interest in a transition in Cuba and complaining that all the deals down there are being cut by foreign competitors. There's a very high degree of business interest in Cuba."
So far, Clinton Administration officials have responded only by restating long-held positions, as when Alexander Watson, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, recently came under questioning on Cuba after giving a pep talk on hemispheric trade to an audience of corporate executives at the State Department.
"The Europeans and the Asians are knocking on the door in Latin America," Mr. Watson warned. "The game is on and we can compete effectively, but it will be a big mistake if we leave the game to others."
Eric Williams, managing director for Latin American sales for Federal Express, asked, "Do your comments on free trade apply to Cuba?"
"No, no," Mr. Watson said. "That simply can't be, not for now."
John D. Tessier, a Connecticut consultant who specializes in Latin America, waded in. "Isn't there some incongruity on our policy toward the Communist world?" he asked. "Why do we have one policy toward North Korea, another for Vietnam, another for China, but complete coldness toward Cuba?"
"Cuba is a special case," Mr. Watson responded. "This Administration will maintain the embargo until major democratic changes take place in Cuba. Then, and only then, will the United States respond with carefully calibrated steps. And that's where we are."
Perhaps the most outspoken critic of the embargo among corporate executives has been Dwayne O. Andreas, chairman of Archer Daniels Midland, the giant grain processor in Decatur, Ill.
"Our embargo has been a total failure for 30 years," Mr. Andreas said in a June interview with CNN. "We ought to have all the Americans in Cuba doing all the business they can. It's time for a change."
Jose Cardenas, a spokesman for the Cuban-American National Foundation, the powerful anti-Castro lobby, acknowledged that business interest in Cuba had increased. "There are always a few people who are willing to make a buck -- and the moral ramifications be damned," he said. "But most people know that stable business conditions will not exist in Cuba as long as Fidel Castro is in power. And when it comes down to it, these businessmen won't bleed for the issue."
Even as executives like Mr. Andreas are urging an end to the embargo, a Republican bill in Congress would tighten it considerably. The bill, sponsored by Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina and Representative Dan Burton of Indiana, would, among other measures, punish foreign countries and companies, including subsidiaries of American companies, that trade with Cuba.
The Clinton Administration has threatened to veto the bill, partly because of a provision that would allow thousands of Cuban exiles to sue the Cuban Government in Federal courts in the United States to recover properties that have been expropriated since the 1959 revolution. Administration officials said such lawsuits could overwhelm the courts with dubious new litigation.
Administration officials say the threat of a tighter embargo has actually focused the attention of the business executives on the issue, and drawn more open expressions of disfavor.
John S. Kavulich, president of the U.S.-Cuba Trade and Economic Council, which works with the cooperation of the Castro Government to disseminate commercial information about Cuba, said 1995 had brought an increase in the number of executives scouting out Cuba, even above 1994, when he said more than 500 representatives of American businesses visited there.
More than 100 of the American business representatives who have visited Cuba have signed "letters of intent" with state-owned businesses, outlining areas of potential cooperation if trade relations are normalized, Bruno Rodriguez Parrilla, Cuba's delegate to the United Nations, said in an interview.
The Clinton Administration's decision on May 2 to repatriate Cuban boat people, reversing three decades of immigration policy and angering the most conservative Cuban exile organizations, has led some executives to conclude that the Administration is rethinking its Cuba policy.
Many executives say they sense that change may be coming -- despite repeated Administration declarations to the contrary. Ron Perelman, who owns Revlon as well as the Consolidated Cigar Corporation, predicted in a recent interview with the magazine Cigar Aficionado that the embargo would be lifted within five years.
"We think it's inevitable," said Thomas J. Polski, a spokesman for Carlson Companies, which owns the Radisson Hotel chain and a Caribbean cruise liner. "We see Cuba as an exciting new opportunity -- the forbidden fruit of the Caribbean."
Others question how rapidly change will come. John E. Howard, international policy director at the United States Chamber of Commerce, which opposes the embargo, said American corporations were not yet as active on Cuba as they were in the lobbying campaign that led to the normalization of relations with Vietnam in February.
"The time was right, politically, to make that happen on Vietnam," Mr. Howard said. "I question whether the time is right to make it happen on Cuba."
But executives cut off from a market they consider potentially lucrative are speaking out anyway.
Carlson is one of several companies whose executives have criticized the embargo in Congressional testimony since early last year. Another is Otis Elevator, based in Farmington, Conn., whose executives want the chance to modernize the thousands of Otis elevators in Cuba and have both testified and sent letters to Congress protesting the embargo.
At a hearing on American-Cuban relations before the House Ways and Means Committee on June 30, the vice chairman of the U.S.A. Rice Federation, Keith Broussard, said, "The U.S. rice industry views the Cuban market as one of great potential once the embargo is no longer in place."
Sandra M. Alfonso, who heads a commission set up by Gov. Edwin Edwards of Louisiana, told Congress at the same hearing that pre-embargo Cuba had been Louisiana's No. 1 trading partner and that the state had lost 6,000 jobs because of the embargo. Louisiana could easily recover those jobs and more, Ms. Alfonso said, but not "if the existing sanctions remain."
Although some executives are speaking publicly, Administration officials said more were expressing their views on the embargo in private meetings at the White House and the State Department.
"I'm hearing concerns from many U.S. businessmen that they are losing out," said Richard Nuccio, the White House's special adviser on Cuba. "But frankly I don't think it's very true" that American businesses are missing major opportunities, he said. The Europeans, Latin Americans and other foreign competitors investing in Cuba "are mostly people who put money in short-term or high-risk investments" and could be displaced by American investors if the embargo is lifted, he said.
One exception, Mr. Nuccio said, is in the modernization of Cuba's telephone system, an undertaking that has begun with major investments from Italian and Mexican companies.
"Once others wire the country, Americans are not going to re-wire it," Mr. Nuccio said. "The embargo against Cuba is the most comprehensive against any country in the world -- it's a tough embargo. We do it because we believe that it is only pressure that drives Cuba toward economic or political reform."

HEADLINE: Mill Sought by Bronx Is Blocked;
Railroad Bluff Delays A Project in Train Yard

BYLINE: By DON VAN NATTA Jr. 

 BODY:
For the South Bronx, the proposal to build a paper recycling mill in the old Harlem Rail Yard appeared to be a rare sure thing.
Announced in May 1994, the plan called for a $280 million plant that would recycle a daily torrent of office paper from New York City's trash. At the same time, it would provide 1,000 permanent jobs and other economic benefits for the South Bronx, including housing, day care and health care services for the workers. 
 Residents, environmentalists, government leaders, even the White House embraced the idea. "Great," President Clinton wrote in a White House memo describing the mill. "V.P. or I should visit site when it opens."
But now, 15 months later, it is uncertain whether the mill will ever open. The plant's groundbreaking, originally scheduled for April on a 19-acre tract just north of Randalls Island, has been postponed indefinitely. And the project's partners -- a nationally renowned environmental group and a South Bronx community organization -- are struggling to overcome a series of setbacks.
A suit filed by a Manhattan lawyer, a railroad buff who objected to putting the mill in a railroad yard, stalled any progress on the project for a year. By the time the partners won the suit in the appeals courts earlier this month, the mill's two principal investors, a pair of international paper companies, had withdrawn their pledge to invest in the project.
"The lawsuit hurt us very much; there's no doubt about it," said Allen Hershkowitz, a senior scientist at the National Resources Defense Council, the environmental group pushing the project. "Even though the lawsuit was groundless, all the confidence that someone would have in this project was wiped out. And now we have to get it back."
In the last few days, Dr. Hershkowitz said, two other paper companies have expressed interest in investing in the project now that it is "litigation free." But there is much to be done before the project can once again be considered a sure thing.
The difficulties facing the Bronx Community Paper Company illustrate how even the best-intentioned environmentally sensitive construction projects, backed by enthusiastic support from neighborhood residents to the Oval Office, can be stymied. The project's problems have also reinforced the long-held perception among investors and developers that it is extremely difficult to develop manufacturing projects in New York City, with its myriad bureaucratic, political and legal hurdles.
For 30 years, community leaders and residents in the South Bronx felt powerless to stop the exodus of manufacturers from their neighborhood for the suburbs. Most often, community advocates fought to stop the construction of what they perceived were environmentally harmful projects, like the medical waste incinerator in nearby Hunts Point.
Several years ago, community development groups began trying to attract new, nonpolluting industries to the South Bronx, particularly to the abandoned Harlem Rail Yard, which has been an eyesore for 25 years.
Yolanda Rivera, chairwoman of Banana Kelly Community Improvement Association, a leading community organization in the South Bronx, sought the advice of local and national environmental experts. She met Dr. Hershkowitz, who was familiar with a pollution-free process that the paper industry is beginning to try commercially: it turns office paper into clean pulp that printing companies use to make high-grade writing and printing papers, like glossy magazine covers.
Quietly, for two years, Dr. Hershkowitz and Ms. Rivera discussed something never done before: building a paper recycling plant in an inner-city area, a plant that would benefit from being close to the recyclable material.
Two paper companies, S. D. Warren Company of Boston and Modo Paper Company of Stockholm, were attracted. The companies agreed to invest a total of $550,000 to defray the $2 million needed for detailed engineering and economic studies.
When it was announced in May 1994, Ms. Rivera and Dr. Hershkowitz portrayed the paper mill as a pioneering project built upon the unlikely cooperation of an environmental group, a community development association and two paper companies.
Beyond that, the project planners had an abiding social conscience. Of the $280 million cost, $6.2 million would be spent on social service projects in the South Bronx, including a dormitory for the homeless and a family learning center offering programs in child care, health care, literacy training, employment and housing.
The project's leaders said they were committed to knocking down the skepticism of many investors about manufacturing in New York City. "Most executives would never think about building in New York," said Bruce Pulver, a financial adviser to the project. "I have frequently been involved in projects that have been stopped by environmental groups or community opposition."
This project, the partners said, would be different because the partners themselves were the usual sources of grass-roots opposition that can severely delay development proposals.
But John McHugh, a Manhattan lawyer and passionate railroad advocate, was committed to stopping the project. Since 1982, he has argued that the former Harlem Rail Yard should be used solely as a railroad transportation hub, which he says is badly needed by what is left of New York City's industrial base.
"They want to put a paper recycling mill in the middle of what was supposed to be a rail yard, and that would destroy the rail yard forever," Mr. McHugh said.
He also said he was angry that the mill partners had been able to lease their site from Francesco Galesi, a developer who in turn had a 99-year lease from the state for the rail yard that Mr. McHugh complained was "far below market rent."
Two years ago, Mr. McHugh told an environmental group at a Riverdale synagogue about the damage the mill would do to the rail yard. "After the meeting, several people approached me," recalled Mr. McHugh, who informed the audience that he lives in Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J., not the South Bronx. "They wanted to find out how they could stop it."
In the audience was Gwynn Smalls, a co-founder of the South Bronx Clean Air Coalition, who said she believed the project's partners had not given residents enough information to squelch their concerns about the mill.
"People just didn't know enough," said Ms. Smalls, who is asthmatic and remains concerned that the paper mill could harm the environment. "Whenever we asked for specific documentation, we were told they would get back to us, and then they didn't get back to us. There was a lot of mistrust, and relying on good faith is not enough for us."
Dr. Hershkowitz and Ms. Rivera met with Mr. McHugh, who told them they should find another site for the plant. They argued that there were no other economical sites in the South Bronx.
For Ms. Rivera, the darkest hour came during a meeting with the plant's opponents, including Mr. McHugh. "It became clear that this had nothing to do with environmental issues or what was best for the community," Ms. Rivera said. "I told them I found it incredibly maddening to think that they would stand in the way of the welfare of everyday folks. I told them, 'I hope the community never discovers what you've done here.' "
Richard Schrader, an adviser to the project, said Mr. McHugh's arguments about the mill were an easy sell in the South Bronx. "I think the South Bronx is emblematic of all the broken promises that the government has made and never come through on," Mr. Schrader said. "They don't trust outsiders who promise gold and deliver snake oil.
"Most importantly, though, those most vocal opponents of the project are really people who are isolated from mainstream politics. That kind of isolation, particularly in a poor community, breeds contempt toward any outsider."
The South Bronx Clean Air Coalition agreed to sue to stop the mill; Mr. McHugh represented them free. In March, a trial judge agreed with his clients that the original plan had discouraged bidders from considering exclusive development of the site as a railroad yard.
The group's partners were stunned.
There were other problems. A few months earlier, S. D. Warren, a division of Scott Paper, had been bought by Sappi, a South African paper company. The high debt of the purchase made it impossible for Sappi to remain in the Bronx project, which some board members saw as a "risky venture," said James D. Black, vice president of S. D. Warren.
Mr. Black gave the bad news to the partners on the same day they heard they had lost the lawsuit. "They were all sitting around, very long-faced," he said. "They knew why I was there. I told them we couldn't keep our end of the project. It was a very bleak moment."
Mr. Black said he had advised the partners that getting another paper company was essential to the project. "They tried," he said, "but they were absolutely handicapped in getting another paper company after having lost the lawsuit." Modo has also withdrawn its commitment to invest, but the mill's partners say it is still interested in buying some of the pulp and may lend technological expertise.
Still, the loss of both companies' support left the project moribund. Then, on Aug. 10, the state appellate court ruled unanimously in favor of the project, even saying that Mr. McHugh's clients "were less motivated by environmental concerns than by economic, political or other factors."
The mill's partners, though vindicated by the ruling, acknowledge that the hard part lies ahead, as they try to recruit new investors. Last week, Mr. McHugh rejected their accusation that his lawsuit had hurt that effort.
"We didn't do this to them," he said. "They did it to themselves. They could have put this mill in any number of places -- the Hunts Point peninsula, for one. But they chose a rail yard for a paper mill, which makes no sense. As a result, they probably killed themselves off, and that's not very smart."
The partners remain optimistic, saying that the project's main selling point -- a recycling mill adjacent to thousands of tons of recyclable office paper -- has not changed.
Dr. Hershkowitz said: "What has clearly happened is people are now saying the project that was impossible to carry out, because of community opposition, has now gotten beyond that opposition."

HEADLINE: A Cleanup Program Helps the Unemployed

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON 

 BODY:
The City of Bridgeport, Conn., is hiring residents who are unemployed or on welfare to clean up trash in some poor neighborhoods.
The program is focused on areas that are blighted by illegal dumping and abandoned buildings. Residents who own pickup trucks are paid $30 a ton to haul the trash to a regional incinerator. City officials estimate that about 9,000 tons of trash have accumulated on private property in the area covered by the project. 
 The program, called Trash for Cash, works like this: The city first tells the owner to clean up the property. If the property owner fails to act, a task force assigns the job to a program participant and charges the property owner for the cleanup.
The Resco incinerator, which takes municipal trash from the Bridgeport area, has reduced its fee for taking trash to $30 a ton, from the usual $79, to help subsidize the pilot program. GEORGE JUDSON

(Photographs by Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Judge Who Is Also a General Repairs Haiti's Judicial System

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26

 BODY:
Donald F. Campbell has two jobs. When he is not presiding over divorcing couples and deadbeat dads, he is fixing broken countries.
Since American troops entered Haiti last September to reinstate the exiled President, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, among the biggest challenges has been resurrecting Haiti's tattered judicial system, which suffered from decades of neglect under a host of dictators and military juntas. 
 Much of that burden has fallen to General Campbell, a New Jersey Superior Court judge in civilian life who is also a two-star general in the Army Reserve responsible for helping countries rebuild after wars or natural disasters.
General Campbell, a family-law judge in Burlington County, led a team of 18 Army Reserve judges and lawyers to Haiti in February for a three-month assignment to review the judicial system, begin training the country's 400 judges (many of whom have little or no legal background), modernize the country's 19th century legal code and begin repairing dilapidated rural courthouses.
Since then, from his Army command at Fort Bragg, N.C., and from his courthouse in Mount Holly, N.J., General Campbell has worked closely with the United States Agency for International Development, the United Nations and Haiti's Justice Minister, Jean-Joseph Exume, to maintain the momentum his legal shock troops started.
"Their needs are so basic you did not need a Harvard law degree to understand what had to be done to improve their system," General Campbell said in an interview at the Pentagon. The general, a decorated Vietnam veteran, commands 5,800 Army civil affairs troops who are judges, doctors, health inspectors and fire chiefs as civilians, and who use those same skills when called to active duty.
So far, there have been small successes. The Justice Ministry in Port-au-Prince has light bulbs again. Each of the country's judges has a set of books containing Haiti's legal code. And on Thursday, a newly functioning criminal court convicted a Haitian man of killing a prominent supporter of Mr. Aristide in 1993, one of the most notorious murders during the country's last three years of military rule.
But there are still plenty of hurdles. Haiti has no bail system. Its criminal court is in session only twice a year, leaving many suspects to spend more time in jail awaiting trial than the length their sentences would be if they were tried and found guilty. The country's largely rural population still relies more on vigilante justice than the courtroom variety.
"It's going to be a long, arduous process that will require time, effort and patience," said General Campbell, 52, who earned sociology and law degrees from Seton Hall University.
General Campbell's unusual background gives him a good chance to succeed. He has been a Superior Court judge in Ocean and Burlington counties since 1982, hearing more than 200 jury trials ranging from death-penalty murder cases to medical malpractice and child-custody complaints.
"The fact I was a judge gave me credibility with the Haitians," said General Campbell. "It was absolutely key. We couldn't accomplish anything without their full cooperation."
The Haitian Government required General Campbell and his team to trade in their battle fatigues for dark suits during their assignment. "We had to be in civilian clothing so we gave the impression it was not the U.S. military but the U.S. legal community that was offering assistance," he said.
In a country in which the Justice Ministry last spring had little idea how many judges and courthouses it really had, General Campbell sought to bring military efficiency to disarray and uncertainty.
The team helicoptered around the country with Mr. Exume, visiting virtually all of the 400 judges and justices-of-the-peace. About one-third had held their jobs for years, sometimes decades. Most others were appointed by Mr. Aristide.
"In rural areas, a few of them couldn't even read or write," General Campbell said. "They were respected elders who people thought would make good judges."
The American team interviewed each of the judges, noted their concerns for improved security, and reviewed with them the Haitian constitution, ethics and the responsibilities of judges.
At General Campbell's recommendation, Mr. Exume agreed to increase a judge's salary to about $320 a month from $80 a month. Legal forms, absent in some courthouses for 10 years, were flown in. Fifteen of the American military's Chevrolet Blazers were donated to help Haitian judges travel around the countryside.
"They were a roving, experienced and disciplined force that could focus on problems and get things done," Michael Morfit, head of the Agency for International Development's Haiti task force in Washington, said of General Campbell's team. "They were prepared for just about anything."
The team recommended changes to Haiti's Napoleonic legal code. Under the code, for instance, judges, not police officers, investigate crimes. That could lead to conflicts of interest, the general said. Lawyers from France and Louisiana, the only state with a legal system based on Napoleonic law, were brought in to help.
In the last few months, the Agency for International Development and the Haitian Government have opened a formal training center for judges in the Haitian army's former military academy. French-speaking judges from countries like Canada and Senegal have joined Haitian lawyers as instructors for rigorous two-week courses.
The United States plans to spend $18 million over the next five years to restore the Haitian judiciary, its courthouses and some of the nation's 17 prisons. In October, General Campbell said he expects an eight-member legal team will return to some of the areas visited last spring.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Judge Donald F. Campbell of Burlington County, N.J., is helping to rebuild Haiti's judicial system. (Laura Pedrick for the New York Times)

HEADLINE: The PATH War;
Giuliani's Call for a Fare Increase Provokes Anger and Veiled Threats

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani called for a fare increase on the PATH commuter line last week, opening a new front in the border wars with New Jersey, it almost seemed as if he were complaining about a railway whose route was entirely west of the Hudson and never entered New York City.
The PATH does come into the city, of course, making nearly as many stops in Manhattan as in New Jersey. So if the system provides service in both states, why does Mr. Giuliani keep attacking it and its owner, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, declaring that the city is being shortchanged? In other words, who actually benefits from the PATH? 
 Port Authority officials and transportation experts disagree with Mr. Giuliani's assertion that the Port Authority Trans-Hudson is essentially a New Jersey institution. Although they acknowledge that 85 percent of PATH riders are New Jersey residents, they ask whether Mr. Giuliani would prefer that the 65,000 or so commuters who take PATH daily to Manhattan drive instead.
"If you didn't have PATH, think about the kind of traffic and congestion that would create," said John J. Haley Jr., the deputy executive director of the Port Authority.
New Jersey officials questioned how Mr. Giuliani could say he was determined to revitalize the office market in Lower Manhattan when he wanted to raise the fare on the PATH, which brings tens of thousands of commuters to its World Trade Center station every weekday.
And transportation experts noted that New Jersey commuters are taxed by New York City and State and spend millions of dollars a year on everything from clothes to restaurant meals to Broadway shows. In 1993, the most recent year for which figures are available, New Jersey residents paid $910 million in taxes to New York State and $63 million to New York City, officials said.
There are no statistics on what percentage of those amounts is paid by PATH commuters, but the figures are substantial. One out of every three New Jersey residents who come into jobs in the central business district in Manhattan, from Battery Park to 59th Street, uses PATH.
"We all benefit, both sides of the river, from a good transportation system, and the PATH is an essential part of the region's transportation system," said H. Claude Shostal, president of the Regional Plan Association, which studies land-use issues. "We are one region, one economy. If PATH would disappear, both sides of the river would be deeply hurt."
The issue has long roiled relations between the two states, and is again flaring now that tough times are forcing officials like Mr. Giuliani to focus on patching their budgets.
Mr. Giuliani contends that because so many of PATH's users are New Jersey residents, the $200 million annual subsidy that the railway receives from the Port Authority is a gift to New Jersey, draining money from the authority's finances that could go to projects in New York City.
The size of the subsidy, Mr. Giuliani says, also prevents the authority from paying the city more rent for Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports, which the authority leases from the city. By raising the fare from $1 to at least $1.25, he says, the authority could lower the subsidy on the PATH, which runs through Newark, Harrison, Jersey City, Hoboken and Manhattan.
"If I see New Yorkers getting hosed, I am going to fight for them," Mr. Giuliani said, touching off a backlash from Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and other New Jersey officials, who announced that they were against raising the fare and the $4 toll on the Port Authority's bridges and tunnels. Some New Jersey legislators even threatened to retaliate by increasing commuter taxes for New Yorkers who work in New Jersey.
Mr. Giuliani also drew comparisons between the PATH and the New York City subway system, which is operated by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, a state agency, and receives a smaller subsidy than the PATH in terms of its costs. He said that city residents should not have to pay $1.25, soon to go up to $1.50, while the PATH remains $1.
Even if the fare were raised by 25 cents, it would yield only another $15 million, hardly significant in relation to the Port Authority's or the city's budget. If the tolls on the agency's six bridges and tunnels were also raised, from $4 to $5, that would bring in $140 million.
Mr. Giuliani doubtlessly knew that by demanding a fare increase, he would stir anger in New Jersey. Yet because so few New Yorkers ride the PATH, he faces little prospect of protests from his constituents, and might instead be able to rally some of them with his complaints that the Port Authority favors New Jersey.
Port Authority officials agree that the PATH deficit is too high, but they say they are working on a plan to reduce it by cutting at least $10 million from the railway's $155 million budget without decreasing service. Eventually, they say, fares should cover about 50 percent of the costs of the system, up from the current 25 to 38 percent, depending on the method of calculation.
No mass-transit system in the country earns a profit, and most transportation experts say that a system is successful if it reaches the 50 percent point.
"I am not saying that we don't have to fix things in PATH, but it is not broken," said Peter S. Kalikow, an authority commissioner from New York. "The last thing that we should do is raise fares and tolls."

SECTION: Section 8; Page 11; Column 1; Sports Desk 

LENGTH: 1312 words

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
If You Want to Go Far, Go With the Long Ball

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
The season was different from the first pitch. The strike forced a reduction in the schedule from 162 games to 144. Then, because the strike forced cancellation of the playoffs last year, this year's playoffs were granted uniqueness, featuring wild-card, or nonchampionship, teams for the first time.
The idea, then, would fit in with the unusual nature of the season. Instead of having three rounds of playoffs in competing cities all over the country, let the division champions and wild cards send their four top home run hitters and their four best pitchers to Colorado and settle this year's championship in one mammoth home run contest at Coors Field, Home of the Home Run. 
 Of course, the Rockies' rocket launchers would be favored, but the Rockies would have to qualify first by winning the National League West championship or finish with the best won-lost record among second-place teams. And if they did make it, their pitchers would have to pitch against the other teams' hitters.
Oh what a dandy show it would be. Balls soaring into the atmosphere, projectiles flying first over this fence, then over that one, incoming missiles threatening the safety of citizens within the park or anywhere near it.
As fanciful as this scenario is, it is one way of recognizing the squads of home run hitters that have powered teams into championship or contending status. Consider these statistics, with home run totals through Friday's games:
Rockies: Dante Bichette 31, Vinny Castilla 30, Larry Walker 28, Andres Galarraga 27.
Indians: Albert Belle 31, Manny Ramirez 29, Jim Thome 21, Paul Sorrento 20, Eddie Murray 15.
Angels: Jim Edmonds 30, Tim Salmon 29, Tony Phillips 20, J. T. Snow 18, Chili Davis 17.
Red Sox: Mo Vaughn 32, John Valentin 22, Jose Canseco 20.
Mariners: Tino Martinez 26, Jay Buhner 24, Edgar Martinez 24, Mike Blowers 18.
Dodgers: Eric Karros 24, Mike Piazza 22, Raul Mondesi 20.
The Rockies have the most awesome squad. Entering yesterday's games, their quartet was first, second, third and tied for fifth among National League leaders. They were a total of five home runs (Walker 2, Galarraga 3) away from becoming the first team since the 1977 Los Angeles Dodgers to have four players with 30 or more.
Don Baylor, the Rockies' manager, seems most impressed with Castilla, the third baseman, who never had hit more than 14 home runs in a season in his five-year professional career.
"It's pretty impressive to see Castilla, a third baseman, especially a right-handed hitter, with that kind of power," Baylor said of the player acquired in the expansion draft from Atlanta. "When we got him, Bobby Cox said he'll hit for you. I didn't think he meant home runs."
Of his four power hitters, Baylor added, Castilla "probably has more of an uppercut swing."
"He's the guy who probably can get the ball in the air more consistently than the other guys. Bichette can go out in either field, Galarraga and Walker the same. Vinny is better when he's hitting the ball to right-center because of his home run swing. He wants to pull, but when he thinks about hitting the ball the other way, he's hit the ball over the right-center field fence."
If Baylor has one complaint about his home run squad, it's that they change their hitting styles when the Rockies play on other fields. To be sure, the Rockies have distinctly split hitting personalities depending on the site of their games.
As a team, the Rockies are hitting .315 at home, .247 on the road. They have hit 112 home runs and scored 387 runs in 57 games at home but have hit only 50 home runs and scored 218 runs in 54 games on the road. The popular belief is that the Rockies benefit from Coors Field and the mile-high altitude. But Baylor blames the drastic difference on the players' approach to hitting.
"On the road, they don't try to hit the ball the other way," he said. "When we get back to Coors Field, they say now I'm going to hit the ball where it's pitched and go the other way. On the road, we get home-run-pull happy. Instead of taking a soft single to right, they try to pull. That's something that on the next road trip I'm going to try to convince the guys to do. It's not just home cooking. It's their mental philosophy and approach."
Baylor pointed to a telling statistic. "Our strikeouts go up on the road," he said. "You'd think you'd be swinging for the fences at Coors Field and strikeouts would be higher. But they're higher on the road."
The Rockies have struck out 401 times on the road, 344 times at home.
Home does have its advantages. "There's really no safe lead in this park when you have these four guys in a row," their manager said.
 
 
Dangerous When Healthy
 Juan Gonzalez of Texas and Jose Canseco of Boston have missed much playing time with injuries, but when they play, they are dangerous. Gonzalez has averaged one home run for every 11.7 at-bats, Canseco one every 14.1. Mark McGwire of Oakland is another slugger who has been undermined by injuries. He's on the disabled list now with a home run ratio of one every 8.8 at-bats.
Henry Aaron hit one home run every 16.4 at-bats, Babe Ruth one every 11.8.
 
 
More Than Memory Slipping
 At 2:18 A.M. Eastern time last Thursday, the Yankees tumbled 14 1/2 games behind the Boston Red Sox -- 17 years after they were popularly but mistakenly believed to have been 14 1/2 games behind the Red Sox.
In the memorable 1978 race, the Yankees fell 14 games back July 17 and remained there the next two days. Contrary to faulty memories, they never dropped 14 1/2 out.
They reached that precise deficit last Wednesday night when the Red Sox edged California, 6-5, in 10 innings after the Yankees had lost in Oakland earlier in the day. When they made it 15 1/2 the next night, the Yankees had plummeted 11 games in the standings in 19 days.
"That's almost unheard of," said the general manager of another team. "It must be something in the clubhouse, the chemistry or something,"
Maybe something in the water.
 
 
Picking on the Astros
 The Houston Astros should take it personally.
In 10 Cincinnati victories (in 10 games) against them this season, Ron Gant has collected 14 hits in 36 at-bats plus seven walks for a .389 batting average and .488 on-base percentage. He has slugged seven home runs and driven in 15 runs.
Using the same number of games the Reds played the Astros in each of their three series, in the 10 games before they played, Gant batted .237 with no home runs and 7 runs batted in (5 in one game); in the 10 games he played after the Reds-Astros series, Gant batted .243 with 2 homers and 5 r.b.i. Gant hit more home runs and drove in more runs in the 10 games against the Astros than in the 20 games before and after.
 
 
Talks Turn Positive
 If clubhouse chemistry can help produce winning teams, maybe good chemistry can have a positive effect on the attempt to get a new labor agreement. The low-profile talks between lawyers for the owners and the players will continue this week amid scouting reports from both sides that the chemistry has been good.
"I don't know what that means, where it will take us," said a member of management who has been involved in the negotiations the past year but not in these talks. "But it's better than it ever has been."
The talks have been described as "frank and civil," even pleasant, and different in tone from the talks that dragged on unsuccessfully during the eight-month strike. However, this round of talks has not reached the stage of full-blown bargaining. Tone won't produce an economic formula agreeable to both sides.
One segment of the meetings has focused on playing the playoffs and World Series without threat of interruption, not that anyone expects an interruption. Pension contribution and service time have been topics of critical conversation toward that end.

HEADLINE: The Green Republican

BYLINE: By Keith Schneider; Keith Schneider, a former national environmental correspondent for The New York Times, is executive director of the Michigan Land Use Institute.

 BODY:

THE MAKING OF A CONSERVATIVE ENVIRONMENTALIST
With Reflections on Government, Industry, Scientists, the Media, Education, Economic Growth, the Public, the Great Lakes, Activists, and the Sunsetting
of Toxic Chemicals.
By Gordon K. Durnil.
200 pp. Bloomington:
Indiana University Press. $19.95. 
 IN 1992, an American-Canadian agency charged with overseeing the health of the Great Lakes surprised the White House, never mind governors in eight states bordering the lakes, by making a radical proposal. Convinced that the toxic byproducts of chlorine-based industrial compounds were harming wildlife and perhaps poisoning people, the panel called for phasing out one of the basic chemical feedstocks of modern manufacturing, straight elemental chlorine.
One might assume that the man behind such a noble gambit was a learned statesman and veteran environmentalist. Hardly. The recommendation's main champion was Gordon K. Durnil, the panel's American chairman, a Rush Limbaugh-loving conservative Republican from Indiana.
Here was a plain, middle-aged guy who freely admits that before being appointed by George Bush in 1989 to the International Joint Commission, a little-known but influential oversight agency that watches the Great Lakes, his closest brush with industrial ravage occurred while swimming with childhood friends in an abandoned waste pit they called Acid Lake. In fact, Mr. Durnil acknowledges in "The Making of a Conservative Environmentalist" that he possessed absolutely no qualifications for one of the continent's senior environmental posts, other than having served as Republican party chairman in Indiana and cultivating a close political friendship with former Vice President Dan Quayle.
How could such a naif advance one of the single boldest environmental policy ideas of the 1990's? The answer, we are told, is a simple tale of personal discovery. A Midwestern party operative late in life suddenly awakens to find truth in the popular concern for the safety of the earth. The message is that if someone as conventional and as conservative as Mr. Durnil can latch on to one of the great social transformations of the American century, then so can every other Republican in the country.
The fact that they have not, particularly this year when Republican leaders in the House and the Senate are desperately trying to unravel 25 years of environmental regulation, has Mr. Durnil in a gentlemanly lather. Instead of listening to the drumbeat of broad public support for clean air and clean water, Mr. Durnil writes, conservative lawmakers are stoking their campaigns with corporate cash and adopting the knuckleheaded antiregulatory ideas of lobbyists.
It is an easy trap to fall into. As a professional party insider, Mr. Durnil says he watched unquestioningly as industrial money made his campaigns' wheels turn. But as an international policy adviser advocating a position at odds with that of his old lobbyist friends, Mr. Durnil writes, he saw how insidiously industry wielded its influence. "On my tour with the International Joint Commission I watched the chemical industry, through its lobbyists, fight any potential for change and then try to avoid responsibility for its actions." He adds, "Rather than join the dialogue regarding the responsibility we all have to future generations, their typical tactic was to disrupt such dialogue."
Such firsthand reporting makes this earnest book both exasperating and intriguing. Mr. Durnil draws few substantive conclusions about what he witnessed, other than the obvious: industry plays by its own rules and ordinary people are getting hurt. The book also leaves too many questions unanswered. What, for example was the reaction of Mr. Quayle -- who spent his tenure as Vice President advocating that restrictions on industry be reduced -- when his Indiana political buddy urged a ban on industrial uses of chlorine, an act tantamount to ending the cutting of forests for paper and lumber?
Still, Mr. Durnil has some useful observations after five years in the trenches of the environmental policy wars. Scientists, he says, are too reticent about recommending action, despite having enough evidence to do so. Environmentalists are prone to drifting off into "dream-world words." The press suffers from a "lack of preparedness," and most government officials, he says, behave as though they'd been injected with "a shot of Novocain."
Given this striking lack of leadership, Mr. Durnil says, there is ample opportunity for Republicans to reap long-lasting political benefits by taking a new interest in safeguarding health and nature. Alas, that is a lesson that too many conservatives still seem not the least bit interested in learning.

HEADLINE: Famous Long Ago

BYLINE: By Anthony Gottlieb; Anthony Gottlieb is on the staff of The Economist. He is writing a history of Western philosophy.

 BODY:

HYPATIA OF ALEXANDRIA
By Maria Dzielska.
Translated by F. Lyra.
157 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
Harvard University Press. $29.95. 
 THE transformation of Hypatia of Alexandria into St. Catherine of Alexandria is arguably the biggest act of chutzpah in hagiography. A pagan scholar and philosopher, Hypatia was wise, virtuous, adored by those who flocked to hear her and a fearsome match for any intellectual opponent. She was murdered by her Christian enemies in 415 because they could not shut her up in any other way. Even better, from a dramatic point of view, or so Hypatia's legend came to have it, this beautiful young virgin was tortured by a gang of slobbering men before they finished her off. Such a story was much too good to waste on a non-Christian. So the colorful tale was expropriated in the Middle Ages and recast with Catherine, a fourth-century Christian murdered by pagans, in the starring role instead. According to the old hagiographies, this St. Catherine was put on the wheel and killed because she cleverly confuted the pagan sophists sent to argue her out of her faith. It sounded better that way.
Half of the truth behind this historical mix-up began to emerge in the 16th century, when the myth of St. Catherine was punctured. But Hypatia started to attract her own mythmakers -- who are active to this day, as Maria Dzielska of the Jagiellonian University in Cracow shows in this fascinating study. Ever since Hypatia got a good write-up from Voltaire and in Gibbon's "Decline and Fall," she has enjoyed a secular version of canonization. She may never have become the patron saint of wheelwrights, mechanics and the University of Paris or the tutelary saint of nuns and virgins or had a firework named after her, but Hypatia has inspired a large and fanciful literature. For more than two centuries, she has popped up in plays, poems and novels in English, Italian, German and French. She is the heroine of at least three recent historical novels. Two feminist academic journals have taken her name.
Hypatia was, like her father, a distinguished mathematician as well as the leading Platonic philosopher of her day. She commanded respect not only as a teacher and a paragon of probity but as a wise counselor in civil affairs. But unfortunately for her, she was hated by the local bishop (later canonized as St. Cyril), whose men dragged her off and killed her. Because she was not a Christian, because she had scientific interests and because she lived toward the very end of ancient civilization, she has been portrayed as a defender of science against religion, as a doomed representative of the values of pre-Christian antiquity and as the last candle of free inquiry to be snuffed out before the long night of clerical scholasticism. In his "History of Western Philosophy," Bertrand Russell wrote of "the lynching of Hypatia, a distinguished lady who, in an age of bigotry, adhered to the Neoplatonic philosophy and devoted her talents to mathematics. . . . After this Alexandria was no longer troubled by philosophers."
In fact, Hypatia was not the end of anything. Philosophy and science flourished in Alexandria a full century after her death (most notably in the person of John Philoponus, a Christian writer on physics and philosophy who was so astonishingly ahead of his time that he tends to be left out of history in order to keep the story simple). Nor, it seems, was Hypatia a martyr to paganism. Although she was certainly no believer in Christianity, she did not attend pagan temples either, or join those who opposed their conversion into churches. Some of her pupils were Christians, two of whom later became bishops.
The conclusion of Ms. Dzielska's meticulous and convincing argument is that Hypatia was assassinated for political reasons. She was caught in the middle of a struggle for power between Cyril and Orestes, the imperial prefect of Alexandria, with whom she was friendly. Cyril feared that such a powerful supporter made Orestes unbeatable, so he encouraged rumors that she was a witch and a troublemaker. A gang of Christian thugs employed by Cyril -- Alexandria was a rough place in those days -- apparently took matters into their own hands and decided to do the boss a favor by getting her out of the way. It seems that friends of Cyril's also beat up Orestes. In short, Hypatia was simply in the wrong place at the wrong time with the wrong friends.
None of Ms. Dzielska's evidence undermines her subject's appeal, unless you insist on having your heroines young. (It emerges that Hypatia was about 60 when she died.) In fact, her stature grows in the course of the author's trawl through letters, near-contemporary documents and the latest scholarship in obscure journals. This gem of academic detective work may be the last word on a subject that has fascinated for centuries. Perhaps, though, it will provide a starting point for even better novels.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 16; Column 4; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 970 words

HEADLINE: RECORDINGS VIEW;
New Age Mists Envelop Traditional Irish Songs

BYLINE: By DAVID BROWNE; David Browne is the music critic for Entertainment Weekly.

 BODY:
AS YET ANOTHER SIGN that it's a small world after all, yesterday's Mongolian field recordings are today's accompaniment for Upper East Side wine and cheese parties. Ambient techno bands pepper their spacy noodlings with the bleatings of Asian folk singers; last year's brunch album of choice was a collection of centuries-old Gregorian chants.
It was only a matter of time before the same transformation overcame traditional Celtic music. Several years ago, the Irish folk-pop band Clannad had a worldwide hit with "Theme from Harry's Game," but it's unlikely that anyone did the jig to it. The song, with its breathy harmony singing and utter lack of rhythm, was the musical equivalent of a dark, tranquil moor. It could have easily passed for a movie theme or a car commercial. In fact, it was both -- the soundtrack of "Patriot Games" and the music for a Volkswagen ad. 
 "Theme From Harry's Game" is included on the new Clannad compilation, "Themes," one of a series of inaugural releases on Atlantic's new Celtic Heartbeat label. Along with Enya's "The Celts" and a slew of other new releases, the albums epitomize the vogue of Celtic New Age music, not for a pub but for the coffee bar just down the street from it.
The pioneer of Celtic easy-listening music is the Irish pianist Phil Coulter, who has brought his orchestrated, Mantovani-o'-the-mist instrumentals to concert halls in both England and America. Yet a new generation has taken that sound one step further. Celtic New Age has none of the rough-hewn voices, hearty sing-alongs, "diddley diddley" rhythms, or breakneck fiddle or accordion solos of the traditional style. Instead, the songs are wrapped in an electronic gauze and have only hints of folk melodies, and those melodies aren't so much sung as exhaled.
If this loftier, headier style has a Woody Guthrie, it is Enya (Eithne Ni Bhraonain), a former member of Clannad whose multiplatinum, smooth-as-ice albums "Watermark" and "Shepherd's Moon" have been heard at chic bistros as well as on the soundtrack of "Baywatch." "The Celts" (Reprise) isn't actually a new album; comprising music for a BBC series of the same name, it was first released in 1987 and has been remixed (it also includes one new track). Because it is a soundtrack, some of its songs last barely over a minute, and none have the quirky hooks of Enya's hit "Orinoco Flow (Sail Away)." Yet with its all-encompassing vocal massage, synthesizers that emulate harpsichords and its doe-eyed, soul-searching laments ("Don't know why/ Thoughts desert me"), it is quintessential Enya.
Enya's sister, Maire Brennan of Clannad, has a voice that matches her sibling's for purity but is even more of a blank slate. It is, unfortunately, an all-too-perfect match for the music. Clannad's "Themes," made up of songs written for, or used in, movies and television commercials, engulfs her voice in the band's watered-down pop. An occasional hint of tension arises -- as in the arresting chorus of "I Will Find You," Clannad's contribution to the 1992 movie "The Last of the Mohicans" -- but mostly the results are musical Irish oatmeal.
On her own, as on her latest solo album, "Misty Eyed Adventures" (Atlantic), Ms. Brennan takes a few more chances, tossing into the mix rattling percussion or an almost buoyant jig. But she often comes across as a second-hand Enya, offering a lifeless ode to the Irish climbers who conquered Mr. Everest ("The Mighty One") or zapping the spunk out of Joni Mitchell's cheeky ecology song, "Big Yellow Taxi."
The influence of both Enya and Clannad is heard in several other new recordings. "The Old Man and the Sea" (Mesa), the debut album by the Scottish trio the Color of Memory, favors the same mix of stultifying, breathy singing and abstract lyrics ("Into my own, guiding the light, enter the stream"). Bland as it is, the group is downright emotive compared with the Irish choir Anuna. Its debut album, "Anuna" (Celtic Heartbeat/Atlantic), sounds like an attempt to cash in on the Gregorian-chant craze. With harmonies that are pristine but often bloodless, the album comes off like accompaniment for a museum tour.
Celtic New Age has also left its mark on instrumental music, where tastefulness is emphasized over passion. "Blue Shamrock (Celtic Heartbeat/Atlantic), a collection of guitar and bouzouki pieces by the guitarist Alec Finn of the eclectic traditional band DeDannan, is little more than pleasant. More ambitious is Marie Breatnach's "The Voyage of Bran" (Celtic Heartbeat/Atlantic), a concept album not about keeping the digestive system regular but about the voyage of an 8th-century Irish sailor. The album runs aground with too many fusion saxophone instrumentals, but Ms. Breatnach's fiddle waltzes are often moving.
Even if some of this music makes listeners feel as if they are trapped in a Dublin elevator, the new Irish and Scottish chill-out music raises important questions: Should folk music resolutely hew to tradition? Or should it adapt to the times?
Perhaps an analogy to Celtic folk's American cousin, country music, provides an answer to that question. In America, young country fans relate more to the likes of Garth Brooks than to grizzled veterans like Waylon Jennings and Willie Nelson; the new country sound, a hybrid of 70's singer-songwriter pop and Southern rock, speaks to them, as do the song's themes of suburban angst. The same goes for Celtic New Age and its audience. If anything, the Irish have even more problems to confront, like staggeringly high unemployment.
Given such circumstances, the new genre of Celtic New Age pop is, in its own way, as much of its time as American country. It is music that reacts to the deep problems of the contemporary British Isles, not with leaps and bounds but with one long, sorrowful sigh.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Marie Breatnach--Often moving fiddle waltzes, but too many fusion saxophone instrumentals.; Maire Brennan of Clannad. (Photographs from Atlantic Records)

LENGTH: 919 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Suburban Dreams and Nightmares

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

 BODY:
MOTHER is alcoholic. Dad is broke. Sister is promiscuous and brother is a superficial fool. Welcome to "A Cheever Evening," a sampler of the lowly emotional, psychic and moral estate of elite wannabes, as disserved by A. R. Gurney at the Westport Country Playhouse.
Though Mr. Gurney has long labored under the influence of John Cheever, the similarity between the two writers is skin deep; the differences as disparate as hollowness and vastness. Cheever wrote with a sense of mortal pain that does not intrude on Mr. Gurney's terrain. It's not for nothing that Mr. Gurney has been, by now tiresomely, labeled the official chronicler of WASP culture. 
 Cheever, who died at his home in Ossining in 1982 at the age of 70, evoked Chekhovian longings, plumbing the depths of the soul's unrest. Mr. Gurney writes of a safe discontent without alienation; Cheever dealt with spiritual unhappiness, whatever the cost.
Culling 17 Cheever stories into what he calls a theatrical tapestry, Mr. Gurney has assigned to six actors a multitude of roles. Interactive recitation alternates with dialogue that switches to description, in a flash, in a playgoer's digest of abridged selections to highlight predetermined themes. The evening serves up snippets of several stories, more extended selections from others, while excerpts of some recur in the context of still others.
In defeat of a grandly intended homage, the elegant prose of a masterly weaver of short stories becomes tedious and repetitive. It's a counterproductive thing that a little of "A Cheever Evening" goes a very long way.
It isn't long before one gets the point. This tapestry is laced with recriminations masked by proprieties, the "specious rites and ceremonies," the all-consuming concealments of suburbia's entrapments.
Here is a last generation of "captives of financial and sentimental commitments." They settle in apartments near Sutton Place until houses in Scarsdale are graspable.
Then they bicker, recalling better times. What happens as soon as they get what they presumably want? They wallow in sheer pointlessness. Husbands are bored with their wives' extravagances. Wives are fed up with their husbands' insensitivities. Miserable relationships. Disastrous marriages. Adultery. Divorce. And so it goes.
This is the world of smooth roads, manicured lawns, boarding schools, dancing schools, schools excellent and exclusive, schools restricted and segregated.
"Where have we gone wrong?" is the question of the evening. It is followed by "Is divorce so dreadful?" and "Is marriage the most wonderful thing in the world?"
"We're happy, aren't we?" asks one wife.
"Of course we're happy," insists her husband, gulping hard, eyes rolling.
Married for 20 years, one husband remarks after dinner: "And somehow we made it through another meal."
While this sort of story-theater style sounds like an actor's dream, it doesn't work out that way, although Jennifer Van Dyck, of last year's original Off Broadway cast with Jack Gilpin, is effective at registering free-floating dread. Yet, because of the sketchiness of the pieces, there's little chance to explore character, except in terms of knee-jerk desperation or shallow caricature.
Because Dana Ivey, in particular, is so accomplished at icy remove and real sophisticated wit, one has the odd sense that she could have phoned it all in. That includes her stints as a wife whining about her ailments, a woman coveting her neighbor's luxuries, a renegade 78-year-old waltzing on ice at Rockefeller Center and a hoity-toity mother who prefers flowers to food (if given the choice) and had no tolerance for Jews.
Jonathan Walker plays a boozy father dragging his underage son (Laurence Luckinbill) from one restaurant to another for lunch. But no one will serve the teen-ager a martini. The story is "Reunion"; none are identified in the program. Mr. Luckinbill and Karen Valentine play lovers meeting clandestinely.
Ms. Valentine is also a "sweet little daughter," a new wife in town ("The Chaste Clarissa") who is "as stupid as she is beautiful," a grown-up daughter regressing to having tantrums on the floor, and a vindictive wife who shrieks: "You've ruined my life" to the husband who goes on calling her sweetheart. Meanwhile, she pours lighter fluid on the salad and bastes the lamb chops with pesticide.
Mr. Luckinbill as an unemployed midnight robber breaks into neighbors' homes to steal their money, safe in the knowledge that he won't disrupt the deep sleep of those who "fight a lot and drink a lot." That's from the story "The Housebreaker of Shady Hill."
Neither Mr. Luckinbill nor Ms. Valentine, under Nicholas Martin's understated direction, rise to the showy opportunites of the transitions from character to character.
No matter that the second act moves from the "hill towns" of Westchester to a rented New England seaside house where summer folks look to "rent their happiness." The air remains static and claustrophobic, with all credits to Susan Roth's subtle lighting shifts.
Besides gin and vermouth, old-fashioneds, Scotch ("What Republicans drink") and even a glass of port are ever-recurring reinforcements. Given the glossy veneer with which Mr. Gurney has condensed Cheever's concerns, one character's advice ("Make yourself a drink") sounds like a ripping idea rather than denial's despairing command.
"A Cheever Evening," Westport Country Playhouse, 25 Powers Court, Westport. 227-4177. Performances through Saturday.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Laurence Luckinbill, Jennifer Van Dyck and Karen Valentine in "A Cheever Evening" by A. R. Gurney, playing at the Westport Country Playhouse through Saturday. (Jayson Byrd)

HEADLINE: Life After The Westchester: All Business

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
HITE PLAINS
FIVE months after an upscale regional shopping center opened for business here, other retail activity in the city appears to be thriving -- deflecting for now predictions from some quarters that an older shopping area, a discount center and other smaller stores would languish in the shadows of The Westchester's 2.5 million square feet.
Retail business is up citywide, which in the last two years has become the major shopping destination between New York City and Stamford. And each shopping area seems to have targeted a different type of customer -- what analysts refer to as niche marketing. 
 At the Galleria, a 15-year-old mall less than a mile from The Westchester, the lines at checkout counters last weekend were long with back-to-school shoppers, who did not need a retail analyst to tell them why the older, smaller and less-glitzy shopping center continued to draw crowds.
"The bottom line is that the price is right here," said Doris King, a shopper at Waldenbooks in the Galleria. "I like visiting The Westchester because it's so pretty, but it's too expensive for my pocketbook."
Some customers shop both malls. And like Mark Kaplow, who was at the 880,000-square-foot Galleria last weekend with his wife, Pamela, and their twin sons, 9-year-old Scott and Jeff, those customers visit each for a different reason.
"We're at the Galleria to buy posters for the boys, and for that we don't need a Neiman Marcus," Mr. Kaplow said, referring to one of the anchor stores at The Westchester.
By contrast to the price-conscious shopper at the Galleria, those frequenting The Westchester's 118 stores are "an upscale clientele, customers with household incomes of $95,000 and more," said John P. Hoeller, the manager of The Westchester. He said that mall's two anchors, Neiman Marcus and Nordstrom, "set the tone for us."
While Nordstrom markets itself as a mid-priced value-oriented department store, it also features live piano music and other upscale shopping amenities. Neiman Marcus unabashedly markets itself as a store for the well-heeled, with its Christmas catalogue last year featuring a jeweled teddy bear for $200,000.
At the Galleria, two moderate-price department stores, J. C. Penney and Stern's, anchor the 150 shops there and cater to "a mid-price audience," said Cindy Bohde, vice president for the Urban Retail Properties Company in Chicago.
"Each mall appeals to very different audiences," she said, "and one doesn't take away from the other."
Stores at the Galleria -- which underwent a $12 million face-lifting last year on its 14th birthday -- earn about $400 a year per square foot, "which is very, very good for a shopping center," she said.
Projecting early sales, Mr. Hoeller at The Westchester said stores there also appear to be earning about $400 a square foot, with Williams-Sonoma, Pottery Barn, Crate and Barrel, Ann Taylor and Eileen Fisher among the top performers.
Adding to an already full retail equation, the Westchester Pavilion, which is close to The Westchester, offers shoppers 173,000 square feet of discount stores like the Sports Authority, Borders Books and Music, Office Max and Toys 'R' Us. The Pavilion, too, is thriving, said Carl R. Esser, a director for Jones Lang Wootton Retail Management in Dallas. "One mall feeds off the other, like automobile dealers in the same area," he said.
Shortly after the Westchester Pavilion opened last year, it was beset with lawsuits from unpaid contractors and possible foreclosure proceedings. It was sold by its original owner, Fischer Reese Associates of White Plains, to the State of Wisconsin Investment Board, which took over the mall's mortgage and hired Jones Lang Wootton Retail Management. Remaining legal actions, mainly liens by contractors, including C. W. Brown of Thornwood against some of the mall's tenants, "have nothing to do with the mall itself," Mr. Esser said.
The Westchester Pavilion is considered a power mall, and its tenants are referred to as "category killers" because they offer extensive discount selections in many categories of merchandise. Mr. Esser said the tenants were "doing $300 to $500 a square foot of business a year, which is excellent for big-box retailers."
Not to be left out of the burgeoning retail scene, Saks Fifth Avenue, which is across the street from The Westchester, announced plans earlier this month to renovate its 120,000-square-foot store and to bring in other retailers on the six-acre site there.
Bloomingdale's, too, has announced plans to expand its 250,000-square-foot store, which is less than a mile from Saks Fifth Avenue and The Westchester on a site owned by New York Hospital. Bloomingdale's leases the property from the hospital under the terms of a 99-year agreement.
In the face of increasing economic pressure, the hospital announced plans in the spring to allow for expansion of the 20-year-old Bloomingdale's store and the construction of a supermarket, upscale restaurant and perhaps another department store.
Geoff Thompson, a partner in Thompson & Bender, a public-relations firm that represents the hospital, said New York Hospital planned to situate one of the entrances to its park-like shopping area near the main entrance to The Westchester, to reduce the distance between them. "Bloomingdale's was feeling isolated," he said, "and it was not unaware of the competition."
One retail analyst observed that Bloomingdale's and Saks were taking risks in expanding to meet the competition, but that their decisions appeared well-calculated.
"They're making an educated guess that they have to either remodel or leave town, because if they don't spiff up now, they may not be in the game in a few years," said Howard L. Davidowitz, chairman of the retail analysts Davidowitz & Associates in Manhattan.
White Plains -- which in an earlier heyday was called the City of 1,000 Stores and may soon deserve that description again -- offers yet another option for shoppers: a 352,000-square-foot Macy's department store near the Galleria.
But Federated Department Stores, which owns Macy's, agreed last year to sell its White Plains store and five others in an antitrust agreement with G. Oliver Koppell, who was then State Attorney General. Mr. Koppell no longer holds that post, and because the agreement was never made final, the store may remain open. Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco has been studying the matter.
Mary Ann Shannon, a Federated spokeswoman, would not say if the White Plains store would close or remain open. She also refused to comment on unconfirmed reports that Macy's would co-anchor the new Bloomingdale's shopping area.
Meanwhile, some analysts are worried about whether the current wealth of different shopping experiences in White Plains can survive the competition.
"We think the market in White Plains is becoming oversaturated, redundant," said Robert E. Kerson, managing partner for the retail analysts Levy, Kerson, Aronson & Associates in Manhattan. "There's a lot of cross-shopping among the better stores like Bloomingdale's, Nordstrom's, Saks and Neiman Marcus."
He said that despite public relations comments to the contrary his firm believes The Westchester got off to a slower start than expected and that the Galleria is struggling to keep pace. "You have to wonder about how these malls are really doing, because there is only a certain amount of disposable income in an area," Mr. Kerson said.
But Mr. Hoeller said The Westchester was logging close to 12,000 cars in its parking areas on a Saturday and up to 7,500 cars on Sundays and weekdays. "That is precisely as we expected," he said.
While Ms. Bohde at the Galleria did not have comparable figures, she said that of the 112 regional shopping centers managed by Urban Retail Properties, the Galleria continued to be a "top performer."
In general, retail observers saw the intense competition as healthy. The city's Finance Commissioner, John T. Powell, reported that sales-tax receipts were up 25 percent for the fiscal year 1994-95, and at least some of that was attributable to the opening of The Westchester and other new retail activity in the city.
Stefanie Elkins, a spokeswoman for the International Council of Shopping Centers in Manhattan, said that each mall in White Plains was "fulfilling a need."
She also said that in general, the principle of clustering of malls and shopping centers works well, because shoppers begin to view an area as "a retail destination."
A similar clustering of retailers has taken place in Buckland Hills in Connecticut in the last five years. "One opened and the others followed," she said. "The competition was more helpful than harmful."
"But as far as White Plains goes, the situation bears watching," she said. "We have to see how it all shakes down."
