SECTION: Section 6; Part 2; Page 124; Column 1; Fashions of The Times Magazine

LENGTH: 835 words

HEADLINE: BEACH DREAMS

BYLINE: By CYNTHIA ZARIN; Cynthia Zarin's most recent book of poems is "Fire Lyric." She is a frequent contributor to The Times Magazine.

 BODY:
The paraphernalia of summer is different from the trappings of fall. In summer the dowry of the world turns Day-Glo; what in autumn will be somber, hemstitched, restrained, in summer is silly, outre, a mess. The shy student who in October will wear a black beret enlivened by one small diamante pin in summer slouches slack-jawed by the water, wearing a hat the color of a tiger lily. To Henry Adams, writing about his boyhood in New England a century and a half ago, summer was drunken and winter was school. When I was a child my parents owned a bungalow in the woods with a view of a cove; when we arrived I would go around the back of the house and look for my reflection, 11 months older, in the kitchen window. The bayberry and scrub pine shone greenly through me so that I became, in the wavy kitchen glass, not a product of the heavy, ponderous year but a mirage, a figment of summer. For the last 15 or 20 years, through the Indian summer of adolescence, through marriage and motherhood, I have worn exactly the same clothes in August; paradoxically, it is the month in which I have thought most elaborately about clothes. In other months I have dressed like a mountaineer, like Hippolyta, like a French chambermaid, like a schoolboy, like Janis Joplin. Some years it is a wearing business, and sometimes it is less so.
Through it I observe with passion and awe my friends whose dress stays constant: for a time I worked alongside a woman who had made whatever economies were necessary to wear only clothes by Sonia Rykiel. One morning she appeared in a Missoni jacket; it was as if she had joined a vaudeville troupe and changed her name. I am deeply envious of what others might see as obsession but I see as organization of a high order; this envy accompanies my desire for the contemplative life, for convents and the hush of long corridors, for vespers and ecclesiastical dress. In this guise I imagine myself aging in a small but not provincial town -- Vezelay or Bevagna -- wearing a wool skirt by Valentino, a blouse and very good shoes, worn but cared for.
But in August the costume designer in me is visiting her aged mother in Cap d'Antibes. Content in her absence I wear an Indian-print wrap skirt, old enough for a coming-out party, and a gray T-shirt with a picture of a steer and a slogan that reads, "TEXAS RANGERS." I have no affiliation with Texas, nor any with the location advertised by my other summer shirt: "The Beurre Blanc Yacht Club." I have a pair of gray shorts, a pair of mustard, too-short linen pants from Fiorucci that were given over to me by the first wife of a childhood sweetheart, and a sundress printed with menacing tropical fish. There is also a cotton jacket in an unpleasant shade of blue. None of these garments is remotely becoming. They smell of salt, and I cling to them because they are my summer skin. Years ago my mother had a pink hooded sweatshirt that she wore at the beach. During the winter months of exile from the ocean I would go to the cupboard and bury my face in it.
If we are lucky, as children in summer we are covered in salt and sand and scratched by brambles; we don't think for a minute about what we wear because we live in our skins. Ten years later on the same spit of sand we think without ceasing about what we wear because we have become naked in the garden; we fear not the sun but the harsh, curious gazes of our friends. When we grow up, we live again in our skins; we care, but not as desperately, about our bodies, which have after all been put to use and which in any case are buried in the sand every day by our children. Like workers on a vast plain we wear large hats to shield our faces from the sun; our bathing suits are like armor for beetles.
A moment later it is September. Like children we pull up our socks, buckle our shoes, button our overcoats, but the questions for those of us still deep in the dress-up box are: What socks? Which shoes? Whose overcoat?
I cling to my summer clothes as a charm both for and against change. To wear them is to become again the mirage in the window who, for that moment, could be anyone, but who still needs, come the fall, to get dressed; to wear them is evidence that, indeed, as anyone can see, I have nothing to wear. "Beware of all enterprises that require new clothes," wrote Thoreau. Beware, comes a voice, of those that don't. "Three prs. black tights," "School shoes (green suede??)," "Brown velvet dress p. 83," read the lists that surface now and then, written decades ago, as I sat with my mother on the beach studying the premature fall fashion magazines, from which sheathed, impossibly elegant versions of ourselves beckoned like silent screen stars. "WHITE dress. Buckles?" reads a later, cryptic list. It is an easy thing to do at the edge of the water: to rummage among the bright pages for a scarf, a hat, an evening gown, here at the tail end of summer, where the earliest creatures first crawled out on land and tried on their new shadows.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 9; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1574 words

HEADLINE: The Companies He Keeps

BYLINE: By John Rothchild; John Rothchild is the financial columnist for Time magazine and the co-author of the Peter Lynch books, "One Up on Wall Street" and "Beating the Street."

 BODY:

BUFFETT
The Making of an American Capitalist.
By Roger Lowenstein.
Illustrated. 473 pp. New York:
Random House.
$27.50. 
 BACK when he was only a millionaire, Warren E. Buffett took the tour of William Randolph Hearst's castle at San Simeon. Fed up with hearing the tour guide recite the prices Hearst had paid for the contents, Mr. Buffett apparently piped up: "Don't tell us how he spent it. Tell us how he made it!" In this engaging biography, Roger Lowenstein tells not only how Mr. Buffett made it but how he has managed to avoid spending it -- the most fascinating part of the story.
By the latest tally, Warren Buffett is running neck and neck with Bill Gates as the richest man in the country. In the annals of American tycoonery, we've seen shipping magnates, oil barons, media moguls and real estate developers reach the pinnacle of wealth, but Mr. Buffett is the first stock picker. His $10 billion is an inspiration to stock pickers everywhere, and also a painful reminder that the rest of us must have been picking the wrong stocks.
Much has been written about Mr. Buffett's methods, but far less about the man, so there were a lot of blanks for Mr. Lowenstein, a Wall Street Journal reporter, to fill with "Buffett: The Making of an American Capitalist." He ran into an immediate problem: the best source wasn't talking. Mr. Buffett played the sphinx (as he often does with writers), neither collaborating nor interfering, leaving it up to Mr. Lowenstein to figure him out. It's the same hands-off approach Mr. Buffett takes with managers at the various companies in which he owns the biggest chunk of the shares.
Free to pursue the Buffett topic without undue influence from Mr. Buffett, Mr. Lowenstein coaxed details out of his subject's children, cronies, business partners, high school chums and many others. The result is a delightful portrait of a homespun capitalist straight out of Carl Sandburg, until you get to the exceptions. Mr. Buffett has little use for Wall Street shenanigans, except that he got himself involved in the recent turmoil at Salomon Brothers; he enjoys simple pleasures ("All Warren needs to be happy is a book and a 60-watt bulb," his wife once said), except for the corporate jet; he lives in semi-seclusion in Omaha, except when he's hobnobbing with the likes of Bill Clinton or Dolly Parton; he and his wife are still married, except that he hasn't lived with her in almost 20 years. He lives with someone else, but continues to see his wife.
Mr. Buffett's cradle wasn't papered with stock certificates, but there were numerous indications of what lay ahead. Born in 1930, he was, by the age of 4, running around the house with a money-changer strapped to his belt. At 7 he suffered a mysterious and near-fatal illness that landed him in a hospital bed. Almost delirious, he handed the nurse a page of scrawled calculations and told her they represented his future capital. Like John D. Rockefeller, Warren Buffett knew he was destined to be rich, and wasn't shy about saying so.
In adolescence, Mr. Buffett was a walking conglomerate of profitable enterprises: selling tip sheets to bettors at the Omaha race track; running two paper routes simultaneously; scavenging for out-of-bounds golf balls that he then resold to the previous owners; buying Cokes wholesale in six-packs and peddling them retail to the summer crowd at the local lake; installing secondhand pinball machines in barbershops, in direct competition with the Mafia.
The budding capitalist was hoarding his capital by instinct, looking for a theory to channel his pecuniary drive, attracted to stocks but not to Wall Street. He found his mentor in the classroom of the Columbia University professor Benjamin Graham. Graham had made a discovery that was revolutionary at the time: stocks are not poker chips; they are claim checks on businesses that have real worth.
This was in the 1950's, when stock prices had only recently returned to the highs they'd set in 1929, and when the very words "stock market" evoked the same image as the words "Las Vegas" do today. Individuals didn't invest in stocks so much as "play the market." When people thought of great fortunes made on Wall Street, they thought of the robber barons of the 19th century, or the banking tycoons whose antics had been investigated by Congress after the crash of '29. Mr. Buffett has proved you can get rich on stocks without scandal, and Ben Graham taught him how to do it.
The United States economy was entering a new era of stability, in which recessions no longer led to depressions or panics, and companies, for the first time in American history, were making steady profits. Suddenly, Warren Buffett had found his calling: searching for the bargains that Graham called "cigar butts," companies whose intrinsic value was greater than the market value of their stock. This required math, at which Mr. Buffett excelled; a maverick's disdain for conventional wisdom, which he had; plus money to buy the stocks, which he soon raised.
In the 1960's, Mr. Buffett acquired a controlling interest in a textile mill, Berkshire Hathaway, which he has used ever since as a holding company for all his other cigar butts (Coca-Cola, Gillette, Capital Cities/ ABC, the Washington Post Company, etc.). Since Berkshire Hathaway is publicly traded, anybody could have invested right along with him, including this reviewer, who is still kicking himself for not having risked $1,000 on the man after coming into contact with him in the early 1970's. That $1,000 would be worth $368,000 today.
Beyond the stock-picking arena, Mr. Lowenstein breaks new ground with his annals of Buffett the skinflint. By my rough calculation, Mr. Buffett could give himself an allowance of $8 million a month without dipping into his capital, yet he continues to reside in Omaha, in the same house he bought in 1957 for $31,500. The housekeeper comes in once every two weeks.
Mr. Lowenstein tells us how Katharine Graham, when she was the publisher of The Washington Post, once found herself in an airport with Mr. Buffett, The Post's biggest investor as well as her confidant and sometime dinner companion. She needed to make a quick phone call and asked him for the dime (the going rate in those days). He fished a quarter out of his pocket and wandered off to get change. "Warren," Mrs. Graham snapped, "give me the quarter!"
When his wife purchased $15,000 worth of home furnishings, he complained to a friend, "Do you know how much that is if you compound it over 20 years?" This is an important clue to Mr. Buffett's modus operandi. He's always thinking in terms of the future value of money, so every dollar spent today is a lost opportunity to make $10 a few years out. This may be the best argument for penny-pinching ever devised.
Mr. Lowenstein also makes a great deal of the fact that Mr. Buffett hangs on to everything: his house; his Cherry Cokes (in the 1980's he took the drastic step of switching from Pepsi); the shares in his portfolio, where the annual turnover is less than the daily turnover of the average mutual fund; and his shares in Berkshire Hathaway (he's never sold a single one).
He has hung on to his wife as well. She's Susan Buffett, a nurturing and sympathetic companion who tenderized Mr. Buffett and brought out the best in him, but then left him during a midlife crisis in 1977 to pursue other interests, principally torch singing. Mr. Buffett refused to let go, even after she helped fix him up with a replacement in Omaha, Astrid Menks. To this day, he escorts Mrs. Buffett to various functions outside of Omaha and lives happily with Ms. Menks in Omaha. "If you knew everybody well, you'd understand it quite well," Mr. Buffett has said of this curious troika.
 MR. BUFFETT has also maintained a close relationship with his three children by Susan, but as you might have guessed, very little money is trickling down. He has long contended that inherited wealth is bad for the recipients, as well as for society in general. Kay Graham may have persuaded him to soften his stance and at least leave his children a week's worth of interest in his will; otherwise, the rest is going to charity in what promises to be the biggest bequest in history.
Generally, Mr. Lowenstein sticks to the facts and refrains from psychoanalyzing the man he's never interviewed, except in the spots where he talks about Mr. Buffett's death phobia. Is it possible, Mr. Lowenstein wonders, that the real reason he amassed all of those billions and held on to his wife, his stocks, his house and his Cherry Coke is that he's terrified of facing the Grim Reaper alone? Is Berkshire Hathaway merely the barricade that stands between Mr. Buffett and the inevitable?
Aside from this odd and unconvincing bit of speculation, everything else rings true, and Mr. Lowenstein has done a masterly job over all. Once again, Mr. Buffett was right not to meddle in the business at hand, and in spite of his not saying anything directly to the author, Mr. Lowenstein has picked up numerous examples of his wit. Here's an exchange from the annual meeting of Berkshire Hathaway, when a questioner in the crowd expressed fear of Mr. Buffett's death:
"I'm thinking of making a purchase of Berkshire," the person said, "but I'm concerned about something happening to you, Mr. Buffett. I cannot afford an event risk."
Came the reply: "Neither can I."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Warren E. Buffett as chairman of Salomon Brothers, an interim appointment, in 1991. Deryck C. Maughan, right, succeeded him. (THE NEW YORK TIMES)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Biography; Review

HEADLINE: Where Good Bridges Make Good Neighbors

BYLINE: By Verlyn Klinkenborg; Verlyn Klinkenborg, the author of "Making Hay," is working on a book about horse trainers.

DATELINE: BIG HORN, Wyo.

 BODY:
It's been a good grass year in this part of Wyoming half a state away from the Presidential penumbra cast by the vacationing Clintons -- a late spring, plenty of water, intermittent thunderstorms, just enough rain to put some extra hurry into haying. My neighbors, Alan and Gayle Barnett and their two boys, are rushing, as all ranchers do in August, to use the light and heat of these long days in a way that won't bring regret come winter.
Last month, my girlfriend and I walked with Gayle and our dogs, Tavish and Rooster, up a gravel road to visit Alan at the haystacks he was building. It was nearly 10 P.M., and Alan had been up since 4:30 that morning. Light hung in the sky as though it was never going to grow dark. It had been a hot day and the bales still held the warmth of the sun -- "field heat," Alan calls it. 
 The ranchers I know have pretty much given up on the distinction between night and day. Last weekend, outside Riverton, 150 miles southeast of Jackson Hole, ranchers were cutting and raking and baling all through the night, partly to get out of the heat and partly for reasons you would understand if you saw how far toward the horizon the hayfields stretch.
The hay was a very dark green, with overtones of blue, and it dried rapidly in the fierce sun. I thought I had been given wheat straw to feed my horse until I broke into the bale and saw its color, as true an indicator of quality as the deep maroon tint of raw tuna. A grass year this good is a rare thing.
I had gone to Riverton for a horse-training clinic, and by the time I arrived I remembered that Wyoming is a state you have to drive all the way across just to get to the middle of. On the highway between Casper and Riverton, there's not much to look at. It's dry, dusty ground. From time to time a ranch road cuts away at right angles, headed somewhere beyond the next rise. Cattle tend to bottle up in the wet spots, and sheep, for some reason, seek the bare, eroded gullies, or perhaps it's just that they erode any gully they happen to occupy.
As good as the grass has been, that's how bad the cattle prices are this summer. I don't offer that as a formula, just fact. A friend of mine, the horse trainer I'd gone to Riverton to see, was working with a rank young colt, the kind of horse sometimes called a canner -- a grim reminder that the floor value of any horse is its price-per-pound at the slaughterhouse door. My friend said, "Cattle prices being what they are this year, you'd do better raising canners than cattle." It was a sad joke, and the small crowd standing around the corral laughed, appreciating its sadness.
There might have been more people at the horse-training clinic if the cattle prices weren't so bad. One thing dividing small ranchers from the rest of us is the trouble we have imagining what it's like when the amount of cash in your pocket depends directly on the dollar value of the beasts that are grazing your summer pasture. It's painful to think that your herd of cattle could be standing knee deep in good Wyoming grass, gaining weight and losing value.
When I got back from Riverton, I asked Alan Barnett about the talk I'd heard in Riverton of low cattle prices. "A friend just invited me to a big weekend roping," he said, nodding. "Seems like every weekend there's a big roping. But if you haven't got some extra cash, you don't go. We decided to put our effort into the boys' riding. It's what we wanted to do as a family."
I asked him why cattle prices had dropped, and he brought up the North American Free Trade Agreement. "Fat Canadian cattle, Mexican cattle being trucked to our slaughterhouses and sold on our streets," he said. "I'm open-minded. If Nafta's good for the economy of the whole country, that's just fine. But it sure is hurting us."
What's hurting is the fact that calves were selling for a dollar a pound 18 months ago; the other day Alan sold his at 66 cents. And though many ranchers blame Nafta for the drop, the rules in the industry didn't change when the trade agreement passed. Over the last four years, ranchers in the United States as well as Canada have built up their herds. Meanwhile, a drought in northern Mexico and the collapse of the peso, combined with the free trade pact, have driven substantial numbers of Mexican cattle into the American market.
Other than cattle prices, the Clintons' vacation up in the Rockefeller fastness at Jackson Hole has been the talk of Wyoming. There was even a rumor that the President was going to saddle up and join the Great American Cattle Drive, which passed through Sheridan this week -- men on horseback driving 250 cattle from Fort Worth to Miles City, Mont. But the nearest he has gotten to people who depend on livestock was a rain-drenched rodeo in Jackson Hole, to which he wore cowboy boots and a bolo tie.
What my neighbors tend to talk about is the Presidential cigars, the Presidential golf clubs, the Presidential walk along the shores of Jenny Lake. ("It's a great thing for our country to have something like this," he said. "Fabulous!") It's too bad that Mr. Clinton isn't able to vacation in the agricultural economy of Wyoming, rather than in its tourist economy. But then wherever a President goes he carries a tourist economy with him. As one rancher put it, the Clinton vacation "epitifies" Washington.
I asked Alan what he thought about the President's visit. "It's got nothing to do with us," he said, a note of dismissal in his voice. We talked about horses for a while, and then we talked about a wooden bridge that he and some friends and neighbors had rebuilt last month.
"My dad taught me and I'm trying to teach my boys that there's nothing worse than a bad neighbor," said Alan. "But there's nothing better than a good neighbor."
He paused, letting this thought drift back over our conversation, as if to suggest that the relationship between the Federal Government and farmers and ranchers should somehow go beyond agricultural policy and subsidies and trade agreements. His silence implied that even when its intentions are good, the Government rarely knows how to be a good neighbor. "Bill Clinton doesn't know what that bridge means to me," he added. "I couldn't have built it by myself. I couldn't have done it."
I had been one of the people at the bridge-building. It was another hot day, and to Alan it had probably been a relief to get out of the hayfields and into the cool water of Little Goose Creek. When we were finished pouring cement for the piers and abutments, each of us inscribed something -- a name, initials, a paw print -- in the wet cement. I found a horseshoe and we set that in cement, too. Then we sat in the shade in Alan's yard and had a beer.
Last night, I rode my horse over that bridge. The wood still looks green, and the lag bolts are still shiny. My horse, Adeline, is doing fine. I didn't know how fine until I took her to Riverton. She and I stood in the corral there, in some dire heat, hayfields all around us, and she made me look good. Looking westward from the corral I could see the Wind River Range shouldering its way up to the Tetons and Jackson Hole, which seemed farther away than it ever had. I tried to imagine what the President and Mrs. Clinton were doing at that very moment. But it was too hot to think.

HEADLINE: Millions of Mothers Can't Choose Not to Work

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Yes, Motherhood Lowers Pay" (Op-Ed, Aug. 22), Danielle Crittenden misses the point in a way that has become frighteningly familiar in an era dominated by right-wing rhetoric. She seems to think all families are similar in composition to her own and that the choice mothers face is whether to stay home while their husbands support the household financially or to find one of "the best nannies in the world." For far too many women there is no such choice. 
 Single mothers cannot rely on the earning power of another. And the sad reality of today's economy is that for many families it is simply not an option for one wage earner to leave the work force. For many couples the reality that women earn less for similar work means difficult economic times can become an almost unwinnable battle.
Ms. Crittenden' article is an example of the growing disconnect between better-off professionals and struggling working families. No one is asking government to subsidize day care so that mommy can become a partner at the law firm.
What many Americans do ask of their government is to make the burden of juggling financial responsibilities and parenthood manageable in a changing economic environment.
 
DAVID MERTZ
East Rockaway, L.I., Aug. 22, 1995

HEADLINE: Why Is a Seal Different From a Lamb?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "World's Last Baby Seal Hunt Is Jobs for Namibians" (Aug. 19): 
 If animal rights activists succeed in ending Namibia's harvest of seals it will be another example of Western environmentalists imposing their morality on a foreign nation and strangling an important source of jobs and income for a struggling economy. Aldert Brink, a seal harvester, has it right when he asks how seals differ from fish or cattle, and how their consumption and use, for whatever purpose, differ from other animal-based industries. To claim that the Namibian Government does not have the right to harvest a scientifically determined limit of young seals is like arguing that American ranchers have no right to slaughter lambs for our tables.
While in some regions seals may be endangered and should be protected, in Namibia more than one million seals compete for scarce food resources and breeding areas. Far more young seals are crushed by mature bulls or die of starvation in their first year than fall prey to the harvesters' clubs. Harvesting limits are re-evaluated annually based on careful studies of conditions and population levels.
Unlike most worldwide animal industries, the Namibian seal harvest results in no major alterations of the environment or food chain. Is this not more "environmental" than farming and ranching, which demand massive fencing, irrigation and alteration of the environment?
Our Western minds may find baby seals too cute to kill, and think seal-penis aphrodisiacs are a foolish and wasteful superstition. Yet how many of us indulge in juicy lamb chops without worrying about the "little lamb" or carry our keys on good-luck charms made of rabbits' feet?
The Namibian seal harvest provides essential jobs and brings valuable foreign currency to a young nation struggling to develop its economy and provide a decent standard of living. Having achieved our level of existence at least partly through far more exploitative use of natural and living resources, we are in no position to pass judgment on others.
 
GREGORY S. MILANO
San Francisco, Aug. 21, 1995

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Skilled Foreign Workers Gain American Jobs
Computer companies fondly predict a future in which millions of Americans desert their offices for laptops on tropical beaches. And corporate America is already getting a lot of work done on foreign shores, but some of it is not being done by Americans. Instead, businesses are paying well-educated foreign nationals to do the same tasks for a fraction of the cost. 
 Often, the new tools of the information age subject many white-collar Americans to the same global wage pressures their blue-collar counterparts have struggled with. [Page A1.]
 
The Smudging of Windows 95
Celebrity in America is a cycle that includes elements of adulation and homage, followed by skepticism and mockery. So in light of the shouted buildup to last week's introduction of Microsoft's Windows 95 operating system, how long did you really think it would take before the nation's cartoonists took their shots? [D3.]
 
For millions of "temps," the hourly workers who populate American businesses, doing the work of secretaries, bookkeepers and word processors, Microsoft's new operating system means going back to class for a crash course, or losing the chance of getting extra work and higher pay. [D3.]
 
Power to the Microprocessor
According to the digital revolutionaries at an Aspen, Colo., conference on issues arising from the information revolution, the age of electronic communications will transform the world's political, social and economic foundations just as the agricultural and industrial revolutions did -- only faster. Technology, Peter H. Lewis. [D3]
 
The Electronic Billboard
A community of innovators has developed in the business of computer graphic design. Their work is spread across the World Wide Web as they contract themselves out to companies hungry for an Internet presence. Taking In the Sites, Thomas W. Holcomb. [D9.]
 
NBC in Cyberspace
A new NBC service is offering around-the-clock news, detailed background material about subjects like the Balkan war and the O. J. Simpson trial, national and local weather forecasts and access to selections from the NBC News archives -- all in cyberspace. [D7.]
 
Big Games, Bigger Players
It used to be that the video game division was the second banana at the big media companies. But with sales of $10 billion last year, the game business is getting better and better billing, as Disney, Viacom and other media and entertainment giants are developing more and more of their material in house. [D7.]
 
Big Tobacco Fights Back
Under continuing demands to curtail cigarette advertising, tobacco companies are training their sights on the news media. Philip Morris has already been successful; ABC opted to apologize for a recent report on the industry rather than fight a big lawsuit. [D5.]
 
A U.S. Meeting With China?
Despite differences that remain unresolved, Beijing wants to go ahead with preparations for a meeting this fall between President Clinton and President Jiang Zemin. Such a restrained but positive outcome could signal some stabilization in the difficult Chinese-American relationship. [A1.]
 
A Dispute in Timberland
A month after the Clinton Administration bowed to Congressional demands that it allow the sale of more timber from public land, the legal wrangling has begun over expanded logging in the old-growth forests of the Northwest. At stake are Federal sales of timber in Oregon and Washington, mostly from forests that provide nesting sites for the Pacific marbled murrelet, an elusive sea-going bird threatened with extinction. [A13.]
 
Undercover and Over-the-Counter
In the malls of America, espionage shops peddle "invisible" inks and books on "secret" codes next to stun guns and electronic eavesdropping devices. This could be the harmless stuff of James Bond fantasies, but the Government thinks many of the products are potential tools for drug smugglers, kidnappers and unethical businessmen. [A10.]

HEADLINE: Philadelphia Shaken by Criminal Police Officers

BYLINE: By DON TERRY 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23

 BODY:
The congregation at Refuge Evangelical Baptist Church was rocking here last Sunday to glory songs, trumpets and the word of the Lord. But no one had a reason to shout "Hallelujah" louder than Betty (Mizzy) Patterson, a stout, 54-year-old grandmother in a flowered sun dress.
Mrs. Patterson, a widow, who cleaned other people's floors and clothes to keep her family together and now delivers newspapers before dawn with her grandson, was framed by corrupt police officers and spent three years in prison in the early 1990's after being falsely convicted of selling crack cocaine. 
 Mrs. Patterson and her church always knew she was innocent, but only in the last couple of months has the rest of the city learned the truth.
And although Philadelphia has been rocked by one police scandal after another in recent years, the new charges reveal a group of officers so corrupt, so calloused to the rights and welfare of residents, that the details have shaken this city to its roots.
Mrs. Patterson is one of dozens, perhaps even hundreds of victims of a band of five renegade officers who for at least three years haunted her predominantly poor and black North Philadelphia neighborhood, beating, robbing, lying and planting phony evidence on the good and the bad, Federal and local prosecutors said.
"She went to jail for three years for something she was apparently completely innocent of," said Lynne Abraham, the Philadelphia District Attorney. "This whole thing has made me physically ill. This is the ultimate betrayal of the public trust, and it has some very destructive consequences. It justifies people's suspicions of the police."
Earlier this year, the officers pleaded guilty in Federal Court to being criminals in blue; nearly 50 drug cases that they were involved in, including Mrs. Patterson's, have been overturned by the courts and the District Attorney's office. Hundreds more could also be thrown out.
Scheduled for sentencing in October are Officer John Baird, 40, Sgt. Thomas BeGovanni, 44, Officer Steven Brown, 48, Officer James Ryan, 39, and former Officer Thomas Ryan, 38, who is on disability. Most of them have apparently been cooperating with investigators.
A sixth officer, Louis J. Maier 3d, 38, from the same district, was charged today in Federal District Court with conspiracy to violate civil rights. There are reports that even more officers will be charged, expanding the scandal and the city's potential liability.
Ken Rocks, a vice president of the local Fraternal Order of Police, said he anticipated more arrests any day, an expectation he called "very, very distressing."
"This is killing morale," Mr. Rocks said of the department, which has already endured several brutality and corruption scandals over the last two decades.
At least 1,400 drug-related cases are expected to come under review, and the scandal could cost this city millions of dollars in lawsuits -- dollars that Mayor Edward G. Rendell says "we desperately need for human needs and basic services."
Prosecutors and defense lawyers also say they expect several murder convictions to be reviewed or even thrown out as a result of the scandal.
Mrs. Patterson's lawyer, Jennifer St. Hill, said that three of the five officers who had already pleaded guilty used a warrant secured with lies to illegally search her client's home, and at least one of them planted drugs in a bedroom. None of the officers has officially admitted doing that, but during an interview with investigators one officer said his partner had planted drugs as they searched for evidence against Mrs. Patterson's three sons, who were suspects in a drug-related killing.
"When the police are indistinguishable from the bad guys," Ms. Abraham said, "then society has a serious problem."
So far, about a dozen people have been freed from prison or parole. Mrs. Patterson was on parole before her case was vacated last month, and most of the other overturned cases involved people on probation, many of whom had criminal records.
"Shaking down drug dealers is no excuse for breaking the law," Ms. Abraham said.
Bradley S. Bridge, a local public defender who first sought dismissal of the tainted cases and who is seeking the dismissal of others, sees more such cases on the horizon.
"It keeps hemorrhaging," said Mr. Bridge, who first asked the District Attorney to dismiss the cases after the officers were indicted last February on Federal charges, including conspiracy, obstruction of justice and "pocketing more than $100,000 in cash they robbed from suspected drug dealers through beatings, intimidations, illegal searches and denying suspects their constitutional rights."
The first batch of dismissals included 42 cases and nearly as many defendants. Mr. Bridge has written prosecutors asking that another 60 cases be dismissed and, he said the other day with a sigh, "The end is nowhere in sight."
Mr. Bridge said the scandal could change how juries perceive the police. In the past, Mr. Bridge said, many jurors took what a police officer said on the witness stand almost as the gospel truth.
"Too much credibility has always been given the police in court," Mr. Bridge said. "Maybe that will change a little bit now. No one who comes to court should be given a ticket to be believed."
The revelations of police corruption have already given encouragement to the supporters of Mumia Abu-Jamal, a black radio journalist condemned to die for killing a police officer here in 1981. Mr. Abu-Jamal is seeking a new trial partly on the ground that he had been framed by the police.
On the other side of the country, conjuring suspicions of police misconduct is a major part of the strategy being employed by O. J. Simpson's lawyers to convince a jury that he was framed in the slayings of his former wife and her friend. Judge Lance Ito is considering allowing Mr. Simpson's lawyers to give jurors hours of tape recorded conversations in which a former detective, Mark Fuhrman, boasted of beating suspects and other abuses.
The five indicted Philadelphia officers were assigned to the 39th District, but they roamed through other rough patches of North Philadelphia, a part of town plagued with unemployment, poverty and the deadly violence that often accompanies drug money.
They were aggressive officers and several of them were well known on streets where drugs are almost as available as newspapers. When the young men in the neighborhood saw the officers coming, they would run or disappear in doorways.
The other day, Rashine Brown, 20, and Cynthia Taylor, 24, who works for the Internal Revenue Service, were putting oil in their cars on their block in North Philadelphia. Both said they had known about the renegade police officers long before they were charged.
"I can't even remember all the bad stories I heard about those cops," Mr. Brown said. "They used to beat people down, take their money. A lot of people were scared of them."
Mrs. Taylor said the officers operated for so long outside of the law because they patrolled a poor neighborhood, ignored and abandoned by the city, a neighborhood not unlike parts of Chicago's South Side or Harlem, where a scandal in the New York police department is unfolding.
"You can't trust cops around here," Mrs. Taylor said. "They're in it for themselves, not the community. I guess they forgot why they took the job."
The human toll of the scandal will be difficult, if not impossible, to calculate. Unlike Mrs. Patterson, George Porchea, 27, was still in prison when the years of police lies became public. But on July 20, after being locked up for nearly three years, Mr. Porchea was able to watch his daughter graduate from pre-school a few hours after he walked out of a courtroom in City Hall a free man.
He has not seen his oldest daughter yet. She was placed in a foster home in North Carolina while he was in prison.
"I'm trying to get her back," he said. "I'm trying to get my whole life back."
Mrs. Patterson was released on parole in 1994, but long before that she had much to be thankful for. Her church and its interracial congregation stood by her from the day she was arrested in 1989.
And she remained loyal to her church. As soon as she could, Mrs. Patterson got a job in the prison laundry, where she made less than 50 cents a day. Still, each month she sent her $5 tithe, said the Rev. Wilbert S. Richardson, her pastor.
To pass the time, Mrs. Patterson, who made it to the 10th grade, buried herself in her Bible and became a mother figure for many of the younger inmates who called her "Miss P."
One of the women was Patricia Lytle, who was serving time on a drug charge that she admits she was guilty of. On Sunday, Mrs. Patterson brought Ms. Lytle to her church.
"The whole time," in prison, Ms. Lytle said, "you wouldn't believe how the women would look to her. She was grinning and smiling while the rest of us were crying. She was always hugging and praying. Girls would come to her for comfort."
Last Sunday, Pastor Richardson asked Mrs. Patterson to come forward and testify about her faith. She carried her Bible to the front of the church and read from the Acts of the Apostles, where Herod has thrown Peter into prison unjustly.
"That's me," Mrs. Patterson told the congregation, her voice heavy with the accent of her native South. "I, too, was like Peter in prison. When people see me, they are amazed at what can happen to a person."
When she closed her Bible and smiled, church suddenly surged with with song and the sound of trumpets.
Mrs. Patterson waved her hand in the air and in a clear, free voice, shouted, "Hallelujah."

HEADLINE: Busier And Busier Signals

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Diane H. Tremblay knows how bad it can get.
When she bought the Covered Bridge Bed and Breakfast Reservation Service in the northwest Connecticut town of Norfolk nine years ago, Ms. Tremblay experienced a mysterious drop in the number of customer calls. She finally discovered the problem: The recording that was supposed to direct callers from the service's old telephone number was not being reached by the reservation service's many out-of-state callers. 
 If the experience of other states is any guide, Ms. Tremblay's business, and thousands of others in Connecticut, may face similar missed signals when a large portion of the state receives a new area code today.
"If my phone's not working, I'm out of business," Ms. Tremblay said.
Since January, nine other states have adopted new area codes in response to the telephone industry's need for more phone numbers, and there have been problems in nearly every instance. Businesses complain that they go to the trouble and expense of putting the new area code on nearly everything -- from their business cards and stationery to the sides of their trucks -- only to discover that customers cannot get through. Instead, callers receive either a busy signal or, worse, a message saying the number is invalid.
Because the new area codes are being introduced piecemeal around the country, the full impact of the coming changes is only beginning to be felt. But like a swarm of killer bees, the new prefixes are moving from state to state, wreaking havoc.
"This is bigger than going from leaded to unleaded gasoline," said Edward B. Dyl, an executive at the AT&T Corporation who is helping the company's customers adjust to the changes. "The impact is in the billions of dollars. It's incalculable. We have not found a facet of the telephone business that is not affected by this."
Call it information-age scarcity. Because of the surge in demand in recent years for new telephone lines, a consequence of all the fax machines, pagers, cellular telephones and computer modems being added, the country's potential telephone numbers are running out. To meet the growing demand, the telecommunications industry will be introducing 16 new area codes around the nation over the next 16 months -- the most new codes ever adopted in such a short period since area codes came into widespread use after World War II.
The newest one goes into use today in six of Connecticut's eight counties -- including the capital, Hartford -- when many homes and businesses that have long used the 203 prefix will begin a 13-month transition to area code 860. Until Oct. 4, 1996, calls will be connected whether the caller uses the new 860 code or the old 203. But after that date only the 860 code will work in those counties.
Because modern phone networks rely on digital call-switching equipment that consists of, in effect, specialized computers, whenever a new area code is introduced, thousands of telephone companies around the world have to reprogram their switches to recognize the new code. Businesses, too, must adjust the computerized switchboards known as private branch exchanges, or PBX's, that route calls from their offices to the telephone network. And while various area-code glitches have cropped up, the PBX problem appears to be the most common. Traditional area codes had either a "0" or "1" as the middle digit, but the new codes can have any number at their center. As a result, tens of thousands of office switchboards programmed to look only for the old-style numbers must be reprogrammed or, in some cases, replaced.
Mr. Dyl of AT&T estimated that 40 percent of the country's PBX's have yet to be updated. About a third of PBX's need only to be reprogrammed, he said, while the remaining two-thirds require new software or replacement.
In states where new codes have gone into use -- including Arizona, Colorado, Georgia, Texas and Washington -- lawsuits, bitter accusations and cries of desperation have ensued.
Bette Laswell, who runs a computer software business from her home in Tucson, Ariz., saw the number of calls to her toll-free "800" number plunge from nearly 100 a month to fewer than 25 after Tucson's area code changed from 602 to 520 in March. And she said her own investigation determined that many of the people who had trouble getting through were not calling from PBX phones. When she complained to her local phone company, U S West, she said company officials told her that the decline had nothing to do with Tucson's new code.
But Ms. Laswell said that after she had her "800" number calls routed back through the old 602 area code, business picked up again. But that was a short-term fix, possible only during the grace period in which Tucson customers can continue using the old code. When the grace period ends early next year, she will be forced to return to area code 520.
"Virtually all of my sales are phone sales," she said. "This has been a nightmare."
A spokesman for U S West said that his company had investigated Ms. Laswell's complaint and found no problem with the new area code. But he said her problem might have been caused by the provider of her "800" service, or by calls coming from areas where the caller's own local phone companies had failed to adjust their switches to the new Arizona area code.
In June, state regulators in Arizona agreed to extend the transition to the new area code by several months to give customers and U S West more time to adjust. Last week regulators in Colorado -- also a U S West state -- granted a similar 90-day extension.
After new codes were introduced in Alabama and Washington in January, businesses in each state filed lawsuits trying to block their introduction. Each attempt failed, but the plaintiffs are still seeking damages from the local telephone companies.
And by a quirk of technology and geography, Schaumburg, Ill., finds itself at odds with its phone company, the Ameritech Corporation. The boundary line for a new area code would run through Schaumburg, forcing some people there to use the new 847 code, while leaving their neighbors with a separate area code. The only way to give all of Schaumburg a single area code, Ameritech has said, would be if about 24,000 Schaumburg households were willing to change their entire phone numbers -- not only the area code but the seven other digits, too. Schaumburg has filed a lawsuit seeking to force Ameritech to devise a less disruptive plan.
Introducing new area codes was bound to be difficult under any conditions, but contributing to the confusion, some analysts say, is the fact that the entire telephone industry is going through momentous change. The days when the Bell monopoly system coordinated the nation's phone technology ended more than a decade ago, but things are about to become more decentralized. Deregulation is on the verge of freeing the seven regional Baby Bells to pursue new businesses, while allowing other companies -- including cable television operators and long-distance carriers -- to compete in the local phone market.
To prepare themselves for the competition, many of the regional Bells have cut costs and laid off workers. There just are not as many people to sweat the details as there used to be. But Jack Ott, U S West's numbering plan administrator, said he did not think any of the problems resulting from the new area codes were a result of the company's attempts to streamline its operations.
"We're spending a lot of resources on the area code splits," he said. "The problems that we're having are not because of anything in the U S West network. It's problems with other networks -- like, for instance, in foreign countries."
Some of the mistakes that have been made by the telephone companies cannot be blamed on others. Last month, the Bell Atlantic Corporation alerted 388,000 customers in northern Virginia that their area code would be changing to 540 from 703. There was only one problem: The mailing was sent by mistake to customers whose codes would not be changing. The cost of alerting the right customers and disabusing those who received the incorrect notices was about $150,000, the company said.
The telephone companies and industry analysts say the biggest problem is persuading businesses to upgrade their local switchboards to recognize the new codes. Even if business customers in an affected region update their PBX's, if callers from other parts of the country do not make the change as well, they will not be able to get through once the new area codes become mandatory.
Most large businesses have been willing to make the change, which can cost $6,500 for a software upgrade, or tens of thousands of dollars if the PBX needs replacing. But many small to medium-sized businesses have been reluctant to spend the money, figuring that they do not make many calls to Alabama, western Washington or some other regions that have introduced the new codes.
But such economizers will be in for a shock in March, when a new 888 area code goes into use as a toll-free prefix, in addition to the traditional 800 prefix. PBX's that have not been upgraded will not be able to reach any toll-free services that use the 888 code.
Last week, the Federal Communications Commission convened a meeting of state regulators, telephone company executives and PBX manufacturers to discuss what more might be done to raise awareness of the area-code changes and to ease the transition.
"When you think about it, what we just did was not that great a change," said Ron Conners, the director of the North American Numbering Plan, the organization that administers the national telephone numbering system together with the F.C.C., state regulators and the phone companies. When the current batch of numbers runs dry, he explained, it will be necessary to introduce four-digit area codes, which will require every American phone number in every data base on the planet to be changed.
That will not happen until 2025, based on current estimates. But Mr. Conners is not so sure the numbers will not run out sooner. New offerings, like the wireless personal communications services being developed, are bound to soak up millions of additional phone numbers. "And there is no guarantee," he said, "that no one will come up with a new service tomorrow that will eat up a lot of numbers."
Meanwhile, at the Covered Bridge Bed and Breakfast Reservation Service, Ms. Tremblay's operators are standing by.

HEADLINE: U.S. and China Plan Meeting Of Their Leaders in October

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Aug. 27

 BODY:
After two days of talks that left "fundamental differences" in Chinese-American relations unresolved, a senior State Department official said today that China nonetheless wanted to proceed with preparations for a summit meeting between President Clinton and President Jiang Zemin in October.
The positive tone from the official, Under Secretary of State Peter Tarnoff, suggested that both Washington and Beijing were determined to build on the momentum created last week with the release of the Chinese-American human rights activist Harry Wu and the subsequent White House decision that Hillary Rodham Clinton would attend the United Nations Fourth World Conference on Women in Beijing in September. 
 After a half-hour meeting with Foreign Minister Qian Qichen today and several hours of discussions with Mr. Qian's subordinates on Saturday, Mr. Tarnoff said at a news conference: "While on substance the differences were not bridged, I think we did have a full airing of views. And there was a commitment on both sides that there are other aspects to the relationship we are determined to proceed to work on together, notably the upcoming meetings of our foreign ministers and Presidents."
The importance of this restrained and generally positive outcome to the visit is that it may begin to stabilize the fragile Chinese-American relationship, which erupted in May when Mr. Clinton decided to allow Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, to make a private visit to the United States in June.
A summit meeting is still anything but assured. Administration officials, however, have been saying for weeks that there is a tight "window" in which to try to prepare for a meeting between President Clinton and President Jiang during the 50th-anniversary celebrations for the United Nations. It is thus necessary to press an American diplomatic effort, the officials said, if only to stop the deterioration in relations and the escalating demonstrations of military power that China, and now Taiwan, are planning in the East and South China Seas.
The additional significance of the positive tone emerging from the talks this weekend is that it signals an easing in the explosion of anger among China's military leaders over American policy toward Taiwan.
It may also signal that Foreign Minister Qian, who has been the architect of China's recovery from the isolation that followed the 1989 Tiananmen massacre, has somewhat redeemed his influence in the management of foreign policy. It is a policy that has been undermined this summer in internal factional struggles both with the military leadership, and with the State Security Ministry, which supervised the apprehension and handling of Mr. Wu, the human rights activist.
In his remarks to reporters, Mr. Tarnoff placed great emphasis on a reiteration that "far from seeking to isolate China, we desire to engage the People's Republic in a wide-ranging and constructive relationship with us and with the international community."
But Mr. Tarnoff said he could report no immediate progress on restoring ambassadorial relations that were in effect downgraded in June or on ending the cycle of military exercises China has undertaken this summer to intimidate Taiwan.
"I observed that two great powers such as China and the United States should have ambassadorial representation in their respective capitals in order for them to maintain a constructive exchange of views," he said.
Since Ambassador J. Stapleton Roy returned in June, China has yet to agree to the nomination of James Sasser, a former Senator from Tennessee, and the Chinese Ambassador, Li Daoyu, has not returned since being called back to Beijing in the same month.
Mr. Tarnoff continued: "I don't claim we have a meeting of the minds on the Taiwan issue. We did not receive any demands. We did not receive any threats."
But he said it was "welcome" news that China had ended its second military exercise of the summer on Friday, and he admonished both sides that "military exercises on one side or the other are not conducive to the kind of atmosphere that we hope would prevail."
Although giving what appeared to be a bleak report on the lack of agreement on the status of Taiwan, human rights in China and weapons proliferation, Mr. Tarnoff said he was "encouraged" by the tone of the talks. Chinese officials, he said, "made clear how seriously they regarded the issue" of Taiwan, where the Nationalist Government once represented all of China at the United Nations, but with which Washington broke relations in 1979, when it established diplomatic ties with Beijing.
Mr. Tarnoff appeared to be unpersuasive in arguing that China should be willing to tolerate future visits by Taiwan leaders as long as they are "private, unofficial and personal in character."
In a dispatch issued by the official New China News Agency, Foreign Minister Qian was quoted as saying: "The U.S. permission of the visit by Lee Teng-hui had brought about serious consequences to relations between China and the United States, greatly hurt the feelings of the Chinese people and intensified the relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait."
"China hopes that such kind of event will never occur."
In earlier public statements, Chinese leaders have demanded that President Clinton take "concrete steps" to atone for the "mistake" he made in reversing longstanding United States policy on visits of Taiwan leaders. By allowing private but high-profile visits of Taiwan leaders, the United States is indulging in what Beijing sees as a strategy by Taiwan's President to pander to the island's pro-independence voters.
After President Richard M. Nixon opened relations with Beijing more than two decades ago, United States policy was to encourage China and Taiwan to negotiate their future under a "one China" policy. This diplomatic strategy deferred the issue with an expectation that political and economic development would eventually draw the two sides into some permanent accommodation.
Beijing considers Taiwan a province of China, but in recent years has sought to lure the Nationalist Government in Taipei to expand trade and investment ties with a goal of eventual reunification.
Mr. Tarnoff conceded that he was not able to say that he had "turned a corner" on any of the contentious issues that have incited a summer of tensions between Washington and Beijing.
Still, he said, "I certainly detected on the Chinese side an interest in engaging, in talking about our differences and in looking for ways for the dialogue to resume."

HEADLINE: U.S. Officials Say Bosnian Serbs Face NATO Attack if Talks Stall

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27

 BODY:
Administration officials said today that unless there is quick and significant progress on an American peace plan for the Balkans, the Bosnian Serbs could face a new round of NATO air strikes that might be extended to a six-month bombing campaign intended to "level the playing field" while the Bosnian Army receives weapons from abroad.
Appearing on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," Richard C. Holbrooke, the Administration's chief negotiator on the Balkans, said, "If this peace initiative does not get moving -- dramatically moving -- in the next week or two, the consequences will be very adverse to the Serbian goals." 
 Administration officials acknowledged that the threats are clearly intended to ratchet up pressure on the Bosnian Serbs before peace talks resume in Europe this week. The talks were delayed by the deaths of three American diplomats in a road accident outside Sarajevo eight days ago.
The threats of air strikes and the idea of getting the allies to support a multilateral lifting of the international arms embargo on the former Yugoslavia also appear intended to discourage Congress from overriding President Clinton's veto of a bill that would defy the embargo unilaterally. Such a vote would be an embarrassing repudiation of Mr. Clinton's stewardship of foreign policy.
State Department officials said in interviews today that the United States and its European allies have been holding off on large-scale air strikes in retaliation for recent Serbian shelling and sniper attacks in Sarajevo and Gorazde only because they wanted to give the peace talks a chance.
A senior White House official said today, "In the series of carrots and sticks in the new peace initiative, we've made it clear that if there is a failure to achieve peace, with the Bosnian Serbs being the only party holding out, we'd be required to move ahead with things like lifting the arms embargo and compensating the Bosnian Government with air strikes to offset any superiority the Bosnian Serbs had in the interim."
They said that a lack of progress in the talks could also prompt a decision in September to withdraw United Nations peacekeepers, a step that would send tens of thousands of American and NATO troops into the Balkans to assist the pullout. Administration officials said that if the United Nations withdraws, the United States would push for a multilateral lifting of the arms embargo, accompanied by 6 to 12 months of "compensatory" strikes against the Serbs.
These threats are similar to ones repeatedly made and dropped by the United States and its allies during the last two years. But Administration officials insist that a number of circumstances make it easier to follow through this time than before: There are fewer United Nations troops to be taken hostage in Muslim enclaves, and France and Britain are determined not to have their troops in Bosnia suffer through another winter of stalemate and sniper fire.
"The reality is, if the Bosnian Serbs don't want to negotiate, then the game will basically be just to wait for the trigger for air strikes," said a State Department expert on the Balkans. "And the trigger would be Sarajevo or Gorazde -- some of the things that have been going on right now."
The American peace plan, like an earlier version pressed by the five-nations referred to as the "contact group," calls for granting the Muslim-Croat federation 51 percent of the country's territory while the Bosnian Serbs receive 49 percent, down from the 70 percent they now hold, and insists that Bosnia be a single, nonpartitioned, internationally recognized state. The details of the American plan differ somewhat from the contact group's version, and some flexibility is built in.
There are parts of the plan that neither the Muslim-led Bosnian Government nor the Croats like, but American diplomats said today that the main obstacle is the Bosnian Serbs' continued refusal to begin negotiations on the basis of the 51-49 percent split.
On "Meet the Press," Mr. Holbrooke said, "I would be misleading you and your viewers this morning if I were to suggest that there's been any movement yet on that critical issue -- and that is, will the Bosnian Serbs accept the concept of the basic contact group plan."
Mr. Holbrooke left for Paris tonight where he is to pursue the Administration's peace initiative in meetings with French officials, with Bosnia's President, Alija Izetbegovic, and with representatives from the contact group members -- Russia, France, Britain, Germany and the United States -- as well as other nations pressing for peace in the Balkans.
Mr. Holbrooke says quick progress in the peace efforts is vital because the war could intensify quickly and because Britain and France have said they have to make up their minds in September about whether to withdraw their peacekeepers from Bosnia before winter.
During the last week, Mr. Holbrooke's strategy has been to deliberately heighten the pressure on the Bosnian Serbs because the Administration views their side as the principal aggressor and as the chief obstacle to peace.
On "Meet the Press," he repeatedly raised the prospect of increased NATO involvement to prod the Serbs to get serious about peace efforts.
"One way or another, NATO will be heavily involved, and the Serbs don't want that," Mr. Holbrooke said. "NATO will either assist the U.N. withdrawal, or there will be more active NATO air over the skies. These are not things the Serbs should want. So, we hope that they will recognize that the coming week or two is potentially decisive."
Afterward, a senior State Department official said the presence of tens of thousands of NATO troops in Bosnia would be unpleasant for the Bosnian Serbs and for Serbia because there are likely to be confrontations between the Serbs and the NATO forces.
The peace team, led by Mr. Holbrooke, is scheduled to leave Paris Tuesday night for Belgrade for meetings on Wednesday and Thursday with President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia.
"Time is running out," said a senior State Department official. "It's time to find out once and for all, are Serbia and the Bosnian Serbs seeking to reach an agreement or are they seeking to string us along forever?"
Mr. Holbrooke spelled out several others parts of the peace plan today: all ethnic groups must receive equal treatment in all states and the territorial integrity of Croatia must be respected, meaning that the disputed region of Eastern Slavonia would be returned to the Croats. He also said there must be an economic reconstruction program for the region.
Last week, when Bosnia's Foreign Minister, Muhamed Sacirbey, visited Washington, he not only made pleas for relief from Bosnia's $2 billion in foreign debt, but also sought aid for rebuilding.
"Everyone recognizes there will have to be a pot of gold at the end of the rainbow for Bosnia and maybe the other states, too," said a European diplomat.

HEADLINE: Old-Time Boss Rules Russia's Showcase Port

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER 

DATELINE: VLADIVOSTOK, Russia, Aug. 21

 BODY:
Spread regally across the rolling hills above Golden Horn Bay, Vladivostok has in just a few years become the garish showcase for all that ails modern Russia, and most of what could save it.
No other city holds more promise for the future or greater potential for prosperity. Its mighty port, sprawling forests and vast mineral wealth have made trading partners from Seoul to Seattle drool. There are yachts in the harbor and $60,000 Range Rovers on the pitted streets. 
 But in the last year Vladivostok has also become the country's Cape Fear: a city caught in a dark web of graft, run with an iron fist by a man who openly questions the value of democracy.
When this closed military port opened up for the first time three years ago, many people saw in Vladivostok and the surrounding Primorsky region a glorious Pacific gateway to the new Russia. Foreign businesses by the score rushed to stake claims in the capital of the Wild East, 6,000 miles from Moscow.
But these days, with profits eaten by taxes and bribes, car bombs a common occurrence -- there have been three this month, including one in front of the American Consulate's business office -- and many senior members of the regional administration under investigation for corruption, reality comes in more somber hues.
"This is a mafia town, a town of thugs," said Igor L. Alekseyev, the regional representative of a Japanese import consortium called the Vladivostok Corporation. "And if businesses want to come here it is usually in spite of the government, not because of it. Think about it. What does it mean that this territory, the great hope of Russia, is led by a man who opposes a free market and free speech?"
For one thing it means companies are starting to have some costly second thoughts about the place, despite gold reserves that rival those of any single country and a potential fish catch among the richest in the world.
Hyundai, the South Korean giant, spent lavishly last year to begin construction of a $50 million business center here. But a few months ago, battered by 18 types of taxes that it said would cost more than any possible profit and shocked by demands for huge bribes, the company decided to cut its losses and pull out of the deal.
American companies -- including Weyerhaeuser, which is eager to get a piece of the Russian Far East's 300 billion cubic feet of timber reserves -- are prepared to invest heavily despite the problems. But so far, few have been able to make their way through the red tape.
The regional Governor, Yevgeny Nazdratenko, says nothing is as important to him as attracting international business. But unlike his neighbors in the nearby region of Khabarovsk, he offers no incentives.
Instead, he calls market experiments "foolish" and privatization the theft of the nation's assets. He refers to former Prime Minister Yegor T. Gaidar, the country's best known advocate of open markets, as "a blind Bolshevik."
Governor Nazdratenko said in an interview that democrats, whom he refers to as "opposition groups," should be able to have "clubs," but not rallies. Newspapers that have been critical of his administration suddenly find their printing costs rising far beyond their means.
"The word democracy has come to mean anything is permitted," said Mr. Nazdratenko, who by all accounts makes every political decision of any significance in the region. "They say I am a dictator because I am opposed to that. Call me what you want. I'm used to it."
Regional governors have almost unlimited authority in Russia today, and Mr. Nazdratenko has found an extremely loyal following among many of his constituents by vigorously reminding Moscow that if it wants to take, it had better start giving. But as the country struggles to define the scope of central power and the limits to regional freedoms, Mr. Nazdratenko's brazen challenge to the rule of the Kremlin has sent troubling echoes across the continent.
Deeply popular with many of the unemployed and disaffected voters here, he is not a subtle man. Last year, President Boris N. Yeltsin was forced to call off an election for governor after Mr. Nazdratenko had his opponents disqualified by tripling the number of signatures that candidates needed to register. Then all electric power to the region conveniently failed in the final four days of the registration drive during the crucial television advertising hours from 7 to 11 P.M.
"He was blatant," said a Western businessman who has been here for two years and hopes to stay. "He always is. He rules with the big stick. The common folks are conservative here, and they love his act. He blames Moscow for everything, and the people always believe him. Foreigners have two choices. You either buy in or get out."
Buying in is increasingly costly. Local taxes run about 45 percent of income for foreign investors, and the Kremlin's tax bite is almost as steep. And that does not count the payoffs required of everyone.
Last month, one of Mr. Nazdratenko's closest associates, the region's tax chief, was arrested and accused of fabricating corruption charges against the former Mayor, Viktor Cherepkov. Mr. Cherepkov, the city's only democratically elected official, was carried out of his office by the police last year after the Governor accused him of corruption. All charges against him have been dropped, but he has not been reinstated.
"At this moment, the word democracy in Vladivostok has become a dirty word," said Mr. Cherepkov, who is living in Moscow and suing to get his job back. "It's a purely criminal, fascist and nomenklatura regime, which didn't exist even under Communism."
Such talk -- and there has been a lot of it -- has not shaken the Governor's position here. He has remained the law for a few simple reasons. He has the common touch and can spend hours commiserating with a factory worker thrown out of his job or schoolteachers unable to find the money to buy textbooks.
Nobody seriously challenges him in the region, because there is no opposition. He has made sure of that. Everyone in power is an ally; everyone who succeeds in business has a line to his office.
More than that, though, Mr. Nazdratenko is a fully committed, openly devoted supporter of Mr. Yeltsin, and these days that is a rarity. Deeply unpopular, Mr. Yeltsin simply cannot afford to dump a stalwart in one of Russia's most important regions only a few months before parliamentary elections in December.
"He has managed to convince people in this area that without him they would even be worse off than they are," said Tatyana G. Romanenko, editor of Arsenyevskiye Vesti, the only openly democratic newspaper in the area.
Her weekly paper has had to change printing houses seven times in the last year, as regional officials have raised prices and put other roadblocks in front of her. She now uses a small press in Khabarovsk, 300 miles away.
"People here are conservative and scared," she said. "He plays on that well. He tells them it's him and them against Moscow. Everyone always loves to hear that."
It also, to a large degree, happens to be the truth. As a closed city until 1992, Vladivostok was a company town with 900,000 residents.
The company was the defense industry. Almost every factory in this region, the home of the Pacific fleet, was turning out warplanes, submarines or something to support it. That effort is languishing now, and Moscow has little help to offer. Navy frigates sit rotting in the harbor, and one of the finest natural ports in the world remains profoundly underdeveloped.
Subsidies, once steady and always necessary in this region of exceptionally high prices, have been cut almost completely. Not surprisingly, real unemployment -- including the thousands who have jobs but get only a minimal salary and do no work -- runs at nearly 30 percent. Jobs in mining, timber and chemical industries are all disappearing, replaced by nothing.
Forced to rely on the marketplace to earn its keep, Vladivostok still has not been given the freedom to sell most of its remarkable trove of resources freely. Moscow still demands most of the raw materials that make this region one of the richest in Russia, or in any country. The central Government simply refuses to pay a fair market value for them.
Meanwhile, the loss of housing subsidies, school support and other traditional benefits has brutally wounded this region.
"The Governor says, 'Give us the ability to operate independently and we will succeed,' " said Anatoly Pavordenko, who runs a small commercial fishing fleet here but must often sell his catch to the Government at below-market prices. "I think he is absolutely right.
"We are being told by Moscow to grow up and do it ourselves. Then they force us to go begging for the right to profit from our own work. If it wasn't for our Governor, we would probably starve."

HEADLINE: March on Chicago Points to Jail as Symbol of Failed Urban Policy

BYLINE: By DON TERRY 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 27

 BODY:
A sprawling warehouse of the criminal and the dispossessed on the city's West Side, the Cook County Jail has been getting bigger and bigger for decades.
Designed for 8,200 inmates, it now holds 9,000, more than 1,000 of whom have to sleep on mattresses spread across the floor. 
 The jail's newest addition, Division XI, is scheduled to open this fall, and by the time the last contractor is paid it will cost about $100 million.
"There is not a black college in America with as much money in it as that new jail," the Rev. Jesse Jackson said on Saturday as he and more than 2,500 people marched for six miles past vacant lots and weary row houses to the sleek white building.
There, with prayers and fiery speeches, they demanded a "national urban policy" that emphasizes jobs and education over incarceration and revenge.
"We intend, to make museums of these jails," Mr. Jackson said through a public address system. "Right now, they are just ovens, burning up our children."
To Mr. Jackson and others, Division XI, is a shiny new symbol of what the former Presidential candidate calls the "jail-industrial complex," the multibillion-dollar a year business of building and maintaining prisons and locking people up, especially, he says, a disproportionately high percentage of blacks.
There are more than one million people under lock and key across the country and almost everywhere he goes, Mr. Jackson said, he sees new jails going up and plants, schools and housing for the poor going down.
"If this were Italy, we would call this Fascism," Mr. Jackson said, addressing the marchers as they rallied in a park across the street from the new jail. "Here we call it conservatism: a plan to lock up our youth and not build them up."
John Stroger, the president of the Cook County Board of Commissioners, which is responsible for building lockups and hospitals, said Division XI was built to relieve the jail's severe overcrowding because of a longstanding Federal court order.
He said Division XI is a state of the art "humane" facility that "helps us comply with the court order and at the same time respond to the high incidence of crime that is causing the overcrowding in the first place."
This city is just one of many across the nation facing a rising number of people in the criminal justice system. The Federal Government announced today that a record 5.1 million Americans were either behind bars or on probation or parole at the end of last year. The numbers, released by the Justice Department's Bureau of Justice Statistics, found that the number under some kind of correctional supervision amounted to almost 2.7 percent of the nation's adult population.
In Chicago, Mr. Stroger said he was trying to develop programs that would guide young people away from crime but in the meantime, he said, society cannot ignore the mayhem in the streets.
"We have to do more up front," he said, "so our young people won't end up in the criminal justice system."
Some of the marchers on Saturday agreed, at least partly.
"We need jails to get the gang-bangers off the street," said Falanda Mabrey, 25, a cashier at a grocery store. "But it's better to get them in somewhere where thay can learn something."
Indeed, the marchers represented a cross section of generations and backgrounds, from a retired police commander to a mother whose 17-year-old son is in Cook County Jail for murder.
Fraternity brothers and gang members also marched and so did teachers and short-order cooks, Christians in T-shirts and Muslims in bow ties, teen-agers and gray-haired men and women who marched with Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., at least in their hearts, through Mississippi and Chicago and anywhere else Jim Crow said if you are black get back.
On Saturday, Elizabeth Harrison, 75, a retired hotel linen room supervisor from Woodville, Miss., watched the marchers stream past as she sat on a relative's stoop.
"This is the first time I've seen this many young people marching together since Martin Luther King," she said.
Dr. King's name and spirit were repeatedly evoked by the marchers on Saturday, and although many of the people marching through Chicago this weekend had not even been born when he stirred a nation with his visions of brotherhood and racial fairness, they sounded sorrows and fears and commitments that seem to echo from across the years.
"The system is prejudiced against African-American males," said Joseph Wesley, 23, of the Omega Psi Phi fraternity. "I don't want to see a system that is designed to incarcerate African-American males."
The march began in front of a church on the South Side, the skyscrapers of downtown looming a few miles away in the haze. But many children in Chicago's inner city, Mr. Jackson said, will see the inside of Cook County Jail before they make it to the public observation deck of one of the city's tall buildings.
"America has adjusted too well to this predicament of unfairness," said Mr. Jackson, who wore Air Jordan basketball shoes for the long march. "America has got to wise up."
Waving his hand toward the gathering crowd behind him, Mr. Jackson added, "There's going to be a lot more of this."
Next summer, the Democratic National Convention will be held in Chicago.
