HEADLINE: Japan's Hard-Line Trade Minister Wins Party Leadership

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 28

 BODY:
Japan's outspoken Trade Minister, who stared down the United States in the recent automobile negotiations, essentially won the battle today to lead the largest party in the governing coalition, enhancing his chances of becoming the next Prime Minister.
Ryutaro Hashimoto became the near certain choice to lead the Liberal Democratic Party today when his opponent for the job, Foreign Minister Yohei Kono, suddenly dropped out of the race as it became obvious he would lose by a wide margin. While it is possible that another candidate will enter the race before the Sept. 22 party vote, it is considered highly unlikely that anyone could beat Mr. Hashimoto. 
 The expected ascension of the 58-year-old Mr. Hashimoto to the presidency of the Liberal Democrats threatens to further destabilize the already fragile Government because he is a nationalistic conservative whose policies are at odds with those of the other two parties in the coalition, including the Socialist Party of Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama.
Mr. Murayama, for example, apologized this month for Japan's aggression in World War II. Mr. Hashimoto is chairman of the Bereaved Families Association, a million-strong group of relatives of Japanese soldiers who died in the war. It led the fight against any apology.
"It's not clear how it will happen, but the Murayama coalition will collapse after Mr. Hashimoto becomes president," Masumi Ishikawa, a political columnist for the Asahi Shimbun, one of Japan's largest newspapers, said tonight. Still, Mr. Hashimoto has pledged his support for the coalition, so other analysts think the current Government will remain in place for months.
It is not clear yet whether Mr. Kono will resign from his positions as Foreign Minister and Deputy Prime Minister, which might necessitate a Cabinet shuffle. Mr. Kono, 58, said today that he would leave that up to Prime Minister Murayama, who has not yet commented.
Mr. Kono, who is the incumbent party president, is relatively liberal and his views meshed with the Socialist Party and the other coalition partner, the small Sakigake Party.
Despite the potential for conflict between Mr. Hashimoto and Mr. Murayama, some analysts noted that the Liberal Democrats and Socialists, who were archenemies for 40 years, have never been very compatible yet have stayed in a marriage of convenience for the sake of remaining in power. That motivation remains.
Moreover, there is strong pressure for the Government to hold itself together for at least a few months, long enough to draw up a new stimulus package to help Japan's faltering economy and to play host to a meeting of leaders from Asian-Pacific region countries, which will be held in Osaka in November.
Nor is it certain that Mr. Hashimoto will be able to fulfill his long-held ambition of becoming Prime Minister. His victory today was in some sense equivalent to winning the primary. But it is not clear the Liberal Democrats would be able to win enough seats in Parliament to be able to choose the next Prime Minister.
In announcing that he would not run for re-election as party chief, Mr. Kono said he wanted to avoid "strife" in his party. But it had become clear in recent days that he would lose badly because he is being held responsible for the party's failure to win as many seats as it expected in elections last month for the upper house of Parliament.
Party members, especially younger ones, also expect the more aggressive Mr. Hashimoto to have a better chance of leading the party back to its former glory. The Liberal Democratic Party, which despite its name is conservative, held power for nearly 40 years until 1993, when it was overthrown because of voter disgust with rampant corruption. The Liberal Democrats squeezed back into power in June of last year by allying with the Socialists.
Mr. Hashimoto, known for his slicked-back hair and cigarette holder, is one of Japan's more outspoken and colorful politicians. At one point during the recent auto talks he said of Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, "He's scarier than my wife when I get drunk."
He has defended Japan's huge trade surplus as a "precious asset," and his nationalist streak has sometimes made him difficult for the United States to deal with.
In the automobile talks, Mr. Hashimoto refused to agree to Washington's demands to come up with voluntary targets for Japan's purchase of foreign auto parts, despite the threat of tariffs on Japanese luxury cars. His strong stance appears to have raised Mr. Hashimoto's popularity, and a recent newspaper public opinion poll pegged him as most popular choice for Prime Minister.
Even if he becomes Prime Minister, Mr. Hashimoto might not bring about significant changes in Japan's policies because politicians often exercise less power than the bureaucracy, especially if they are operating in a coalition.
"There is not too much difference in policy," said Ikuo Kabashima, professor of political science at the University of Tsukuba. "It's more image we see."
There are two ways Mr. Hashimoto can become Prime Minister. One would be for Mr. Murayama to resign and hand the job to Mr. Hashimoto. While analysts say the 71-year-old Mr. Murayama is tired and unpopular and might not be averse to that, his party might not accept it.
The other way would be for Mr. Murayama to call for new elections for the lower house of Parliament, which many people would expect to happen late this year or in the first half of next year. In that case, Mr. Hashimoto would become Prime Minister if the Liberal Democratic Party won a clear majority of seats.
But Professor Kabashima said a clear Liberal Democrat victory is unlikely because the opposition New Frontier Party, based on its performance in the upper house elections in July, looks to be pretty strong.

HEADLINE: BANKING'S NEW GIANT: THE DISPLACED;
Job Losses to Fall Hard in New York City

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
In a city where finding work remains tough, thousands of New Yorkers face losing their jobs in the wake of the merger of Chemical Bank and Chase Manhattan Bank.
The two banks, which together employ about 75,000 people across the country and overseas, said yesterday that they expected to cut about 12,000 positions in the next three years, about a third of them in New York City. 
 While many of those cuts could come from attrition -- about 20 percent of the banks' employees leave every year, according to Kenneth Herz, a spokesman for Chemical Bank -- layoffs will probably be necessary to achieve the cost savings in certain areas that managers are expected to seek.
And the toll could be higher here than predicted, some analysts suggested, because the banks are planning to eliminate 100 of their 480 branches in the city. Indeed, that number could grow. When Chemical Bank bought Manufacturers Hanover in 1992, it said it would eliminate 80 branches, but in fact the number of branches has dropped by 177.
Moreover, both banks have many clerical and technical workers -- what the industry calls "back office" employees -- in the New York region, and their offices are likely to be consolidated and perhaps moved out of the area. Big banking companies like Citicorp have increasingly moved their back offices to the South and Midwest.
The cuts come at a time when overall job growth in New York City has been flat, and few industries can be described as robust. Even though national employment has been growing strongly for much of the last three years, roughly 3.3 million people were on payrolls in the city as of July, nearly the same number as a year ago, according to the New York State Department of Labor. The city has lost about 240,000 jobs in the last five years.
"It will be very, very difficult for the people affected here to move into other sectors of the economy," said John L. Wieting, regional commissioner for the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics in New York. "There aren't a lot of other sectors seeing major expansion right now."
The job losses may also hurt other industries and even local governments that find their tax rolls shrinking.
"The ripple effects should extend to virtually every area and facet of the economy -- the real estate markets, house prices and rents, local stores and retailers of all kinds," said David Hensley, an analyst at Salomon Brothers. But because the effects will occur over several years and will be widely dispersed across the region, he said, "this shouldn't be viewed as a death blow."
Many of the city's job losses have already come in the banking industry, which was a big source of employment growth in the early 1980's. At commercial banks alone, the number of jobs has plunged from 118,000 in July of 1988 to fewer than 75,000 today.
On a percentage basis, the drop in banking jobs has been even steeper than in manufacturing, Mr. Wieting said. Jobs at banks and other financial institutions like credit unions have fallen 36 percent since 1988, just before the most recent peak in New York City employment, while manufacturing jobs have dropped somewhat less.
Unfortunately for the banking employees, industries that hire workers with similar skills have also suffered drops, said Jeffrey Weissenstein, who analyzes labor markets for New York State. Ten thousand fewer people work in the insurance industry today than in 1989. And the securities business, despite a rebound since 1991, has lost more than 13,000 jobs from its peak of 163,000 in 1987.
One area that has recently been growing is business services, which includes everything from advertising to office cleaning. Here, there has been a gain of about 17,000 jobs in the last three years, to 225,000, though it is far below its peak of 265,000 jobs in 1988.
"In the city as a whole, the areas that have continued to grow are health services and social services, and that seems to be iffy right now," Mr. Weissenstein said, noting that some hospitals have announced cutbacks. Plans in Washington and Albany to rein in spending on Medicare, the health care program for the elderly, and Medicaid, which pays for medical services for the poor, are likely to add to the job losses.
New York is not the only area to lose banking-industry jobs. Nationwide, the number of people working for banks, savings and loans, and other depository institutions has fallen by about 222,000 since July 1989, or roughly 10 percent of the work force. In California, financial institutions have retrenched even more steeply, not only because of mergers and takeovers, but because of problems in the real estate business and high mortgage rates, Mr. Hensley of Salomon Brothers said.
Nationwide, while more than two million people remain employed by banks and related institutions, the outlook for bank workers is bleak. The accounting firm of Deloitte & Touche predicts that as many as 450,000 further jobs may be swept away over the next decade.
Behind the decline is the expected demise of bank branches, which are threatened not just by mergers, but also by new technology.
"Our forecast in that in the next 5 or 10 years, a great deal of the work done in branches will be done electronically," said Frank Woosley, national director of financial-services consulting for Deloitte & Touche.
Though 40 percent of all banking transactions were done in branches last year, only a quarter are expected to take place in branches by the end of the century. And branch employment is directly related to the amount of work that occurs there, Mr. Woosley said.
The one bright spot in New York City's overall employment picture is that private industry overall is adding jobs, albeit at a slow pace. In the last 12 months, companies have created 20,000 positions, though those gains have been offset by a drop in government jobs.
"There is enough growth in the private sector, if the government ever stabilizes," Mr. Hensley said. "People shouldn't feel like they have no options."

HEADLINE: Selling Weaken Stocks, With Dow Off 7.40

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The stock market succumbed to selling yesterday that weighed down major market indicators despite an upbeat performance by banking issues.
News of the $10 billion planned merger of the Chemical Banking Corporation and the Chase Manhattan Corporation to form the country's biggest bank intensified speculation about other consolidation in the industry, and many financial issues rose. In other banking deals yesterday, the National City Corporation said it would buy the Integra Financial Corporation for $2.1 billion and SFFed Corporation, the parent of the San Francisco Federal Savings and Loan Association, said it would be acquired by First Nationwide Bank in a $250 million deal. 
 But the buying in the banking sector had a minimal impact marketwide.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 7.40 points, to 4,594.00, after turning lower in the afternoon.
Broader market indicators were also lower, with the Nasdaq composite index skidding 11.82 points, to 1,008.15, after a slump in technology shares.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index dipped 0.16 point, to 300.69, and the Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 1.05 points, to 559.05. The American Stock Exchange market value index declined 0.79 point, to 530.18.
Advancing stocks led declining issues by 1,145 to 1,104 on the New York Stock Exchange, where trading activity eased. Volume on the Big Board's floor amounted to 267.9 million shares.
Market analysts said Wall Street was destined to remain listless this week in the sessions leading up to the long Labor Day weekend. United States financial markets will be closed next Monday for the holiday.
"It just appeared to be a pre-Labor Day lull," said Ned Riley, chief investment officer of the Private Bank, an investment subsidiary of the Bank of Boston. "Clearly, the economy news at the end of the week will dictate the trend, especially in the bond market, which undoubtedly will affect equities."
The employment report for August, scheduled for release on Friday, kept investors from making major commitments to the market. The report will be scrutinized for hints about the health of the economy.
Most forecasters do not expect the report to contain market-moving news, but if the data depict unexpectedly vigorous economic growth, both the stock and bond markets could be disappointed. Many investors are hoping the Federal Reserve will nudge interest rates lower again next month, but signs of an economic revival could deter the central bank.
The merger news provided a focus for investors, although the impact was confined to banking issues.
Chase Manhattan topped the Big Board's list of active issues, spurting 6 5/8, to 59 5/8, on trading of 7.95 million shares. Chemical rose 5 3/4, to 60 1/8, and was the second-most-active Big Board stock, with more than 6.9 million shares changing hands.
Several other banks were among the heavily traded issues. Citicorp, which will be displaced as the nation's biggest bank if the Chase-Chemical union is completed, was up 7/8, to 66 1/2. PNC Bank rose 1/2, to 26; Bank of New York rose 2 5/8, to 43 3/4, and Bankers Trust New York rose 2 1/4, to 69 7/8.
Technology stocks were laggards on the New York Stock Exchange, International Business Machines declined 2 1/4, to 101 5/8; Motorola fell 1 7/8, to 70 7/8, and Texas Instruments was down 3 5/8, to 70 7/8.
Prominent among Nasdaq's decliners were the volume leader, Intel, down 1 3/4, to 58 5/8, and Microsoft, down 45/16 , to 901/16 .

HEADLINE: Health Plans That Can Put Cash Into Workers' Pockets Are Finding Favor

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Melissa Holloway, a City Council member in Jersey City, may get a $700 windfall from a health plan that rewards people who use few or no medical services. The city earmarked $1,400 for individuals and $1,800 for families in special medical savings accounts this year. She has used hers only once so far, for a battery of tests that found no problems. At the end of the year, she can keep the balance remaining in her account.
The health plan, which Jersey City offered to 174 nonunion employees in a one-year trial, also provides a Blue Cross of New Jersey health plan that pays all costs after a high deductible is met. Individuals in the new program pay the deductible, the first $1,500 in medical bills, with money from the accounts and their own pockets; for an employee with family coverage, the deductible is $2,000. Other employees have conventional Blue Cross coverage, with deductibles of $200 for an individual and $400 for family coverage, or managed-care plans that limit their choices of doctors. 
 A growing number of employers across the country offer some type of medical savings plan, like the one in Jersey City, and the plans are finding support on Capitol Hill, especially among Republicans, who have introduced legislation to make the accounts tax-exempt. Supporters say these plans can slow health spending because consumers hesitate to use their own money for care they may not need.
Jersey City has saved $22,000 because the insurance premiums are lower for the high-deductible policies for the 97 employees in the plan. But those employees have to pay income tax on the money put into their medical savings accounts by their employer, which adds to their expenses, even if they use the money for medical care. If they use little or no medical care, they will save money, compared with more traditional insurance coverage; if they have many medical expenses, they will lose money.
While some employers put liberal amounts into medical savings plans for employees, other employers, especially small companies, provide only high-deductible insurance and a smaller contribution, or nothing, leaving employees to pay most bills on their own.
Critics say the main winners when medical savings plans are adopted are the insurance companies that sell the high-deductible insurance policies to small businesses that cannot afford either insurance with lower deductibles or health maintenance organizations and other types of managed health care. The medical savings plans mainly attract healthy customers who cost insurers little or nothing, the critics add.
"As a single person and in reasonable good health, it's not a bad program," Ms. Holloway said. She said she would sign up again if the city offered the accounts next year, "unless some other health problems arose between now and December."
But Tom DeGise, the Jersey City Council President, has two young children and predictable medical costs, so he decided against the savings account. "I would go through the deductible rather quickly," he said. Under current tax law, he is more likely to save money by choosing the conventional health plan, even though he pays 20 percent of his medical fees under that plan.
The concept of medical savings accounts has been endorsed by Speaker Newt Gingrich and Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader. Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, and 105 co-sponsors, including 11 Democrats, have introduced a tax measure that would encourage the accounts.
Under the Archer bill, money that employers or employees put into the accounts would not be taxed, and employees could leave unspent money in their accounts for future medical needs or nursing home insurance. Employees would be taxed on the unspent money only if they withdrew it for nonmedical uses.
That would make the savings accounts different from the health benefits called flexible plans, offered by many big employers. In flexible plans, an employee can put part of his or her paycheck into an account held by the employer for a selection of benefits, including health care. The money is not taxed but the employee can lose money if not all of it is spent because the balance goes to the employer at the end of the year.
The Archer bill could make medical savings plans more attractive by allowing employees to carry unspent money in medical savings plans over to the next year. A Senate version is expected after the recess.
Congressional budget cutters are also considering the accounts as an option in revising Medicare, but experts say the added costs to the Treasury could be enormous if elderly people used the plans to pocket the cash until they needed care, leaving only the sickest patients under conventional Medicare.
The Clinton Administration has not taken a final position, said Chris Jennings, the President's special assistant for health policy. The accounts raise "significant questions" that should be considered in Congressional hearings, he said.
Supporters say the legislation would make the lower-cost, high-deductible insurance more attractive for millions of people with little or no coverage. But economists say many small employers would not be so generous as Jersey City. Some companies might cover half, or less than half, of a $2,000 deductible policy. If some version of the Archer bill is adopted, many small businesses may simply offer employees the opportunity to finance the tax-exempt accounts out of their own wages.
Dr. Stuart Altman, a health care economist at Brandeis University, said the medical savings accounts "would break apart the insurance market, and millions of middle-class people would not be able to find affordable health care." He said older people and others with high medical costs would have to pay even more for conventional insurance as younger, healthier people switched to the savings accounts because the current rates for conventional insurance are based on spreading costs across large numbers of both sick and healthy people.
Most individuals with conventional coverage would save $400 to $600 a year under a medical savings plan, depending on how much the employer put into the accounts and what Congress decides about their tax status, the American Academy of Actuaries, a professional group, said in May. But costs would rise for the one person in four whose expenses consumed all or most of the deductible.
For the 8 percent with the highest medical expenses, the actuaries said, the added costs would be a steep $800 to $900 a year, on average.
Large employers fear that the medical savings plans would drive up their costs by siphoning off healthy employees and disrupting managed-care networks, like health maintenance organizations. Younger people would go for the chance to get the cash, they say, and might postpone needed medical services.
"Common sense tells you that the young, healthy people would go into the medical savings accounts," said Susan Shackson, senior director of public policy at the Ford Motor Company, which spent $1.4 billion on health benefits last year.
Ford, a self-insured company with generous benefits, would expect to contribute the entire deductible for these people, who now cost the company very little. "Ten percent of the population accounts for 70 percent of the medical costs, and 30 to 40 percent don't cost anything," said Charlie Pryde, a governmental affairs executive with Ford.
"Today, they are just part of the risk pool, lowering our average costs," Ms. Shackson said. "Tomorrow, you could have extra costs."
Members of the National Federation of Independent Business, most of them small companies, strongly supported tax-free status for medical savings accounts in a survey last year; 58 percent were in favor, 22 percent opposed and 20 percent undecided.
But managed-care companies say it would be unfair to give special tax breaks to people choosing high-deductible insurance. "We believe all insurance products should be treated similarly from a tax perspective," said Art Lifson, a vice president in Washington with the Cigna Corporation, a major health insurer.
Mr. Archer's bill, which would give tax advantages to savings accounts tied to high-deductible insurance, would cost the Treasury $2 billion over seven years in lost revenue, the Joint Committee on Taxation said.
Another concern was voiced by Dr. Donald Parsons, a Washington spokesman for Kaiser Permanente, the California-based health maintenance organization. He said the savings accounts "undermine the opportunity for early treatment" that may catch potentially costly diseases because people would delay treatment until symptoms were severe and expensive to treat.
But James Rodgers, an economist with the American Medical Association, which supports the accounts, said doctors did not think that people would skimp on most essential care because they were spending their own money.
The Council on Affordable Health Insurance, which is supported by insurance companies that specialize in high-deductible policies for individuals and small businesses, is campaigning for Federal tax concessions for medical savings accounts. The council's leading backer, the Golden Rule Insurance Company, based in Indianapolis, is headed by J. Patrick Rooney, a former Republican candidate for Governor of Indiana, who has donated extensively to Mr. Gingrich's political action committees and television shows.
Concord Management, a Golden Rule customer in Grand Rapids, Mich., switched from conventional Blue Cross coverage to medical savings accounts in 1993. It provided $2,000 for each employee's account, fully covering an insurance policy with a $2,000 deductible. "We've been very happy; people got money back," said Randy Velting, a partner with Concord, a nine-person real estate firm. "But I don't think anyone has had a catastrophic medical problem" that would wipe out the saving, he said. "We know there is no free lunch."

HEADLINE: States Improve in Warning Consumers About Polluted Fish

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28

 BODY:
The number of warnings issued by state health authorities against eating fish caught in polluted waters increased 20 percent in the Government's fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30, 1994, according to a survey published today by the Environmental Protection Agency.
While the increase has continued to rise, agency officials said it did not necessarily suggest that water quality was worsening, but rather that state agencies were doing a better job of detecting problems and informing the public. 
 The warnings apply to fish caught by recreational anglers and others who fish for their own food. They are issued by state health authorities when local fish are thought to be tainted by toxic substances that concentrate in the flesh of fish.
The survey also found that the warnings now cover more than 1 in every 25 miles of rivers and 1 in every 7 acres of lakes.
In a speech today to the American Fisheries Society in Tampa, Fla., the Administrator of the E.P.A., Carol M. Browner, said the warnings covered about 125,000 miles of rivers.
"Here in Florida, every inch of coastline carries a warning, plus 80 inland water bodies and the entire Everglades," she said.
Ms. Browner said the survey showed that water pollution problems were far from solved. Measures supported by the Republican leadership in Congress to amend the Clean Water Act and other environmental laws, to cut her agency's budget and to restrict its enforcement powers would only make matters worse, she said.
"The recreational fishing industry is worth $24 billion a year," Ms. Browner said. "Contaminated fish are bad for the economy."
Fish contamination is thought to be of special concern to pregnant women, to children and to people who eat higher than normal amounts of fish, including American Indians and people who depend heavily on fish they catch as a source of food.
The Federal Government does not issue health warnings for noncommercial sources of fish, but advises the states on how to gather and interpret information on contamination.
The survey collected all the public health warnings in force in 46 states. Although all 46 states except Idaho had issued warnings in previous years, last year the warnings included more bodies of water.
Nine states have now issued broad advisories that affect not just one body of water, but waters all over their state: Florida, Maine, Massachusetts, Michigan, Missouri, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York and Vermont.
But statewide warnings do not necessarily mean that fish throughout the state should not be eaten. In New York, for example, people are advised to limit consumption to half a pound a week of fish taken from any freshwater body in the state, including the Hudson River and New York Harbor.
Most warnings across the country were related to mercury contamination, mainly because of air pollution from coal-burning power plants, industrial sites and incinerators. Other warnings were because of polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's; the pesticides chlordane and DDT as well as about 25 other chemicals.
In an unusual approach, the E.P.A. did not release the complete survey in printed form, but instead distributed it on five computer disks that allow statistics and maps to be generated by categories like fish species, state or pollutant. Although the disks are free to the public, they will be useful primarily to researchers and organizations. Most individuals can more easily obtain information about fishing in local waters from state health departments.
The agency also plans to make the information available on the Internet.

HEADLINE: Stephen Goldfeld, 55, Professor; Was Chief Economic Forecaster

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
Stephen M. Goldfeld, a Princeton University professor and former provost who served on the Council of Economic Advisers during the Carter Administration, died on Friday at his home in Princeton Township, N.J. Dr. Goldfeld was 55.
The cause of death was cancer, said Jacquelyn Savani, a spokeswoman for the university. 
 An expert on financial institutions and econometrics, a heavily mathematical branch of economics involving statistical analysis, Dr. Goldfeld was 39 when he was named chief forecaster on the President's three-member council in 1980.
When Dr. Goldfeld took a leave from Princeton and arcane economic concepts to go to Washington, he had been a full professor for 10 years and had been a senior staff economist with the council in 1966 and 1967.
"The only hard part of forecasting is doing it when things are in great disarray," he said after joining the Carter Administration. "Since I've come, things have seemed as if we knew what was going on."
The next year, after Jimmy Carter was defeated by Ronald Reagan, Dr. Goldfeld returned to Princeton. He was chairman of the economics department from 1981 to 1985 and again from 1990 to 1993, when he was named provost, a post he held until the end of June.
Besides being a visiting faculty member at Catholic University of Louvain in Belgium, the University of California at Berkeley and the Technion in Haifa, Israel, Dr. Goldfeld was also on the National Commission for Employment Policy, a consultant to the Federal Reserve Board and a member and senior adviser of the Brookings Institution and its panel on economic activity.
Dr. Goldfeld was associate editor of American Economic Review and five other major economic journals. He also wrote several books, among them "Commercial Bank Behavior and Economic Activity" (1966) and, with R. E. Quandt, "Nonlinear Methods in Econometrics" (1971), both published by North-Holland Publishing Company; and, with L. V. Chandler, "The Economics of Money and Banking," published in 1981 by Harper & Row.
Dr. Goldfeld was born in the Bronx. A mathematics major, he received a bachelor of arts degree from Harvard University in 1960 and his doctorate in economics three years later from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. That year, he joined the Princeton faculty. Three years later, at the age of 26, he was granted tenure, and in 1969 was promoted to full professor.
Dr. Goldfeld is survived by his wife, Laura; a son, Keith, of Manhattan; a daughter, Melanie, of Berkeley, Calif.; and his mother, Ethel Yurman of Deerfield Beach, Fla.

HEADLINE: Bernard Rifkin, 84, Union Leader and Educator

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Bernard Rifkin, a union leader and an educator who helped create the country's first fully accredited labor college, died on Friday at his home in lower Manhattan. He was 84.
Mr. Rifkin retired in 1976 as a director of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, Council 37, A.F.L.-C.I.O. District 37, a nationwide organization based in New York. 
 At District 37, he began a high-school equivalency program in 1968 and went on to organize the School of New Resources, DC 37 campus, for the College of New Rochelle in 1972. The first union-operated college, it offers four-year degrees in subjects like communications, management and labor studies. Union members are offered the chance to complete their college studies with evening and weekend courses.
Mr. Rifkin, who was born in Brooklyn, was associated with several unions as an organizer and top official, including the United Automobile Workers, which he joined in 1953. He was educational director of that union's eastern region and became a close associate of Walter P. Reuther, who headed the U.A.W.
In the 1960's, he was a labor adviser to the United States Agency for International Development. During his stint abroad with the A.I.D., he helped train workers in unionism. He was arranging for the construction of two schools at a tin-mining camp in the interior of Bolivia in 1963 when he and a group of other foreigners and Bolivian technicians were caught in a confrontation between Communist miners and the Government of President Victor Paz Estenssoro. They were kidnapped and held for 11 days before being released unharmed.
With his wife of 58 years, the former Susan Levins, Mr. Rifkin wrote "The American Labor Source Book" (McGraw-Hill, 1979), a hefty compendium of labor history, various unions and a broad range of other subjects concerning labor-management relations.
In addition to his wife, Mr. Rifkin is survived by two sons, Erik of Baltimore and Paul of Falmouth, Mass.; a daughter, Karen Rifkin of Ukiah, Calif., and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: US Air Cuts Fares In Line With Rivals

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Va., Aug. 28

 BODY:
US Air Group said today that it was cutting fares as much as 58 percent from nondiscounted econony prices, responding to moves by the Northwest Airlines Corporation and Continental Airlines Inc.
US Air, based in Arlington, is discounting flights to more than 7,500 destinations in the United States, Canada and the Caribbean. 
 With the markdown, travelers flying, for example, between Charlotte, N.C., and Denver, for example, can save as much as $397.
In most markets, tickets must be bought by Friday and will require a Friday-night stay and seven-day advance purchase. In other markets, discounted tickets can be bought until Sept. 15 and will require a Saturday night stay and 14-day advance notice. All travel must be completed by Dec. 15.
On Sunday, Northwest and Continental announced fare cuts as great as 50 percent on travel in the United States and to some foreign cities.

HEADLINE: Leaky Boats on the Rising Tide

BYLINE: By Steven Rattner; Steven Rattner is a managing director of Lazard Freres & Company, investment bankers.

 BODY:
It's time to move on from the debate about whether income distribution in America is becoming more unequal. Countless studies have confirmed the greatest imbalance of earnings in decades. What we need is a partnership between Government and businesses that can attack the problem not by bringing down the rich but by lifting the rest of Americans.
Since 1973, annual earnings of the bottom 10 percent of workers have dropped by 24 percent (after adjustment for inflation), while those of the top 20 percent have increased by 10 percent. As a result, the United States -- the great egalitarian society -- has the widest income disparity of any modern democratic nation. 
And the problem has gotten worse over the last four years, a period during which more than seven million jobs were created and inflation and interest rates remained low. The average worker's wage dropped 2.3 percent (in real terms) during the fiscal year that ended March 31.
No one should doubt the risks of stagnant incomes and greater inequality. Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said recently that the trend toward greater income disparity could be "a major threat to our society." Sustained economic growth can't occur without rising personal incomes to support consumer purchases. Can it be a coincidence that the last great period of income inequality -- the 1920's -- ended with the Great Depression?
The diminishing standard of living for many breeds resentment over issues like affirmative action and immigration. And conflict also grows between workers and bosses when a chief executive makes 150 times the average worker's salary (up from 35 times in 1974, as reported by Business Week).
With all these social and economic pressures, the current political instability -- rampant anti-incumbent sentiment and talk of third parties and independent candidates -- can hardly be surprising.
To reduce the income gap, we must do something about its source: the mismatch between the skills of the work force and the jobs that are available. Recent job creation has occurred mostly in the highly skilled, professional and managerial areas; but too few workers are being prepared for such jobs. And even these jobs are at risk, since corporations are increasingly hiring educated workers overseas who will work for less.
As a result, for all but a highly skilled few, workers simply don't command the leverage they used to, particularly since the companies they work for face stiffer global competition. Thus, although worker productivity has been rising -- the key ingredient for increased future incomes -- the fruits of the recovery have been shoring up the bottom line rather than reaching workers.
Take the case of American Airlines, whose Transport Workers Union agreed this month to trade wage increases for job and pay protection. For the next three years, 27,000 employees, from mechanics to meteorologists, will receive no across-the-board pay increases. For the three years after that, they will receive only minimal increases. In addition, the airline will be able to hire new workers for less-skilled jobs at lower wages.
The same week came the report of the fate of 800 workers in West Virginia, forced to take lower-paying jobs when Maytag closed a vending-machine plant and opened a new, lower-wage factory in South Carolina.
Some workers are beginning to adjust to the new economy. The growing wage disparity and scarcity of good jobs has already encouraged young Americans to pursue more education. But Government also has a role to play in easing the oversupply of workers competing for low-skilled jobs. That means education initiatives that embrace the market. One such approach would be to offer corporations tax incentives to encourage more training.
Training by employers, however, is not enough; many employers train very narrowly for the job immediately at hand. This can limit a worker's flexibility rather than enhance it. To avoid this pitfall, the Clinton Administration has put forth two creative proposals. First, families making less than $120,000 a year would be permitted to deduct up to $10,000 a year for education and training costs. The Administration would also replace some 70 Federal jobs programs with a voucher system that would pay up to $2,620 a year for up to two years to allow workers the flexibility to get training where the jobs are.
In a period of anti-government backlash, these ideas should be greeted with enthusiasm. But Congressional Republicans have ignored the issue. Indeed, their proposals, essentially huge cuts in everything, would worsen matters. While proposals like the Administration's aren't the only solution, we need to give them a try. It's fine for the rich to get richer. It's not fine for everyone else to get poorer.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Why Not Unions to Combat Sweatshops?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "How an American Industry Gets Away With Slave Labor" (Week in Review, Aug. 20):
It is disturbing that a published interview with Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich on exploitation of workers makes no mention of the most effective remedy for mistreatment: strong unions. Empirical evidence confirms that nonunion workers are more likely to endure sweatshop conditions than are union members. In 1994, for example, union members' earnings were 37 percent higher than for unrepresented workers. 
 While Mr. Reich mentions the Fair Labor Standards Act as one weapon against worker exploitation, the National Labor Relations Act has historically been the most valuable tool. Passed in 1935, it established the legal right of private-sector workers to organize unions. Its supporters argued that the inequality of bargaining power between employers and unorganized employees substantially burdened the flow of commerce by depressing wage rates and the purchasing power of wage earners.
The act endorsed unionization: "It is hereby declared to be the policy of the United States to eliminate . . . obstructions to the free flow of commerce . . . by encouraging the practice . . . of collective bargaining."
Two years after its passage, the N.L.R.A.'s constitutionality was upheld by the Supreme Court. Then, Chief Justice Charles E. Hughes wrote: "Long ago we stated the reason for labor organizations. We said that they were organized out of the necessities of the situation; that a single employee was helpless in dealing with an employer; . . . that if the employer refused to pay him the wages he thought fair, he was nevertheless unable to leave the employ and resist arbitrary and unfair treatment; [the] union was essential to give laborers opportunity to deal on an equality with their employer."
In the years that followed, millions of workers organized and lifted themselves out of sweatshop conditions. In 1945 unionization peaked at 35.5 percent of the work force. From 1950 to 1960, average weekly earnings rose 23 percent. This was the largest sustained rise in living standards in the 20th century and occurred in the only decade when union density remained above 30 percent.
After unionization dipped below 30 percent in 1962, wages rose more slowly. As union density continued to fall, from 1972 to 1995, workers' earnings declined steadily and, to our nation's shame, slave labor has re-emerged in our economy.
That any published conversation on sweatshops, especially with a United States Labor Secretary, can make no mention of labor unions is incredible. Worker exploitation is not insoluble. Renewing our commitment to collective bargaining is a first step.
 
JEFFREY GRABELSKY
Senior Extension Associate
New York State School of Industrial
and Labor Relations, Cornell
New York, Aug. 21, 1995

HEADLINE: Banks Say Loan Demand Is Up Sharply

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28

 BODY:
Demand for consumer loans and mortgages grew sharply in the last three months, and banks made it easier for businesses to borrow, the Government said today.
The Federal Reserve said a survey of lending officers at 83 banks found that credit demand by businesses increased moderately in contrast with a marked rise in consumer loan applications. 
 Continuing a trend begun last year, banks eased standards for commercial and industrial loans, the survey showed. In contrast, lenders said only a few banks were willing to ease terms for consumer installment loans.
The Fed reported three weeks ago that consumer credit grew for the 25th straight month in June, but the rate of increase was the slowest since February.
In today's report, one-fourth of the banks surveyed said that demand for consumer installment loans grew, and half said demand for home mortgages had increased since the last survey in May.
"Banks had indicated a decline in demand for loans in both of these categories in the past two surveys," the Fed said.
There has been little change in standards for approving business loans but a continued easing of loan terms, the survey showed. Fewer than 10 percent of the banks questioned said they had lowered standards for commercial and industrial loans to large companies, and even fewer indicated they had eased standards for small and midsized companies.

HEADLINE: A Sleeping Arts Giant Reawakens

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING 

DATELINE: NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Aug. 26

 BODY:
Dancers twisted and looped like parts of a giant machine on a stage set up in a courtyard that was once the parking lot of the Sprague Electric Company, until the early 1980's the major industry in this sturdy but economically depressed old mill town in the Northern Berkshires.
A dancer, also a part of the performance, pushed fabric back and forth through an old sewing machine on a stage covered with a sea of billowing white material not far from the abandoned factory buildings where more than a century ago mill workers printed cotton. Another dancer quietly sang a familiar old union song, coaxing an audience of about 400 artists, former factory workers and families to join in. 
 The singing rose a little uncertainly through the waning afternoon light, the dancers' moving bodies reflected on windows in the low, sprawling brick buildings surrounding the parking yard. Looking closely, one could see embedded in the grimy interior windowsills the artifacts of a once-healthy economy, bits of colored wire and blue ceramic beads that were used for the electronic parts the plant made.
The sleeping behemoth known as the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, or Mass Moca for short, a huge arts complex intended in part to revitalize the local economy, was reawakening.
The project has nearly died four times in its nine years, the victim of state and art-world politics and changing economic priorities. But in April Massachusetts released $18.6 million to start construction, which is expected to be completed in 1997 or early 1998 at a cost of $26 million. And on Wednesday Mass Moca is to take title to the property, donated by a subsidiary of the Penn Central Railroad, its last owner. Renovation has just begun on several of the 28 buildings in the 13-acre factory complex, which has not been used since 1985. More than a quarter of the available 500,000 square feet will be renovated in the first phase, for which Mass Moca has raised the remaining $8 million.
The concert, a children's workshop and a sampling of new and recent dance by the Everett Dance Theater on Saturday afternoon was the first co-production of Mass Moca and the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, one of eight partners in the complex. On Sept. 23, a performance by the Band will inaugurate the Night Shift Cafe. It is the creation of Mort Cooperman, who founded the Lone Star Cafe in Manhattan, and it plans to present American music, including blues, jazz, and country-and-western, and produce videos and recordings throughout the complex.
"It's finally going to happen," John Barrett 3d, the Mayor of North Adams, said. "This project has had more lives than a cat. A lot of peaks and valleys, but mostly valleys. It's amazing that we're still here."
The Sprague plant was the economic heart and life of North Adams, employing about a fifth of the city's population of 20,000, as was the mill it replaced. The earliest buildings date from 1875, when Arnold Print Works opened a factory to print and dye raw cotton. The factory closed in 1917, and Sprague arrived in the 1930's. Part of the first stage of creating Mass Moca has been compiling the workers' histories in interviews by museum officials and members of the Everett Dance Company.
City residents are excited, said Sandra Burton, a choreographer from New York City who moved to the area 12 years ago and is the coordinator of the dance department at Williams College. "I've sat on the bus from Boston to North Adams and listened to the people who ride that bus and who talk with such excitement about Mass Moca," Ms. Burton said. "People who are not artists. They feel it will open up the region in ways we've needed."
It was Mayor Barrett who suggested the sprawling complex to Thomas Krens, who was then director of the Williams College Art Museum, for a museum of contemporary artworks too large for most New York City museums. Mr. Krens, now director of the Guggenheim Museum, envisioned a hotel and convention center, shops, restaurants and condominiums at the site. State and city officials saw the project as revitalizing a depressed area. "The city leadership of North Adams realized that the days of the single-plant, one-company town were over," Joseph Thompson, the director of Mass Moca, said. "There were no I.B.M.'s, no paper clip manufacturers to come in."
A $35 million state bond issue to help finance Mass Moca was approved in 1988 by the state legislature. But some questioned (and continue to question) whether the complex, first scheduled to open in 1992, could draw enough money and people to survive in a city that is about three hours from New York and Boston and one hour from Tanglewood and Jacob's Pillow.
The money was frozen in 1991 by the new Governor, William F. Weld, who said the project relied too heavily on government support and gave museum officials a year to raise nearly $12 million privately. The museum did not meet that goal and extensions were granted with the understanding that a new plan for the site would be developed. In 1993, Mass Moca announced it would become a multi-disciplinary cultural center with galleries, performance and rehearsal spaces, studios for artists and production facilities. The first phase of construction is expected to provide 65,000 square feet of exhibition space and 25,000 square feet each for theater, for sound, film and multimedia production and post-production facilities, and for other film and multimedia projects.
An early player in the new plan was Sam Miller, a former director of Jacob's Pillow, which will have a sound and production stage. The Guggenheim, an even earlier partner, will lend artworks.
The Kleiser-Walczak Construction Company of Hollywood, which produces computer-generated special effects, will install a studio for new product development. And 501C3, a research and development organization in New York that focuses on multimedia products and on-line programs, will have its headquarters, a lab and a training facility at Mass Moca.
"This could be an artistic center that would enable dancers and other artists to get in at the beginning of new technology rather than take what technology has handed out," said Sali Ann Kriegsman, the current director of Jacob's Pillow. "This might be a chance for artists to sit down and work together and find out how technology can serve them."
The exhibition and theater spaces will be used by the four other partners: the Japanese American Cultural and Community Center of Los Angeles, the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute of Williamstown, the Lucien Aigner Trust and the American History Workshop in Brooklyn.
The handsome brick buildings are linked at their corners or by covered-bridge-like walkways, creating the sense of a ghostly, mazelike city. "The buildings themselves are noble," Mr. Thompson said, "and the raw interior spaces have the sense of scale and proportion and sort of toughness, even, that we intend to preserve as much as possible."
An informal outdoor movie theater will occupy one courtyard, with a screen covering one side of a building. Floors will be removed in the first two buildings to be renovated to create spaces as high as 38 feet and as long as football fields for exhibitions, performances or film production.
The architects are Bruner/Cott, a mill-restoration firm in Cambridge, Mass., and Frank Gehry of Los Angeles and Robert Venturi of Philadelphia. Spaces will open to artists as the renovation of each building is completed. But the Mass Moca site was used even before Saturday's performance.
Last fall, 200 members of the New England Artists' Trust, a regional organization of artists in all media, had its annual meeting there. Writers and performers, painters and sculptors spilled out into raw spaces in buildings throughout the complex to work and talk and get to know each other better. "People did installations," Ms. Burton recalled. "I taught a workshop. We had lunch in different spaces. It was wonderful. We used the space."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Everett Dance Theater performed on Saturday at the factory complex the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art is renovating. (Alan E. Solomon for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Budget Cuts Seen By Science Group As Very Harmful For U.S. Research

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE 

 BODY:
FEDERAL financing of nonmilitary scientific research in the United States will decline by one-third within seven years, the American Association for the Advancement of Science says in a report to be released today. It warns that "the long-term effects of dismantling a coherent scientific enterprise could be very harmful."
The study projects financing trends through the year 2002, based on the budget resolution passed by Congress on June 29 and on subsequent actions by the House and Senate in drafting appropriations bills for the fiscal year 1996. Deep projected reductions in the support of research and development, in some cases 100 percent, represent "the most significant across-the-board funding cuts to the research-and-development enterprise in the post-World War II era," the authors of the report wrote. 
 The A.A.A.S., a professional society with more than 140,000 individual members, is the largest scientific federation in the world and tracks the financing of American science every year. Dr. Albert H. Teich, who directs the association's division of science and policy programs, said in an interview that "what we're trying to do is call people's attention to the implications of present trends."
The current drive in Congress toward deficit reduction and a balanced budget by 2002 is strongly supported by new members of Congress whose election platforms called for sweeping cutbacks in Government spending.
The budget cuts will affect science unevenly. Money appropriated for the National Science Foundation may decline only a few percent in 1996, and the National Institutes of Health may actually get an increase of more than 6 percent. But some major programs of NASA, the United States Geological Survey and the National Institute of Standards and Technology face extinction, and the overall trend in Federal support of science alarms many scientists.
Scientific groups are worried that the era of generous treatment from Congress may be waning. "For many years," Dr. Teich said, "we had a protective umbrella of members of Congress who understood science, were sympathetic toward it and were associated with it. But now we have an awful lot of new people in Congress who don't have any connection with science. It's up to the scientific community to try to reach them."
Many scientists and research administrators acknowledge that Federal belt-tightening has made cuts in research support inevitable. But they believe that Congress has been moving too hastily and without adequate consultation with experts.
An important factor in the trend, besides the need to cut Federal spending across the board, has been the conclusion of the cold war, which, Dr. Teich said, had "provided a geopolitical situation in which political-military power was strongly associated with a nation's scientific and technological prowess." With a decline in the perceived need to maintain that prowess, he said, science has lost political support.
Among the fields in which the association expects the sharpest reductions are research on environmental issues, fusion-energy development, atmospheric and geological problems, unmanned space programs and research assistance to industry. For 1996, research funds for Federal agencies, other than the Defense Department, have been reduced in Congressional appropriations bills by more than 5 percent. The National Institutes of Health was the only major Federal agency granted a budget increase, of 6.2 percent, but it was included in a bill that President Clinton might veto for other reasons.
Some Federal departments and the research they support may not survive the next few years. The Commerce Department has been made a target for elimination by many Congressmen, leading to uncertainty about the future of two of its major research agencies, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and the National Institute of Standards and Technology.
NOAA investigates changes in global climate, like the possible greenhouse warming of the planet caused by gaseous emissions of human industry and the so-called ozone hole, a thinning of the atmosphere's protective ozone layer believed to have been caused by the release of chlorofluorocarbon compounds. NOAA faces a probable reduction in 1996 of 14.1 percent in money for its operations, research and facilities, the science association says.
At the National Institute of Standards and Technology (formerly the National Bureau of Standards), Congress has already eliminated the Advanced Technology Program, a $466.5 million undertaking to assist private industry in the development of technology.
In a recent speech, Dr. Arati Prabhakar, the institute's director, said that "if the current Congress has its way, it will turn the clock back 20 years and put technological innovation on the shelf."
Republican leaders in Congress, however, have argued that Federal subsidies for research conducted to benefit private industry are unnecessary, and that industry should pay for its own research.
The biggest expected dollar reduction in 1996 Federal support for science is the $716.5 million that the House has voted to pare from NASA's $9.5 billion budget. A major share of that reduction would come from Mission to Planet Earth, a system for using satellites to track changes in the earth's ecosystems.
Another research casualty of the 1996 budget will be the Interior Department's Bureau of Mines, for which Congress has provided no money at all. The bureau, which this year is spending $102 million, studies mine safety and supervises the helium-conservation program under which some of this irreplaceable gas, separated from the natural gas with which it is mixed, is stored in underground caverns.
Faced with so-called rescissions, or cuts in money previously appropriated by Congress for the present year, as well as the further cuts expected for 1996, many Federal research groups have begun dismissing scientists and other employees.
For example, the United States Geological Survey, founded in 1879 as part of the Interior Department, has been forced to truncate one of its three main programs, its geology program, which was created to explore and map the nation's geological resources.
"We have reached the point," said Donovan B. Kelly, spokesman for the agency, "at which there is no longer enough money after fixed expenses are paid to support field research in geology. We therefore have to make deep cuts. Nationwide, about 500 employees of the program will be separated by mid-October, and another 200 will be downgraded or transferred to other jobs. It's really hard doing this, when you know the names and faces of the people leaving -- people who were highly trained to do special jobs on behalf of the nation, and who are now being cast off."
Mr. Kelly said he hoped the geological survey's international earthquake network would be preserved. The network links seismographic instruments operated by about 120 countries with the survey's network, giving participating nations timely information about all earthquakes and greatly broadening the data base on which seismological research depends.
High-energy physics research suffered a devastating blow last year when Congress, charging mismanagement, cut off funds for the $10 billion superconducting supercollider, a proton accelerator that would have made the United States the world's leader in the field until well into the next century. Leadership is now expected to pass to Europe after the turn of the century, as a consortium of nations completes the Large Hadron Collider near Geneva. Many American physicists hope to find work there.
Another branch of physics, which holds out the hope of developing hydrogen fusion as a cheap, nonpolluting, renewable source of energy, is expected to suffer a serious reduction of financing in 1996. House action calls for a reduction of 36.4 percent in the budget for magnetic confinement fusion, whose main beneficiary is the experimental Tokamak reactor at the Princeton Plasma Physics Laboratory in New Jersey.
Dr. Ronald C. Davidson, director of the laboratory, said in an interview that if only $229 million of the requested $366 million budget for the laboratory was granted, as Congressional appropriations committees have done, it would be impossible to build a new-generation experimental reactor, the Tokamak Physics Experiment.
Another major fusion experiment, in which microscopic pellets filled with hydrogen isotopes are bombarded by intense lasers, is in progress at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California, which is operated by the University of California for the Department of Energy. But this, too, faces an uncertain future.
Many of Livermore's projects, including the development of nuclear weapons, are directed and paid for by the Defense Department, which provides the laboratory with a traditionally reliable financing pipeline. Defense Department research is not included in the overall research cuts that Congress has been making, and the House Appropriations Committee has set a 4.2 percent increase in military research and development for 1996, bringing financing to $36.7 billion.
Officials of the A.A.A.S. said the association's gloomy new report was not a prediction, merely a projection.
"Between now and 2002 a lot of things could happen," Dr. Teich said. "We could get another President and a different Congress, or we could have a war, or a recession. Lots of things could change. But what worries scientists is the Congressional resolution enacted in June, which is a broad statement of where Congress wants us to be in 2002. It's not a vision that bodes well for the health of American science."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 8, 1995, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Science Times on Aug. 29 about the expected effects of Congressional budget reductions on research misstated the role of the Defense Department in the development of nuclear weapons at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory. The Defense Department benefits from the programs, but they are directed and paid for by the defense programs division of the Energy Department.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Time Warner Offering $8.5 Billion for Turner
Time Warner was said to be offering $8.5 billion to acquire Turner Broadcasting System, but Turner has not decided whether to accept the offer. An executive close to the discussions said that Ted Turner was "enthusiastic" about folding his company into Time Warner.
Under the terms of the proposed deal, Time Warner would purchase the 81 percent of Turner that it does not already own. Shareholders of Turner would receive seven-tenths to eight- tenths of a share in Time Warner in return for each of their shares in Turner. [Page A1.]
 
Time Warner was said to have agreed with Toshiba and Itochu to restructure their investments in its cable systems and movie studio. The Japanese companies will swap their 11.2 percent stake in Time Warner Entertainment for preferred shares in the parent company. [D3.]
 
Mutual Stock Funds Attracted Record $12.4 Billion in July
Investors poured more money into mutual funds that invest in American stocks last month than ever before, and the trend in August appears to be as good or better. The Investment Company Institute, a mutual fund trade group, reported that investors put a net $12.4 billion into equity funds that invest primarily in American stocks in July, up 57 percent from June. The July figures smashed the record of $10.2 billion, set in March 1993. Market Place. [A1.]
 
L'Oreal in Boycott Settlement
L'Oreal agreed to pay $1.4 million to settle a long-running investigation into charges that it violated American laws against cooperating with the Arab economic boycott of Israel. The settlement is the second largest in the 17-year history of the American anti-boycott law. [D2.]
 
Honda Civic Meets Smog Standard
Honda said its new Civic subcompact model met emissions requirements set by California for 1997, making it the first gasoline-powered, mass-production car to do so. [D2.]
 
Dow Rises in Mixed Market
The stock market recovered from an early selloff in technology issues, and blue-chip stocks rallied. The Dow industrials rose 14.44 points, to 4,608.44, but the Nasdaq composite index lost 4.51 points, to 1,003.64. [D6.]
 
Pulling the Plug on a Port?
New York's harbor, one of the nation's premier ports, has lost much of its business to docks on the New Jersey side. City planning experts are asking whether New York would be better off if it let some or all of its commercial shipping business die. [B1.]
 
Self Magazine Editor Quits
Alexandra D. Penney, the fervent and mercurial editor in chief of Self magazine since 1989, again resigned. The announcement comes 13 months after Ms. Penney quit, then returned a week later. She will stay until a successor is named. [D16.]
 
Speeding Up Your Passport
Travelers often experience long lines when applying for a visa or a passport, but a number of companies will navigate these regulatory minefields for individual travelers. Most companies' standard services include processing passports, visas and documents for business transactions that require approval from the State Department and foreign consular offices. Business Travel. [D16.]
 
Putting Fizz in Wine Ads
In a campaign by the Balet & Albert agency, Food and Wines from France is emulating soft-drink marketers like Pepsi-Cola in presenting emotional, life-style-tinged messages. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D3.]

HEADLINE: Port in a Storm: Planners Question the City's Maritime Future

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Government agencies have spent hundreds of millions of dollars in recent years to subsidize the depressed maritime industry in New York City, once one of the premier ports in the world. But now the city's own planning experts are asking for the first time whether the city would be better off if it let some or all of its commercial shipping business just die.
The marine terminals of New York have been eclipsed since the 1960's by those on the New Jersey side of the harbor, which are better equipped for modern shipping because they have more land and easier access to railways and highways. Government-owned terminals in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Staten Island have been unable to keep up, losing $40 million annually in the last two years, with little prospect of breaking even in the near future. 
 Given the scarcity of government dollars, the City Planning Department said in a report, New York City should examine whether those subsidies, and the land where the terminals are located, should instead be used for other transportation projects or for other ventures. Those might include factories, office complexes and recreation areas, officials said.
"The current approach of continuing to do what has been done in the past is expensive and, more importantly, not working," the report said. "Serious questions need to be answered about the ability of these facilities to meet the shipping needs of the next century."
That recommendation is the latest attempt to shape the discussion about the future of New York City's once-prosperous waterfront, an expanse of rotting piers, abandoned factories and unrealized potential.
But it appears to put the Planning Department at odds with city policy over the last decade, which has been to insure that New Jersey, with 93 percent of the harbor's trade, does not get all of it.
Though the Planning Department merely called for a debate about the terminals and their costs, and did not say that the city should close any of them, the report has nonetheless angered some Giuliani administration officials, local politicians and terminal operators in the city.
"I am furious," said Sal F. Catucci, chief executive of American Stevedoring, which manages the Red Hook Container Terminal in Brooklyn. "You have a bunch of morons who don't know what they are talking about, who have never had a business of their own. If they don't have a port on this side of the river, this city is going to be a ghost town."
Mr. Catucci and others say they cannot understand how the Planning Department could express such doubts only months after the city and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates most of the city's marine terminals, had spent tens of millions of dollars to reopen the Howland Hook Marine Terminal on Staten Island.
Though it was released last week, the recommendation attracted little notice at first because it was buried in a report that was put together to buttress the Giuliani administration's contention that the Port Authority was biased toward New Jersey and must be reorganized.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani cited the report last week when he fired the first shot in a border war with New Jersey, saying the Port Authority should raise the fare on the Port Authority Trans-Hudson, or PATH, commuter railway and the tolls on its bridges and tunnels in order to give more revenue to the city.
Though the Mayor focused on how much the PATH loses annually -- about $200 million -- he failed to note that the report also questions whether the losses on the marine terminals in New York City should be allowed to mount. The major terminals run by the Port Authority in New Jersey turn a collective profit, the Planning Department said. It is not clear where Mr. Giuliani stands on the terminals, but senior administration officials said the report was privately denounced by the city's Economic Development Corporation, which oversees the terminals.
The report said that after some study, the city and the authority might still conclude that the losses were justified or might decide that new investments should be made. But the city and the authority should also determine "whether there are other uses for the marine terminals that would make more economic sense," the report said.
In an interview, Joseph B. Rose, director of the Planning Department and chairman of the City Planning Commission, emphasized that he was not calling for the shutting of the terminals. And he said the recommendations about the terminals had to be seen as part of an overall assessment of the Port Authority, which was the purpose of the report.
All the Port Authority's money-losing ventures, including the PATH line and the Port Authority Bus Terminal, should be scrutinized, he said.
"A lot of the marine investments have to be re-evaluated, in the same way that you re-evaluate the PATH and the industrial parks, and the World Trade Center," Mr. Rose said. "Are these investments and these subsidies operating in such a way that they have the benefit that they were intended to have?"
Mr. Rose also said he thought Howland Hook had more potential than the other terminals, particularly those in Brooklyn, many of which have not had tenants for years.
Peter Yerkes, a spokesman for the Port Authority, declined to comment yesterday on the report, but officials outside the Giuliani administration have not been reticent.
Representative Jerrold L. Nadler, a Democratic whose district includes parts of Manhattan and Brooklyn, sent a letter to Mr. Giuliani in which he praised the Mayor for attacking the Port Authority but also criticized the report's assertions about the marine terminals.
Mr. Nadler, a proponent of building a large containerized shipping port in Brooklyn, told Mr. Giuliani that the city should not give up on its maritime industry.
"Rather than precipitously concluding (as the city planning report seems to do) that these terminals should be closed, there should be a public discussion of whether subsidies to these terminals make sense," Mr. Nadler wrote. "If such a debate were to take place, I am confident that the conclusion would be reached that some of these facilities (particularly those along the Brooklyn waterfront) could be made profitable."
