HEADLINE: Surprising Rise In Immigration Stirs Up Debate

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29

 BODY:
The Census Bureau's report this week that the percentage of the country's population that is foreign born is at its highest level since World War II and is accelerating at a record pace has taken demographers aback and is fueling an already intense debate over immigration in American life.
The surprising figures result in part from a declining birth rate among native-born Americans, but more from increased immigration. The proportion of Americans who were born elsewhere rose to 8.7 percent last year, or 22.6 million people, according to the Census Bureau. The bureau estimated that about four million of the immigrants were in the United States illegally. 
 The proportion of immigrants is the highest since 1940, when it was 8.8 percent, although it remains far short of the modern historic high of 14.7 percent in 1910. Since 1970, the percentage has doubled. From 1990 to 1994, 4.5 million immigrants came to the United States, nearly as many as landed during the entire decade of the 1970's.
Though it is written in the flat prose of Government demographic reports, the study, "The Foreign Born Population: 1994" is sure to add to the debate over immigration, which has already emerged as a hot issue in the Presidential race. The issue is particularly incendiary in populous states like California and New York, the two whose populations contain the highest proportion of foreign-born residents. According to the report, nearly 25 percent of California's population and 16 percent of New York's were born outside the United States.
In New Jersey, 13.5 percent of residents were born outside the United States. The report did not provide figures for Connecticut.
Although the United States is a nation that has been largely built by successive waves of immigration, the rising number of immigrants has been the subject of an increasingly bitter debate in recent years. Proposed laws, and ballot initiatives like Proposition 187 in California, have sought to limit the influx of immigrants or to cut them off from a variety of Government benefits.
But despite the widespread attention given to the subject, demographers interviewed today said they were surprised by the large number of recent immigrants, both legal and illegal, turned up in the bureau's study.
"It's a very high percentage," said Jeffrey Passel, director of the Program for Research on Immigration Policy at the Urban Institute, a nonprofit research organization in Washington. He found especially striking the fact that about one in five arrived in the last five years. "That's much higher than numbers we've had historically, going back 20, 30, 40, 100 years," he said.
Even before the latest census report, which noted a quickening pace of immigration, the Urban Institute projected that if current trends continued, the proportion of foreign-born residents would gradually reach 13 percent or 14 percent within the next 50 years.
The bureau's findings are based on a nationwide survey of 60,000 households that asked individuals where they were born. As such, the estimate includes legal immigrants, refugees, illegal aliens, as well as students and tourists whose visas have expired.
"Legal and illegal immigrants, refugees, tourists and student visa overstays, we don't ask," said Kristin Hansen, a demographer with the bureau who compiled the study. "It's just anybody who was in our sample who said they were foreign born. I'm sure that those numbers contain some illegals. How many, I have no idea."
The bureau did not survey residents in dormitory settings, like farm labor camps, military barracks, colleges or prisons. As a result, some experts say the bureau may be underestimating the actual number of foreign-born residents.
Historians, economists, social scientists and advocates for tightened controls on immigration say the rising proportion of foreign-born residents could have striking effects on the country's economic, social and political environment.
"It bodes an accelerating public debate about the role of immigration at this point in our history," said Dan Stein, executive director of the Federation for American Immigration Reform, a group pressing for a moratorium on immigration.
Past waves of immigration helped fuel the ranks of xenophobic, and sometimes violent, groups like the Know-Nothings in the 19th century and the Ku Klux Klan in the 1920's. While, in comparison to the activities of those groups, there has been little organized violence against immigrants, the issue of whether to curtail immigration is certain to be a major issue in the coming Presidential campaign and in Congress.
Bills have already been introduced to deny public assistance to legal immigrants or to make their sponsors financially responsible for them, to streamline deportation of undocumented workers, to crack down on alien smuggling, to end the automatic granting of asylum to Cuban refugees and to beef up the Border Patrol.
Two candidates for the Republican Presidential nomination, Gov. Pete Wilson of California and Patrick J. Buchanan, the columnist, were strong supporters of a successful ballot initiative last year that denied Government assistance to illegal immigrants. Both have made stemming immigration a central focus of their campaigns.
According to the report, the vast majority of foreign-born residents are from Mexico, followed by the Philippines, Cuba, El Salvador, Canada, Germany and China.
Experts say the surge in the number of foreign born people mainly stemmed from the 1965 Immigration Act, which replaced a policy based on quotas for various countries with one that allowed relatives of recent immigrants easier entry into the country. As a result, immigration increased to about 600,000 a year during the 1970's and 1980's.
A new law enacted in 1990 which maintained the policy of family reunification and also gave immigrants with more education and skills a higher priority further increased the numbers to about 800,000 a year.
In addition, a 1986 law provided amnesty to illegal immigrants, allowing them to qualify for citizenship.
The Census Bureau study provides some ammunition to both sides of the immigration debate. It indicates that 20.9 percent of recent immigrants over the age of 25 have bachelor's degrees, compared with 14.7 percent of native-born Americans. Paradoxically, 36 percent of recent immigrants over 25 years old did not finish high school, compared with 17 percent of those born in the United States.
The report also noted that 5.7 percent of recent immigrants have received public assistance, most notably Aid to Families With Dependent Children. That compares with 2.9 percent of native-born Americans, a fact certain to be seized upon by those seeking to curtail immigration.
"These figures clearly show we cannot continue what we have been doing indefinitely," Mr. Stein said. "The question is will we have good, solid sensible reforms now, or radical and extreme proposals down the line."
But Mr. Passel argued that studies conducted by the Urban Institute indicated that the bulk of foreign-born residents receiving public assistance were refugees who had fled political turmoil and arrived in the United States with very little means of support. If refugees are removed from the equation, Mr. Passel said, the percentage of foreign born people receiving public assistance is comparable with native-born Americans.

HEADLINE: Productivity-Geared Study Gives U.S. Schools Poor Marks

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29

 BODY:
The United States does not get its money's worth from the $285 billion a year it spends on education, a panel of productivity experts concluded today.
The panel, the Consortium on Productivity in the Schools, took three years to examine the nation's network of 84,000 public schools as it would a business, focusing on productivity and return. 
 Its report, "Using What We Have to Get the Schools We Need," found a lack of quality control, of investment in research, of defined goals and of accountability, as well as many levels of restrictions and mandates that limit teacher innovation. The report called for greater autonomy for teachers and principals, financial incentives to reward good schools and better evaluation of reforms.
"This report is telling us in no uncertain terms that improving our schools will only happen if we have clear goals and keep from jumping from fad to fad," Education Secretary Richard W. Riley said in a statement.
The Consortium on Productivity in the Schools was formed in 1992 by the Institute of Education and the Economy at Teachers College of Columbia University. It was financed by the G. Victor and Margaret D. Ball Foundation, Citicorp and the Robert and Terri Cohn Family Foundation, and was made up of nine experts on productivity and systems analysis from the fields of industry, health, finance, government and education.
Its chairwoman, Sue E. Berryman, senior education specialist at the World Bank, said efforts to improve education had failed because they had been fragmented, designed to overhaul only parts of the system and not the system as a whole.
The panel called for possible performance contracts, like those used in Hartford, Baltimore and other cities that contract with for-profit companies to run their schools. It also urged succinct performance criteria for "all major functions of the system, not merely teaching and learning." And it said that districts should be permitted to open new schools outside existing bureaucracies and that parents should be able to choose among them. Currently, 81 percent of American children have no choice in school assignment, 11 percent do, and 8 percent are enrolled in private school.
The panel, following a similar recommendation from the American Federation of Teachers, also called for a national examination that all high school students would be required to pass to earn a diploma. And it called for better accounting in everything from the way textbooks are bought to the way teachers are paid.

HEADLINE: John Costello, 52, Who Wrote Of War, Espionage and Mores

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
John Costello, a Scottish-born historian who shed new light on aspects of World War II and helped to untangle the webs of cold war intrigue, died on Saturday while on a flight from London to Miami. He was 52 and lived in Miami and Manhattan.
His New York agent, John Hawkins, said the exact cause of death awaited further tests. He said Mr. Costello was in Britain to do research and had suffered from shellfish poisoning a few days earlier. 
 The subjects of Mr. Costello's dozen books ranged from the war in the Atlantic and Pacific to Anglo-American mores, code-making and code-breaking, and counterintelligence. They were peopled with heroes and villains and moles, Winston Churchill and Rudolf Hess, the treasonous Cambridge cabal and one of the century's master spies, Aleksandr Orlov.
He had an earlier career as a documentary film maker and believed that a historian should bring not only thorough research to his writing, but "color, light, action" as well.
When the Soviet Union collapsed he became the first Westerner to see K.G.B. data for historical use. The upshoot was "Deadly Illusions" (Crown, 1993), written with Oleg Tsarev, a former K.G.B. colonel.
It was the story of Aleksandr Orlov, Stalin's top spy and the highest-ranking Soviet intelligence officer ever to go into hiding in the West. He was the Soviet contact for the Cambridge espionage ring of H. A. R. (Kim) Philby, Donald Maclean, Guy Burgess, Anthony Blunt and the still-mysterious "fifth man."
When he made his break in 1938, he not so much defected but sought refuge from Stalinist purges. In fact, when he finally "cooperated" with United States agents, he failed to mention the Cambridge ring or to identify the scores of other Westerners he had recruited or handled -- spies who continued to inflict damage for decades to come.
"Mask of Treachery" (Morrow, 1988) dealt with Blunt, the royal curator of paintings who was stripped of his knighthood but never disclosed the full extent of his treachery. The book also accused the British of deceiving the Americans about just how much the K.G.B. had riddled British intelligence.
"Ten Days of Destiny" (Morrow, 1991) covered Britain's wartime appeasers and one of the most puzzling incidents of World War II, the solo flight of Rudolf Hess, Hitler's deputy, to Scotland in May 1941.
His "Virtue Under Fire" (Little, Brown, 1986) examined how prewar morality had been battered in the United States and Britain with a rise in underage sin. The author ascribed it to hedonism in the shadow of death.
John Edward Costello was born in Greenock, near Glasgow, and graduated in law and Soviet economic history from Cambridge. He worked as a writer and as a director and scriptwriter for BBC documentaries in London before he became an author of books.
Mr. Costello is survived by his parents, John and Pattie Suzanne Costello of Newbury, Berkshire, England; a brother, Bryan, and sister, Susan Costello, both of England.

HEADLINE: Free Cable TV in Omaha

BYLINE: By Dow Jones 

 BODY:
Basic cable television service at low rates has become increasingly common, but Cox Communications Inc. is apparently the first company to provide it for nothing. The company, based in Atlanta, is offering a basic package of 21 channels to subscribers in Omaha, with no monthly fee. The only charge is an installation fee of $19.95. A Cox Communications spokesman, David Andersen, said the company knew of no other free cable packages in the United States. An analyst at Oppenheimer & Company, Alan S. Gould, said the package, which offers premium channels for a fee, made economic sense for Cox Communications, a subsidiary of Cox Enterprises Inc.

HEADLINE: Where the Budget Ax Turns Dull

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29

 BODY:
This was supposed to be the Lizzie Borden of Congresses, the one whose fiscal broadax would whack away at friend and foe alike in the name of a balanced budget. And in some spots, what remains of Government programs is a gruesome sight indeed.
But eight months into the budget-slicing, the bleeding by corporate America seems to be not a great deal more than from your average shaving cut. Of the $1 trillion that Republicans have pledged to slice from the budget by 2002, say experts at the right-leaning Cato Institute, Federal programs that subsidize business are so far contributing perhaps $75 billion -- and that figure is dropping fast. 
 Toss in a bundle of new corporate tax breaks that Congress intends to pass, say experts from the political left like Ralph Nader's group Public Citizen, and businesses may even emerge from the fiscal blood bath with a net gain.
Those numbers could change drastically, of course, with a few Presidential vetoes or even a hairline crack in Republican resolve. The House and Senate have yet to send a single major spending bill to President Clinton, and the biggest bill of all -- the one that would cut taxes, social programs and programs like farm subsidies -- has yet to be written.
Even so, critics say, the same Congress that believes welfare saps the spirit and dulls the will of people seems to have concluded that business cannot compete without it.
Examples abound. What many critics regard as one of the most egregious Government handouts is the Agriculture Department's market promotion program, which gives cash to American companies -- and in some cases foreign ones -- to advertise and sell everything from Big Macs to mink pelts. This program actually won a 29 percent increase in its budget.
And although the Republican-controlled House condemns handouts to technology companies, it provided about $6 million for logging roads that timber companies use to reach remote stands of trees. Research and development programs in the Energy Department, which benefit a number of companies, had been scheduled to lose two-thirds of their $442 million budget, but lost merely $62 million in the House.
"Right now I'd say business is getting off very lightly," said Stephen Moore, Cato's director of fiscal policy studies.
Robert Greenstein, a former Clinton Administration official who heads the liberal Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, wholly agrees. "The rhetoric was about a new kind of budget-cutting," he said. "The reality was the same old seamy stuff -- the constituents with power are still working behind the scenes, exerting it."
Many in the business world would dispute all this. If programs that aid business are being cut less than programs that aid people, that is partly because aid to business is comparatively tiny, said Bruce Josten, a senior vice president of the United States Chamber of Commerce.
Just how much money is involved here? The numbers vary widely. Congress's own budget office reckons that direct Federal aid to business -- part of what it dispassionately calls "financial support" -- totals $30.1 billion in the 1995 fiscal year. Corporate tax breaks are harder to quantify, but both the budget office and Congress's Joint Committee on Taxation say the total might reach $60 billion.
Mr. Nader's group pegs corporate welfare at precisely $167.2 billion. The Cato Institute discounts all but the most blatant tax breaks and so employs a smaller figure.
Mr. Greenstein's group is relying on Congress's estimate. And it will soon release a report that concludes that the current mix of tax cuts and spending cuts will prove "basically a wash" for business.
If so, that is a far different outcome from what the new Congress advertised when it took control of the budget process in the spring.
As Republicans depicted the situation then, business would assume a reasonable share of the budget-balancing load. The May issue of the party's official magazine devoted two pages to a dissection of corporate welfare, and the straight-arrow chairmen of both the Senate and House Budget Committees took pains to warn that no one would be exempt from the budget knife.
"Everything's on the table," the House panel's chairman, Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, said last spring.
Mr. Kasich, one of Congress's most ardent deficit-fighters, had singled out some $15 billion in corporate subsidies for extinction, and sought to close an additional $25 billion in tax loopholes. And some business-friendly programs on his list have in fact been carved up.
Both the House and Senate agreed in principle to shut down the $4-billion-a-year Commerce Department and move its 36,000 workers and salvageable units, like the National Weather Service, to other agencies. Both have voted to end research into a gas-turbine helium reactor, a $2.6 billion program that experts have called unworkable and critics contend is a gift to the nuclear power industry.
Agriculture Department subsidies for wheat and other crops, many of which go to well-off farmers and corporations, could shrink by as much as $9 billion over the next five years. Most experts say the subsidies distort the food market and often limit production rather than expand it.
The House voted to abolish the Technology Reinvestment Program, a $500-million-a-year effort to help companies convert military technology to commercial use. It also zeroed out the Advanced Technology Program, a $350-million-a-year unit of the Commerce Department that gives businesses seed money for research in any of 11 fields deemed especially promising.
Both programs have the distinction of being Administration favorites; the President had wanted to raise the Advanced Technology budget to $490 million next year. But House Republicans label this as industrial policy and say the companies -- some of them giants -- would spend their own money if the Government did not offer a handout.
The trouble, the critics say, is that that philosophy is not applied consistently. "I think the Republicans genuinely want to balance the budget," Jill Lancelot, director of Congressional affairs for a spending watchdog, the National Taxpayers Union, said in an interview last week. "But the special interests continue to get handouts from the Federal Government, and that's what's disturbing, and sad, and discouraging. This was supposed to be a new day."
As an example of this inconsistency, the Senate has voted to give $238 million next year to the same technology reinvestment program the House has condemned. And it may be poised to restore part of the Advanced Technology Program's funds as well.
The House preserved the Overseas Private Investment Corporation and the Export-Import Bank, agencies that use loan guarantees and other devices to encourage American companies to expand their markets abroad. And instead of abolishing the Economic Development Administration, a $450-million-a-year grant-making agency whose aim is to attract industry but that is derided by many as a warehouse of political pork, the House voted merely to trim its budget by $102 million.
An unlikely alliance that included Friends of the Earth, the Heritage Foundation, Ralph Nader, the National Taxpayers Union and the teamsters' union fought to scrap the $85.5-million-a-year market promotion program, and instead saw its budget increased to $100 million. The victors were an equally unlikely alliance of rural Democrats and conservative Republicans, many of them from states with industries and food companies that get the grants.
"To cut a program like that, which is working to increase our exports, would be a very radical move," argued Senator Barbara Boxer, a California Democrat with important constituencies in the wine, fruit and nuts businesses.
She was joined by Senator Thad Cochran, a conservative Republican from Mississippi, who said that the Government was merely encouraging McDonald's to peddle American poultry and eggs in places like Singapore when it subsidized the company's advertising abroad.
Republican budget-cutters like Mr. Kasich, who hope to make up some of the lost savings by tightening business tax breaks, may be disappointed. The tax bill passed by the House in April not only leaves current loopholes intact, but also awards impressive new tax advantages to businesses, such as a cut in the capital gains rate to 25 percent and allowing depreciation on equipment that would exceed the amount paid for the equipment.
Mr. Greenstein of the Center for Budget and Policy Priorities estimates that the business tax provisions already approved by the House would cost the Government $51 billion in lost revenue over seven years. An added $195 billion in breaks and lower rates would go to individuals.
Mr. Moore of the Cato Institute said he agreed that some corporate tax breaks were little more than handouts and he cited tax benefits that are given only to producers of methanol as one example. But breaks awarded to all of corporate America, like the depreciation provisions in the House tax bill, are less subsidies than they are changes in fiscal policy, he contended.
He also suggested that those quick to attack the new rulers on Capitol Hill should first look backward.
"I'm the first person to criticize Republicans for their lack of fortitude in cutting corporate welfare," he said, but then acknowledged that "the Democrats ran this place for 40 years, and never cut these programs."
"And it's true on the tax side as well," he added. "Who do we think created these loopholes? This is a bipartisan problem."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Weaken In Line With Bond Futures

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities sagged yesterday in sympathy with bond future contracts, which came under pressure from increasing doubt about the chances of another Fed easing.
Traders said a Market News Service report appeared to have been behind the raised anxiety level of a few market participants. It suggested that Fed policymakers were increasingly confident that the economy was rebounding to an acceptable, noninflationary growth pace and were content to leave short-term interest rates unchanged unless they saw that demand would slacken. 
 However, bonds erased most of the day's losses in late afternoon when the Johnson Redbook survey of major retailers showed sales were off last week, removing some of the inflation fears.
Tony Crescenzi, director of fixed-income trading at Miller, Tabak, Hirsch & Company, a New York brokerage firm, said he was not surprised by the market's reaction to the report. "Because the market has been building in expectations for a rate cut, it is particularly vulnerable to reports showing strong data," he said.
The 30-year bond, which dropped as much as 11/32 in the session, closed down 4/32 in New York to a price of 10 25/32 to yield 6.71 percent, up from 6.70 percent on Monday.
The September Treasury bond futures contract, which has acted as the primer to recent gains in the cash market held above its early lows after new United States data, but remains below Monday's high of 112 28/32. However, some traders suggest this key technical level could be retested in the days ahead, much as it was on Monday.
While the data released yesterday provided little direction for investors, it did give them something to think about. July new-home sales were at an annual rate of 715,000 units and close to expectations, with sales up four-tenths of 1 percent. Analysts said the annual rate was close to economists' average forecast of 712,000 units.
Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston, said the "headline figure hid significant weakness in the underlying details of the new-home sale report." He noted that aside from a 22.5 percent jump in sales in the South region, national sales outside that region plunged 14.9 percent.
The Conference Board's consumer confidence index for the month of August was a bit higher than expected. The overall number was reported at 101.0, down from a revised 101.4 in July but well above economists' forecasts of 100.5. The higher consumer confidence expectations gave some bond traders jitters, since a strong economy would mean no need for easing.
But Mr. Alexy said: "We attached very little significance to this morning's confidence data for two reasons. Confidence readings are not a leading indicator of consumer spending; they tend to be lagging indicators, or coincident at best.
"Also, with the exception of a strange one-month drop in June, the Conference Board's index has been moving sideways in a range of between 99.4 and 104.6, which leaves us near the middle of that range now."
On the technical side of trading, Robin Mesch, chief fixed-income analyst at Thomson Research, predicted the price of the September contract would go higher, with a probability of 113 21/32 -- 28/32. "I figure some consolidation will take place there, which will ultimately resolve to the upside to retest the high 114 27/32 to 115 range," Ms. Mesch said.
She expects some choppy trading in the quarter, and looking ahead to the fourth quarter, she said: "I think the market is setting up to roll over to the downside, but that will not happen until about the first quarter of next year. The market doesn't turn on a dime, turning a train around takes some time."
In the municipal market, yields were little changed. Some investors are encouraged by the drop in the supply of bonds this week at the same time funds are seeing an inflow of money.
With rates in the corporate market at a five-week low, some issuers are getting the jump on the expected pickup in sales after the Labor Day holiday, managers report.
Among the $1.55 billion of corporate issues in the market yesterday were the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae; the Nationsbank Corporation, the Champion International Corporation and Motorola Inc.
Traders said there was strong investor interest in the Nationsbank deal because of their long maturities. The $350 million of 20-year bonds were priced to yield 7.75 percent, or about 98 basis points -- nearly a full percentage point -- more than Treasury securities with a comparable maturity.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Regains Momentum While the Mark's Rally Sputters

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar strengthened yesterday as a rally in the German mark faded.
The dollar, bolstered by speculation that interest rates in both Germany and Japan might be reduced, rose to 1.4779 marks in late New York trading, from 1.4667 marks on Monday. It also surged to 98.21 Japanese yen from 96.77 yen. The British pound slipped to $1.5431 from $1.5497. 
 The recent rally in the dollar had been held back by an advance in the mark after the resignation of the French Finance Minister on Friday. But many analysts said the reaction to the departure of the minister, Alain Madelin, had been overdone, saying there would be little change in French economic policy as a result. Yesterday, the mark retreated against other European currencies.
The dollar's rise against the mark picked up steam after Hans-Jurgen Kobnick, president of the Bundesbank in Rhineland-Palatinate state, was quoted in a German newspaper as saying that German interest rates still had room to ease.
Bob Near, vice president at the Bank of New York, said, "In very quiet and thin markets, a little bit of talk went a long way in helping the dollar stay well bid on the day."
After a surprising half-point cut last Thursday in the official German discount rate, to 3.5 percent, a number of traders expect the Bundesbank to trim its securities repurchase rate today from the current 4.39 percent.
"There is a big concentration on the interest-rate differential between the United States and Germany," said Dave Glowacki, senior trader at NBD Bank in Detroit. "The market believes that as German rates drop and U.S. rates hold steady, that should point to some purchases of U.S. assets, which would lead to some purchases of U.S. dollars."
Lower yields in Germany would make dollar-based investments relatively more attractive.
Expectations about interest rates also helped lift the dollar against the yen. The dollar rose on news that the International Monetary Fund had again urged Tokyo to cut interest rates to help spur economic growth.
The Japanese economy has been hurt by a long-simmering banking crisis and a strong yen.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Prices for Copper Contracts Slip As Demand Hits a Seasonal Ebb

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Copper prices sagged yesterday as demand for the metal endured a seasonal slump.
On other markets, silver and wheat prices fell sharply. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities fell 0.36 point, to 239.33. 
August shutdowns of copper fabrication plants in the United States and Europe typically result in a drop-off in demand, analysts said. But they forecast higher prices in the fourth quarter as consumption rises.
"Certainly, activity in the U.S. economy is going to pick up in the second half of the year versus hardly any growth in the second quarter, and that will help copper demand," David Rinehimer, an analyst at Smith Barney, said.
On the Commodity Exchange of New York, copper for September delivery dropped 2.25 cents, to $1.346 a pound on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
The drop followed a similar plunge in prices on the London Metal Exchange on indications of easing near-term supplies. The London exchange was closed on Monday for a holiday.
The September copper has dropped 6.5 percent from its Aug. 17 high of $1.434 a pound. Silver prices fell after signs of rising stockpiles eased concerns over tight supply. On the Commodity Exchange, the September silver contract fell 9.3 cents, to $5.519 an ounce.
Wheat prices fell sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade after the Agriculture Department reported that the spring wheat crop was in better shape than traders expected.
Wheat steepened its slide late in the session as speculators who bid prices up sharply last week took profits.
In a report released after trading ended on Monday, the Agriculture Department rated 54 percent of American spring wheat in good to excellent condition as of Sunday, down from 56 percent a week earlier.
"The deterioration of the spring wheat crop was not as bad as expected, given the amount of rain they've had," said Joel Karlin, research analyst with Kemper Securities Inc.
Excessive rain in the northern Plains has slowed the harvest and left wheat vulnerable to disease.
Wheat for September delivery fell 6.75 cents, to $4.34 a bushel.
Corn and soybean prices also fell, partly in reaction to better crop ratings than expected.
September corn slipped 1.5 cents, to $2.9025 a bushel, while September soybeans dropped 2 cents, to $6.0375 a bushel.

HEADLINE: A China Agenda for Mrs. Clinton

 BODY:
It was never realistic to think that Hillary Rodham Clinton could lead the American delegation to the Beijing women's conference without becoming entangled in the difficult relationship between the United States and China. Once her visit was linked last week to the release of Harry Wu, the connection became undeniable. But that should not stop Mrs. Clinton from going to China to make herself and her country heard as champions of women's needs and rights.
The challenge for Mrs. Clinton is to advance the cause of women without seeming to bless China's repressive treatment of its own citizens by her presence. She can manage that if she is fearless in her defense of women throughout the world, including China, and makes clear that she does not condone the clumsy steps taken by the Chinese authorities to suppress dissent outside the conference halls. 
 The great advantage of having Mrs. Clinton lead the United States delegation is the added attention and articulate voice she will bring to the official American agenda for the conference. The people chosen to represent this country -- including members of both parties -- have been instructed by the Clinton Administration to raise issues like violence against women, improved access to education and health care and the promotion of greater political and economic equality. Neither those goals nor the overall themes of the conference fit the extremist image conjured up by some critics of the gathering, like Senators Bob Dole and Phil Gramm.
The United Nations holds these women's conferences only once every 10 years. For the tens of thousands of women who attend them, and the millions more they represent back home, particularly in the less developed world, the meetings provide much-needed encouragement and a spur to local action.
Women's rights are human rights, so there can be no question of keeping human rights off the agenda, however much the subject discomforts the Chinese hosts. China is not the worst offender against women's rights. But it is home to one-fifth of the world's women, and the problems of women there cannot be ignored, including abusive population policies, like forced abortion and sterilization.
Beijing's leaders wanted the prestige of being host to the conference, especially after the humiliation of losing their bid to stage the 2000 Olympics. They have proved unable, however, to tolerate the public demonstrations and clash of views that go with an international meeting like this.
Regrettably, China has exiled nongovernmental delegations to the women's conference to a remote site 40 miles from Beijing, held back visas for unofficial participants and reporters and rounded up Chinese political activists in advance of the conference.
Mrs. Clinton has an obligation to express her country's contempt for these steps, while registering its strong support for the goals of the conference. China's leaders may not appreciate that approach, but anything less from the leader of the United States delegation would be a betrayal of American principles.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: The Nation's Biggest Bank

 BODY:
The marriage of Chase Manhattan Bank and Chemical Bank may well be a boon for the two banks and their stockholders. It means that a newly efficient and productive behemoth based in New York City will be better equipped to compete globally with the financial giants of Europe and Asia. But the $10 billion merger is also a sign of the decline of this region's fortunes as a financial-employment center, as Chase and Chemical proceed with plans to cut $1.5 billion a year in expenses by eliminating 4,000 jobs and perhaps 100 bank branches in the metropolitan area alone.
Mindful of the potential blow to the economy and consumers in New York City, executives at both banks have gone out of their way to offer assurances that they will try to ease the pain caused by the merger. They promise that the job reductions will be carried out by natural attrition and retirement incentives where possible. They also promise not to reduce services in poor areas of the city, some already underserved by big banks. 
 The promises are welcome but deserve to be met with some skepticism, since they have been made in other mergers in the past and not always carried out. The office of Mark Green, the city's Public Advocate, has performed useful research in recent years on the decline of banking services in poor neighborhoods as retail banking has shrunk in general. It would be salutary for Chase and Chemical to cooperate with his request that they disclose their plans for shutting down branches deemed redundant. New Yorkers will also be eager to learn what will happen to Chase Manhattan Plaza, and lower Manhattan real estate values generally, now that the bank's headquarters will be consolidated in midtown.
As for reinvestment in the communities they serve, both banks have good records. But here too, the public needs to keep a careful eye to make sure that future performance continues to serve all New Yorkers. Even those financial institutions that have achieved excellent records in meeting the needs of poor communities or in helping to finance development projects in marginal neighborhoods have done so only after strong public pressure.
The creation of the nation's largest bank continues a trend of consolidation that is going on throughout the country, not just in New York. The pace of change in recent years is startling, with tens of thousands of banking jobs disappearing in New York City since 1988. A major factor in the trend is that consumers are using other institutions for their financial needs, including mutual funds, insurance companies and credit cards.
The banks, meanwhile, have struggled because of problems of their own making, investing too heavily in such things as third-world loans and bad real estate schemes. The Chase Manhattan Bank has been allowed to keep its name after being absorbed in the Chemical deal, but it was the one looking for a partner after investors came to view its financial health as weak because of poor prospects for future growth. In combining forces, Chase and Chemical say their financial clout will be greater than the sum of their two parts. But for that to be true, the banks will have to make the combination work with better and more aggressive business management.
The merger's painful consequences for employment in the New York region are a reflection of the larger problems afflicting the American economy, which has grown more productive but performed disappointingly in terms of producing new jobs. One of the most urgent problems facing the country and New York City is to figure out how to let the financial giants achieve economic and productivity growth in a fashion that benefits workers as well as the wealthy who own the bulk of the nation's capital. Only then will everyone be entitled to join in the cheers of the shareholders when two financial giants merge and announce the cutting of thousands of jobs.

HEADLINE: New-Home Sales Rise Briskly, Carried by Gains in the South

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29

 BODY:
Sales of new homes rose at the fastest pace in a year during July, helped by low mortgage rates and signs of consumer confidence, a Government report showed today.
New-home sales rose four-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 715,000, the Commerce Department said. The gain was the third consecutive monthly rise and the strongest sales rate since March 1994, when sales were running at 722,000 a year. 
 But all of the increase in July occurred in the South, the nation's largest home market. Sales in the rest of the country declined from June, with sales in the Northeast plunging 33.3 percent.
Economists attributed the gain in home sales to mortgage rates that were significantly lower in July from the beginning of year and by signs that consumers were not becoming discouraged by the direction of the economy.
A stable consumer outlook was seen in a report today by the Conference Board, a private business-research group. The Conference Board's index of consumer confidence eased only slightly in August to 101.0 after a big bound in July to 101.4 when it jumped nearly seven points from June.
The index, using a 1985 base of 100, surveys 5,000 homes. It gauges opinions about the current and future state of the economy.
Economists were encouraged by the reports, noting the housing sector was rebounding from first-half weakness and that it appeared consumers did not lose heart during a second-quarter slump in economic growth.
A third report today from the Labor Department reinforced the favorable prices picture, showing that import prices took their biggest tumble in more than one and a half years, down six-tenths of 1 percent. The last time there was a bigger drop was December 1993, when they fell 1 percent.
Export prices gained three-tenths of 1 percent in July, meaning that companies selling their products abroad earned more.
Cheaper imported petroleum prices and less costly industrial supplies, or raw materials, were the main reason for the better performance on the import side.
"Taken together, the three reports carry the basic message that the consumer sector that we have been quite worried about seems to be in fairly good shape," said Robert Dederick, economic consultant to the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "People are feeling well, they're willing to make large commitments, and inflation is not a problem."
While economic growth nearly stalled in the second quarter, sales of new homes jumped in May by 10.5 percent, to a rate of 671,000 a year,before gaining 6.1 percent in June and edging up another four-tenths of 1 percent last month.

 BODY:

Time Warner and Turner Seeking to Please Malone
 Executives of Time Warner, Turner Broadcasting and Tele-Communications Inc. shuttled between New York hotel suites and conference rooms, as they worked on an $8.5 billion deal in which Time Warner would buy Turner. 
 In an attempt to satisfy John C. Malone, the chief executive of Tele-Communications, which owns 21 percent of Turner, people involved in the talks said that Tele-Communications was offered a mixture of voting and nonvoting shares in Time Warner. Turner stock rose $6.50, to $30.50. [Page A1.]
 Despite skepticism that the merger would work out, entertainment industry executives were matter-of-factly accepting that their environment was changing. [D4.]
 
Japan Closes Credit Union, As Banking Crisis Worsens
 Japanese Government authorities closed the Kizu Credit Cooperative in Osaka, the nation's largest credit union, and bailed out the Hyogo Bank in Kobe. The twin collapses are expected to wipe out Government rescue funds. [D3.]
The news strengthened the dollar, lifting it nearly one yen to 99.11 yen. [D13.]

Signal Seen on French Economy
 Economists say the ouster of France's Finance Minister, Alain Madelin, has sent a clear signal that President Jacques Chirac has chosen to let the deficit deepen to get people back to work. [D3.]

HEADLINE: Asia-Pacific Regional Trade Group Is Showing Signs of Life

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
A six-year effort to strengthen trade and economic cooperation among the United States and 17 other nations in the Asia-Pacific region is showing new signs of vigor.
At a meeting in Indonesia last November of heads of government of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, President Clinton and the other leaders set 2010 as the goal for "free and open trade and investment" among the group's richer nations, with a target of 2020 for the poorer countries. Now, efforts are under way to accelerate the trade-liberalization process. 
 The 18 nations in the group account for more than half the world's economic output.
Japan, which will be host at this year's meeting, in Osaka in November, is pressing other members to begin tariff reductions at the start of 1997, trade officials said. They added that the Japanese effort had a good chance of succeeding.
At the same time, an advisory group appointed by the Asia-Pacific governments wants officials of these nations to underscore their commitment to free trade by agreeing to accelerate tariff cuts already promised in the new world trade accord.
The declaration signed last November included a pledge to "accelerate the implementation of our Uruguay Round commitments." The talks that produced the trade pact, held under the aegis of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, are known in diplomatic shorthand as the Uruguay Round.
The advisory group has also called on the economic forum to create a mediation service that would resolve trade disputes, coordinate antitrust policies, harmonize nations' industrial-product standards and help the International Monetary Fund protect the region against financial crises.
At first, the Pacific forum "seemed slow and hesitant, but in the last two years it's moved much faster," said C. Fred Bergsten, head of the Washington-based Institute for International Economics and chairman of the advisory group, at a Washington seminar last week. Mr. Bergsten presented the advisory group's recommendations yesterday to Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama of Japan.
Australia, a member of the Asia-Pacific forum, has estimated that if all trade barriers among the 18 nations were dropped, the world's annual economic output would increase $366 billion by 2010. By some estimates, the world trade accord, by comparison, is expected to increase output $112 billion a year.
Obstacles remain. Malaysia's Prime Minister, Mahathir Mohamad, when he signed the forum's free-trade declaration last year, said his officials would carry it out "at our own pace." And at talks with Australian aides last week, Japanese trade officials suggested excluding unspecified "sensitive sectors" from the free-trade pledge.
The other members of the Asia-Pacific forum are Brunei, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand, Canada, Mexico and Chile.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
As Depositors Panic, Japan Shuts Largest Credit Union

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 30

 BODY:
The crisis in Japan's banking system, stemming from hundreds of billions of dollars in bad real estate loans, took a big jolt today as Government authorities closed the nation's largest credit union and bailed out a regional bank on the brink of collapse.
In Osaka, hundreds of frantic customers clamored to withdraw their money from the Kizu Credit Cooperative, which had roughly $12 billion in assets and $9 billion in problem loans, as rumors of its impending shutdown circulated. Many customers were still without their money when the doors closed this afternoon, though Government officials assured them that all deposits would be honored. 
 A few hours later, the Ministry of Finance and Japan's central bankers provided a second major surprise, announcing a complex rescue package for the deeply troubled Hyogo Bank in Kobe, which had nearly $7 billion in uncollectible loans and had lent heavily to real estate ventures affiliated with itself.
The twin collapses are expected to wipe out the money in Japan's Deposit Insurance Corporation, the insurance fund analogous to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in the United States.
The Japanese fund, underwritten by fees paid by banks and other lenders, currently has 870 billion yen -- roughly $8.5 billion. It has already committed 100 billion yen to guarantee deposits at the failed Cosmo Credit Corporation, which had been Japan's biggest financial failure until today, and Government officials predicted that the two new failures would require about 800 billion yen more. Some of that will be come from the Bank of Japan, the nation's central bank.
Top officials, rushing to head off a wider panic, said that the worst problems were now behind them and that the country's biggest banks had more than enough capital to write off their own bad loans.
"There may be more bankruptcies, but much smaller ones," said Sei Nakai, deputy director general of the banking bureau at the Ministry of Finance. The biggest banks, he said confidently, generate annual profit on the order of $23 billion and "can work through their problem loans." Besides, he added, "we won't let them go bankrupt."
But industry analysts said the pain was far from over. Five savings institutions have collapsed in the last several months, each caused in large part by soured real estate loans that were made when property prices soared to previously unknown levels during Japan's "bubble economy" of the late 1980's.
As big as the failures so far have been, they account for less than $35 billion in problems loans. Government and industry analysts estimate that the total volume of loans either in arrears or uncollectible is at least $400 billion and possibly as much as $700 billion.
The spreading contagion has already forced officials to commit $1 billion in public money to make good on deposits held by the Cosmo credit union, and it remains unclear just how much additional money taxpayers will have to come up with in the months ahead.
Bank regulators tried to cover today's two failures primarily by lining up commitments from major creditors of the failed bank and credit union, as well as money from the deposit insurance fund. The country's central bank is considered almost certain to become a lender of last resort in future bailouts.
The immediate impact of the growing Japanese bank crisis on financial institutions in the United States and other countries is expected to be barely noticeable. Foreign banks have not been big creditors of the financial institutions that have failed so far, officials here say, and the biggest drag on global business is likely to stem from Japan's broad economic slowdown.
Industry analysts here said that Japan's bankers and policy makers are almost certain to face painful choices in the months ahead. "The banks being liquidated now are really too small to matter -- you can shoot them in the head and it's not really a problem," said Alicia Ogawa of Salomon Brothers. "The bigger problems are resident in the major commercial banks, and those situations are not so easy to solve."
The big city banks and credit unions, some of which have assets of more than $300 billion, employ thousands of people and cannot be easily merged with healthier institutions. Since laying off employees remains taboo in this country, Ms. Ogawa said, banks have little incentive to acquire each other because they can gain very little in the way of cost reductions from closing branches.
Much like the the go-go operators who fueled the American savings and loan crisis, some of Japan's aggressive lenders have worsened the problem by making risky loans to companies owned by friends and cronies.
Kizu, the Osaka credit union that collapsed today, emulated the pattern of scores of American savings institutions by using high interest rates to build up deposits at blinding rates. Noticeably flamboyant, the credit union also attracted depositors with television ads dominated by pretty women.
Bearing far less resemblance to the humble image of a credit union than to the likes of a Charles Keating, Kizu's deposits and loans each nearly quintupled between 1988 and its closing today, and some of its biggest loans were to two affiliate companies.
Self-dealing loans, a prominent element in the American savings and loan scandals, appear to be common in Japan, as well. Government experts recently estimated that executives at 157 of Japan's 374 credit cooperatives were involved in outside companies. The Government also estimated that 39 percent of the credit unions were violating a law that bars them from lending more than 20 percent of their deposits to a single borrower.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Depositors in Osaka clamored for their money at the Kizu Credit Cooperative, Japan's biggest credit union, yesterday before Government regulators closed it as the crisis in the nation's banking system deepened. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Traders Bailing Out of the Yen As Japan's Bank Crisis Grows

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar surged against the yen yesterday as currency traders bailed out of the yen after Japanese regulators shut a credit union and announced a rescue package for a regional bank.
The dollar touched its highest level against the yen in nearly seven months. 
 During Asian trading, the Japanese Goverment closed down the Kizu Credit Cooperative of Osaka and prepared a rescue for the Hyogo Bank of Kobe, which had nearly $7 billion in bad loans.
The growing crisis in Japan's banking system is making traders wary of Japanese financial markets, prompting the selloff in yen.
"The market now is looking for a weaker yen," said Charles Spence, director of currency sales at Standard Chartered Bank in New York, "as the crumbling banking system in Japan is causing foreigners to hedge any investment they still hold on to there." It is also causing Japanese investors to flee to American assets, he said.
After falling to post-World War II lows against the yen in April, the dollar has recovered nearly all its losses for this year -- which at one point exceeded 20 percent.
The banking crisis and sluggish recovery in Japan indicate that the dollar can reach 110 yen by the end of the year, said Hillel Waxman, manager of foreign exchange at the Bank Leumi Trust Company in New York.
The dollar rose as high as 99.25 yen -- its highest since Feb. 10, when it reached 99.36 yen. It later settled in New York trading at 99.11 yen, up from 98.21 yen on Tuesday. The dollar edged up to 1.4781 German marks from 1.4779 marks in late trading. The British pound rose to $1.5452 from $1.5431.
Despite another cut in a German interest rate, the dollar was unable to advance very far against the mark, which continues to gain support from political turmoil in France and Italy.
In its regular weekly money market operation yesterday, the Bundesbank cut its 14-day securities repurchase agreement rate, known as the repo rate, to 4.30 percent from 4.39 percent. Last week, the repo rate, a benchmark for most other short-term German rates, was lowered to 4.39 percent from 4.45 percent.
Traders said yesterday's rate cut was expected.
"Any weakness in the mark that was caused by the repo-rate reduction was overwhelmed by the purchase of marks for other European currencies," Mr. Spence of Standard Chartered said.

HEADLINE: Fischer Black, 57, Wall Street Theorist, Dies

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
Fischer Black, an economist whose groundbreaking work in financial theory helped revolutionize modern Wall Street, died yesterday at his home in New Canaan, Conn., after a yearlong battle with cancer, his family said.
Mr. Black, 57, was a partner in the investment banking firm of Goldman, Sachs & Company. 
 He was the father, with two other noted economists, of a seminal theory that first gave Wall Street a complex but workable solution to a simple but intractable puzzle: how to value an option.
An option is a financial instrument that allows, but does not require, an investor to buy an asset, like a stock, at a prearranged price during a fixed span of time. Until 1973, when the theory that Mr. Black helped devise was first outlined in a University of Chicago journal, the difficulty of sorting through all the variables that would affect the value of an option during its lifetime had severely limited the growth of the options market.
The options pricing theory devised by Mr. Black and his collaborators and fellow economists, Myron Scholes and Robert C. Merton, solved the puzzle of options pricing by devising a complicated mathematical equation, known as the Black-Scholes model, that took into account the many variables.
The solution helped lay the cornerstone for today's vast global options market, a marketplace that touches almost everyone with a stake in the capital markets, from corporate executives who receive stock options as part of their pay package to modest mutual fund investors whose money-market funds use options to hedge their interest-rate risk.
The Chicago Board Options Exchange, the first devoted soley to options trading, opened its doors just as the Black-Scholes study was published in 1973. Mr. Black and Mr. Scholes came to be regarded as almost the patron saints of the new exchange, said Merton H. Miller, a professor at the University of Chicago and the winner of the 1990 Nobel Prize in economics. "Whenever Fischer and Myron went on the floor of the Chicago Board Options Exchange, business stopped and everybody would give them a standing ovation," Mr. Miller said.
In academia, there had been keen competition to be the first to find a solution to the options pricing puzzle, recalled Paul Samuelson, the Nobel laureate and a professor emeritus at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "It was like the race to the North Pole, and they were the very first to get there," he said. "I had worked on the problem, too, and I was close, but no cigar."
An original and unorthodox theorist, Mr. Black was known for offering impromptu late-night criticism of his colleagues' work. Mr. Miller said he received many such calls: "It would be 11 P.M. and the phone would ring and you'd hear Fischer's voice saying 'On page 31, you have made a fundamental error,' " he recalled with a laugh.
Fischer S. Black Jr. was born in Washington in 1938. He graduated from Harvard in 1959 with a degree in physics and, in 1964, was awarded a doctorate in applied mathematics. Peter L. Bernstein, the author of a study of ideas that shaped Wall Street ("Capital Ideas, the Improbable Origins of Modern Wall Street," The Free Press, 1992), said Mr. Black quickly "found his scientific studies too abstract" and headed for the world of business.
It was while working at Arthur D. Little & Company in the late 1960's that he collaborated with Mr. Scholes and Mr. Merton, both junior faculty members at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, on the options-pricing model. Mr. Black then formed his own consulting firm in 1969, and in 1971 became a visiting professor of finance at the University of Chicago, where Mr. Merton was instrumental in adding him to the faculty as a professor of finance in 1972.
In 1975, Mr. Black moved to M.I.T., where he remained until joining Goldman, Sachs in 1984. He later became a partner in the firm, helping to create hedging, trading and portfolio management strategies for its clients.
In making the transition from academia, Mr. Black was among the first of what came to be called the rocket scientists on Wall Street, financial experts who helped usher in an era of increasingly intricate, often useful and sometimes controversial financial instruments.
After his cancer was diagnosed a year ago, Mr. Black continued to correspond by computer with colleagues and friends until a few weeks ago, and this summer he saw the publication of his second book, "Exploring General Equilibrium" (M.I.T. Press).
Mr. Black is survived by his parents, Fischer and Elizabeth Black of Tampa, Fla., and by his third wife, Catherine Tawes Black of New Canaan. Two earlier marriages ended in divorce.
Survivors also include four daughters, Alethea Black of New York City, Melissa Black of Boston, Ashley Black of Atlanta, and Paige Black of Winchester, Mass.; a son, Terry Linton of Washington; a stepdaughter, Kristen A. Tawes of New Canaan; a stepson, Kevin L. Tawes of Boston; a brother, Louis E. Black of New York City, and a sister, J. Blakeney Bartlett, of Fairlee, Vt.

HEADLINE: Blinder Is Undecided on Leaving the Fed

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve's vice chairman, Alan Blinder, said today that he had not decided whether to leave when his term expires early next year, but he did not deny reports that he was planning to return to teaching at Princeton University.
Inquiries about Mr. Blinder's plans were prompted by reports from Princeton University that officials in the economics department there expect him to return to the faculty in February. 
 In a brief statement provided by a Federal Reserve spokesman, Mr. Blinder said: "No decision has been made. My term ends Jan. 31. I would have to be reappointed. I haven't made any decision, and as far as I know the president of the United States hasn't made any decision."
Mr. Blinder was in Stockholm today and was not available to elaborate on his statement.
There have been growing speculation on Wall Street and in Washington that Mr. Blinder, 49, intends to leave the Fed because President Clinton is expected to reappoint Alan Greenspan as chairman of the central bank next year rather than name Mr. Blinder to the top spot.
The Administration has reportedly decided that Mr. Blinder, a self-described dove on inflation, would face insurmountable problems in being confirmed as chairman by the Republican-controlled Senate, while Mr. Greenspan is a popular choice.
Mr. Greenspan, a Republican, was appointed to the Fed by President Ronald Reagan and reappointed by President George Bush.
Mr. Greenspan has led the central bank's efforts to keep inflation in check by engineering a series of seven interest rate increases concluding in February. The Fed reversed course in July, cutting short-term rates for the first time in three years in reaction to signs that the economy was stalling.
Mr. Blinder joined the Clinton Administration as a member of the White House Council of Economic Advisers in 1993 and was named Fed vice chairman last year. He has been on a leave of absence from Princeton that is scheduled to end in February.
There is already a vacancy on the Fed's seven-member board of governors, created when John P. LaWare quit earlier this year.

HEADLINE: Perot Tells Senate Committee It's Time to Get Experts' Opinions on Reining In Medicare

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30

 BODY:
Ross Perot, who made a fortune selling computer services to the Government, lectured Congress today on how to save Medicare from bankruptcy, saying the program must be re-engineered by experts with fresh ideas for controlling costs.
Mr. Perot, who is again considering running for President as an independent, repeatedly likened Medicare to a decrepit airplane. 
 "We have looked at the complete instrument panel, and there's only one thing to do if you're flying, and that is eject quickly, because this plane is going down," the Texas billionaire said at a hearing of the Senate Finance Committee, convened mainly as a forum for him.
Republicans in Congress say they are cutting the growth of Medicare to preserve the program, not to balance the budget. But Mr. Perot was not shy about making the connection, saying, "You've got to put a lid on this thing and slow it down now to balance the budget."
He said he might barnstorm the country to educate Americans about Medicare if the two parties did not face up to the issue this fall. Four Republicans attended today's hearing, called by Senator Bob Packwood, the Oregon Republican who is chairman of the committee, but no Democrats showed up.
Mr. Perot encouraged Congress to experiment with innovative ways to finance health care for the 37 million elderly and disabled people now enrolled in Medicare. He said the Government should not pressure them to enroll in health maintenance organizations, as some Republicans have suggested.
"If someone were to ask me what is my principal concern about H.M.O.'s, it's the concentration of power; it's the giant salaries," Mr. Perot said, alluding to recent reports about compensation of top H.M.O. executives and the growing influence of such plans in the health care industry. "You know, that doesn't look good to me."
Health maintenance organizations, which provide comprehensive care in return for fixed monthly premiums, "tend to turn the doctor into just an employee," Mr. Perot said, and "the day we do that, we will have really damaged health care." Doctors, he said, should "play a leadership role and not be just lowered to bidding their services to an H.M.O."
Mr. Perot did not offer a blueprint for redesigning Medicare, but suggested that wealthy people should pay more for their care. "It would be a joke for me to ever get a Medicare check" because "I don't need it," he said.
He also said that Congress should not write rigid rules into law. "Let's experiment with it," he said. "Let's not dive into an empty pool at night and break our necks. Let's tiptoe into the water with some of these things and find out what works."
When Mr. Perot ran for President in 1992, he promised to bring the efficiency of private industry to the work of Government. But in earlier years, auditors from the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, often criticized work done by his companies for Medicare and other Federal programs.
For example, at a Congressional hearing in 1980, an auditor testified that Medicare beneficiaries, doctors and hospitals in Illinois "experienced an entire year of poor performance" by Electronic Data Systems, one of Mr. Perot's companies. The auditors said the company had sent "ominous form letters" to Medicare beneficiaries and had destroyed thousands of claims as a way to reduce huge backlogs of unfinished work.
Aides to Mr. Perot acknowledged in 1992 that there had been problems but said that they had been corrected and that the Government continued to do business with him.
Victor F. Zonana, a spokesman for the Department of Health and Human Services, said today that President Clinton shared many of Mr. Perot's concerns. "We are taking a tough look at Medicare costs, to save money, but there is a right way and a wrong way to do it," Mr. Zonana said. "The right way is by taking it from health care providers. The wrong way is by taking it out of beneficiaries."
Mr. Perot said that Federal officials were afraid to let experts help design a new health care system. "We have this sense that anybody that understands medicine would have a conflict of interest," he said. "So we bring in philosophers, economists, beekeepers, symphony conductors and people like that to put together a health care system, and then we wonder why it didn't work.
"We pass social programs assuming that everybody's got the same size foot, and then we wonder why their feet hurt."
Mr. Perot said he hoped Democrats and Republicans would work together to shore up Medicare and to restore confidence in the two-party system. But if they do not, he said, he is ready to run for President as an independent.
"The American people will go" for such a third-party candidate, he said. "They are restless to go. They are mad at me for not doing it now."

HEADLINE: Growth Revised Upward, but It Was Still Weak

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The economy grew at a somewhat faster clip in the second quarter than originally estimated, the Government said yesterday, but the rate of expansion was still the weakest in nearly four years.
For the April-June period, the Commerce Department said gross domestic product, which measures all goods and services, grew at an annual rate of 1.1 percent on an inflation-adjusted basis, more than double the rate of a half of 1 percent reported a month ago, when a preliminary estimate of second quarter growth was released. 
 The slightly faster rate of growth was largely a result of upward revisions in consumer spending and a rise in farm inventory investment. But the change did little to alter opinions among private analysts about the economy's prospects for the balance of the year.
"The entire revision was in two categories, consumption and farm inventories, which alone was responsible for about 40 percent of the overall increase in gross domestic product," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities Inc. "But being on a trading floor in New York, I can't get excited about farm inventories."
After slowing sharply during the first six months from an unsustainably rapid pace in the second half of 1994, most analysts still expect the economy to rebound to the rate of growth of 2 to 2.5 percent that is favored by the Federal Reserve. In the first three months of the year, the economy grew at a 2.7 percent annual rate, down from the more than 4 percent average rate of growth recorded for the last six months of 1994.
"On the margin, the economy wasn't as weak as we thought in the second quarter, and this bodes better for the second half," said Paul Mastroddi, a managing director at J. P. Morgan Inc.
The revised report contained "more good news than bad news," said Donald Ratajczak, director of the economic forecasting project at Georgia State University. "Capital spending is still strong, exports are still good and there are no inflationary concerns."
Worries about inflation were the primary force behind the seven increases in short-term interest rates engineered by the Federal Reserve over a 12-month period beginning Feb. 4, 1994.
The absence of inflationary pressures was prominently mentioned when the Fed reversed its previous course in early July, pushing short-term rates down by a quarter of a percentage point.
Yesterday's report provides further evidence that inflation remains in check.
"The economy looks like it is headed to a 2 percent to 3 percent growth path," said Allen Sinai, chief global economist at Lehman Brothers, "and that is exactly where the Fed wants it."
As measured by the gross domestic product deflator, the prices of goods and services rose 1.6 percent during the second quarter, slightly higher than the 1.3 percent rate reported in July, but less than the 2.2 percent rate recorded in the first quarter.
The fixed-weight price index for domestic purchases, which in contrast to the deflator does not reflect the changing composition of output, rose at a 2.8 percent rate, up slightly from the 2.7 percent rate of increase that was originally reported.
The Commerce Department will make its final revision to its second-quarter G.D.P. report at the end of September.
The department also said that using a new method of calculating growth that it is phasing in this year, G.D.P. expanded five-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter, and did not decline by two-tenths of 1 percent, as first reported. The new method will formally replace the older system at the end of 1995 and is designed to measure price changes more accurately.
Analysts cited improving home sale numbers, which should lead to increased sales of consumer durable items, strong capital spending and a likely improvement in the nation's trade accounts as reasons they expect growth to pick up.
Mr. Ratajczak, who projected that the economy was growing at a 2 percent annual rate in the third quarter, said that despite sluggish auto and back-to-school sales, consumers almost certainly are spending more money this quarter than they did in the previous three months.
"We know they are spending more, if not on autos, then on utilities, because of the heat, which affects anyone from the Mississippi Valley to the East," he said.
Increased spending on utilities could well cut further into the personal savings rate, which fell significantly in the second quarter from the first.
Yesterday, the Commerce Department said the personal savings rate in the second quarter was 4 percent, not 4.1 percent, as originally reported. In the first quarter, the savings rate was 5.1 percent.
"The heat will boost service consumption in July and August," Mr. Fine said, "but I don't know if consumer spending will remain strong. We do know the third and fourth quarters will be better than the second. Growth in the second half should be characterized as moderate, not strong. And it will not engender increased inflationary pressures."

HEADLINE: Governor Closes Harlem Development Agency

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
After months of wrangling, the Pataki administration yesterday formally shut down the Harlem Urban Development Corporation, a semi-independent 23-year-old agency that used state and private funds to spur economic activity in the hard-pressed area.
In its place, Gov. George E. Pataki created a new entity, the Harlem Community Development Corporation, which will receive 40 percent less in funding and will have a board of directors dominated by appointees of the Governor. 
 The move came after a long fight over how much money the state would provide to economic development efforts in Harlem, where the unemployment rate consistently hovers in the mid-teens and census figures show that 30 percent of the population lives in poverty.
Earlier this year, state officials announced that they would assume authority over their economic development efforts in Harlem, instead of continuing to turn the money over to the autonomously run Urban Development Corporation. While that organization has had mixed success with housing and retail development over more than two decades, it was also criticized in some quarters as a costly and ineffective tool of the local politicians who sat on its board.
In a statement, Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation -- which until recently was known as the New York State Urban Development Corporation -- said that the Governor's action "brings to an end the 23-year uncontested reign" of an organization that was criticized "for its lack of leadership and failure to stimulate economic growth despite an investment of more than $100 million in state funds over the years." Last year, the Urban Development Corporation received $3.1 million from the state.
The Governor's action has prompted charges from the Urban Development Corporation's employees and supporters, who assert that state-appointed outsiders cannot adequately address the economic needs of Harlem. One person who attended the first board meeting of the new organization yesterday, and who spoke on condition of anonymity, described the meeting as "a room full of board members who don't even know each other, much less the community."
Meanwhile, many of the 37 workers who were employed at the defunct organization are threatening to sue the state, charging that they were promised jobs with the new organization only to be told last week that their payroll allocation for the fiscal year, which ends next March, has already been spent.
