HEADLINE: U.S. OPEN '95;
Just Off in the Distance, a Stadium Is Taking Shape

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
The quietest place at the National Tennis Center during the United States Open is next door, where a steel and concrete shell will be a 23,500-seat stadium by 1997 -- the major part of a project estimated to cost $227 million.
But the price tag, which began as a $150 million project, could go up to $265 million. 
 Construction, which began in March, was halted for the two weeks before the Open began and will not resume until two weeks after the tournament ends.
The skeleton of the stadium's south end is most visible: plumbing fixtures, elevator towers, escalator pits, staircases, and a photographers' dugout. Two levels of luxury suites are still concrete slabs and steel beams. A blue and white banner covers the grounds of the future stadium court, built on a former landfill and the foundation of the 1939 World's Fair's Federal Building.
"Biggest banner in the world," said Page Crosland, a spokeswoman for the United States Tennis Association, which controls the tennis center and the Open.
The new stadium will replace the 20,000-seat Louis Armstrong Stadium, which will be renovated and pared down to 10,000 seats. The 5,500-seat grandstand will also be redone and reduced to a 4,800-seat structure.
The United States Open moved to Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in 1978 to a stadium and grandstand built over the Singer Bowl, which was left over from the 1964 World's Fair. But the U.S.T.A. has wanted something new since the late 1980's.
"What's there is a kind of crummy Erector set," said Federal Judge Robert J. Kelleher, who served as the U.S.T.A. president in 1967 and 1968, and was a strong proponent of open tennis, which began in 1968.
"Egos are involved. Australia built a magnificent place; Roland Garros built a great place and now Wimbledon may have the best plans yet. There are a lot of egos involved and people like Bumpy Frazer could not sit still while that was happening, whether the U.S.T.A. had the money or not."
J. Howard Frazer preceded the current U.S.T.A. president, Lester Snyder Jr.
Snyder said: "You could keep putting Band-Aids on the facility, but it would never be first-rate. Its time had come. Look at other areas." He admitted that the U.S.T.A. looked at other cities, but decided, "This was the place to be, where the U.S. Open ought to be."
The U.S.T.A. is certain it has the money to finance the project. The central financing is a $150 million bond issue arranged through New York City's industrial development agency. The bonds are tax exempt and sport a lower interest rate than what the U.S.T.A. would have found on its own.
The association pays the debt service on its own and the extra $77 million the project now costs. It has shifted $70 million from its general fund to help pay its costs and plans to move another $40 million this year and in 1996, said Bob Garry, the association's director of finance and administration.
Another $51.5 million earmarked for operating expenses can be tapped if the costs continue to escalate, Garry said.
"The only reasons to cause the costs to escalate is if we try to make changes and we have to protect ourselves against doing it," Garry said.
Garry said the U.S.T.A.'s construction spending won't come at the expense of what it spends on tennis programs in 17 sections nationwide. In 1994, it spent $16.1 million on the sections, up from $15.8 million in 1993.
"We have built-in increases to sections in each year," he said, adding that the association anticipates revenues to increase in coming years, partly from the 90 luxury suites expected to bring in at least $8 million a year in revenues.
The luxury suite income could just about pay for the interest the U.S.T.A. must pay on its bonds. This year, the interest cost is $9.6 million.
Part of the price of having the city lease 28 acres for the construction project in a deal made by Mayor David N. Dinkins in the last days of his administration was the requirement that the U.S.T.A. pay higher rent.
The base rent of about $400,000 (up from $320,400 last year), is one component of the payment: the association must also pay 1 percent of U.S.T.A. and tennis center revenues. The 1995 rent should be about $1 million, said Garry.
"It's a good deal for us," said Henry Stern, the city's Commissioner of Parks and Recreation. "They're building and paying for their own stadium, but we'll own it, while other franchises want the city to do that all for them."
Stern's main objection to the U.S.T.A.'s leases with the city -- 25 years with options to go up to 99 -- is a provision that would levy fines on the city totaling $325,000 if planes from LaGuardia Airport disturb the matches. "That makes the city responsible for events out of our control," he said.
Stern has no objection to leasing land for tennis that had been used by regular parkgoers. But Benjamin Haber, of Kew Garden Hills, said: "It was monumentally stupid of the city to allow it. How do you justify giving up urban parkland for a commercial operation? It's a blight."

LENGTH: 494 words

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Advance On Fed Official's Comment

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities ended higher yesterday, helped by a stronger dollar and by comments from a top Federal Reserve official pointing to lower interest rates.
But trading was thin, with many market participants staying on the sidelines until tomorrow's employment report. 
 Government securities rallied a bit at the opening of the session on comments earlier yesterday by Alan S. Blinder, the vice chairman of the Fed. Mr. Blinder, speaking at a news conference in Sweden, said there was room for further interest rate cuts. He added that recent economic reports showed the decision to leave rates unchanged on Aug. 22 was the correct one and that he "still has an open mind on rates," according to the Swedish news agency Direkt.
Douglas Burtnick, senior fixed-income analyst in Boston for Technical Data, said, "The market started out with a roar" following Mr. Blinder's comments, "until it became obvious that 'open minded' doesn't indicate that he's doing anything more than sitting on the fence waiting for more information."
The rally stalled after the Commerce Department released its second revision of the gross domestic product for the second quarter. The revision showed the economy growing at a 1.1 percent, up from an initial estimate of half of 1 percent. The Commerce Department releases G.D.P estimates three times a quarter.
While it was the weakest growth rate since the end of 1991, Ken McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, a market research and analysis firm, said, "The underlying data indicate that the economy is on a sound footing and will grow at a good clip in the second half."
The G.D.P. data revived concerns that the Fed might hold off cutting short-term interest rates if the economy was seen as stronger than previously believed.
Many in the market had already priced in a rate cut by the Fed, and prices retreated somewhat.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 6/32 of a percentage point, to 102 11/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.69 percent, from 6.71 percent on Tuesday. In futures trading, the December Treasury bond contract was steady, trading in a price range of between 111 29/32 and 112 9/32 .
Anthony Dwyer, chief market strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said Treasury prices were bolstered by the rising dollar, which makes American assets more attractive to foreign investors.
Today, the market will see the weekly jobless claims report and the Chicago Association of Purchasing Managers survey. Some market participants are likely to react to the data since they come just before the employment report for August and the National Association of Purchasing Management's survey. In addition, the Treasury is auctioning $18 billion of 20-day cash management bills today.
Many in the market say that tomorrow's employment data will be important in providing a gauge of near-term monetary policy outlook.

SECTION: Section D; Page 2; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 862 words

HEADLINE: Economic Scene

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
IS a revamping of the civil justice system another one-day wonder, an issue that lets politicians tut-tut over waste, fraud and abuse before it is nibbled to death by lobbyists?
It certainly is looking that way, as Congressional Republicans shuffle toward unambitious limitations on shareholder suits and product liability and President Clinton threatens to veto almost any change of substance that hits his desk. But there is one area of civil justice that could win political points for Republicans long after the public has moved on to fresher outrages: auto insurance overhaul. 
 Indeed the potential political gain is magnified by evidence of the link between auto insurance revisions and medical care costs. As a new study by the Rand Corporation's Institute for Civil Justice suggests, changes in incentives to overuse medical care after auto accidents could prove crucial in meeting the Republican commitment to balance the Federal budget.
While accident rates are stable, there are still lots of reasons why auto insurance premiums have gone through the roof in the last two decades. Cars cost more to fix and medical care is costlier. And on the whole, Americans are more inclined to sue each other. But the monster in the auto insurance box is the growth in successful claims for intangible injuries -- what lawyers call pain and suffering.
Newly published estimates by Rand break down by state the potential savings from prohibiting the recovery of damages for pain and suffering. Drivers in Connecticut, Hawaii and Massachusetts would see their premiums fall by 40 percent or more. Even New York, which limits access to juries by means of a tough "no fault" law, stands to save 35 percent. Over all, the potential saving is 31 percent of auto insurance premiums -- some $26 billion annually.
Pain and suffering suits have an unintended side effect that has only recently been highlighted by Michael Horowitz of the Hudson Institute and Jeffrey O'Connell of the University of Virginia Law School. In less-than-catastrophic injury cases, they argue, claimants often run up big medical bills because their lawyers have learned that settlements for pain and suffering are generally figured as a multiple of medical expenses. Rand estimates that in 1993 more than one-third of claimed medical costs were fraudulent, adding $4 billion to the nation's health care bill and $9 billion to $13 billion to payouts for pain and suffering as well as legal fees.
Rand is not alone. The Federal Bureau of Investigation has been devoting considerable attention to the connection between medical costs and auto insurance fraud, pursuing what it calls Operation Sudden Impact. In May, along with announcing the latest series of arrests, Louis J. Freeh, the F.B.I. Director, estimated that "every American household is burdened with over $200 annually in additional premiums to make up for this type of fraud."
States could simply bar pain and suffering claims in auto accidents. But in most legislatures that is out of the question, partly because trial lawyers are bitterly opposed and partly because it seems intuitively unfair to lock the courthouse door to claimants and throw away the key.
That is where the "choice" concept, offered by Mr. Horowitz and Mr. O'Connell, fits in. They would allow people to buy auto insurance with or without the right to sue for pain and suffering. Those who opted out to save money could still make claims for full economic losses. But they could neither sue nor be sued for intangible losses unless the defendant was drunk or intended to do injury. Those who want to retain the right would pay for it: If they are injured by someone who had opted out they could collect pain and suffering damages from their own insurance companies, much the way claimants now collect from their own insurers when they are harmed by an uninsured motorist.
Apart from decimating the ranks of ambulance chasers and putting tens of billions of dollars in consumers' pockets, the legal scholars note two other advantages. According to Rand, the biggest winners would be the poor, who would no longer pay insurance premiums that reflect the pain and suffering claims of affluent drivers. Equally important, there would be more incentive to link auto premiums to the safety features of automobiles since the bulk of compensation for injury would be paid by one's own insurance company.
Initial efforts to include an auto insurance "choice" requirement in the Republicans' civil justice changes were tarred as just another attempt to subvert the will of the states, and there is hardly a groundswell for trying again soon. But two Republican Senators, Spencer Abraham of Michigan and Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, think they have found a way around the objection that may put it back on the political agenda: give each state the option of eliminating choice by an affirmative vote of the legislature.
Mr. Horowitz likes the compromise and almost hopes a few states would deny their residents the right to choose in order to highlight the size of the windfall. "Premiums in adjacent states would be lower by a third or more," he exalts.

LENGTH: 107 words

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
NIAGARA MOHAWK WARNS OF POSSIBLE TOUGH MEASURES

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

 BODY:
Shares of the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation dropped 9 percent yesterday after the utility, which is based in Syracuse, warned that it might be forced to cut its dividend or take other steps in a difficult business climate. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Niagara Mohawk complained of growing competition, a sluggish economy, regulatory obstacles and other adverse influences on its business. Niagara Mohawk said it might have to restructure contracts or take "even more severe actions" to "keep the company financially viable." Niagara Mohawk's shares fell $1.25, to $12.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

LENGTH: 127 words

HEADLINE: Bring Back the W.P.A.

 BODY:
To The Home Section:
Architectural treasures, landmark structures in the national parks, are crumbling ("America's Crumbling 'Parkitecture,' " Aug. 10), and in the inner cities, unemployed, untrained young men and women are hanging out idly, wasting time and their young lives. 
 It seems to me that the two seemingly unrelated disasters have a common solution. Taking the example of the Roosevelt-era Works Progress Administration, the Government could create a cadre of young people to be involved in restoration of the national treasures at a reasonable cost, while learning a trade, discipline and making a worthwhile investment in the nation and their own lives.
I see no downside to this solution. So why not?
 
MARCEL TUCHMAN ,M.D.
New York

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
